HEADLINE: 10 People Are Charged With Spying for Cuba

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Eight men and two women were charged today with spying for the Cuban Government by trying, sometimes successfully, to infiltrate American military sites and Cuban exile organizations.
Officials with the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the United States Attorney's office here said national security was never compromised. But the officials described a sophisticated operation led by three men they believe to be members of the Cuban security forces. The suspects sought to report on the operation of American military installations, political and humanitarian activity by groups opposed to President Fidel Castro of Cuba and on American government and law enforcement, the officials said. 
 A criminal complaint charging the 10 said the group, operating since 1994, targeted Boca Chica Naval Air Station in Key West, MacDill Air Force Base in Tampa and the United States Southern Command, which oversees operations for the Caribbean and Latin America and recently moved its headquarters to Miami from Panama.
One defendant, Antonio Guerrero, was a civilian employee in the public works department of the Key West naval station whose real job, the complaint said, was to report to Cuba on any "unusual exercises, maneuvers and other activity related to combat readiness."
Another defendant, Rene Gonzalez, posed as an F.B.I. drug informer to "to give misinformation," said Thomas E. Scott, the United States Attorney in Miami. And two other defendants tried to get information and employment at the Southern Command, which Mr. Scott called "a priority objective" of the network.
The arrests marked the first offensive by Federal law-enforcement authorities against espionage by suspected Cuban agents, Federal officials said. They also come as Cuban exiles, smarting from the Federal prosecution of a group of exiles accused of plotting to kill Mr. Castro, are demanding that the United States target Cuban agents working in the United States.
F.B.I. officials said their investigation of Cuban intelligence gathering in South Florida began after Brothers to the Rescue, known for making mercy flights between Florida and Cuba searching for people in boats fleeing Cuba, lost two planes in an attack by Cuban fighter jets in 1996. But the officials declined to say whether the beginning of their effort was related to that incident. In a bizarre twist after the shootdown, a member of the group, Juan Pablo Roque, reappeared in Cuba to denounce Brothers to the Rescue and other Miami anti-Castro groups, and it became known then that he had been on the F.B.I. payroll since 1993 as an informer.
Luis Fernandez, a spokesman for the Cuban Interests Section in Washington, would not comment on the arrests.
The Cubans arrested today are also accused of penetrating exile groups to create animosity and discredit their leaders and of manipulating political figures and news organizations through anonymous or misidentified telephone calls and letters.
In Miami, where many exiles have long assumed that the city is crawling with Cuban spies and double agents, none of it came as a shock.
"If they're finally deciding to clean house, I salute them for it," said Rafael Penalver, a prominent exile lawyer who is on the board of a medical clinic that employed one of the defendants as a receptionist last year. "I hope it's a concerted effort to get to the root of the problem."
The complaint said the Cubans had code names, false identities and accents, escape plans and alibis for if the were arrested. They reported to Cuba through high frequency radio, officials said, and some traveled to and from Cuba.
Mr. Scott, the United States Attorney, and Hector M. Pesquera, the F.B.I. special agent in charge, refused to say how far the defendants got in their intelligence gathering or how threatening the information given to the Cuban Government was. The complaint said they provided Cuba with detailed descriptions of the construction and geography of the Southern Command headquarters. It also said Mr. Guerrero gave information on security areas and aircraft at Boca Chica and the addresses of naval officers.
Mr. Pesquera said the arrests had left Cuban intelligence gathering "in a complete state of disarray."
"This is a significant blow to the Cuban Government," he said.
But even before the arrests, the espionage network seemed to have run into hard times. The criminal complaint said that its officers had to routinely submit financial reports to Cuba detailing expenses for the operation and that at one point Cuba sent back word that it had to cut back. "Because of the economic state of our country," one communication read, "headquarters has been obligated to reduce the budget of all the comrades there."
The leaders of the network were identified as Manuel Viramontes, whom the criminal complaint describes as "a Cuban national and captain in the Cuban military" who has lived in the United States since 1992; Luis Medina and Ruben Campa. They and the other seven were charged with illegally acting as foreign agents, conspiring to deliver defense-related information to a foreign government and conspiring to defraud the United States. They could face sentences up to life imprisonment and fines of $750,000.
"It's not good news for anybody who wants to see a relaxation in U.S.-Cuba relations," said Max Castro, a Cuban affairs expert at the University of Miami's North-South Center. "Even though these are things that are typically done by all governments, whenever a country finds out it's been done in its territory, it's considered a hostile act."

HEADLINE: EATING WELL;
The Nearer the Tree, the Sweeter the Fruit

BYLINE: By Marian Burros 

 BODY:
THERE is no better time than right now -- O.K., you could have started earlier in the summer -- to get into what nutritionists call the Five-a-Day habit: eating five servings of fruits and vegetables every day.
This is a habit that scientists suggest can help prevent a host of diseases, including heart disease, cancer and stroke. But it is a habit that very few people have cultivated because most of us prefer the taste of potato chips to fresh potatoes and fruit-flavored candy bars to fresh fruit. 
 That's stiff competition, but at this moment, when many fruits and vegetables are local and at their peak of flavor, they have a fighting chance. The recipes here suggest ways to bring out the best flavor of what's in the market -- green beans and potatoes, tomatoes and plums. You might also consider taking vegetable-hating children to pick-your-own farms and letting them help harvest what you want them to eat.
Locally grown fruits and vegetables are better for reasons beyond freshness. The varieties grown locally differ from what is grown thousands of miles away because they do not have to withstand a long arduous journey. They can be selected for flavor, rather than hardiness. A fruit can be picked at the moment of ripeness, when it has the perfect balance of sweetness and acidity; a vegetable can be picked while it is immature, that is, young and tender.
This makes perfect common sense but has been difficult to document because little scientific work has been done on the taste of fruits and vegetables picked at the right moment for eating, versus those picked to travel well for thousands of miles.
When I called the Produce for Better Health Foundation, which was created by the produce industry and others to promote the Five-a-Day plan, its president, Dr. Elizabeth Pivonka, sidestepped the question of which tastes better, local produce or produce that travels across the country or across the world. Instead, Dr. Pivonka said, "There is a lot of good fruit from Chile."
No doubt there is, and I'm sure the Chileans enjoy it at the peak of flavor. With an increasingly global economy, we will get more fruits and vegetables from the ends of the earth, but eating nectarines in February and asparagus in November is no way to learn how they should truly taste.
At least one scientist, Dr. Alley Watada of the Agricultural Research Service of the Agriculture Department in Beltsville, Md., has been studying the difference in taste and nutrition between locally grown tomatoes picked when perfectly ripe and those picked while ripening. Dr. Watada said, "Without question, the red ripe tomatoes had the most nutrients and tasted the best."
The taste was determined at the Horticulture Crops Quality Laboratory by a sensory panel, a group of people trained to recognize differences in taste. The ripest tomatoes also had about 5 percent more nutrients like vitamin C than those that were not fully ripe, he said.
Incidentally, Dr. Watada has done work with honeydews, too. And guess what he said? The locally grown honeydews now in the market taste better than the ones that come from Chile in the winter.
 
MEDITERRANEAN COUSCOUS SALAD
Time: 35 to 40 minutes
 
3 cups vegetable or chicken stock or broth
2 cups instant whole wheat couscous
3 tablespoons olive oil
6 tablespoons balsamic vinegar
4 teaspoons Dijon mustard
2 large cloves garlic, minced
 Grated zest of 2 oranges
1 or 2 jalapenos, trimmed, seeded and finely minced
2 dozen green or black medium French, Italian or Greek olives, pitted and finely chopped
 1/2 cup chopped capers
2 cups (about 10 ounces) julienned red bell peppers
1 pound zucchini, cut into julienne strips
 1/2 cup finely diced red onion
1 cup diced fennel
 Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
2 medium-large ripe tomatoes.
 1. Bring stock to boil in covered pot. Add couscous, remove from heat and allow to sit for five minutes, until liquid has been absorbed.
 2. Whisk oil, vinegar, mustard and garlic in a serving bowl. Add orange zest, jalapenos, olives and capers, and mix well. Stir in the red pepper, zucchini, onion and fennel, and season with salt and pepper. Stir in the couscous.
 3. If not serving immediately, refrigerate without the tomatoes. No more than 30 minutes before serving, cut up the tomatoes and stir in.
 Yield: 6 to 8 servings.
 
 
GREEN BEANS AND POTATO SALAD
Time: 30 to 40 minutes
 
2 pounds tiny new potatoes, scrubbed but not peeled
1 pound young green beans or haricots verts (French green beans), washed and trimmed
3 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil
 1/4 cup white wine vinegar
2 tablespoons lemon juice
2 teaspoons Dijon mustard
4 teaspoons chopped fresh thyme
 1/2 cup finely chopped red onion
 Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste.
 1. Cook potatoes in water to cover for 10 to 20 minutes, depending on their size, until they are tender but firm; drain, and cut in quarters or halves, again depending on size. Meanwhile, steam the green beans 5 to 7 minutes, depending on their thickness; drain, and rinse under cold water to stop the cooking. Cut in quarters or thirds, depending on size.
2. In a large bowl, whisk together the oil, vinegar, lemon juice and mustard; stir in the thyme and onion. When potatoes are cooked, stir them into the dressing. If the salad is not to be served immediately, do not add the green beans: the acid of the dressing will turn them gray. Cover the beans well, cover the dressed potatoes and refrigerate separately.
3. To serve, let the vegetables return to room temperature. Stir the green beans into the potatoes and dressing, and season with salt and pepper.
Yield: 6 to 8 servings.
 
PLUM COMPOTE
Time: 20 to 30 minutes, plus chilling
 
 3/4 cup sugar
1 cup dry white wine
4 whole cloves
1 3-inch stick cinnamon
 Zest of 1/2 lemon
16 large, firm ripe red or black plums, stemmed.
1. Combine the sugar, wine, one cup of water, cloves, cinnamon and lemon zest in a saucepan large enough to hold the plums. Bring the ingredients to a boil, and cook, uncovered, for 5 minutes.
 2. Add plums, and bring mixture back to a boil; lower heat, and simmer plums for 10 to 20 minutes, depending on their ripeness, until they are tender but still hold their shape. Some plums will be ready before others; remove them as they are. Then when they are all cooked, return the plums to the syrup, remove from heat and let cool.
 3. Chill plums in the syrup. Serve over vanilla ice cream or frozen yogurt with some of the syrup, or serve with their syrup topped with whipped cream or creme fraiche.
 Yield: 6 servings.

HEADLINE: Boeing's Rating May Be Lowered

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Sept. 15

 BODY:
The Boeing Company's credit rating may be lowered by Moody's Investors Service as production problems trouble the world's largest aircraft maker and Asia's economic crisis increases the risk that sales there will slow.
Moody's said today that it might lower the rating on about $6.8 billion of debt, a move that could raise the company's borrowing costs. The New York-based credit rating agency cited Boeing's "continuing poor operating performance" and concern about the "timing and the degree of resolution" of the production delays in its commercial aircraft business. 
 Boeing is now producing planes more consistently after struggling last year with a series of bottlenecks costing the company $3 billion in pretax charges since 1997 and helping create the Seattle-based jet maker's first annual loss in five decades.
Moody's placed Boeing's "Aa3" senior debt rating under review, as well as the "A3" senior debt rating for the Boeing Capital Corporation. Shares of Boeing fell 12.5 cents, to $34.25.
Representatives at Boeing were not immediately available for comment.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Singapore Airlines and Delta take different approaches to premium service for passengers.

BYLINE: By Jane L. Levere 

 BODY:
SINGAPORE AIRLINES and Delta Air Lines announced two differing strategies to upgrade their long-haul in-flight service for business travelers.
Singapore Airlines, which wins frequent plaudits for its service, is investing about $300 million to upgrade its first- , business- and economy-class offerings. Delta, meanwhile, is totally eliminating its first-class service and upgrading its business-class service on trans-Atlantic, trans-Pacific and United States-Brazil routes. 
 Singapore Airlines' new services are being phased in over the next 18 months on its long-haul fleet of 37 Boeing 747-400's. The new first class will feature airport check-in at a special lounge and a redesigned airplane cabin with 12 so-called mini-suites equipped with seat-beds, power outlets for computers, retractable desks and 14-inch video monitors; previously there were 16 seats in first class. Passengers in this cabin will be able to dine when they wish.
Singapore Airlines' new business-class service will have seats that the airline says are based on a first-class seat frame; the cabin will have 58 seats, down from 65. Seats will also have privacy dividers and power outlets. The new business-class food service will also be available whenever passengers wish.
Singapore Airlines' economy-class passengers will have upgraded seats and will be offered champagne throughout flights.
Delta's new business class, which will be introduced next spring, will feature new seats, upgraded wine and food, and a modern entertainment system. Delta is investing $125 million in its new business-class cabins, which will be offered on its MD-11 and Boeing 767-ER and 777 aircraft.
Dr. Choong Kong Cheong, deputy chairman and chief executive officer of Singapore Airlines, said the carrier had opted to upgrade all three of its in-flight cabins because "Singapore's passengers always expect the best from us." He added, "We're determined to stay ahead of the competition."
He also said Singapore Airlines had been planning these changes for two years and that it would proceed with them, despite the recent crisis in the Asian economy. "We're a global airline," he said. "The Asian economy has affected Asian airlines quite badly, but other airlines are in the pink of health. We're continuing to upgrade our product and service because we can't afford to be left behind."
Delta officials said they had chosen to entirely eliminate international first-class service because the demand for business class far exceeded that for first class. According to data released by the carrier, in 1997 the intercontinental business-class market grew four times faster than that for first class; it also said there were seven times the number of passengers in the industry's business-class market than in the first-class market.
Pointing out that on many nonstop trans-Atlantic routes Delta has no competitors, Stephan Egli, vice president of Delta's Atlantic and Pacific business unit, predicted that travelers on these routes who have to choose between Delta's business-class service and one-stop, first-class service on another carrier might well pick Delta for its greater convenience.
Sam Buttrick, aviation analyst for Paine Webber, said, "The paying first-class customer is limited to a relatively narrow number of markets, which is why we see different carriers coming out at different ends of the spectrum."
 
Fly the Crowded Skies
The number of passengers on United States air carriers is expected to jump by 50 percent in the next nine years, according to the Federation of Travel Clubs.
Citing projections from the Federal Aviation Administration, Mark Brown, executive vice president of the travel club group, told Reuters that airline ridership would reach 900 million by 2007.
According to the American Automobile Association, there were 599 million passengers in 1997, a 34 percent increase from a decade earlier.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Argentina Seeks $8 Billion In Emergency Loan Reserves

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 15

 BODY:
In an attempt to ease any future economic tremors from neighboring Brazil, Argentina is negotiating loan packages totaling more than $8 billion with various international lenders to insure Government financing in case of a severe economic slowdown next year.
Publicly, Government officials are still painting a rosy picture of the economy, making every effort to differentiate Argentina from other emerging market countries. The proposed 1999 budget sent to Congress this week projects a 2 percent increase in spending based on increased tax receipts generated by a 4.8 percent annual growth rate, more than double what most Wall Street economists expect. 
 But privately, Economy Ministry officials are expressing concern that Argentina is vulnerable to any crisis in Brazil over the next several months, since 30 percent of Argentina's exports are purchased by Brazilians. While they express hope that Brazil can avoid a devaluation, Government economists say they expect the Brazilian economy to slow further in the coming months, with officials in Brasilia, the capital, keeping interest rates high, raising taxes and lowering expenditures.
"We are not expecting a devaluation in Brazil," said Deputy Economy Minister Pablo Guidotti. But he added, "We continue analyzing, and if necessary, we can revise our projections."
Hoping to anticipate any severe recession in Brazil, Mr. Guidotti and other officials are putting the final touches on loan packages with the World Bank, the Inter-American Development Bank, the International Monetary Fund and Eximbank of Japan that could total as much as $8.5 billion. These lines of credit are expected to be signed in the next two weeks, Government officials said, noting that they would complement commercial borrowing and were intended to reassure foreign investors.
Local economists noted that the Government had not drawn from a $2.8 billion I.M.F. credit line, nor issued high interest rate bonds to cover expenses. Neither action is necessary, they said, because the current budget deficit is a modest 1 percent of output.
David Malpass, chief international economist for Bear Stearns, noted that Argentina already had contingency lines of credit with several international investment banks in case of a future emergency. But he said officials were seeking the added loan packages because "they didn't want to be perceived as inactive while Brazil was being attacked." Referring to the policy of pegging the Argentine peso to the dollar at a 1-to-1 rate, he added, "Argentina has been holding a pretty strong hand provided by convertibility."
Martin Redrado, a former senior aide to President Carlos Saul Menem, said the Government was negotiating the loan packages "to insure that whatever happens to Brazil, Argentina will have the muscle and the money to weather the crisis."
Recent statements by President Clinton and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin stressing the importance of Brazil and promising to stand by the economies of the region have bolstered confidence in Argentina, at least for the moment.
Share prices on the Buenos Aires stock exchange, which had dropped by 50 percent this year as of last week, rallied 8.90 percent today. The benchmark Merval index has gone up better than 20 percent over the last three trading sessions.
In Brazil, the Bovespa stock index soared 18.68 percent today, reflecting easing concerns on Wall Street that Brazil would soon devalue.
"This is a Rubin rally because he expressed U.S. interest in Brazil's financial stability," Mr. Malpass of Bear Stearns said. "The immediate threat of a Brazilian devaluation has been lifted."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Decline Again as World Stock Markets Stabilize

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
United States bonds fell for the second time in three days yesterday as stock markets stabilized around the world, reducing demand for Treasury securities with long-term yields near record lows.
Bonds are "playing off the equity markets," said Todd Barre, who helps manage $10 billion of bonds at Harris Bank in Chicago. Treasuries have moved inversely to stocks in recent weeks, rallying when tumbling stocks spurred a rush into safer investments, and falling when stocks climbed. 
 The price of the 30-year bond fell 14/32, to 103 22/32, pushing its yield up 3 basis points, to 5.25 percent. Prices and yields move in opposite directions.
Bellwether 30-year bond yields dropped about half a percentage point in the last two months, as stocks slumped on concern that slowing economies will hurt corporate profits. Yields touched 5.13 percent last week, the lowest since the Government began regular sales of the securities in 1977.
"A lot of this drop in yields has been flight to quality," said Edgar Peters, who helps oversee $17 billion as chief investment strategist at Panagora Asset Management Inc. in Boston. "If the feeling is there's no need to be worried, people would start to sell their bonds."
The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin will testify today to the House Banking Committee about global economic turmoil.
Fed policy makers next meet to set interest rate policy on Sept. 29.

HEADLINE: German Socialists Turn From Slogans to Jingles

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Until recently, Detmar Karpinski's biggest accomplishment was advertising Lucky Strike cigarettes. Today, he is producing one of the slickest and most American-style political advertising campaigns that Germany has ever seen.
Hired by the Social Democratic Party and its candidate for Chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, Mr. Karpinski as created a media campaign that is an artful dance between cozy images of a happy Germany and edgy criticism of Chancellor Helmut Kohl. 
 A commercial playing in movie theaters shows four astronauts in a Star Trek setting about to be "beamed" to another planet. When the beaming is over, one astronaut is left behind and he turns out to be a corpulent and befuddled Mr. Kohl. The message: the 68-year-old chancellor is "not ready for the future."
In a blitz on television, on billboards and in glossy magazines, Social Democratic ads combine images of gauzy warmth with a sneaky punchline. Billboard posters, aimed a provoking fears about cuts in health care, show a blond boy whose smile reveals a missing tooth. "We don't want to tell the difference between rich and poor just through a smile," reads the biting caption. A magazine ad centers on an aging, framed photograph of beautiful children and the slogan: "You should have more in your retirement than memories."
These and a barrage of other ads mark a major departure from the dull and didactic fare that have usually graced German political campaigns. They are also a far cry from the old-school ads for Mr. Kohl, whose most ubiquitous campaign poster features his picture and the slogan "World Class for Germany."
Mr. Schroder and his campaign managers have adopted techniques used by Ronald Reagan, Bill Clinton and Tony Blair. They have focused relentlessly on feelings rather than facts. They have carefully honed their themes based on market research. And they began mapping their strategy more than 18 months ago, before Mr. Schroder even became the party's official candidate in the election, which is set for Sept. 27.
"The S.P.D. had an image that was somewhat old-fashioned and needed to be modernized," said Mr. Karpinsky, creative director for the Hamburg-based advertising agency KNSK-BBDO, referring to the Social Democrats. "One had the impression that they didn't really want to win an election, that they just wanted to be in the opposition."
Advertising plays a much smaller role in Germany than in the United States. The Social Democrats say they are spending about $23.5 million on paid advertising, though Mr. Kohl's party, the Christian Democrats, insist that the spending is much greater. Their own spending, they say, is about $30 million.
But the Social Democrats say they have systematically used advertising, sometimes to illustrate a new stylishness. Inasmuch as the advertising is clever and fast-paced, it appeals to younger and more video-savvy voters who have grown up watching MTV. Indeed, party officials used the first wave of campaign posters for the sole purpose of showing them to journalists.
Negative political advertising, prominent in American campaigns, has been almost non-existent here. Though Germany's high unemployment rate under Mr. Kohl is the Social Democrats' most important theme, party officials say that attack ads would have alarmed voters.
Instead, Mr. Karpinsky has produced a campaign loaded with happy images and with a critical message at the end. One television ad describes the things people strive for and shows families and children, hikers and bicyclists, playgrounds and modern factories. The screen then abruptly goes black, and a message reads: "But 4 million unemployed Germans can't."
"Negative advertising can work, but it would be wrong in this country," said Mr. Karpinski. "We didn't want to frighten people with attack ads. We wanted to make them comfortable with the party, so the images you see are always positive an optimistic."
Indeed, Mr. Kohl and the Christian Democrats briefly tried negative advertising but quickly retreated. Known as the "red-handed" campaign, Christian Democratic billboards warned darkly that the Social Democrats might join forces with the successor to East Germany's old Communist party, the Party of Democratic Socialism. Billboards showed two red hands shaking, with the slogan "Watch out, Germany!"
But Christian Democrat supporters say the ads repelled many people because they seemed overly alarmist. Though Mr. Kohl continues to warn about alliances with the Communists, the red-handed posters have all but disappeared.
The Social Democratic officials say they scrupulously pruned their messages based on their research with focus groups and polling. With unemployment at near-record levels, joblessness inevitably became the top issue. But other once-popular issues have been ignored. "It wasn't any surprise that unemployment was in first place," said Mr. Karpinski. "But what did surprise us was that the environment had slipped from 5th place to 18th place. That was a big change, and the result is that the environment is not a part of the advertising."
The last wave of advertising is most focused on Mr. Schroder himself. A 90-second television ad depicts the candidate alone on a windswept beach, mulling over his vision as the camera pans over an endless expanse of water -- an image meant to convey vision and new horizons. As the camera zooms in on Mr. Schroder's face, viewers hear his voice speak passionately about the need for vision and his desire to make Germany better and stronger.
The most prominent print ads now feature black-and-white pictures of Mr. Schroder that are meant to look as if they came from newspapers and depict a statesman with the weight of the world on his shoulders.
"We knew that our first job was to convince people that we really are ready to govern,' said Michael Donnemeyer, a spokesman for Mr. Schroder's campaign. "Now we are focusing on the candidate himself, because we know that our most important weapon is Schroder himself."
Mr. Kohl and the Christian Democrats continue to wage a much more stodgy campaign. The newest billboards show nothing more than the colors of the German flag and the slogan: "Security Instead of Risk."
Mr. Kohl's television ads are only slightly more lively. One shows Frankfurt's mayor, Petra Roth, expounding on the strengths of Germany and Mr. Kohl's unmatchable experience in world affairs. Another shows Mr. Kohl in a montage with other world leaders, including President Clinton. The message is that Mr. Kohl is a respected world leader who can guarantee stability.
Campaign officials admit that their advertising lacks sizzle, but insist that is part of their message as well. "People want a Chancellor and not an actor," remarked Andreas Fritzenkotter, Mr. Kohl's top media adviser, in a German newspaper interview. "Schroder is waging a campaign as an advertising man, not as a politician who speaks and behaves from conviction."

GRAPHIC: Photos: With a national election campaign in full swing, political advertising is ubiquitous in Germany. A Christian Democratic poster, left, urged Germans to vote for an upswing, while a Social Democratic billboard, center, stressed health care, (Photographs by Frank Ossenbrink) and a Social Democratic television spot, right, used a "Star Trek" theme to suggest that Chancellor Helmut Kohl is too old-fashioned for the space age. (Reuters for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: F.C.C. Responds to Its Digital-TV Critics

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission today lashed back at critics in the telecommunications industry who have blamed his agency for the problems plaguing the introduction of digital-television services, scheduled to begin in just six weeks.
Executives from the television programming and manufacturing industries have faulted the commission for not setting clear rules and standards for digital broadcasts and related equipment. In many cases, the commission chose instead to let industry set the standards itself. That has led to interindustry disagreements and crippling incompatibilities in some areas. 
 For example, the first high-definition sets now on sale cannot receive HDTV programming from cable systems because the standards for the cable that connects the set to the cable box have not been completed -- an unresolved interindustry detail for which some set makers blame the F.C.C.
But in a speech to a group of broadcasters today, William E. Kennard, the F.C.C. chairman, called the criticisms self-serving efforts to "goad the Government by playing the blame game."
Most businesses ask his agency for help, Mr. Kennard said, "only if they think Government will give them a regulatory advantage." If not, he added, "They'll try to keep Government out."
The Government should get involved, Mr. Kennard added, only "when arguments are distorted by the prism of self-interest."
Separately, the Sony Corporation plans to announce on Wednesday that unlike other television manufacturers it will sell a high-definition television set that is a conventional-style table-top model with a picture tube, beginning in November. Every other manufacturer plans to sell large rear-projection sets, some as big as a compact automobile.
More than 90 percent of the TV's sold today are conventional models with a picture tube, known as "direct view" sets. That leaves many industry analysts asking how the transition to digital television can succeed, as long as manufacturers offer digital sets in a style that is not popular with most buyers.
James Palumbo, a Sony vice president, said his company chose direct-view because such sets offered the highest picture quality, and that he believed Sony would gain a competitive advantage. "We think the market will initially have a bigger audience for direct-view sets," he said.
Other manufacturers are not producing direct-view sets now because they are more complicated to manufacture and still cannot display an HDTV image at its highest level of resolution. The Sony executives acknowledged that without saying what level of resolution their HDTV would offer. "It's misleading to do that," said James Bonan, another Sony vice president.
But in one respect, Sony's strategy is similar to the other companies'. They are all entering the high-definition television market with high-end products loaded with options and added features -- and extraordinarily high price tags. With rare exceptions, the first high-definition television sets will sell for at least $8,000. Sony's 34-inch direct-view set will be priced at $9,000.
Mr. Kennard, in his speech to the International Television and Radio Society in New York today, said no one should be concerned with the high initial prices. "If you control for inflation," he said, "the first color sets in 1955 cost about $4,500." (Actually, RCA put the first color television on the market in 1953, and it cost $1,000 -- just over $6,000 in today's dollars.)
Mr. Kennard added, "The entire history of the introduction and pricing of consumer-electronics equipment tells us that soon enough, digital-television receivers will be increasingly affordable."
"But let's not kid ourselves," he continued. "The digital-television rollout will be complicated." He urged patience, "for the transition to digital TV is inevitable."
Mr. Palumbo said Sony management held a similar view. "This is just the beginning," he said, "trial and error." 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Preventing World Recession

 BODY:
A quarter of a century ago when Washington was mired in scandal, the greatest challenge to global prosperity since the Great Depression presented itself in the form of an Arab oil embargo that promptly led to spiraling inflation, recession in the Western world and, within a few years, a third-world debt crisis that stifled development in Latin America for a generation. The largest economies were unable to respond to those challenges in a timely manner, and the world suffered.
Now, with Washington immersed in another scandal, another major threat to world prosperity has arisen from the collapse in Asia and plunging commodity prices that endanger much of the past decade's progress in developing countries. There is reason to hope the response this time will be better. The Group of Seven countries say they will cooperate in stimulating world growth. Those actions should include a coordinated lowering of interest rates by central banks in Europe and America. 
 The current crisis has brought on a widespread shift in investor psychology. Those who invested in developing countries with too little regard for risk now can see only risk as they flee. That capital flight has forced developing countries to raise interest rates to protect their currencies, thus putting a further drag on economies already in recession. Many such countries depend on the export of commodities, whose prices have plunged as world growth has slowed. Many companies, particularly in Asia, are unable to meet their dollar-denominated debt obligations because their home currencies have collapsed.
President Clinton, in an important economic address in New York this week, was right to say the world must look for ways to ameliorate those problems by spurring growth in the industrial world, particularly in Japan, whose own recession could not be occurring at a worse time. He was also right that ways need to be found to relieve some of the debts facing Asian countries.
None of that will be easy. In retrospect, the International Monetary Fund probably pushed for policies that were too restrictive when the Asian crisis erupted a year ago. But its aid is needed more than ever in the current situation, as countries deal with panicky investors.
It is a measure of the sad state of the Clinton Presidency that the President's effort to address the world's economic problems was viewed by many through a Monica prism, with commentators wondering whether Mr. Clinton was trying to change the subject. The real question here is whether the American Government can deal effectively with major problems at the same time Congress considers the Starr report. Congress should immediately provide the $18 billion needed by the I.M.F., and its leaders should make clear that they are open to further actions that may be needed to avert a world recession.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Denver Calls Old Airport Ground Zero for Growth

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: DENVER, Sept. 15

 BODY:
The luggage carousels and ticket counters have been sold to Peru and shipped to airports in the Andes.
Wrecking crews have begun the months-long job of tearing down the main terminal, with its sign that greeted generations of American skiers: "Welcome to Denver, Colorado. One Mile High." And the runways have been painted with large yellow crosses to ward off pilots who may not have heard that Stapleton International Airport closed in February 1995. 
 But three and one half years after Denver's $5 billion new airport drew the nation's attention, the old airport is grabbing back the spotlight. A development project one third the size of Manhattan is taking shape there, only 10 minutes east of downtown Denver.
"Every significant home builder in the state of Colorado has approached us about doing something at Stapleton," said Dick Anderson, president of the Stapleton Development Corporation, the nonprofit company chartered by the city of Denver to develop the old airport site.
Referring to projects that recycle large swaths of industrial areas in cities, Mr. Anderson said: "These 'in fills' are a better way to go than urban sprawl."
The interest in seven square miles of dirt newly opened to development reflects Denver's continuing economic boom and mounting concern over the metropolitan area's sprawl.
Last week, the Sierra Club issued a report on urban sprawl that ranked the growth of metropolitan Denver second only to metropolitan Kansas City in cities with populations over one million. From 1990 to 1996, the Denver metropolitan area increased by two-thirds, ballooning toward its current size of 535 square miles.
Excess growth routinely tops lists of concerns in public opinion polls here. Last year, the Denver Regional Council of Governments approved a blueprint to confine growth to 730 square miles by 2020. But the Sierra Club noted that this boundary was largely voluntary, and it forecast that by 2020 the metropolitan area could expand to 1,150 square miles.
The impact of growth has been felt in recent months -- in rolling electricity brownouts during a heat wave, wells running dry in some suburbs, 10-digit local telephone numbers, classrooms improvised from trailers, and, as the speed of highway traffic slows, renewed debate over building a passenger rail system through the city and into the Rocky Mountains.
But most of the growth has occurred in three southern suburban counties -- Douglas, Elbert and Park -- that have ranked among the top five fastest-growing counties in the nation.
Opponents of sprawl are hailing both the Stapleton project, which will bring 10,000 new homes to the area, and a 3,200-home project at the former Lowry Air Force Base because they are close to the city center.
"They put people much more closer in, where there already are people, utilities and infrastructure," said Kirk Cunningham, a Colorado Sierra Club member who worked on the sprawl report.
According to blueprints, Stapleton will provide homes for 25,000 people, becoming the region's second-largest development, after Highlands Ranch, a southern suburb. Construction on the first houses is to begin next spring, four years after the last jet took off.
Some Denverites criticize the pace of conversion as slow. But Development Corporation officials say the Federal Aviation Administration and Denver had little experience in dismantling and redeveloping a big city airport.
At first, Denver sought buyers, or at least tenants, for the terminal and concourses. One, Concourse E, was built at a cost of $58 million, but was used for only eight years. Planners soon discovered that there are few alternative uses for airport terminals. The decision to tear down the concourses came after a July 1997 hail storm drilled about 4,000 holes in the roofs of the old terminal and concourses, causing severe water damage.
The 12-story control tower will be retained as a monument to the site's history, probably with an observation deck for tourists.
Since 1990, the average price of a home in the Denver area has jumped by about 50 percent, to $200,000 today. Denver's Mayor, Wellington E. Webb, has vowed that Stapleton, which is city property, will include low- and moderate-income housing, but that collides with a mandate by the Federal Aviation Administration, which was a source of many grants for improvements at Stapleton, to sell airport land at fair market value. Dollars earned from Stapleton land sales defray the construction cost of its successor, Denver International Airport.
Planners hope to be able to offer town houses here for as little as $100,000.
With Interstate 70 and a rail line cutting through the old airport property, Stapleton is also to become a commercial and industrial center, providing 30,000 jobs. Already, United Airlines, part of the UAL Corporation, has invested $140 million in an expanded pilot training center on 400 acres, and the Catellus Development Corporation, a commercial real estate company, is building the Stapleton Business Center, 3.6 million square feet of offices and industrial space. Under a new master plan, 17 million square feet of commercial space is to be created around the old airport.
Denver's convention and tourism business is so strong that the wall of hotels facing the old airport terminal survived its closing. Companies moving to the site are served by the second-largest concentration of hotel rooms outside downtown.
In addition, one-third of the old airport area, 1,700 acres, is being preserved as open space: a nature area, an 18-hole golf course and a bicycle path along the course of Sand Creek.
The northern corner of this open area will link with the Rocky Mountain Arsenal National Wildlife Refuge, a vast preserve 20 times the size of Central Park in New York that is being created on the site of a former chemical munitions factory.
In a north-south arc, the wildlife refuge, Stapleton and Lowry seem to channel Denver's future growth to the east. As the Rockies wall off growth to the west, the city is spreading east, drawn in part by the new airport. Denver International Airport, once lampooned as a white elephant, has now attracted 8 major office and industrial projects and 19 hotel projects. This summer, officials inaugurated major eastern links on a beltway that eventually is to ring metropolitan Denver.
Indeed, some predict that the development of Stapleton and Lowry will barely slow Denver's eastern sprawl, as tract-home subdivisions continue to march through wheat fields.
"Sprawl is an upper-class, elitist word that closes out the aspirations of lower-income and minority Americans for a safer and more spacious place to live and raise their kids," said John Andrews, board chairman of the Independence Institute, a libertarian think tank here. "People say, 'Don't Los Angelize Denver.' They are howling at the moon."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
As Energy Council Gathers, Oil Industry Seeks Answers

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
This week, Houston is throwing a party for more than 30 oil ministers and 8,000 other officials and executives from at least 82 countries. To make sure everyone attending the World Energy Council Congress feels sufficiently welcome, the city greeted them on Saturday night with a light show featuring 2 million watts of spotlights, 14 powerful lasers and 12 tons of explosives, enough to make car alarms wail all over downtown. Coming Thursday is what is being billed as the state's largest sit-down dinner ever, requiring a banquet hall also known as the Astrodome.
But not even the local brand of relentless hospitality can make up for oil prices that nobody here wants to celebrate. So this week's gathering of the most powerful figures in world energy has become only a brief break from a new and unexpected round of cutbacks and even, in some cases, layoffs. 
 Just a year ago, executives griped about the bonuses they had to pay to hire and keep geophysicists. Now they wonder how to keep those geophysicists busy.
"Have you found anybody who is not cutting back?" asked Robert Mosbacher, the former Secretary of Commerce. He recounted how the Houston company that bears his name had delayed planned drilling in Mississippi, Texas, Louisiana and several foreign nations.
Compared, of course, with the industry's roller coaster ride through the 1970's and 1980's, the 1990's might seem more like swan boats. Still, companies that boasted last year of having the slimmed-down staffs and the new oil-finding technologies to weather low oil prices are now saying that by "low" they never meant the current $14 a barrel.
"The industry is suffering from reverse sticker shock," said Daniel Yergin, the president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates and one of the meeting's featured speakers.
Scott Sheffield, the chief executive of Pioneer Natural Resources, for example, gathered his employees this afternoon to urge them to cut every expense.
Pioneer completed about $5 billion in acquisitions last year, becoming one of the nation's largest independent oil companies. It also contracted for drilling services at top dollar. This year, to help pay down $2 billion in assumed debt, it has had to dispose of about 10 percent of its properties. Exploration and production outlays have been cut to $450 million from $600 million this year and will drop to $300 million next year.
"We were flying high until oil prices cratered," said Marsha D. Sheffield, the company's public relations chief, before leaving to help her husband with his cost-cutting appeal.
The major oil companies -- with interests in refineries, gas stations and petrochemical plants -- are more diversified and financially stronger, but not immune. Texaco has trimmed its $4.6 billion exploration and production budget by about 10 percent. Peter I. Bijur, the company's chief executive, and his hovering public relations representatives stressed in interviews here that the operative word was "deferred," not canceled or cut.
The oilfield services companies, however, are past the point of maintaining the appearance of normalcy. Nabors Industries, the world's largest land driller, has cut nearly 3,000 workers across the oil patch from a peak of 13,000 last fall. A year ago, Nabors had to ask customers wanting rigs and crews how long they could wait. Now the only question is, "How soon can we start?"
Among other oilfield service companies, EVI Weatherford laid off 1,300 of its more than 11,000 employees this year, and Schlumberger laid off 700 of its 9,200 domestic oilfield service employees through July.
Houston, and Texas more generally, where technology has passed energy as the state's largest employer, are unlikely to feel nearly the pain of the 1980's. Then, entire Houston office towers and subdivisions were left vacant as developers and homeowners walked away from their properties and their payments.
Last year, through July, oil and gas production gave the Houston region 3,800 new jobs. Through July this year, the industry lost 100 jobs. Over all, the continuing expansion in retailing and construction had allowed the area to keep adding jobs at a strong pace. But Robert W. Gilmer, a Federal Reserve economist based in Houston, said those sectors were coasting on the energy industry's past strength; he predicted a slowdown for the rest of the year. Without a stronger energy business, he said, "We can't survive for long by taking in each other's laundry."
Houston's bane is the nation's boon, however, as low energy prices help sustain strong economic growth with scant inflation. But oil exporting nations like Russia and Mexico are being pinched.
The World Energy Council, representing the interests of energy producers across several industries, gathers in a different spot every three years. This year's formal sessions are concentrating on technology -- both to improve efficiency, and reduce pollution. Breakfasts, lunches, receptions and dinners, meanwhile, often combine deal-making and international diplomacy, all the more so now that British Petroleum had agreed to buy Amoco.
At a Monday breakfast, drilling company executives vied for the attention of the guest of honor, Luis Giusti, chief executive of Petroleos de Venezuela S.A., the Venezuelan national oil company. Even Venezuela, having displaced Saudi Arabia as the United States' largest foreign source of oil, has cut its capital budget, mostly for exploration and production, to $4 billion from $6 billion. "I think the $18 to $20 oil era is going to be replaced by the $14 to $16 era," Mr. Giusti said in an interview.
The experts attribute low oil prices to feuds among exporters and the near-evaporation of Asian demand. American energy companies at least have the consolation of steady natural gas prices. But with huge volumes in storage, these companies are praying as fervently as ski resort operators for a frigid winter. Outside investors like Thomas O. Hicks and Richard Rainwater are raising their stakes, with Mr. Rainwater even buying oil futures.
So far, Houston's oilmen -- and, in the 1990's, oilwomen -- have remained optimistic enough to avoid serious cutbacks on life's necessities. But, chastened perhaps by past reversals, they have far fewer necessities than in the 1970's.
Back then, recalled Stephen Zimmerman, owner of La Colombe d'Or, a restaurant and hotel installed in an oil baron's mansion, oilmen would begin with Dom Perignon, move on to choice Burgundies and first-growth Bordeaux -- "whatever they could pronounce" -- and finish with $100 shots of century-old Armagnac.
And that was for lunch.
Then came the 1980's crash. He had a friend deliver an oil barrel, planted it in his entrance hall and pegged the price of lunch to the price of crude.
But even in the best of recent times, his biggest seller had been the house wine, and then only at dinner. "The newer guys never learned to entertain," he sniffed. "A lot of them think a Caesar salad and grilled chicken breast is a gourmet meal."
But Mr. Zimmerman, for one, has made provisions in case a still lower oil price compels an even more modest style. Back in the garage sits the oil barrel, ready for its return.

HEADLINE: Panel Unveils Suggestions For Cutting Property Tax

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
A state commission charged with finding ways to lessen local property taxes in New Jersey offered 60 recommendations today, including a cap on annual increases in salaries of public employees, consolidation of some functions of local school districts and state financing of local prosecutors offices.
In addition to suggesting cost-cutting measures, the commission called for legislation that would allow some local governments to collect taxes on parking, entertainment and hotel room fees and to impose fees on developers whose projects would increase burdens on schools and parks. 
 If all the measures were adopted, said Barbara Cannon, the Mayor of Old Bridge Township and the commission's chairwoman, property taxes could be reduced as much as 10 percent.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is expected to announce on Wednesday which measures she would support. Leaders of the Republican-controlled legislature were silent on the proposals, waiting to see what measures Mrs. Whitman would support.
But Democrats and others greeted the proposals with reactions that ranged from resigned yawns to truculent fuming, saying that the recommendations were either old, inadequate or too radical.
Mrs. Whitman set up the Property Tax Commission last December after she narrowly won re-election against a Democratic challenger who effectively attacked her policies on auto insurance and her failure to reduce property taxes. On a per capita basis, property taxes in New Jersey are the highest in the nation.
But in coming up with its recommendations, the commission remained true to the Governor's early admonition that it not pursue a wholesale shifting of the burden for financing education and other services from local to statewide taxes, as some have sought.
"The commission concluded that a significant shift of the revenue source for local education from the property tax to a statewide tax could create serious economic consequences for the state," the commission said in its report. "Additionally, such a shift would require New Jerseyans to forgo a degree of local control over the education of their children, as additional state controls would be necessary to maintain the benefits of additional state aid."
Among the cost-saving steps envisioned by the commission's recommendations was cutting education costs, by far the main component of the state's high property taxes, by allowing school districts to consolidate or merge certain functions. For example, transportation operations for neighboring districts could be merged for savings. Purchasing operations for a group of districts as well as administrative and payroll functions could be merged and shared to lower costs.
Similar consolidations could be used, the commission said, in municipal services ranging from trash collection and disposal to police and fire services. The recommendations include the offering of financial incentives in the form of transitional aid from the state to smooth the way to such changes.
The Senate Democratic minority leader, Richard J. Codey, said that much of what is recommended is drawn from measures put forward in the past by Democrats and Republicans in the Legislature, but not embraced by Mrs. Whitman.
"The only thing new in this report is the ink," said Senator Codey. "Some of these things are likely to get done now in some fashion because she is either getting out of the way or jumping on the ship as it sails out of the harbor."
Lynn Maher, spokeswoman for the New Jersey Education Association, the state's largest teachers union representing 90,000 active teachers, angrily said that the proposal to cap public employee salaries and peg increases to the rate of inflation as measured by the Consumer Price Index would surely be challenged legally by the group and other employee unions.
Charles J. Coleman, a professor of management at the Rutgers University School of Business in Camden and an expert on public sector labor relations, called the recommendation for a cap on salaries "a dumb idea."
"You don't control things with these overall initiatives," he said. "What you are going to end up with is the good people leaving and the bad people staying."
William G. Dressel Jr., the executive director of the New Jersey State League of Municipalities, said that the group had no problem with what was in the report, but thought it did not go far enough in shifting public education expenses to the state.
He added that the group favored the consolidations and the host of financial incentives that the commission proposes for localities that merge services and functions. But like others, he rejected the proposed cap on salaries, saying that while it might strengthen local officials' hand in labor negotiations, it also severely limited their discretion.
One commission member, James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, conceded that the recommendations were "no silver bullet." The commission sought to outline choices that took into account that New Jersey, as the most densely populated state in the nation, has more government per capita than other states.
"New Jersey citizens might like that, and what the commission wants to make clear is that if they want that then they have to realize that they will have to pay for it," Mr. Hughes said.
Other recommendations from the commission include devising joint purchasing agreements for localities to command better prices on a host of items; providing early retirement incentives for local employees and allowing decertification of some civil service positions; creating joint municipal courts, and speeding local property tax revaluation by creating a state program to absorb increases initially and phase them in over three years.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Markets Continue to Rise As Dow Climbs 79 Points
Stocks rose for the third consecutive day. Traders and analysts attributed the continued increases to optimism about a coordinated approach to the global economic crises.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 79.04 points, or 0.99 percent, to 8,024.39, its highest close this month. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 7.96 points, to 1,037.68, and the Nasdaq composite index gained 12.42 points, to 1,678.11. Page C8. 

The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond increased to 5.25 percent, from 5.22 percent on Monday. Bellwether 30-year bond yields have dropped about half a percentage point in the last two months. C8.
 
Prosecution Upheld in Insider Case
A New York State court upheld the right of Robert Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, to prosecute insider-trading cases. Defendants' lawyers called the ruling a dangerous application of state law that could increase all stockbrokers' liability. C2.
 
Head of F.C.C. Responds to Critics
William E. Kennard, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, lashed out at critics who have blamed his agency for the problems plaguing the introduction of digital television services. The F.C.C. had decided to let the telecommunications industry set the standards for high-definition television sets. C2.
 
Task Force Calls for Bank Changes
A task force has recommended approval of mergers of large Canadian banks and the easing of rules for foreign banks to operate there as long as the public interest is protected. C4.
 
Future of American Home Improves
Things are starting to look up for American Home Products, which has suffered product recalls, liability lawsuits and a weak drug pipeline recently. But its proposed merger with Monsanto will make the new company a pharmaceutical and agricultural giant. Analysts also see signs of encouragement in American Home's bounty of new drugs. Market Place. C7.
 
A New On-Line Women's Service
America Online is selling three of its women-oriented services to a new venture formed by Geraldine B. Laybourne, the former head of Walt Disney's cable unit and the former president of Nickelodeon. She will develop them for a new women's service offered by America Online. Advertising. C6.
 
Retail Sales Rose Just 0.2% in August
Retail sales rose two-tenths of a percent in August, less than had been expected. Gains in apparel and furniture sales were offset by a drop in auto sales. Retail sales at stores open at least a year rose 4 percent. C7.
 
For the Oil Industry, Tales of Woe
The world's energy-industry luminaries are in Houston for the triennial meeting of the World Energy Council Congress, but despite a lavish Texas-style welcome, they have little to cheer with oil prices at about $14 a barrel. C23.
 
Old Denver Airport's New Life
Three and one-half years after Denver's $5 billion new airport drew the nation's attention, the old airport is grabbing back the spotlight. A development project one-third the size of Manhattan is taking shape at what once was known as Stapleton International, a reflection of Denver's continuing economic boom. A12.
 
Group Seeks New Sleepwear Rules
A coalition of consumer and fire prevention groups is seeking tougher fire-protection standards for children's sleepwear. A16.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Rise 0.2%, Below Expectations

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Retail sales rose less than expected in August as gains in apparel and furniture were offset by a drop in automotive business.
August sales rose two-tenths of a percent after declining six-tenths of a percent in July, the Commerce Department said today. When autos are excluded, August retail sales rose three-tenths of a percent after increasing six-tenths of a percent in July. 
 Analysts had expected a rise of five-tenths of a percent in overall August sales and a gain of two-tenths of a percent without autos.
"Spending has moderated from robust growth in the first half of the year, and any continued weakness in equity markets will portend less exuberant spending going forward," said Steven Wood, chief economist at BancAmerica Robertson Stephens in San Francisco.
Still, a strong labor market, rising incomes, subdued prices and high consumer confidence will keep consumer spending rolling along, Mr. Wood said. Resilient consumer spending has been an important factor in the economy's strength this year. Consumer spending -- which accounts for two-thirds of gross domestic product -- rose at a 5.8 percent annual rate in the second quarter, compared with 6.1 percent in the first three months of the year.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 2146 words

HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE PUBLIC;
Keep Clinton in Office, Most Say In Poll, but His Image Is Eroding

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE with JANET ELDER 

 BODY:
The public's view of President Clinton's moral character has sunk to the lowest level of his Presidency, but most Americans say they still believe he is a vigorous leader who should not be impeached or forced to resign, the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows.
Slowly but steadily, the public's perception of Mr. Clinton's personal image has slipped since January, when Americans first learned of his relationship with a former White House intern. But over time, the cumulative shift has been striking. 
 In itself, the report released last week by Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, seemed to have little additional impact on these attitudes. Americans said they disliked Mr. Starr and suspected his motives. Though only 1 in 20 respondents said they had read the full report, and about half said they had read part of it, most people said the graphic sexual details were unnecessarily salacious and intended to embarrass the President.
And despite the glare of publicity about the affair, Mr. Clinton's job approval rating stands at 62 percent, impressive by any reckoning.
Still, by several measures, the survey showed that most people now see Mr. Clinton as bereft of the code of ethics that they try to live by. Sixty-six percent of Americans said Mr. Clinton did not share their moral values, while 29 percent said he did. In January, the public was divided on Mr. Clinton's morals, and after his re-election two years ago, a majority perceived Mr. Clinton as someone who did share their ethical standards. And for the first time since Democrats lost the House in 1994 -- and only the second time in Mr. Clinton's six years in office -- more Americans viewed the President unfavorably than favorably, with 39 percent viewing him favorably and 45 percent not.
While people say they want to put the scandal behind them, they also want Mr. Clinton to be reprimanded for his conduct -- but not impeached or forced from office. Fifty-seven percent of those polled said Congress should vote to censure Mr. Clinton; 33 percent were opposed to censure. More than 6 in 10 Americans said they thought the best thing for the country was for Mr. Clinton to finish his term. In answer to another question, 58 percent said it was not necessary for Congress to hold impeachment hearings at all, while 36 percent said it was.
The public's personal view of Mr. Clinton has diminished over nine months roughly equally among all groups, rich and poor, urban and rural, young and old, male and female. For example, the perception that Mr. Clinton shares the moral values of most Americans has dropped by 10 percentage points among men and 14 points among women -- not much of a gap.
The poll of 1,813 adults nationwide, conducted Saturday through Monday, also found that the public blamed Mr. Clinton and not his enemies for the crisis, a change from a few months ago. Fifty-four percent blamed Mr. Clinton and 36 percent blamed his enemies -- figures that have roughly reversed since February. More and more, people have come to believe that Mr. Clinton probably did encourage Monica S. Lewinsky to lie under oath.
In the latest survey, 46 percent said he did encourage her to lie, 18 percent said he did not, and 32 percent said they did not know. When respondents were pressed, the numbers were even more stark: 61 percent said Mr. Clinton encouraged Ms. Lewinsky to lie. The poll has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus two percentage points.
Yet even against these harsh judgments, Mr. Clinton is protected by an important bulwark that has confounded the pundits -- as well as the President's Republican detractors -- since the scandal broke: the measures of Mr. Clinton not as a man but as a President continue to be strikingly strong. He is seen as an effective leader by 66 percent of those polled.
And Mr. Clinton's job approval rating, which White House officials have clung to as their best evidence that the scandal has not tarnished his command of the office, stands at 62 percent. Earlier this month it was 60 percent, and last month, immediately after he told the nation he had had an inappropriate relationship with Ms. Lewinsky, it was 65 percent. When the scandal broke in January, Mr. Clinton's job approval rating was 56 percent.
"He's running the country well," said Morley Fogel, 61, a retired salesman and a Democrat from Tequesta, Fla. "He's just not running his life very well."
Mr. Fogel, a poll respondent who was re-interviewed yesterday, added: "He's ruined a legacy that he could have left as a President who turned around the economy. Instead, he'll be remembered as a philanderer."
Another respondent, Victoria Livingston, 72, a retired teacher in Phoenix who said she voted as an independent, put it this way: "This situation upsets me a lot. But I think he should be allowed to finish out his term. What he's done is a personal thing. It doesn't have anything to do with what he's doing for the country. He's done a very good job for the country."
The poll showed that people continued to draw a sharp distinction between the President's personal and public lives. Fifty-eight percent said they viewed the situation more as a private matter, while 35 percent said it was more a public matter having to do with Mr. Clinton's job as President.
But Presidential approval ratings can plummet sharply. The last President to serve two terms, Ronald Reagan, also enjoyed high approval ratings in his second term. But his ratings fell 21 points from October to November of 1986 -- to 46 percent -- amid public concern over the Iran-contra affair. It was the sharpest one-month drop in Presidential approval ever recorded.
While people were critical of what Mr. Starr included in the report, they also disapproved of how Congress handled the matter. Thirty-seven percent said the House did the right thing in releasing Mr. Starr's report, with all the graphic sexual details, while 59 percent said the full report should not have been released.
Despite those concerns about how lawmakers are handling the crisis, Congress as an institution drew a higher approval rating for the job it was doing than it had since the Times/CBS Poll first began asking about Congressional job ratings, in 1974. Fifty-six percent of Americans now say they approve of the way Congress is doing its job.
Those ratings are an encouraging sign for incumbents as their general election campaigns begin in full force. But the survey offered few clues as to how the scandal might reverberate on Election Day. Seventy-four percent said the scandal would have no effect on whom they supported for Congress.
The Lewinsky matter seems to have had little effect on voters' images of the two parties, according to a CBS News poll taken before the Starr report was made public. More than half of the public said they held a favorable view of the Democratic Party, roughly the same number who said they had a positive view of the Republican Party.
In that poll, the images of the parties remained similar to what they were in the last election. Democrats were perceived as the party that would make better decisions on social issues like education and health care. Republicans were seen as being tougher on crime and better at upholding traditional family values.
Both parties were seen as offering candidates with similar levels of honesty and integrity. But over all, the Republican Party was considered to have higher ethical standards than the Democratic Party.
Despite the appetite for Mr. Clinton to be censured, only 32 percent in the latest Times/CBS News Poll said it would be better for the country for him to resign. Asked, in another question, their views if it turned out that Mr. Clinton did obstruct justice, 22 percent said he should apologize, 30 percent said he should resign, 19 percent said he should be impeached, and 26 percent said the matter should be dropped.
And regardless of what they thought should happen, in the end, 18 percent said they expected Mr. Clinton to be impeached, 11 percent said he would resign, and 62 percent said neither would happen.
"I don't think Congress has the stomach for an impeachment proceeding," said George O'Donnell, 44, a poll respondent from Marion, Iowa. Mr. O'Donnell, an independent who is a motor vehicle inspector, said censure was a fitting punishment. "A censure, if you look at it like a plea bargain or reduced charges, says: 'You lied. We know it. But we're going to let you continue your term.' "
A Republican respondent from Buffalo who identified herself only as Marie, 66, a retired restaurant owner, also made a distinction between the President's private behavior and his public performance.
"This country seems to be doing very well, and I don't see that a personal problem has anything to do with running the country," she said. "The stock market is doing well. There are more jobs for people. Basically, I think the American people are happier than they've been in many years."
In another sign that many people were sympathetic to Mr. Clinton in his predicament, 53 percent said it would be understandable for him to lie under oath or to encourage Ms. Lewinsky to lie under oath about their sexual conduct; 41 percent said it would not be understandable.
As speculation swirled over how Mr. Clinton's travails would affect Vice President Al Gore, the survey found that Mr. Gore's favorability rating has not been noticeably affected. Twenty-four percent have a favorable view of Mr. Gore, 21 percent unfavorable, and most people are undecided or do not know enough about him.
Hillary Rodham Clinton's support has been buoyed by the revelations about her husband's infidelity. Fifty-percent of Americans had a favorable opinion of her, 25 percent unfavorable.
And while Speaker Newt Gingrich has sought to cast himself as a statesman and above partisanship in dealing with the scandal, he is still viewed more unfavorably than favorably by the public. Twenty-four percent give him a favorable rating, 31 percent unfavorable, and the remaining are undecided or do not know enough about the Speaker.
Mr. Starr's negative ratings, while consistent, are also high. Forty-three percent of Americans said their view of him was not favorable, 23 percent said it was favorable, and the rest were undecided or did not know. Fifty percent said Mr. Starr's report was mostly a one-sided look at some facts, while 35 percent said it was fair and balanced.
"A lot of it could be politically motivated," said a poll respondent, Marcelline Farris, 47, a nurse in Lenore, W. Va., who is a Democrat. "They've been hounding him since he's been in office. The country needs to move on. He's human."
Still, many Republican lawmakers said they expected the polls to shift to the point where Mr. Clinton's job approval ratings would suffer.
"Anything this big has got to have some impact on the polls," Senator Trent Lott, the Republican leader, said in an interview. "But it won't be reflected for days or even weeks. The average man and woman out there didn't spend the weekend reading the Starr report."
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
 The latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Saturday through Monday with 1,813 adults throughout the United States.
The survey was organized as a tracking poll, with independent daily samples, designed to capture daily shifts in public opinion, if they occurred, as Americans heard or read about the report to Congress by the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 42,000 active residential exchanges across the country.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic region, sex, race, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples (combining all three days of interviewing) will differ by no more than two percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups the potential sampling error is larger. For example, for any one day's results, it is plus or minus four percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variations in question wording or the order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat different results.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk
