HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Stocks in Brazil Rally, Buoying Latin Markets

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Record gains by Brazilian stocks accelerated today, the third consecutive day of a rally that has driven up the market 45 percent. The strong gains were fueled by a growing sense among investors that developed nations would protect Latin American economies from the devastation that has crippled Asia and Russia.
In a financial crisis rooted in fear, and feeding on panic, the reality that any international bailout remained somewhat amorphous seemed almost beside the point. President Clinton's speech on Monday calling on advanced countries to support Latin economies, and suggestions in London by officials of the Group of Seven industrial nations of a new economic approach to promote growth in emerging markets, as distinct from a tight monetary policy, were enough for stocks to rally. 
 In Sao Paulo, Brazil's benchmark Bovespa index closed up 18.68 percent, with most other Latin markets rising along with it. In Argentina, the key index closed up 8.9 percent, while Mexican blue chips gained 12.92 percent. Improvements in Chile and Venezuela were more modest, at 3.71 percent and 3.75 percent, respectively.
But investment analysts continued to insist that the upturn, just four trading days after Brazilian stocks plunged 15.82 percent, was a sign of volatility more than health. Some $900 million left the country on Monday, cutting dollar reserves to less than $50 billion. As of 7 P.M. today, $350 million more had left central bank coffers.
"These currency outflows will come down once it's sure that the Brazilian foreign reserves will be backed by some kind of overdraft protection from the I.M.F.," said Florencio Deteresa of Global Emerging Markets North America. "All these markets have been hit by very high volatility."
Stocks also rose on word that President Fernando Henrique Cardoso planned to telephone President Clinton, which some interpreted as a sign of growing coordination at the highest levels of government to steer Brazil, the world's ninth-largest economy, through its turbulence.
"The markets are looking for a signal that there's going to be decisive coordinated international action to prevent the crisis from forcing Brazil into devaluation," said Francisco Larios, a senior emerging markets economist at Standard & Poor's DRI, "and these rumors feed the hope that such action is being worked on. That's fine, however, we have to see much more in terms of preventive action before confidence is restored on a more permanent basis. This is a time when you're going to have rumors left and right." Last week, Standard & Poor's downgraded Brazilian debt to negative status.
After the markets closed today, the President's spokesman, Sergio Amaral, said Mr. Cardoso wanted to thank Mr. Clinton for his speech on Monday, which he said contained variations on ideas Mr. Cardoso had broached in his first meeting with Mr. Clinton in April 1995.
 A White House spokesman said late on Tuesday that President Clinton had talked not only to Mr. Cardoso but also to President Ernesto Zedillo of Mexico and Jean Chretien, the Prime Minister of Canada, according to Bloomberg News and Reuters. Mr. Clinton wanted to get the leaders' firsthand assessment of the regional and global economic situation, said the official, who provided no other details.
Brazil has said it is not seeking help from the International Monetary Fund, but Mr. Cardoso has called for a cut in United States interest rates to ease pressure on emerging economies. The President has insisted that the problems roiling Brazil stem from international uncertainties, rather than weaknesses in its economy.
Mr. Cardoso's view was echoed tonight by Michel Camdessus, managing director of the I.M.F., during a appearance at the European-American Business Council in New York. Mr. Camdessus said despite Brazil's troubles, it had made "enormous progress in the right direction."
He said the I.M.F. "stands ready to help with advice, opinions and if needed, financial assistance, but as of now, Brazil has not asked for financial support."
President Cardoso, three weeks before he seeks re-election on Oct. 4, would be loath to accept strict conditions that would likely be part of a conventional I.M.F. bailout package, political analysts here say. But there was talk among analysts of possible overdraft protection from the I.M.F. that would carry softer conditions.
Yet in Washington today, George Soros, the international financier, warned that the I.M.F. lacked sufficient funds to ward off turbulence. "I don't think any bailout is possible," Mr. Soros said at a Congressional hearing. "Clearly there would be a great need for I.M.F. assistance and the I.M.F. needs greater capacity than it has to meet those needs," he said.
David Rothkopf, president of the Newmarket Company, investment advisers in Washington, agreed, saying that with the uncertainty he did not expect the Brazilian stock rally to sustain itself. The recent buying, he said, showed some bottom-fishing. Now, he said, "I think things will be bad but not disastrous." Mr. Rothkopf said world leaders and economists seemed overwhelmed by "the first protracted international crisis of the global era."
"I don't think the institutions are in place to deal with such a thing," he added, "and the leadership that's in power now doesn't have the experience to deal with it, and they don't have the tools they need."

HEADLINE: Iraqi Official Criticizes U.N. Chief Over Role in Arms Inspection

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 15

 BODY:
A senior Iraqi official close to President Saddam Hussein leveled an unusual direct attack on Secretary General Kofi Annan today, apparently trying to draw Mr. Annan into a growing confrontation over arms inspections.
Iraq is on the verge of cutting off all cooperation with United Nations inspectors and could either expel inspectors or force a situation in which they would have to be withdrawn, ending years of painstaking disarmament and raising questions about how Iraq can be prevented from rearming. 
 The crisis has demoralized the United Nations Special Commission, which is responsible for dismantling Iraq's prohibited weapons and insuring that Baghdad cannot build new ones.
Iraq wants a restructuring of the paralyzed commission and more initiatives by the Secretary General, who met on Monday with representatives of the five permanent members of the Security Council -- Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States -- and this month's Council president, Hans Dahlgren of Sweden, to discuss a review of Iraqi relations with the United Nations if and when cooperation resumes.
In Baghdad today, the Iraqi official, Hamed Youssef Hummadi, an adviser in the President's office, said in an article in an official newspaper, al-Qadissiya, that Mr. Annan had failed to honor a promise the Iraqis said he made in February, "which called for ending the embargo imposed on Iraq."
Mr. Annan's agreement, reached in a meeting with President Hussein in Baghdad, opened formerly closed sites to inspectors, a requirement for moving toward the end of inspections. But it did not promise an automatic end to sanctions.
Mr. Annan is "not enthusiastic" about involving himself in this crisis, at least not at this point, a Western diplomat said here today. Diplomats say that it is impossible to know whether the Iraqis really believe in their interpretation of events or are merely trying to provoke reaction.
Mr. Hummadi's comments reflected Iraqi annoyance with Mr. Annan's insistence that Baghdad must reverse its decision, made on Aug. 5, to stop on-site inspections, a clear violation of the Secretary General's accord. Mr. Annan told diplomats from the Security Council on Monday that he agrees with them that no review of relations with Iraq can be conducted until the decision is reversed.
Peter Burleigh, the acting chief United States representative at the United Nations, said in an interview today that if the Iraqis wanted a comprehensive review of their relations with the United Nations, that is exactly what they will get.
"We're very comfortable about what the bottom line of that review would be," Mr. Burleigh said.
In Cairo, another senior Iraqi official renewed the attacks on United Nations inspectors today. Foreign Minister Mohammed Saeed al-Sahaf, who is seeking support at a meeting of the Arab League, said that Iraq had "no confidence in the arms inspection committee and in the policies of the United States."
Mr. Sahaf is expected to have some success in Cairo, because attitudes have been hardening against sanctions and the problems they are causing Iraqi civilians, experts say.
"We face a rising tide of anger in the streets in many Middle Eastern cities, which our friendly countries in the region are finding harder to control," said Phebe Marr, a historian of modern Iraq at the Woodrow Wilson Center in Washington who has returned from several months in the region.

HEADLINE: Mayor Wins Chance to Take Storied Kennedy House Seat

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Michael Capuano, the Mayor of the Boston suburb of Somerville, fought off nine rivals to inherit one of the most storied of political seats in the country tonight, winning the Democratic primary in the Eighth Congressional District, which sent a young John F. Kennedy to Washington more than half a century ago.
So entrenched are the liberal leanings of the Eighth that Mr. Capuano is considered a shoo-in to win the general election in November and claim the seat of the second Kennedy to hold it, Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, who is retiring. 
 Mr. Capuano ran largely on skilled hometown organization, effective television ads and a can-do record as Mayor that included reducing class size in Somerville schools to 19 pupils.
In the Massachusetts race for governor, Acting Gov. Argeo Paul Cellucci solidly defeated the State Treasurer, Joseph D. Malone, for the Republican Party nomination. Mr. Cellucci, who had 58 percent of the vote with 92 percent of precincts reporting, will face State Attorney General Scott Harshbarger, who won the Democratic primary tonight with 51 percent of the vote, with 88 percent of precincts reporting. Political pollsters consider the race between Mr. Cellucci and Mr. Harshbarger a toss-up.
In Rhode Island, which also held its primary today, the stage is set for a similarly hard-fought governor's race. Lincoln Almond, the Republican incumbent, who was unopposed, will face a rematch against a former state senator, Myrth York, a Democrat.
In the Eighth District of Massachusetts, which includes parts of Boston and several suburbs, early estimates held that only about 75,000 people voted, meaning that with the crowded field of 10 candidates, all it took was a few thousand votes to win -- and Mr. Capuano's Somerville contained 15 percent of the Democratic voters in the district.
The appetite to vote was blunted by the strong economy combined with less-than-compelling statewide races and perhaps a tinge of added political alienation brought on by the scandal in Washington, analysts said. William Galvin, the Massachusetts Secretary of State, predicted that of the state's 3.3 million registered voters, only about 1 million would come to the polls.
Voting in the Eighth District was hampered as well by widespread confusion among constituents trying to keep the cornucopia of candidates straight.
Ruth Nicolora, a grandmother of 15, who was interviewed after she voted in North Cambridge, said she had voted for Chris Gabrieli, a venture capitalist, because "I liked him from the start." And yet, she said, "I bounced back and forth between different ones. I liked the Mayor of Somerville."
It would have been easier, she said, if Mr. Kennedy had stayed in the race.
"It's a hard seat to fill after Joe," she said.
Mr. Kennedy, the eldest son of Robert F. Kennedy, announced that he was retiring, for now, from politics to devote himself more to family and business following the skiing death of his brother, Michael.
Mr. Capuano's victory was snatched from the hands of Raymond L. Flynn, the former Mayor of Boston and United States Ambassador to the Vatican, who had become the early front-runner in the race. He suffered from a constricted campaign budget and the problem that, though his name recognition was high, opinions about him among voters were deeply mixed between a core of strong support and a core of strong antipathy caused in part by his anti-abortion stance. He conceded the race to Mr. Capuano late tonight.
Polls had also put former State Senator George Bachrach and a former talk-show host, Marjorie Clapprood, among the front-runners in a race that has proved the most expensive Congressional contest ever in Massachusetts.
Mr. Capuano appeared to have been bolstered in part by relatively strong turnout in his hometown of Somerville, a densely populated, well-worn old city of triple-decker houses and confusingly irregular grids of streets known to confound even the well-oriented.
Indeed, despite the lofty history of the Eighth -- the political home of President Kennedy, the longtime House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. and Boston's Rascal King Mayor, James Michael Curley -- the race appeared to devolve down to the most retail of retail politics. A poll commissioned by The Boston Herald found that among voters who supported Mr. Capuano, a full 44 percent had met him.

HEADLINE: Who Should Decide The Sex of a Baby?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Researchers Report Success in Method to Pick Baby's Sex" (front page, Sept. 9): Aristotle observed that a higher proportion of females were conceived in the presence of a cold southern wind. He also believed that facing north during sexual intercourse would result in the conception of a greater number of males. 
 Now that methods are available that can truly improve the likelihood of conceiving a child of a chosen sex, it is critical that we examine the consequences more deeply.
Many would agree that the desire to avoid sex-linked diseases would constitute a valid reason for the use of sex-selection techniques. However, some parents might use these techniques because of their belief in differences in the social and economic roles of girls and boys. What, for example, would be the consequences for a child born of the "wrong" sex to parents who were so intent upon having a child of the "right" sex that they went to the considerable trouble of taking advantage of the new medical technology?
 
NEIL G. BENNETT
New York, Sept. 9, 1998
 
The writer is a demographer at Columbia University.

HEADLINE: Good Pay, Good Teachers

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The growing dearth of teaching talent available to public schools across the country should come as no surprise (Week in Review, Sept. 13). The economic and social incentives for top college graduates to pursue teaching over more prestigious and lucrative fields simply do not exist. 
 In the past, qualified women who lacked employment opportunities in other fields filled this need. However, today's female college graduates have vastly increased job opportunities.
The answer lies not in raising graduate school standards or erecting more rigorous credential requirements. Rather, we must reassess and transform our national priorities. When Americans are finally willing to make the education of our children a top national priority, then we will no longer have to worry about the paucity of teaching talent in our public schools.
 
WENDY R. SHELDON
San Francisco, Sept. 13, 1998

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
The Dow Extends Its Climb to a Third Consecutive Session

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices rose again yesterday, the first time prices have risen for three straight sessions on Wall Street in more than a month.
Extending a theme sounded in recent days, traders and analysts said equity prices were responding to statements from policy makers in Washington and elsewhere that a coordinated response from industrialized nations and lending institutions like the International Monetary Fund to what has come to be seen as a global economic crisis was under serious consideration. 
 The most likely first step to resolving the crisis, according to traders and analysts, is a cut in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve Board and other central banks.
"I think investors are encouraged that policy makers are considering this as a global crisis rather than isolated brush fires," said Christine A. Callies, chief investment strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston.
"Since investors are concerned that falling asset prices are a symptom of global problems, bouncing asset prices might be a sign some of those problems are being relieved. In short, the markets believe the monetary authorities are going to blink."
Although more stocks rose in value than declined, the bulk of the gains were concentrated among blue-chip stocks that make up the Dow Jones industrial average and high-capitalization issues in the Standard & Poor's 500 index.
By the close, the Dow had gained 79.04 points, to 8,024.39, up just under 1 percent on the day and the highest level so far this month. It was the first three-day advance for the Dow since Aug. 5 through Aug. 7, and puts the blue-chip index back above 7,908.25, where it began the year. Still, the index remains about 1,300 points, or 14 percent, below its July 17 peak of 9,337.97.
The smallish advance was noteworthy for another reason: It is the first time since Sept. 4, when the Dow fell 41.97 points, that the closely watched index has not registered a gain or a loss exceeding 100 points.
Among broader market measures, the Standard & Poor's 500 Index rose 7.96 points, to 1,037.68. The Nasdaq composite index gained 12.42 points, to 1,678.11.
Al Goldman, chief market strategist at A. G. Edwards in St. Louis, said the market "was dull as dishwater until the last 20 to 30 minutes," when he said some computerized "buy" programs came in to the market and traders began buying stocks.
Fed chairman Alan Greenspan and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin are scheduled to testify today before the House Banking Committee on the global economy and financial markets.
Mr. Goldman said the market was pricing in expectations of a cut in interest rates.
However, it is unlikely Mr. Greenspan will provide clear signals about the Fed's intentions during his testimony. Analysts said it was just as unlikely that Mr. Rubin would use the forum as an opportunity to jawbone the Fed.
But the officials may well use the occasion to urge passage of the $17.9 billion in additional funds for the I.M.F. requested by the Clinton Administration, financing that would trigger more than $82 billion in contributions from other member nations.
George Soros, the billionaire hedge fund manager, urged legislators yesterday to approve the full amount, telling Congress it can no longer ignore the "disintegration of the global capitalist system."
Anticipation of interest rate relief and a replenishment of the I.M.F.'s financial resources helped to send equity markets in Mexico and Brazil soaring yesterday.
Brazilian stocks, battered since mid-August, when Russia defaulted on international debts, soared more than 18 percent. Mexican shares rose by nearly 13 percent.
Asian markets were also strong, but with the exception of London, most other European exchanges posted declines.
Prospects of a cut in interest rates and help for troubled developing country economies helped to strengthen stocks of banks and other financial services that have been battered by rolling crises in Asia, Russia and Latin America.
Among the biggest gainers were Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, which climbed 3 3/16, to 56 5/16. American Express rose another 3 3/16, to 84 7/8. J. P. Morgan was up 2 7/16, to 94 7/16. Providian Financial Corporation shares soared 11 1/2, to 72 15/16, after the credit card company's chairman said it could increase earnings by as much as 50 percent this year and next, exceeding analysts' forecasts.
Drug makers, led by Merck & Company, also posted strong gains.
Merck, which gained more than 3 on Monday, rose another 3 1/2 yesterday, to 135 1/2. Eli Lilly & Company rose 1 1/8, to 77 5/16. And Bristol-Myers Squibb was up 1 1/8, to 106.
Still, investors continued to punish companies with deteriorating growth prospects.
The Coca-Cola Company, which relies on foreign sales for about 75 percent of its profits, fell 2 1/8 yesterday, to 61 3/16, after a Lehman Brothers analyst, Michael Branca, cut his 1999 earnings estimate because of slowing sales in Eastern Europe, Asia and Latin America.
Mr. Branca also cut his 1999 earnings forecast for Pepsico Inc. Pepsi lost 1 5/16, to 30.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Hedge Fund And Banking Losses Pile Up

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Tiger Management L.L.C., a well-known hedge fund, and the BankAmerica Corporation, one of the country's largest banks, reported huge losses yesterday in emerging-market investments, evidence that the economic havoc in Asia, Russia and Latin America is continuing to roil United States financial companies.
It was the second time BankAmerica reported an emerging-market loss in less than a month. 
 Tiger Management, run by Julian Robertson, with $22 billion in assets, said it had lost $600 million from Russian ruble-denominated debt in August. Officials for Tiger Management, which is based in New York, declined to comment further.
So far this year, on average, the value of hedge funds investing in emerging markets has declined 35 percent, according to an index of 20 funds compiled by the Hennessee Hedge Fund Advisory Group, a New York firm that advises hedge fund investors. Hedge funds are lightly regulated pools of capital that seek high rates of return in relatively risky investments.
Most of the hedge-fund declines, about 23.4 percent, came in August and were largely a result of losses in Russia, said Charles Gradante, Hennessee's chief investment strategist.
"I think things can get a little bit worse before they get better," Mr. Gradante said, regarding his outlook for emerging-market hedge fund performance this year.
Until the fundamentals of the economies in Asia, Russia and Latin America begin to mend, further losses are possible, he said.
While Tiger Management's losses were focused on Russia, problems in other emerging markets may start to take their toll on financial service companies.
Yesterday, BankAmerica said it expected to lose at least $330 million in nontrading income in the third quarter. That number includes $220 million of trading losses the bank announced last month. Most of BankAmerica's earlier losses were attributed to Russia, where the bank had reduced its exposure from $412 million to about $100 million. But this time around, some analysts said, the bank's report is more comprehensive and likely includes loan losses in Latin America, where it has more than $33 billion in exposure.
In spite of the declines, BankAmerica said it expected to earn about $500 million in after-tax profit in the third quarter.
BankAmerica declined to give specific details about the losses, "but if you look at where the volatility has been," Latin America would be the "logical conclusion," Joel Silverstein, senior banking analyst at Prudential Securities, said.
After the bank's earlier announcement, Mr. Silverstein lowered his third-quarter earnings estimates to 80 cents a share, from $1.20. He and other analysts are now scrambling to revise the numbers, expecting to lower forecasts even more.
Recently, concern about emerging markets has turned to Brazil, which is plagued with a large budget deficit, interest rates approaching 50 percent and expectations that a currency devaluation may come soon.
Before it began a rally last Thursday, the benchmark Brazilian stock index had fallen 56 percent since Aug. 1. Since Thursday, it has surged 45 percent. Yesterday, Brazilian stocks rose 18.7 percent, posting their biggest one-day gain in more than three years amid expectations that foreign governments would come to its aid.
Despite the Brazilian market's recent gains, analysts still see Latin America as a trouble spot.
"There's a likelihood that other banks with exposure to Latin America could be taking losses as well," Joe Morford, an analyst at Van Kasper & Company in San Francisco, said. 

CORRECTION-DATE: September 17, 1998, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about losses posted by American financial companies from investments in emerging markets misstated the BankAmerica Corporation's loans and investments in Latin America. They total $11.3 billion, not more than $33 billion.

HEADLINE: U.N. Rights Official, Back From China, Sees Better Attitude

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 15

 BODY:
At the end of what she called "a successful but not always easy first visit to China," the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, Mary Robinson, said today that despite continuing human rights abuses, she had sensed among Chinese leaders a new willingness to discuss the country's rights record.
Mrs. Robinson said she had been told by Chinese officials that they were prepared to sign the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights next month. She said the Chinese Government had also signed a letter of understanding with the Human Rights Commission requesting technical assistance in resolving human rights issues. 
 "China has human rights problems, major problems," Mrs. Robinson said at a news conference today in Beijing. But she added, "I was interested in the awareness of and willingness to admit human rights problems among China's leaders."
Mrs. Robinson praised China's willingness to allow the United Nations Human Rights Commission to work in the country, since China has previously rejected what it regarded as outside interference in its internal affairs. "It has to be apparent what a ground-breaking visit this is," she said. "Human rights is not talked about here."
But human rights groups reacted with only cautious optimism, noting that the ultimate success of the Commissioner's visit hinges on whether China's avowed commitment to human rights leads to concrete changes in a country where people are imprisoned without trial and cannot speak out against the Government.
Mike Jendrzeczyk, Washington Director of Human Rights Watch Asia, said the commitments are "a step forward, but what remains to be seen is whether China takes specific actions as a result of the trip." He and others expressed disappointment that Mrs. Robinson had not met with dissidents or their relatives.
Indeed, Mrs. Robinson's 10-day trip was punctuated by poignant reminders of the contradictions in China's human rights policies, where scattered signs of liberalization are often offset by harsh repression.
During the visit, dissidents from two provinces said they had gotten somewhat encouraging signals when they applied for permission to organize an opposition party, an act that had landed dissidents in jail just three month ago. And, at a seminar, Mrs. Robinson heard Chinese lawyers criticize the lack of protection defendants have under Chinese law.
But that same week, officers of Beijing's Public Security Bureau arrested and allegedly beat an imprisoned dissident's wife, Chu Hailan, as she tried to deliver a letter to Mrs. Robinson in her hotel lobby. And a liberal journalist and editor, Shi Binhai, was taken from his home and 10 days later was still being held without explanation or charges.
Such contradiction were not lost on Mrs. Robinson, who said that she had called the Foreign Ministry to demand Ms. Chu's release after she heard about the arrest. Ms. Chu was released that same evening. Mr. Shi's status is still unclear.
Mrs. Robinson said that during her visit she had received a number of faxes, letters and oral messages regarding individual cases. "I have become aware of a number of cases that I will bring up with authorities back in Geneva," she said.
Mrs. Robinson said that in meetings yesterday with President Jiang Zemin and Deputy Prime Minister Qian Qichen she had inquired about the whereabouts of the 9-year-old boy decreed by the Dalai Lama to be the reincarnation of the Panchen Lama, the second-ranking spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhists. China has said the boy and his parents are under its protection at an undisclosed location, and has selected its own youth as the Panchen Lama.
The Commissioner also urged President Jiang to meet with the Dalai Lama and asked for a review of the sentences of those arrested in connection with the 1989 pro-democracy protests in Tiananmen Square.
Mrs. Robinson traveled to Beijing and Shanghai, discussing a broad range rights issues, from dissidents to China's justice system to discrimination against women. She also made a brief visit to Tibet, which she characterized as "very restrictive and very difficult, as many opportunities in the country are."
Nonetheless, she defended her work there -- which included passing out copies of the United Nations Universal Declaration on Human Rights in Tibetan at a local school -- as a step in the right direction.
Mrs. Robinson repeatedly said that the main goal of her trip was merely to "start a process of cooperation" and did not say if she had gotten any concrete commitments for change during her lengthy meetings with Chinese leaders.
Many human rights experts say they are anxious for details. While they say they are happy that China has now given a timetable for signing the covenents and has committed to further cooperation with the United Nations, they note that Beijing has not always lived up to such promises.
The International Covenant on Political and Civil Rights, which China plans to sign next month, along with the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, which China signed last year, are comprehensive documents protecting rights from freedom of speech to freedom to form trade unions. But China's governing bodies still have to ratify both documents and might try to attach caveats that would blunt their impact, Mr. Jendrzeczyk said.
Some dissidents said that Mrs. Robinson's visit as well as a slight loosening of official policy had already helped their cause.
 "China is beginning to acknowledge the existence of human rights through this visit and through these covenants," said Wang Youcai, a dissident from Hangzhou who was arrested in July for trying to form a political party. "I think the likelihood I'll be re-arrested now is small."

HEADLINE: COUNTRY MUSIC REVIEW;
Old Mountain Music (Black, No Sugar)

BYLINE: By JON PARELES 

 BODY:
Gillian Welch and David Rawlings are a two-member austerity program. At Tramps on Monday night, their songs renounced four decades of pop to revive the Appalachian roots of country music, with concise melodies and stripped-down narratives that make no time for ornament or sentimentality.
Their tunes are waltzes and ballads that sound like variants of Elizabethan tunes, holding on to the irregular structures of rural music. The lyrics are about the staples of old-time mountain music -- hard work, whisky, death and Christian faith -- and rarely reveal they were written in the 1990's. Singing about coal miners in East Tennessee, Ms. Welch distilled the situation to one-syllable basics: "I'm down in a hole/Down in a deep dark hole." 
 The songs are set in places like Alabama or Kansas, but Ms. Welch is no backwoods find. She grew up in California and attended the Berklee School of Music, where she met Mr. Rawlings. Yet the duo is committed to the style of the Carter Family, the Stanley Brothers and the Louvin Brothers, and it honors the nuances of some of the nation's most quietly startling music.
Both performing and on their new album, "Hell Among the Yearlings" (Almo Sounds), the duo sticks to bare bones, limiting even the number of their instruments. Ms. Welch sang lead and played acoustic guitar or banjo; Mr. Rawlings sang harmonies and played all his leads on a 1935 arch-top Epiphone guitar, deftly shifting his technique to make it sound like a mandolin, a Dobro or a flat-picked bluegrass guitar.
The duo also recreated the calm fatalism of old-style singers, who never raised their voices even as they sang about disaster or exaltation. Ms. Welch used the flattened vowels of Appalachia, staying tight-lipped as she sang and allowing herself an occasional quaver, while Mr. Rawlings harmonized like a pale shadow, utterly self-effacing.
Ms. Welch and Mr. Rawlings aren't alone in holding on to the Appalachian style. Folk and bluegrass festivals are full of songwriters who prize its clarity and economy. But most also have a saccharine side, a strain of good-old-days nostalgia that also runs deep in country music. Ms. Welch and Mr. Rawlings are not just skillful and careful songwriters but also purposefully dark, as if based on Depression-era Walker Evans photographs.
In their sepia-toned songs, rural life is little more than toil and trouble in this world and stubborn hope for the next; their backwoods are home to orphans, unglamorous barroom girls and long-suffering addicts. In "Caleb Meyer," a woman kills a would-be rapist with his broken liquor bottle. That extremism is the only thing that betrays them as children of the rock era.
The Spartan approach was less helpful for Richard Buckner, who opened the show playing duets with Eric Heywood on guitar or pedal steel guitar. Mr. Buckner writes songs about isolation, lost loves and roads to nowhere, some artlessly blunt, some more elaborately literary, all depressive. Over his own plain strumming, Mr. Buckner sang in short, gruff phrases and an occasional grunge-rocker's growl. But the stark settings lost the melodic continuity that a band brings to his songs.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gillian Welch at Tramps on Monday night. (Amy Elliott)

LENGTH: 1393 words

HEADLINE: DESIGN PREVIEW '99: INSPIRATION;
A Desert Prophet Wins New Disciples

BYLINE: By FRANCES ANDERTON 

DATELINE: PALM SPRINGS, Calif.

 BODY:
ALBERT FREY hates waste. He sees no need for water-hungry lawns or spacious homes. He lives modestly in a 16-by-32-foot house made of low-maintenance materials that he built for himself 34 years ago. His principle in life and architecture, he explained, is to "do the most with the least."
So why are the young and the affluent drawn to this 94-year-old man living in a space they'd normally consider too small to swing a cat in? Why did Tom Ford of Gucci and the designer Brad Dunning each commission him to design a versatile aluminum guest house? Why is his own house the backdrop for fashion shoots and the subject of a new book? 
 Because Mr. Frey is the embodiment of a minimalist philosophy of life and design that is enjoying a revival by a generation fattened on the go-go 1980's and 90's. Nostalgic for the perceived simplicity of the West Coast modernism of their parents' youth, this generation has put itself on a visual diet.
In the last decade, indifference or even neglect of the spare buildings of pre-World War II and postwar California modernists has been supplanted by a passion for them. Houses by Richard Neutra, R. M Schindler and John Lautner have been flying into the hands of 30- and 40-somethings in entertainment and design. The trend started in Los Angeles but has shifted 110 miles east to Palm Springs, which also boasts a wealth of modern buildings by talented local architects. Thanks to preservationists and fashion magazines, Palm Springs is fast gaining a belated reputation as the Miami Beach of midcentury modernism, in which Mr. Frey is pre-eminent.
"Without Frey there would not be any modernism in Palm Springs," said Anthony Merchell, a Los Angeles-based preservationist and the author of a coming guide to Palm Springs architecture.
These houses of the 40's and 50's were "very beautiful and streamlined and clean," said Ron Radziner, a partner in Marmol & Radziner Architects, which has restored Neutra and Frey houses here. "It's very sad that for a while, a lot of decoration seemed more important," he added.
Why the interest in Mr. Frey? As Jennifer Golub, the director of broadcast production at TBWA Chiat/Day, and author of "Albert Frey/Houses 1 and 2" (Princeton Architectural Press), put it, "Frey is a deeply principled person with so much to teach."
Q UIET, gentle, polite and determined, Mr. Frey lives on a mountain overlooking Palm Springs in a building as spare and lean and elegant as he is. "There's no body fat on the house, and there's no body fat on him," the architect Michael Rotondi, an admirer, remarked.
The house, built in 1964 on a difficult site, is habitat pared down to the barest essentials -- a rectangular, glass-wall shed with a corrugated aluminum roof, in which dining, living and sleeping are all configured in one room around a large boulder, which also provides the lateral bracing.
"It would have been terrible to cut this rock down," Mr. Frey said calmly but emphatically in a German-accented voice. "Its gray granite probably took thousands of years to make this color." He added, "I have very strong opinions about the connection between architecture and nature."
His colors are painterly: yellow curtains to match the encelia plants outside, reddish concrete block to blend with the desert rock. His clothing, pale yellow slacks and sandy desert boots, are part of the composition.
Here you find a man at one with his environment, feeding the lizards, coyotes and a family of quails that show up like favored guests at his door. He does yoga headstands daily, taught to him by one of many women who are his friends.
The Swiss-born Mr. Frey immigrated to the United States in 1930, with the unusual pedigree of having actually worked in the Paris office of Le Corbusier. (He casually remarked that he helped detail the Villa Savoye, one of Le Corbusier's defining buildings.) He hoped to wed the ideals of European modernism to the technology and industrial materials in this country. In partnership with Laurence Kocher, he spent his first few years on the East Coast, exploring ideas about prefabricated houses, the most famous of which is the steel and aluminum Aluminaire House at the New York Institute of Technology in West Islip, N.Y.
His license plate reads "ALUMI," in honor of a material he has loved since he was a child. "My father had a shaving stick in an aluminum tube," he recalled. "I used that to make dishes for my baby sister's doll's house. It doesn't rust. It's easy to work and needs no maintenance."
In 1934, he came to Palm Springs and found a new frontier in the parched desert and mountains. He moved here in 1939 and produced many landmark buildings, including the Palm Springs City Hall, the Palm Springs Aerial Tramway and the Tramway Gas Station, all the while fashioning a modern architecture of organic curves, exposed desert rocks and unadorned exterior surfaces -- an architecture superbly suited to the desert climate and landscape.
His first house, Frey 1, now demolished, started in 1940 as a Miesian pavilion of orthogonal planes and grew more expressionistic with the 1953 addition of aluminum curving walls and a circular tower.
To the eyes of those who do not like the industrial esthetic, Frey House 2, where he lives, is a tin hut. For those that do, it is an exercise in exquisite frugality. Like a Swiss watchmaker, he has combined off-the-shelf materials intricately and cleverly: sliding panels and shelves are made of corrugated glass fiber; a light switch on the boulder has wires cleverly concealed in the rock's fissure; a hanging light is a bulb in a Time-Life globe; outdoor seats are carved in concrete (deck furniture would decay). An extension incorporates a Cor-Ten steel --rather than aluminum -- roof, which can be spot-welded. "Modernism is still in the process of being formed because new products are always being invented," he said.
Mr. Frey's homes are the subject of Ms. Golub's book, an evocative collection of photographs of the houses and their industrial and natural sources of inspiration.
Palm Springs, which prefers Spanish-style architecture, has been less than passionate for his work, allowing the demolition or remodeling of numerous Frey buildings. The city has, however, started to come around, thanks in large part to a revival of international interest, sparked by a 1992 book and traveling exhibition of the architect's work by Joseph Rosa, now chief curator of the National Building Museum in Washington. With the approach of Mr. Frey's 95th birthday, on Oct. 18, preservationists and a developer have joined forces to save the Jetsonian Tramway Gas Station, after a huge battle.
What Mr. Frey and his architecture stand for is an inventive, progressive attitude to life and the environment. So there is an irony in the nostalgia and sentimentality for the futuristic buildings by him and his fellow modernists. In the minds of Le Corbusier and Mies van der Rohe, of Charles and Ray Eames and Albert Frey, modernism was a movement, not a style. It was an all-encompassing social vision in which technology would liberate humanity from dark, hierarchical buildings and lead society into a light and egalitarian world. Even though the buildings never won public acceptance and, then as now, were occupied mainly by design cognoscenti, modernism was not about making a fetish of the home.
Mr. Rosa said that movies, from James Bond films to "L.A. Confidential," and Julius Schulman's black-and-white photographs, have drawn people to the houses. But instead of the "everyday modernism of usability, people are trying to live within the style captured in photos," Mr. Rosa said.
Mr. Dunning, who has produced photo shoots in classic Palm Springs residences, acknowledges the paradox: "Are we in the middle of the revival of a trend, or does this have more longevity?" he asked.
Mr. Frey, who takes delight in the sight of leggy models who drape themselves over his little house, pointed out that modernism "isn't like fashion in clothing." He continued: "Buildings last longer than that. Maybe later on, people discern certain characteristics that they call a style. But I would call it being contemporary."
How has his house withstood the test of time? "It is forever young," he said, a tribute that might apply as well to the sprightly Mr. Frey himself.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Helping a Dissonant Psyche Sing

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

PROZAC DIARY
By Lauren Slater
203 pages. Random House. $21.95.
In 1988, at age 26, Lauren Slater lived alone in a sparsely furnished basement apartment in Cambridge, Mass. She was unemployed, having finished college with a spotty record and having dropped out of graduate creative-writing school after one semester. 
 She then held a variety of mostly menial jobs from which she was usually dismissed because her abilities were compromised by a psychopathology involving depression, self-mutilation and suicide attempts that had led to five hospitalizations.
 She suffered from obsessive-compulsive disorder, which was "for me," she writes in her powerful book, "Prozac Diary," "the nattering need to touch, count, check and tap, over and over again."
Ten years later, Ms. Slater was a changed person. She had a master's degree in psychology from Harvard and a doctorate from Boston College, completed in only two years. She was the director of a clinic, Aftercare Services. She had published a book, "Welcome to My Country," about her work with the insane. She taught writing at Goucher College. She was happily married.
Because the transformation in Ms. Slater's life was brought about by Prozac -- prescribed in 1988 to treat her obsessive-compulsive disorder, when the drug was new and little-known -- you would think that her new book, about that experience, would be an unqualified hymn of celebration.
Up to a point it is. Ms. Slater writes eloquently of her remarkably fast reaction to the drug. After a sudden good night's sleep, she awoke finding that "something was different," as if she had been "visited by a blind piano tuner who had crept into my apartment at night, who had tweaked the ivory bones of my body, the taut strings in my skull, and now, when I pressed on myself, the same notes but with a mellower, fuller sound sprang out."
She continues: "Everything seemed to be moving according to a different rhythm, 4/4 now 2/2, a smoothing out or slowing down. It was, to date, the single most stunning experience of my life, although later it would unfold with ever more complexity, even danger." She concludes, "Somehow, my attention had become flexible, swiveling left, now right, with such ease it made me giddy."
But her praise is very far from unqualified. She treats the drawbacks of Prozac with expressiveness. First, the obvious ones: what her pharmacologist calls "Prozac poop-out," which caused her to "crack up" again after a year, while on a research trip to Kentucky, and forced her to increase her dosage, although "Prozac never again made me as well as it once had."
And she writes of her loss of libido and sexual dysfunction, describing physical relations with her husband: "Boredom is diffuse and psychological. I am not at all bored by Bennett, but it is as though I have been bored into by something else, injected with Novocain at a very specific spot. I want to weep."
But what makes her book most worthwhile is her discussion of the subtler perils of Prozac: for instance, her pain at having to give up what she calls the "illness identity" she had made for herself, "a story of self that had illness as its main motive." She found her drive to write diminished; the voices in her head fell silent. "I can't get anything really creative done in this state," she complained to her doctor. "Well," he replied, "you are not getting as many crises done. You are not accomplishing as many hospitalizations."
So Ms. Slater never stopped doubting the drug. She worried about being addicted and dependent. She worried that without her sexuality, she could not possibly be in touch with her essential self. She tried to embrace the post-modern notion that no real self truly exists, but she found that she could never believe this.
"So. There it is," she writes. "Here I am. Or here I am not. The difference really matters to me. Probably, despite the trends in our universities, it matters to a lot of people. It could be that many people will continue to believe in bedrock or, better yet, to believe in the importance of the search. The search for the genuine. The gem."
Yet despite her doubts, she was unable to give up the drug by the time she completed her book. "I always break up. Maybe not at first. There have been a few weeks, even once more than a month, when I soared through space and saw the stars as peaceful. But each time, eventually, there's a little splitting sound and then a big kaboom, and the wreckage is a mess."
This leaves the reader with the sense of a void about Ms. Slater's future, which is particularly distressing because her book is so involving. It must surely be among the best ones available on the long-term effects of the drug, even superior to Peter Kramer's landmark "Listening to Prozac."
You are left feeling the way Ms. Slater must have felt about her future husband's strange expression of love when they were first getting to know each other. A chemist by profession, he brought her a rose one evening, saying, "For you." But when she reached for it, he withdrew it, dipped it in liquid nitrogen he had brought with him and "pulled back out a frozen flower, a glassed-in growth, color and form perfectly preserved."
When she expressed wonder at it, he said: "We're not through. I love you. We will never be through."
"And with that," she writes, "he bowed, smiled, and hurled my rose at the wall, whereupon, after a perfect click of contact, it broke into hundreds of icy beads.
"Hydrogen, nitrogen, oxygen.
"So damn easy to deconstruct.
"And yet the beads were beautiful, flakes of snow, scarlet hail."
So is the chemistry of "Prozac Diary" beautiful. If only you could trust that its elements might melt into a soul.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Beware Primakov

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The man the Russian Parliament forced President Yeltsin to name Prime Minister is a former K.G.B. agent, a friend of dictators in Iraq and Serbia, and an enemy of the West.
Yevgeny Primakov made it to the top because he was every power center's second choice. They all see this cagey spymaster as a transitional figure easily replaced after the worst is over. They may all be wrong. 
 The Soviet Union had three power centers: the Communist Party, the K.G.B. and the Red Army. In Russia today, there are still three: (1) the oligarchs who stole the state's assets through corrupt privatization and socked away billions outside the country; (2) what's left of the Communist Party, supported by elderly pensioners, and (3) democratic reformers, many appointed and then scapegoated by the weakened Yeltsin.
Last spring the oligarchs directed Yeltsin to fire their own man, Prime Minister Chernomyrdin, who for five years had condoned their stealing of the state's assets. In went a reformist unknown, wet behind the ears, to take the fall for the inescapable devaluation and default. After that victim did his duty, the oligarchs told Yeltsin to put back Chernomyrdin.
But the Communists in Parliament would not go along. They threatened Yeltsin with impeachment and dared him to dissolve the Duma by pressing three times for the oligarchs' choice.
At this point, assuming the Communists would do well in parliamentary elections, the last of those reformers left standing -- Grigory Yavlinsky, head of the Yabloko party in Parliament and untainted by association with failed Yeltsin policies -- proposed Primakov as prime minister.
I reached Yavlinsky by telephone in Moscow to ask: Are you guys out of your minds? When Russia most needs the West, you put in a lifelong enemy of freedom? When Russia's economy most needs the price of its oil exports to go up, you put in the man who wants to get Iraqi production flowing to save Saddam and bring on an oil glut? When Russia most needs the rule of law and private property, you bring in a veteran Communist with no understanding of free enterprise?
"This was a painful compromise," he explained. "Primakov was the only one Yeltsin and the Communists could agree on. I have no deal with him." That turns out to be true; as Primakov surrounded himself with Gorbachev-era Communists, Yavlinsky turned down the offer of a deputy prime minister's post.
Yavlinsky's rationale is that Primakov has promised (1) not to use force in Chechnya; (2) to soothe the West with ratification of Start 2, and (3) to follow the Constitution in organizing elections. Averting civil war, he says, is not nothing.
After the years of ripoff by the crony capitalists, the pendulum of Russian public opinion has swung leftward. Capitalism never had a chance without courts to enforce contracts and cops to stop corruption, but the criminal oligarchy has left capitalism in disrepute and reduced most trade to barter.
In this angry atmosphere, Yavlinsky puts the protection of political freedom ahead of the adoption of sensible economic policies. "This is temporary," he insists, "and somebody has to be in office to protect the nukes and see to it we have free elections."
That's his case for Primakov, and we'll be hearing more of the same stabilizing stuff from his Manila dance partner, Secretary Madeleine Albright. But I wonder.
Here we see the oligarchs in bed with Marxist economists who promise to protect bankrupt enterprises and print inflationary money. Remaining democratic reformers hope that the ensuing disaster will be blamed on the lefties in the Duma elections next year and elections for the presidency the year after.
That's wishful thinking. Primakov will take Russia toward more state economic control, which is only a step away from central political control. The old K.G.B. hand knows how to squeeze the oligarchs to make their media support him. Transition is not his ambition.
Should we bail out Primakov's ailing Russia? The Czech President, Vaclav Havel, offered a sage comment to the Clinton claque of applauding bureaucrats at their joint news conference yesterday: "Better an ill Russia than a healthy Soviet Union."

HEADLINE: Shake-Up Set At Struggling Toys 'R' Us

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
Toys "R" Us, the toy retailer that has been struggling because of increased competition, said yesterday that it planned to revamp its business, close 90 stores, eliminate up to 3,000 jobs and take $495 million in after-tax charges.
Under the direction of its new chief executive, Robert C. Nakasone, Toys "R" Us has been attempting for more than a year to jump-start sales and increase profitability as it faces stepped-up competition from discount chains like Wal-Mart. The company is also searching for ways to please harried parents who are tired of navigating its mammoth, and often dated, stores. 
 The reorganization is also intended to improve cash flow and increase operating earnings by more than $75 million next year and by a greater amount thereafter.
Investors reacted skeptically to the changes, however. The company's shares closed at $18.125, down 75 cents.
The company will close 50 international Toys "R" Us stores, mainly in Europe, 9 stores in this country and 31 domestic Kids "R" Us apparel stores. In addition, the retailer said it would take $281 million in pretax charges to pare inventory, $29 million to close or consolidate stores and distribution centers and to eliminate administrative functions and $102 million for accounting changes. Toys "R" Us will take the charges in the third quarter, which ends Oct. 31.
In addition to the store closings and charges, Toys "R" Us, which is based in Paramus, N.J., said it would redesign its remaining stores into a format that would enable the company to increase its products. The new stores will include an expanded electronics department to appeal to older children, a discount section where parents can get bargain-priced birthday and holiday toys and a clothing section for those looking for one-stop shopping.
"We still don't know the most important thing we need to know, how will these C-3 stores perform," Ursula Moran, an analyst who follows the company for Sanford C. Bernstein, said. C-3, which stands for customer driven, cost effective and a concept for the future, is the code name Toys "R" Us coined for its new store format.
Ms. Moran said that the company had announced a new store design, huge charges and inventory reductions when it ran into trouble in the past, leaving her less impressed this time out. "The company has got a credibility problem to some degree," she said, adding that the latest inventory reduction seems ill timed.
"I'm a little worried about their lobbing out lots of markdown inventory at the start of the holiday season simply because that could provoke a competitive response that might not be so pretty," she said.
About 200 of the company's domestic stores will be converted to the new format next year with the remaining being upgraded within two years. After the consolidation, Toys "R" Us will operate 1,403 stores and 183 Kids "R" Us stores and will eliminate its two Kidsworld stores by folding them into existing toy stores.
The initial phase of the company's revamping has already produced $370 million in inventory reductions this year in United States stores open more than a year, the company said. The new concept and additional inventory reduction, which is necessary to enable stores to accommodate new products, will improve merchandise planning and distribution techniques and allow further improvements in inventory turns in coming years, the company added.
"These actions will be the springboard to implementing our expanded vision for the future, which is to provide not only toys but also to provide our customers with broader merchandise offerings and services for kids and families," Mr. Nakasone said. Mr. Nakasone replaced Michael Goldstein seven months ago.
In the most recent quarter, ended Aug. 1, revenues inched up just 1.6 percent, to $2.02 billion, while earnings before a charge decreased 57 percent, to $15.9 million, or 6 cents a diluted share, from $36.7 million, or 13 cents a diluted share, in the corresponding period a year earlier.
Analyst said the restructuring announced yesterday had been anticipated, so investors were not caught off guard by unexpected bad news. As for the size of the charges, they "cover a multitude of sins," said David S. Leibowitz, an analyst who follows the company for Burnham Securities.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Fed can insulate the U.S. from much of the global crisis.

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein 

 BODY:
FIRST Asia. Then Russia. Now Latin America. There are days when it seems that America might soon be the only economy standing upright.
When financial crisis struck Asia 14 months ago, it seemed a long way away and, besides, the United States economy was roaring along. When Russia fell into a financial abyss recently, America did not see much of a threat from the collapse of such a tiny economy. But now, Brazil, the ninth-largest economy in the world, is reeling. Argentina, Venezuela and Mexico may be close behind. 
 Chaos south of the border is scary. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, thinks so, and he is hardly known for hysterics. He recently observed that with a quarter of the world's population hit by recession "it's just not credible that the United States can remain an oasis of prosperity."
Perhaps. But there are two reasons to believe that Mr. Greenspan is exaggerating the threat. Latin America's predicament is not as grave as Asia's. An even better reason to think Mr. Greenspan might be wrong is Mr. Greenspan himself. As head of the Fed, he can insulate the economy from all but the most extreme collapse of foreign economies.
The news from Latin America has been bleak. Stock markets in the region have fallen more than 40 percent this year and Colombia and Ecuador have devalued their currencies this month. The core of the problem, as in Asia, is pessimism by investors whose initial jitters grow into outright panic. Once investors begin to question whether Brazil or Argentina will run out of dollar reserves or devalue, they flee -- cashing in their investments before someone else beats them to the dwindling reserves or before devaluation slices the dollar value of their assets. Capital flight feeds on itself as shrinking reserves reinforce the notion that the original jitters were warranted.
Brazil could indeed become the next international disaster. Its fiscal deficit exceeds 7 percent of total output, and its high exchange rate has driven its exports, as a portion of total economic output, lower than nearly anywhere else in the world. The excesses leave Brazil vulnerable to capital flight. To prop up its currency, Brazil has spent billions of dollars over recent months and has raised interest rates above 40 percent.
Then comes contagion. Argentina sells 30 percent of its exports to Brazil. If Brazil devalues its currency, as expected, Argentina's exports could become prohibitively expensive in Brazil. That would leave Argentina with fewer dollars, perhaps inciting investors to bolt.
Though Latin America is teetering, there is good reason to predict that it will not topple like Asia. Capital flight and currency depreciation bankrupted many Asian companies because they had borrowed heavily abroad. A company that sells its product for won but borrows in dollars is pummeled when the won drops in value. As Prof. Peter Kenen of Princeton points out, companies in Latin America have borrowed less foreign money than their Asian counterparts and should be better positioned to survive currency devaluations.
There is a raging debate under way about the best way for the United States and its allies to help Latin America snuff out financial chaos before it festers. But however bad the impending crisis turns out to be, it will almost certainly be a manageable problem for the United States.
Each year, the United States exports about $900 billion in goods and services, or about 12 percent of total economic output. Of that, about 20 percent goes to Central and South America. Suppose those exports fell by 15 percent or so. That would amount to less than a 1 percent cut in total spending in the United States -- hardly noticeable. Indeed, even if worldwide financial crises cut exports by 15 percent across the board, the blow to the economy would amount to less than 2 percent of total spending.
But the Fed is not, in the memorable words of Oliver North's lawyer before a Congressional panel, a potted plant. It can react if exports dry up. With low inflation and a strong dollar, nothing stops the Fed from increasing the money supply.
The Fed's problem gets trickier if foreign investors dump stocks on Wall Street and if American investments abroad sour. Fill in any reasonable number, Professor Kenen concludes, and the Fed can cushion the effect on jobs and living standards. As long as countries do not let their banking systems collapse, the Fed can protect domestic jobs.
That said, the Fed cannot know how big a problem Latin America could create for the domestic economy. Nor does it know how to counteract the blow with precision. After all, setting monetary policy today requires looking 18 months or so into the future.
But even though the Fed cannot stabilize the economy perfectly, most experts believe that that Fed can almost surely prevent the domestic economy from foundering -- something that happened in the 1930's because of persistent mismanagement by the Fed policy. It knows better today.

HEADLINE: Host Marriott Services Outlook

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: BETHESDA, Md., Sept. 16

 BODY:
The Host Marriott Services Corporation said today that its third-quarter and full-year earnings will be disappointing, as fewer travelers from Asia and the pilots' strike at Northwest Airlines hurt its airport duty-free retail business.
The company, which also operates food, beverage and retail concessions at roadside travel plazas and shopping malls, said it expects third-quarter earnings of about 50 cents to 51 cents a diluted share. Last year it earned 52 cents. Host Marriott, which was spun off in 1995 from the Host Marriott Corporation, the hotel owner, will report earnings on Oct. 5. Its quarter ended last Friday. 
 Jake Fuller, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, had an estimate of 56 cents a share for Host Marriott's quarter.
Sales at its duty-free shops in key airports in the United States fell as a slumping Asian economy reduced travel from the region, Host Marriott Services said. The shares fell $1.1875 today, or 10 percent, to $10.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Dow Moves 65.39 Higher in Its Fourth Straight Advance

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
A late surge lifted stocks to their fourth straight advance yesterday, the first since June, as traders and investors welcomed President Clinton's statement that he would not resign and shrugged off disappointment that Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, offered no fresh hope of a cut in interest rates.
Testifying before the House Banking Committee, Mr. Greenspan asserted that there was currently "no endeavor to coordinate interest-rate cuts" at a time when "deflationary forces are continuing to emerge." 
 The Dow Jones industrial average finished with a gain of 65.39 points, or eight-tenths of a percent, at 8,089.78, pulling still further away from the brink of a defined bear market with which it has recently flirted.
Other major American gauges also rose, as did those in Europe and Hong Kong. But Brazil's Bovespa index shed 2.11 percent following its huge, 18.68 percent rebound on Tuesday.
"There's been a return of some sanity there," said Lisa Cullen, a Merrill Lynch strategist, referring to Brazil and other countries in Latin America. "That's soothed the nerves of investors."
Telebras, the newly privatized Brazilian phone company, which is a marker for technology stocks generally, traded as high as 80 before closing at 71 15/16, down 3/16.
The Dow, which was up about 50 points at the start of the 1 P.M. appearance by Mr. Greenspan and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, promptly lost its gain and then drifted into negative territory until the upswing of the final half-hour.
"The market had been expecting some Greenspan-Rubin comments that didn't materalize," said Bill Schneider, head of block trading at Warburg Dillon Read in Stamford, Conn. "But the selling exhausted itself, and buyers came back."
Two Internet stocks were among the day's biggest winners, with Amazon.com soaring 11 1/2, to 84 1/2, and Yahoo, which is to replace MCI in the Nasdaq 100 index, up 9, to 93 3/8. Motorola climbed 3 5/16, to 47 1/4, after announcing it would halt work on a new semiconductor plant in Virginia.
Among the Dow industrials, Eastman Kodak was up 2 15/16, to 84 3/4,to contribute most to the gain while Searswas the biggest loser, down 1 3/16, to 47.
But once again a major blue chip -- Gillette this time -- was hammered when it warned of weaker results. Gillette, a stellar growth company, said sales were suffering in the third quarter and watched its shares tumble 4 13/16, to 40 3/16.
Rising stocks on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered falling ones by a margin of about 3 to 2, with 30 issues making new highs and 151 falling to new lows.
The Standard & Poor's 500 rose 7.80 points, to 1,045.48, or 75-hundredths of 1 percent, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 11.80, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,689.91.
Although many in the market still expect the Fed to cut short-term interest rates, perhaps in concert with other central banks to keep turmoil in emerging markets from setting off a global downturn, others are skeptical that rate cuts would be effective medicine.
Kenneth Safian, president of Safian Investment Research, contended that fiscal rather than monetary tools should be used against what he called "overdone disinflation." Citing ample current liquidity, he suggested a tax cut, perhaps on dividends.
After treading water much of the day yesterday ahead of testimony by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, before the House Banking Committee, Treasury bonds advanced.
After the testimony failed to clarify future monetary policy, the stock market weakened on disappointment, and bonds climbed as some investors sought the haven of the Government securities market.
The 30-year bond increased 17/32, to a price of 104 7/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, slipped to 5.22 percent, from 5.25 percent on Tuesday. Most other maturities were mixed.
Gerald A. Guild, senior vice president of the taxable fixed-income department at Advest Inc., said: "I think the Fed will continue a neutral stance and follow the market rather than lead it. I expect the long bond yield to decline below 5 percent."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
InvestorsShrug Off Talk of Global Rate Cut

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
American investors shrugged off yesterday's suggestion that no global interest rate cut was immediately in store to help the world's weak economies.
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, appeared to shut the door on such a move when he told the House Banking Committee that "at the moment there is no endeavor to coordinate interest rate cuts." 
 Still, the Dow Jones industrial average finished the day 65 points higher. Just over a week ago, the stock market had soared on Mr. Greenspan's suggestion that global financial problems posed as great a threat to the United States as inflation did, suggesting that a rate cut to stimulate the economy might be on the horizon.
It is possible, though, that the already struggling emerging markets will falter on the suggestion that help is not immediately on the way. Brazil's stock market, which rallied 45 percent in three days on hopes of a global rate cut and the promise of international aid, eased after Mr. Greenspan's remarks, ending the day down 2.11 percent. Investors also pushed United States Treasury prices up and yields lower, signaling a continued flight to safety and concern about the outlook for equity markets.
But based on one gauge of sentiment, the delay of a global rate cut was no surprise to many investors. That gauge is the futures contracts on the Federal funds rate. The contract "naturally embodies the market's expectation of what the Fed will do," according to a study by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis. The Federal funds rate, or the rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, is the central bank's target for short-term interest rates.
All week, the price on the Fed funds futures contract fell. That indicated a rise in the yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price. As of Friday, the yield for the October contract was 5.25 percent. Because that yield represents the expected average for the month and because the next rate-setting meeting of the Federal Reserve is on Sept. 29, it presaged a cut of one-quarter of a percentage point in the Federal funds target from the current 5.5 percent level, according to Dana Saporta, an economist with Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J.
But by the end of trading yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, the yield had risen to 5.34 percent, meaning that investors see a smaller probability of a rate cut at the September meeting.
This does not mean that they do not expect a rate cut at all. They do, and that is reflected in the futures contracts for later months. The yield on the December contract is down to 5.21 percent, and was as low as 5.14 percent last Thursday.
The indicator now seems to suggest that a rate cut must await two events: the meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank early next month and a worsening of the current crisis. If financial markets stabilize, there might be no rate cut in the near future -- which would presumably push the yields on these futures contracts even higher.
Investors now have to reconsider what is meant by global coordination -- which are likely to be buzzwords for some time. Just because President Clinton and other leaders in the Group of Seven industrial nations recently talked of "ways to respond to the challenges now facing the international financial system," they are not yet springing into action. Rather, world political and financial leaders are merely reassuring investors that they are keeping a close eye on the crisis.
The lack of an automatic safety net was one of the harsh lessons from the Russian economy's recent deep troubles, but that may not have fully sunk in yet.
The shift in sentiment about the prospects of a rate cut can be attributed to several causes. Investors tend to overreact to any news, whether positive or negative. That was the case with Mr. Greenspan's speech at Berkeley, Calif., on Sept. 4. He did not promise a rate cut then; he just suggested that the central bank would consider one if the foreign drag on the United States economy worsened.
Some other officials have also thrown cold water on the idea of a coordinated global cut in interest rates. The president of the German central bank, Hans Tietmeyer, said on Tuesday that there was no immediate rate cut under consideration, adding that lower rates now would be the wrong medicine for Europe.
Gordon Brown, the British Chancellor of the Exchequer, said any coordinated moves by the Group of Seven -- which besides the United States includes Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada -- would not come before the twice-a-year meeting of the I.M.F. and the World Bank. He did not rule out a rate cut, though, when he said that the Group of Seven is "fully focused on the need to maintain demand growth in the current environment."
Lastly, a rate cut by the Federal Reserve is still likely to be weighed domestically, rather than globally, with the key being the strength of the American economy.
William Poole, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, said yesterday that "if the financial turmoil in the world threatens to depress the U.S. economy, then adjustment of U.S. monetary policy is appropriate, and the Fed will make that adjustment when the case for it is clear."
And it is worth remembering that the Fed futures contracts merely reflect investor sentiment. They are not great predictors of Fed action. According to the St. Louis Fed report, the Federal fund futures forecast only about one-third of the changes in rate policy from August 1988 through 1997.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Political Squabbling Snags a Financial Overhaul in Japan

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 16

 BODY:
Days before Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi leaves for a visit to the United States, hopes are dwindling for a passage this week of a landmark series of bills to stabilize Japan's financial system.
The bills have been the focus of global attention, because they are seen as a litmus test of the Obuchi Government's ability to confront Japan's mammoth economic problems. Mr. Obuchi had hoped to have them passed by the time he met President Clinton next Tuesday, for talks on the global financial crisis. 
 But he has been unable to work out a deal with opposition parties, which control the upper house of Parliament. In fact, the opposition is now challenging the Government's entire approach to overhauling the financial system.
All this has left American officials, who very much want Japan to get on with the task of stabilizing its system, increasingly impatient with the stalemate in Parliament.
In Washington today, Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin told the House Banking Committee, "Clearly swift, strong fiscal action that will give a substantial and sustained stimulus to the economy, and sufficient immediate measures to strengthen the financial system, are urgently needed for Japan."
Naoto Kan, leader of the Democratic Party, the main opposition group, has basically swept aside the governing party's draft proposals. Instead, he and his partners in the other opposition parties have folded their ideas into a broad proposal, and that seems to have become the basis for the latest negotiations.
Indeed, a growing possibility is that the Liberal Democrats will be forced to abandon their legislation and rewrite large pieces of it in order to win agreement.
Each party, naturally, is blaming the other for the delays.
"There is no more time for the L.D.P. and the Government to cling to face-saving tactics," Mr. Kan said at a news conference today. "They should give priority to responding quickly to the emergency."
The emergency Mr. Kan referred to is the deepening recession, the eroding balance sheets of the largest banks and the huge quantity of bad debt that is crimping lending and crippling companies. Taichi Sakaiya, head of the Economic Planning Agency, said today that the economy was likely to contract this fiscal year by well over 1 percent.
The political squabbling has focused on how to handle the foundering Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, one of the nation's largest financial institutions. The opposition groups say the bank is insolvent, while the Liberal Democrats maintain that it is solvent and want to save it through a merger with the stronger Sumitomo Trust and Banking Company.
The stalemate is so severe that even as the markets clamor for a rapid resolution of the nation's financial uncertainty, politicians are discussing the possibility of scrapping a program set up in February that provides 13 trillion yen, or nearly $100 billion, to increase the capital of ailing banks. The opposition demands that the Government drop the plan, under which the Deposit Insurance Corporation, Japan's version of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, spent nearly two trillion yen, or about $15 billion, at the end of March buying stakes in the country's biggest banks.
It also demands that a bridge bank proposal, centerpiece of a plan to clean up bad debts, be cast aside for a program to deal with Japan's very large, very shaky banks. It calls for nationalization of large insolvent banks, the stiffening of financial disclosure rules and the establishment of a committee to oversee the process apart from the Finance Ministry, which it says has lost credibility with the markets.
Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa, a key figure among Liberal Democrats, was pivotal in drawing up plans to use tax money to bail out the banks. The opposition's demand to scrap this mechanism is embarrassing for Mr. Miyazawa and could therefore be politically difficult for the Liberal Democrats.
Motohisa Furukawa, a member of Parliament from the Democratic Party and a key negotiator, said that the governing party would either have to accept the opposition plan -- humiliating Mr. Miyazawa -- or accept further delays. "It's now a matter of political decision," he said in an interview today.
The share price of the Long-Term Credit Bank has been pummeled this week, cut nearly in half to a record low. Last month, the bank announced a broad restructuring arrangement and said that in the six-month period ending Sept. 30, it would incur write-offs and other costs totaling 750 billion yen, now about $5.6 billion. The opposition argues that those write-offs should have been taken in the previous fiscal year, which ended on March 31. The bank says those charges became urgent only recently.
If last year's financial statements are revised to account for that charge, the equity capital of the Long-Term Credit Bank falls to nearly zero. Even under the bank's current projections, its equity capital will be only 6 percent of assets at risk, a figure that falls short of the capital-adequacy requirement of 8 percent set forth by the Bank for International Settlements in Geneva.
The Liberal Democrats have argued that allowing the Long-Term Credit Bank, which has 25 trillion yen in assets, or $185 billion, to fail would create turmoil in the financial system. The opposition argues that such an impact is exaggerated.
"The worst scenario would be one in which L.T.C.B. fails and there is a great impact in the worldwide market and a very big impact on the world economy," said Masaru Takagi, an economics professor at Meiji University. "But I think that this is only a fear. It's not the truth."
An American mutual fund that invests in distressed assets and owns a large stake in the bank, Third Avenue Value Fund, has filed a complaint in United States District Court in Manhattan against the bank, its top directors, and Sumitomo Trust and Banking. In its restructuring plan, Long-Term Credit said it would forgive debt worth 520 billion yen, or $3.9 billion, to three affiliates. The fund contends that this has hurt the bank's shareholders and threatens its solvency.
And in a further sign of financial disarray, Standard & Poor's today lowered its outlook on four other large Japanese banks to negative from stable. They are Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, the Industrial Bank of Japan, Sanwa Bank and Fuji Bank.
