HEADLINE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Army Marching on a Different Wavelength;
Joining Conference USA Brings More Television Exposure and Revenue From Bowls

BYLINE: By JOE DRAPE 

DATELINE: WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 15

 BODY:
It has played football for 108 years, 1,011 games in all against teams from across the nation. It maintains a narrow edge over Navy in one of the oldest and most resonant rivalries in college sports. But the history of Army football takes a modern turn Saturday when a pair of teams without a victory square off at Michie Stadium.
When Army (0-1) faces Cincinnati (0-2) here, the Black Knights will turn the page on more than a century as an independent to compete in their first game as the newest member of Conference USA. 
 It is the beginning of an era when Fox Sports Net, new rivals such as Southern Mississippi and post-season games like the Liberty Bowl will become part of Army lore along with Glenn Davis and the Commander-in-Chief's Trophy. In the view of Army athletic officials, it is vital to remaining in the mainstream of big-time college football.
"This shows our commitment to playing Division I-A football," said Al Vanderbush, Army's athletic director. "We were playing a couple of Division I-AA schools and getting criticized for it. Other schools were using it to recruit against us. This makes us more competitive, gives us an identity, and I believe kids today would like to look up and see there is a conference championship to play for and an all-conference team to make."
More important, beyond just survival, it shifts Army's focus to getting a greater share of the millions of television dollars flowing into college football. Besides a competitive schedule and the promise of bowl games, Army now gets a marketing outfit -- the conference -- dedicated to making it network- and cable-ready.
Army is not alone in trying to reposition itself in an increasingly competitive race for television dollars and bowl payouts. Last May, the presidents of eight Western universities, including Air Force, stunned the college athletic community when they announced they were leaving the Western Athletic Conference to form their own league.
They cited everything from unmanageable travel -- the conference stretched from Hawaii to Houston -- to the dilution of geographical rivalries. But the fact that television and bowl money did not stretch far when divided by 16 teams was perhaps the clincher.
Even Notre Dame, the only major power among the eight remaining Division I-A independents, which has its own five-year, $45 million television contract with NBC, is talking to Big Ten officials about joining the conference to insure economic health and stability.
Just as in professional sports, the driving factor in this climate of change is television money. The Big Ten commissioner, James E. Delany, estimates the annual market for college football television rights at $300 million and growing.
In the new Bowl Championship Series that ABC will televise, for example, the title game will be worth from $11 million to $12 million a team.
Jon D. Litner, senior vice president for programming at ABC Sports, says that like the makers of soft drinks, schools are "fighting for shelf space" and are turning to high-quality marketing and aggressive representation.
"There's an enormous amount of revenue that television generates," Litner said. "I'm sure schools are making decisions on who they affiliate with because of television." ABC, along with ESPN -- also under the Disney umbrella -- is the biggest player in college football and will broadcast 21 of 26 post-season games.
Conference USA, in its third year of existence, offered Army access it did not previously have to a television contract and two bowl games. It also offered a schedule of mid-major Southern universities with which academy officials believed a school of 4,000 cadets -- none on true athletic scholarships -- could compete. The conference is composed of Cincinnati, Tulane, Memphis, Louisville, Houston, Southern Miss and East Carolina, and its champion earns an automatic berth in the Liberty Bowl, which last year had a $1.1 million payout per team.
In addition, the Humanitarian Bowl in Boise, Idaho, will hold a place for another Conference USA team, worth an additional $750,000 to each team. And the conference's deal with Fox Sports Net pays immediate dividends in exposure -- five Army games are scheduled to be televised this season and the number could reach nine. Last year, three Army games were televised, including the Navy game.
"The television and bowl opportunities are attached exclusively to the conferences anymore," said Army Coach Bob Sutton. "The independents out there don't really have a voice. We have a broad recruiting base in the South that we're going to reach more effectively. Every game is going to mean something in the conference standings. Kids are going to see us more and we'll be validated as a program."
The athletic budget at Army is $15 million, of which $3 million comes from the Government, primarily to cover salaries. Revenue from football carries the academy's 25 other athletic teams. Vanderbush said attendance and concessions at Army's home games, television contracts and donations connected to the football program account for the vast majority of the remaining $12 million. Army will continue to play Air Force and Navy for the Commander-in-Chief's trophy and, in an essential piece of deal making, did not give up its television rights for the annual classic against the Midshipmen.
The Army-Navy game, recently renewed by CBS through 2008, is among the most lucrative in college sports. The previous contract was worth $1 million a year for both Army and Navy, which remains an independent, and Vanderbush said that had increased significantly, although he would not give a figure.
Vanderbush, the Army athletic director, said that the Conference USA affiliation is initially worth an additional $300,000 to $400,000 a year to Army, though the windfall is largely offset this year because the Black Knights lost a home game in the switch to the conference schedule.
Conference USA is part of the Bowl Championship Series, but is guaranteed a place in only one of the four big-money games -- Fiesta, Rose, Sugar or Orange -- if one of its teams finishes No. 6 or higher in the series' ranking. Still, the conference receives $800,000 this year just for being a part of the series, according to Mike Slive, the conference's commissioner.
Slive said flatly that Army would make more money in Conference USA than it would have as an independent. In turn, he said, the other schools in the conference have acquired a valuable commodity to bolster their status in the marketplace.
"We get its storied tradition and great football history, which helps our name recognition," Slive said. "Contracts and governance are conference-driven. The revenues are market-driven. Our goal is to be at the table and be ready to move up and take our share."
Vanderbush said that the role of athletic director had evolved from that of administrator to that of businessman and entrepreneur. That thought was echoed by athletic directors at places like Southern Methodist, Texas Christian, Rice and the five other universities who were divorced by their higher-profile mates in the W.A.C. and retain the name of their conference but little else.
Roy Kramer, the longtime commissioner of the powerful Southeastern Conference, anticipates more conference realignment. Fortunately for Army, it has made its move.
"My athletic directors can divide," Kramer said. "And unless you have something valuable to bring, conferences may get smaller before they get bigger."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Steps Planned By Magazine To Lift Profit

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
The Reader's Digest Association said yesterday that it would cut several hundred jobs, sell 39 paintings from its valuable collection and reduce its generous dividend by 75 percent to help improve a sagging performance.
The company, which publishes one of the most widely distributed magazines, left unclear how many of its 5,600 employees would ultimately leave. Thomas O. Ryder, the chairman, said he did not yet have a final figure. 
 The dividend cut is likely to have a big impact on an array of cultural and educational institutions that have been the beneficiaries of the publisher's past earnings. The company's founders, Lila and DeWitt Wallace, had established two charitable foundations and seven charitable funds, each intended to support a major cultural institution.
The beneficiaries include such New York landmarks as the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Metropolitan Opera, the New York City Ballet, the New York City Opera, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, the Lincoln Center Theater and the Wildlife Conservation Society. But the beneficiary list also extends to Colonial Williamsburg and Macalester College in St. Paul.
These institutions already had been been hurt by a 50 percent dividend cut announced last year, to 90 cents. At the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the new cuts will mean roughly an 8.4 percent drop in the budget of $119 million for the current fiscal year, which ends June 30, 1999.
The museum said yesterday through a spokesman that the cuts represent "a painful blow for our operating budget and a crippling one for our acquisitions fund because the money we allocate from the Digest gift to acquisitions is a large percentage of that pool."
Linda Janklow, chairwoman of the Lincoln Center Theater, said the Reader's Digest funds had been "the most wonderful source of arts funding and philanthropy in New York City."
The theater received about $3.5 million from Reader's Digest in the 1998 fiscal year, which ended June 30, or 13.4 percent of its budget. Ms. Janklow said her organization had been alerted that the gift would most likely drop to about $2.9 million in the 1999 fiscal year.
In a telephone interview, Mr. Ryder said the dividend reductions were necessary.
"The issues for these institutions is how they get value over time," he said. "They will never get significant value if they drain from the company its lifeblood. We have been paying dividends far in excess of our ability to do it and limiting the growth opportunities in the company."
Mr. Ryder, who joined the company in April, said his job was "to make this stock worth a lot more money long term -- to build the franchise value of the enterprise.
"The dividend cut is a very small part of a very large effort we announced to do that," he continued.
Mr. Ryder said the company was attempting to attract a younger audience to the pocket-size magazine. Reader's Digest has a United States circulation of 14.7 million, but its main audience of older readers has been declining.
Mr. Ryder came to Reader's Digest from American Express, where he had been president of its Travel Related Services International division and chairman of American Express Publishing. While there, Mr. Ryder used television and radio advertising heavily to promote the company's cards. He hopes to use that marketing tool to help Reader's Digest.
Impatient investors have been waiting for Reader's Digest to sell off its non-income-producing art collection, which includes 8,000 works. The decision to sell 39 paintings, the cream of the collection, received a warm reception: shares rose $1.8125, to $19.9375.
The company plans to slash costs and increase annual profit by $100 million to $150 million in the next three years, Mr. Ryder said. In its last fiscal year, profits plunged 87 percent, to just $17.9 million, while revenue slid 7 percent, to $2.63 billion. The company expects slightly higher profits in the current fiscal year.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Shocks and Aftershocks;
The Bear Is Rampant in the Markets for Riskier Bonds

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
The stock market's bear may have gone into hibernation, but the bond market variety is all too alive and well.
Having endured an August from hell in stocks, investors are enjoying a respite in September. But while many stocks have bounced part way back from their losses, bonds -- with the conspicuous exception of United States Treasury securities -- have barely budged. August, one of the most brutal months on record in almost every bond market around the world, has been followed by a September in which most of these securities, even if they are up, have mustered only the merest gains. 
 What happened? Through no fault of their own, investors in a wide variety of bonds, from convertibles to mortgage-backed securities, found themselves trapped in a game of economic dominoes gone awry. Indeed, the bond market action in August is a painful lesson in how the toppling of one market can, in turn, hurt even the most seemingly unrelated market worlds away.
What began in mid-August with a apparently irrelevant de facto default on its debt by the Russian central bank wound up hurting even the most highly rated bonds issued by American corporations with absolutely no exposure to Russia. The only people who escaped the disaster were owners of United States Treasury securities, which were driven to historic highs in price terms as a result of some of the lowest yields in decades.
The situation in Russia caused an about-face in the level of risk that professional investors were willing to tolerate. As long as the International Monetary Fund was willing to bail out countries experiencing economic disarray, investors were comfortable investing in fledgling markets. Russia changed all that.
"The flight to quality, previously, was out of equities and into bonds, and any bonds qualified," said Martin Fridson, chief high-yield strategist at Merrill Lynch. "Now that flight is much more pronounced because investors want to go all the way to the ultimate quality of U.S. Treasury securities. Nothing in between seems safe enough."
What did this new risk aversion mean for various bond markets? Big losses. In August, investors in emerging-market debt lost 28.7 percent of their money, convertible bonds lost 11.8 percent and high-yield bonds lost 7.4 percent of their value. Real estate investment trusts that invest in mortgage securities declined an average 27 percent during the month. Only two non-Treasury sectors showed gains for the period: municipal bonds rose 1.92 percent and the highest-rated corporate bonds inched up 0.51 percent. Treasury bonds, meanwhile, advanced 2.16 percent.
Bonds, remember, are supposed to be boring, predictable investments. No more. "We've probably crammed about a year of volatility into the last six weeks in the bond market," said Randall C. King, senior vice president for asset liability management at PNC Bank in Pittsburgh.
The result of all this volatility has been to bring the issuance of many types of bonds and convertible debt to a near standstill. For example, only one convertible debt issue came to market in all of August.
Why does upheaval in one distant market make for losses closer to home? T. Anne Cox, director of global convertible bond research at Merrill Lynch, explained: "If investors take a hit in one part of their book, their risk tolerance is going to decline across the board. And if everybody does that at roughly the same time, you could see where you'd get some real liquidity pressure."
Hurt the most by the bear market in bonds are hedge funds that made big bets in emerging-market debt and brokerage firms that trade all manner of bonds for their own accounts. Also taking a hit were commercial banks that trade in the same markets. Adding to the upset, many of these concerns used leverage to make their bets, which magnified their losses.
Another piece of bad luck: these big investors typically hedged against losses in emerging-market debt by selling Treasury securities that they did not own. With prices of Treasuries roaring as emerging- market debt plunged, the "hedges" were a disaster as folks found themselves on the wrong side of both of their trades.
As a result, word on Wall Street is that most fixed-income departments at major trading firms have given up all they had made during the first seven months of the year. These departments usually are big money makers for brokerage firms. Last year, for example, Merrill Lynch's taxable fixed-income department generated nearly $1 billion in revenue, 26 percent of the firm's overall revenue for principal transactions.
This year, however, bonuses for employees in these areas are a dream; many firms have already conducted what are euphemistically called head-count meetings. Dismissals will follow.
For individuals, the unhappy sequence of events in the bond market is all that much harder to take because the losses came when interest rates were declining significantly. Yields on the five-year Treasury note, for example, have fallen one full percentage point in recent weeks. The notes traded at 5.43 percent on July 1 and fell to 4.43 percent on Sept. 11. Yesterday they were a little higher at 4.67 percent.
With rates moving down, investors are understandably confounded by losses in their bond portfolios. After all, doesn't Investing 101 dictate that when interest rates fall, bond prices rise?
Indeed it does. But Investing 101 could not have predicted the confluence of events -- the work of professional investors, hedge funds managers and brokerage trading desks which ran away from anything with a whiff of risk to it -- that have paralyzed worldwide bond markets. As the herd stampeded out of junk bonds, convertible debt, emerging- market bonds, even relatively unrisky corporate issues, buyers for these securities disappeared.
Typically, bonds of all kinds trade in tandem. But not in this market; Treasuries have broken away from the pack. "Everybody's focused on the decoupling of stocks and bonds," said Michael Ryan, senior fixed-income strategist at Paine Webber. "What they're not focused on is the decoupling of fixed income."
All fixed-income securities, whether convertibles, high-yield bonds, AAA-rated corporates or mortgage-backed issues, are traditionally evaluated by how much more their coupons yield than Treasury securities with similar maturities. Because Treasuries are as close to a risk-free investment as there is, any bond that is not backed by Uncle Sam has to attract investors with a higher interest rate than those investors would get if they bought Treasuries.
Historically, the average premium at which high-yield bonds, commonly referred to as junk bonds, have traded, for example, is a little under four percentage points higher than similar Treasuries. Now their yields are almost six percentage points higher than Treasuries.
But at the end of last year, according to John DeMeo at Salomon Smith Barney, junk bonds traded at a much smaller premium to Treasuries: a little more than two and three-quarter percentage points above the Government's issues. This narrow spread was the result of yield-starved investors taking as big a gamble as they dared. Those were the days when investors were utterly confident that there was relatively little risk in reaching for that larger return.
So, in the months before what was to be a historic flight to quality, the extra spreads for all non-Treasury debt were extremely narrow. When investors fled, they were fleeing from bonds that were, by traditional standards, highly priced. That only compounded the losses.
Each market has, to some degree, slightly different reasons for its troubles. Convertible bonds, for example, are tied to the fortunes of the typically small stocks that are embedded in their values. These shares have been pummeled by the bear market in small-company equities.
Junk bonds, because they are issued by companies most vulnerable to problems stemming from declines in corporate profits, may also reflect the recent difficulties in small-company stocks and worries about a recession in the United States.
Most investors have probably been unaware of the recent carnage taking place in bonds. That's because it is a much more disparate and less transparent market than the stock market. While it's relatively easy to watch the stock market's ups and downs -- every move is detailed daily in newspapers, on Internet sites and on cable television shows -- bond markets are much harder to track. Because information about trades in these markets is not widely available, only professional traders and institutional investors involved in the worldwide bond markets had a ringside seat for the ugly events unfolding there over the past six weeks.
Toting up the dollars lost by investors in bonds in August is difficult, too, because of the market's opaqueness. But some numbers are available: $48 billion was lost in emerging-market debt that was denominated in dollars, $14.6 billion disappeared from portfolios of convertible bonds, another $15 billion was likely lost in junk bonds and $1.67 billion disappeared during the month from an index of real estate investment trusts that invest in mortgage securities. That's about $80 billion lost.
Investors who are not yet aware of the recent turmoil in bonds may get an unpleasant jolt when they check their mutual fund holdings. There are plenty of bondholders out there: as of Sept. 9, according to AMG Data Services, assets held in bond funds totaled $533 billion, roughly one-fifth the amount currently in stock funds.
A paralysis unlike anything investors have seen for years is gripping non-Treasury bond markets in the United States. Investors who think that September's relative calm in the market is a sign of stability should not be confused. It is a frozen market, where nobody's selling because there are no buyers.
"It's an over-the-counter market and you've got to get these guys to pick up the phone," said Carol Levenson, editor of Gimme Credit, a corporate bond advisory service to institutional investors in Chicago,
Dealers at major Wall Street brokerage firms are no longer bidding for bonds from their customers; they will only take an order if they know they have another customer interested in owning the bonds. And since few investors are interested in adding to their bond positions until they see the market stabilize, most sell orders don't get executed.
As a result, the losses that have been registered in bonds so far probably reflect only a fraction of the real damage done to these markets. If there was actual selling going on, the prices would be far lower. But as long as investors are not forced to sell, the market simply feels ominously quiet.
With the year winding down, more and more investors may be forced to sell their holdings. If the market does not rebound by the end of the year, many large firms want to have their trading portfolios whittled down.
What might the next few months bring to bond investors? Don't expect a big rebound. With Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, declining to elaborate on investors' hopes that he will cut interest rates at the Sept. 29 meeting, the market in all but Treasuries will likely remain frozen.

HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT;
Excerpts From the President's News Conference

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a news conference today at the State Department by President Clinton and President Vaclav Havel of the Czech Republic as recorded by The New York Times:
MR. CLINTON -- Today I am very proud to stand with President Vaclav Havel of the Czech Republic. . . .
I was proud to visit President Havel in Prague in 1994 to see the great energy, creativity, joy of the Czech people unleashed. When we celebrate freedom today we know that many challenges still lie ahead. President Havel recently put it very well. "Something is being born," he said, "one age is succeeding another. We live in a world where everything is possible and almost nothing is certain." 
 Today, our meetings focused on seizing those possibilities and minimizing those uncertainties. . . . We talked about next year's NATO summit here and the Czech Republic's preparations for integration into the NATO alliance. . . .
We spoke about the urgent need to bring stability to Kosovo to prevent suffering there and the current tensions in Albania. We discussed ways to strengthen our cooperation against the terrible scourge of terrorism. . . . We are making progress as friends and partners. That is possible only because of the courage President Havel and the Czech people have shown and continue to show today. We will continue to do the hard work together so that our children can reap the full benefits of it in the new century. . . .
MR. HAVEL The situation of contemporary world is very complicated. We feel it especially in Europe, especially in central Europe, especially in Czech Republic. And I think that in this situation it's extremely important the responsibility of United States, as the biggest, most powerful country all around the world.
And I'm extremely grateful or thankful to Mr. President and his leadership because it was in his time when we received the chance to build new Europe and to build new Europe it means to build the new world, peaceful world. . . .
Q. -- Mr. President, what can the U.S. and NATO do to stop the killing in Kosovo? And what do you say to people who have said that you have lost all the moral authority to lead this nation or to conduct foreign affairs?
MR. CLINTON -- Let me answer the second question first. . . .
I have never stopped leading this country in foreign affairs in this entire year and I never will. . . . We have taken action against those who killed our people and killed the Kenyans and Tanzanians. We have . . . been working for peace in Northern Ireland, for stability in Russia. I have been personally involved in the peace process in the Middle East again as it reaches another critical phase. I gave a speech Monday which I think is about the most important subject now facing the world community: How to limit this financial crisis and keep it from spreading; how to develop long-term institutions that will help to promote growth and opportunity for ordinary people around the world in a way that permits America's economic recovery to go on. . . .
I had a good talk with President Chirac of France, who called me a couple of days ago to talk about some of our common concerns and the U.N. inspection system in Iraq and other things. So I feel good about that.
Now on Kosovo . . . we have looming there, right next door to Bosnia, a significant humanitarian problem. There are many many tens of thousands of people who've been dislocated from their homes . . . at very high levels in the mountains, which means it will get colder there much more quickly than in the rest of the country. . . . We're doing everything we can to avert the humanitarian disaster. . . . We're pursuing negotiated settlement options through Ambassador Chris Hill. . . . We're doing NATO planning and consulting with our allies because I still believe the big problem here is Mr. Milosevic is determined to get a military solution if he can instead of pursuing a diplomatic solution. . . . While the political and legal situation is not identical to what we had in Bosnia, the humanitarian issue is similar. And we don't want a repeat of Bosnia. . . .
Q. -- So you think you do have a moral authority to lead this nation?
MR. CLINTON -- Well, you might -- in my view, that is something that you have to demonstrate every day. My opinion is not as important as the opinion of others. What is important is that I do my job. . . . I'm determined to lead this country and to focus on the issues that are before us. It is not an option. There's no option. We have got to deal with these things.
Q. -- Mr. President, from your understanding of events, is Monica Lewinsky's account of your relationship accurate and truthful? And do you still maintain that you did not lie under oath in your testimony?
MR. CLINTON -- I have said for a month now that I did something that was wrong. On last Friday at the prayer breakfast I laid out as carefully and as brutally honestly as I could what I believed the essential truth to be. I also said then and I will say again that I think that the right thing for our country and the right thing for all people concerned is not to get mired in all of the details here, but to focus, for me to focus on what I did, to acknowledge it, to atone for it and then to work on my family, where I still have a lot of work to do, difficult work. And to lead this country to deal with the agenda before us, these huge issues that I was talking about internationally. Plus, with only two weeks left to go in this budget year a very, very large range of items before the American people here at home. Doing our part to deal with this financial crisis with the, funding the International Monetary Fund, saving the Social Security system before we spend the surplus, doing the important work that we can do to help educate our children, dealing with the patients' bill of rights for these people, 160 million of them in H.M.O.'s.
These are the things to me that I should be talking about as President without in any way ever trying to obscure my own personal acknowledgment and chagrin about what I did wrong and my determination to put it right.
Q. -- Mr. President Havel, you said today that President Clinton is your great friend, I wonder if the discovered misdeeds of President Clinton have any how influenced your approach to him, your relation to him?
MR. HAVEL -- I didn't recognize any change . . .
Q. -- Mr. President, as the Lewinsky matter continues to unfold, can you foresee any circumstance where you might consider resignation, either because of the personal toll on you or the toll on the country? And do you think it's fair if the House should release its videotapes?
 MR. CLINTON -- Let me first of all say that the personal toll on me is of no concern except insofar as it affects my personal life. . . . because I'm working on what I should be working on. I believe the right thing for the country and I what I believe the people of the country want, is now that they know what happened, they want to put it behind them and they want to go and they want me to go on and do my job. And that's what I intend to do. That is the right thing to do.
In terms of the question you asked about the House, they have to decide that. That's not for me to decide. They have to do their job, and I have to do mine. . . .
Q. -- When you gave your deposition, sir, were you fully aware that it might be released, the videotape?
MR. CLINTON -- I think that I knew that the rules were against it, but I thought it would happen. I think that's where I was on that. But it's not of so much concern to me. I mean, you know that I acknowledged an improper relationship and that I declined to discuss the details. . . .
Q. -- Mr. President, you have mentioned in your speech that you appreciate the personal contribution of President Clinton to the NATO enlargement, and you see him also as a personal friend. I'd like to know how do you think that an eventual resignation or impeachment of President Clinton would influence the American foreign policy and the Czech-American relations?
MR. HAVEL -- through translator I believe, first, that this is a matter for the United States and for the American people, who will be their President. When I have made a friendship with someone, I remain that person's friend no matter which office he or she holds or doesn't hold.
Q. -- Mr. President, your initiative on race finishes this month and your press secretary yesterday agreed that the race initiative isn't flying because of your current problems and it was bogged down in the muck and mire.
But do you regret that your personal problems affected your potential legacy on race and that it may just, at best, be a Band-Aid approach to racism in America?
MICHAEL McCURRY -- That's not exactly what I said.
Mr. CLINTON -- I don't know if he said that. But if he did, I strongly disagree with him. I don't think it has affected it at all.
As a matter of fact, I think, the response you've seen from some sectors of the American community have reinforced and acknowledged the centrality of this issue to the work of the last six years, not just the work of the last year.
And let me also say that what is coming to an end here is this phase of it. And there will be a report that the board will give me a set of recommendations. Then we expect to produce a document.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: NEW YORK GOVERNOR;
New Pataki Endorsements Upstage Vallone Upstate

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Sept. 16

 BODY:
A day after winning the Democratic gubernatorial primary, Peter F. Vallone took a victory lap of New York today to re-introduce himself to upstate voters, but he was upstaged when Buffalo's Democratic Mayor endorsed Gov. George E. Pataki for re-election.
Mr. Vallone, who remains little known upstate despite months of campaigning, pointedly made his first stops here and in Albany, in search of a lift from his easy win in Tuesday's primary. And he focused on the stubbornly weak upstate economy, blaming Mr. Pataki. 
 "We are fighting for last place in job creation," he said at a news conference with local officials at Buffalo International Airport. "There's no excuse."
But less than two hours after Mr. Vallone's campaign plane took off, Mr. Pataki's touched down, and the Republican Governor accepted the embrace of Anthony M. Masiello, Mayor of the state's second-largest city.
"I lay aside all partisanship," Mr. Masiello declared at a news conference at a marina on the Niagara Canal. "I focus instead on one simple question: what is best for Buffalo, New York?"
Mr. Pataki boasted that the Democratic mayors of Niagara Falls, Utica and Oneida had already supported him. Of Mr. Masiello, he said, "the Mayor has shown the courage to cross party lines because our policies are right for Buffalo and right for this state."
Other Buffalo Democrats charged that Mr. Masiello acted purely in hope of winning more state aid for his economically distressed city. Democrats worry that a tide of defections like Mr. Masiello's could undermine their candidate.
In the primary, Mr. Vallone defeated his closest competitor, Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, by a 5-to-2 margin. But today, Ms. McCaughey Ross pledged to continue running through November as the Liberal Party candidate, a stance that has infuriated many Democrats, who contend that all she will accomplish is to divide the anti-Pataki vote.
"I respect the leaders of the Democratic Party tremendously and I look forward to working with them in the future," Ms. McCaughey Ross said today in Manhattan. "But I've given my word to the Liberal Party, and I feel it's very important for me to keep my word."
Raymond B. Harding, the Liberal Party chairman, filed a complaint today with the State Board of Elections, charging that efforts by Democrats to persuade Ms. McCaughey Ross to drop from the race amounted to threats and coercion. He cited the comments of Judith Hope, the state Democratic chairwoman, who said Tuesday night that if the Lieutenant Governor remained in the race, "it will get very ugly and will turn out to be a very unpleasant experience."
Mr. Vallone said: "I have no advice for Betsy. She's got to do whatever she does on her own."
As they kicked off the campaign for the general election, the largest share of attention belonged to Mr. Pataki and Mr. Vallone.
The Governor's waltz around the state was clearly intended to overshadow Mr. Vallone, the Speaker of the New York City Council. After the Masiello endorsement, the Governor and the Republican nominee for lieutenant governor, Mary O. Donohue, flew to Rochester and Binghamton for enthusiastic rallies.
The Pataki campaign has begun labeling Mr. Vallone, who is usually seen as a moderate, as a liberal who has raised taxes. Aides to the Governor said Mr. Pataki's first advertisement attacking the Democrat would probably be broadcast this week.
Mr. Vallone, too, intends to air new advertisements this week, but starts the campaign with about $1 million to the Governor's $12 million.
Mr. Vallone's victory over three rivals on Tuesday gave him a new degree of celebrity after a primary that drew little interest. When he appeared here a week ago to receive the endorsement of Dennis T. Gorski, the Erie County Executive, just three reporters turned up and no television cameras. Today, there were more than a dozen reporters and four television cameras.
Mr. Vallone challenged Mr. Pataki to debates, repeatedly taunting the Governor about the paid speeches he has made around the country.
"I know that you've made speeches in California, in Iowa, in New Hampshire and in a couple of other states," he said. "I challenge you, Governor, to debate right here in New York State. Let's start in Buffalo."
Asked about the challenge, Mr. Pataki responded, "I am very proud of our record, and I look forward to a spirited campaign, including debating all the issues." But he would not commit to televised debates, or to a one-on-one confrontation with Mr. Vallone.

HEADLINE: Whitman Proposes $100 Million Tax Rebate

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman embraced a host of recommendations today that she said would eventually reduce local property taxes by $1.2 billion, and then went on to propose an immediate rebate of $100 million in surplus state tax revenue to property owners.
Saying she recognized that New Jersey residents, who pay the highest per capita property taxes in the nation, needed tax relief now, the Governor added that the state's strong economy and the brisk pace of revenue collection in the fiscal year ended June 30 made the rebates possible. 
 She said she could not guarantee that the economy would allow rebates in the future, but added, "When state government takes in more money than we expected, then it's time to remember where that money came from and to give it back."
Mrs. Whitman said that the specifics of the rebate program would have to be worked out with the State Legislature and that it was too early to predict how much would be refunded. But she insisted that the money would go directly to those who paid local property taxes.
Aides to the Governor said that the rebate plan complemented the array of other measures recommended this week by a panel she set up after last year's election to find ways to cut property taxes. Of the 60 recommendations by the commission, Governor Whitman immediately endorsed 17 proposals she said she would enact through executive order or by supporting bills before the Legislature.
The recommendations that she embraced would create state incentives for localities to consolidate and regionalize some services; allow the state to pay the cost of local prosecutors, and authorize some urban areas to levy new or additional taxes on parking, entertainment and hotel rooms.
Like the recommendations of the panel, the Property Tax Commission, which were formally released on Tuesday, the Governor's proposed rebate program met with mixed reaction from Democrats and Republicans. Some praised Mrs. Whitman for trying to direct tax relief to property owners but questioned the timing of it when the state needs to spend money to improve transportation and schools.
Others charged that the rebate program was an attempt to make up for the tepid, or as one said, "the less than ambitious" recommendations of her tax commission. In particular, they criticized the commission for not calling for any major shifts in education costs. Such expenses are by far the largest segment of local tax bills, and critics have said for years that the state should assume more of these costs.
Assemblyman Joseph V. Doria, the Democratic minority leader, termed the $100 million in immediate rebates the "Son of Property Tax Relief Fund" and said neither the rebates nor the longer-term proposals of the Governor's commission would quiet the public furor over residents' heavy local tax burden.
"Many of the recommendations are giving the distinct impression that this Governor is seeking to use bravura instead of substance to extinguish the public firestorm over high property taxes," he said.
Anticipating such criticism, Mrs. Whitman adopted the cautious tone of the commission members, who said yesterday that any wholesale shifting of education costs from local property taxes would mean a loss of some local control -- consequences that required a more complete public discussion.
"The commission's work also supports what I state in announcing its formation," the Governor said. "Namely that the public needs to know, understand and accept the true costs of confronting the property tax problem."
The Governor's rebate program is similar to those of a half-dozen states around the nation that, finding themselves flush in good economic times, have sought ways to ease tax burdens immediately without permanently lowering tax rates or altering tax codes. It is a new experience for many states, which have been experiencing "sustained surpluses" for up to four years running, said Mandy Rafool, a policy specialist with the National Conference of State Legislatures.
According to a survey by the group, Connecticut, Colorado, Minnesota, Missouri, Ohio and Oregon have given such rebates. Only Colorado and Missouri are required by statute or their constitutions to do so whenever there are surpluses, Ms. Rafool said. The rebates ranged from $37 to $260.
Governor Whitman's plan calls for the first rebates to come from fiscal 1998 revenue. In the future, rebates to property owners would occur if state income tax revenue exceeded the Governor's projections by 10 percent and all other state taxes met their projected levels. Twenty percent of the overflow would go into the rebate fund in any given year and it would be disbursed to property taxpayers only when it reached $100 million.
The State Treasurer, James Di Eleuterio, said that last year state income tax receipts were $4.85 billion, or $554 million more than expected. This is above the 10 percent threshold that would cause a rebate and 20 percent of it produces the approximately $100 million that Gov. Whitman proposes to disburse as rebates once the Legislature arrives at a mechanism for allotting it to property owners.
As for the commission recommendations, Mrs. Whitman said she would create a $25 million state fund to provide the financial incentives for municipalities that consolidated services in the interest of efficiency. This would create the so-called Regional Efficiency Aid Program, which would provide the state's 21 counties, 566 municipalities, 611 school districts and 400 local authorities with tax relief if they adopted cost-saving consolidations.
The incentive money from the state will be over and above existing state aid to municipalities. It will be itemized in the local tax bills to indicate how it was apportioned to reduce an individual's local taxes.
The Governor also created a $10 million pool of state money to assist localities in studying such consolidations and mergers.
James W. Hughes, a member of the Governor's commission and dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, said it was wise to start out small with such incentive programs. "This is a bottom-up approach rather than a top-down approach," he said.

HEADLINE: CLINTON PROPOSAL TO AID ECONOMIES MEETS OBSTACLES

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON and DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
President Clinton's push to quell the global financial turmoil ran into several obstacles today as Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, testified that the world's big economies had no plans for a coordinated reduction in interest rates.
"I think I can safely say at the moment there is no endeavor to coordinate interest rate cuts," Mr. Greenspan told the House Banking Committee, but he again hinted that the global crisis could lead the Fed to cut domestic rates. "Deflationary forces are continuing to emerge" in much of the rest of the world, he said, and they are moving toward the United States. 
 Robert E. Rubin, the Treasury Secretary, indicated today that Brazil was the main focus of American concern in Latin America. But in another setback to coordinated action, negotiations involving Brazil, the International Monetary Fund and the major industrial nations over a multibillion-dollar rescue package hit political difficulties. Brazilian officials appear hesitant to seek aid before their country's Presidential election in two weeks, especially because a condition for the help would be agreeing to unpopular budget cuts, people involved in the negotiations said.
Taken together, the political obstacles to assembling a rescue package for Brazil and the obvious discord within the Group of Seven industrial nations regarding a global interest rate cut suggest that President Clinton's agenda will be extremely difficult to enact.
American investors had hoped that Mr. Clinton's call on Monday for a concerted push to contain the fast-spreading global crisis would lead to quick action to shore up the embattled economies of Latin America. Mr. Clinton's words, they hoped, would spur central banks to put aside their traditional fixation on inflation and reduce rates to promote growth.
But Germany's powerful central bank, the Bundesbank, signaled on Tuesday that it continued to see inflation as a threat in Europe, and officials from other nations have also been playing down the possibility of quick action on rates or any other response to the global tumult.
In the United States, however, Mr. Greenspan said there was evidence that the robust pace of growth was slowing and that investors were becoming more nervous about how the global crisis was affecting the domestic financial system.
"I would say that despite the still very solid American economy as of now, there are really the first signs of erosion at the edges, especially in manufacturing," he said.
The Fed will next meet on Sept. 29 to consider interest rates, and despite Mr. Greenspan's hints that a rate cut could be considered, it is by no means clear that the central bank's other members are ready to act.
William Poole, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, said today that although the Fed was under pressure to help other economies and the world financial system, it had to stay focused on restraining inflation in the United States.
While he did not rule out supporting a rate cut, Mr. Poole, one of the Fed's most ardent inflation fighters, said that an "attempt to pursue other objectives that in fact damaged pursuit of price stability in the United States would only add to world financial problems."
Mr. Clinton's comments this week marked the first time that he had detailed a plan of action, and he said at a news conference today that fighting the financial crisis was "the most important subject now facing the world community." He argued that "my objectives were embraced by the leaders, the financial leaders, of the largest industrial countries in the world."
Even some of his closest aides conceded in private that his call for action came late and that the economic problems were now far more complicated than they were in early August, when he first considered giving the speech.
"He should have done this months ago," one of his closest advisers said today, acknowledging that the plan would be even more difficult to achieve now that the President is fending off calls for resignation, impeachment or censure.
United States officials are clearly worried about the fallout if Brazil, one of America's largest trading partners, is hit full force by the economic contagion caused by the flight of investors from emerging markets worldwide.
Mr. Rubin, testifying today, was cautious discussing Brazil, saying that it "is obviously enormously important to this country."
"We have been very focused on this, actually," he said, "for quite some time, and particularly over the course of the past week. I think it is probably premature to comment on specifics other than to assure you that this has been the subject of intense focus through last week, the weekend, and up to the current moment."
In addition to Brazilian caution before a presidential election, the nation's problems are fed by the fear of a renewed attack on the currency as investors continue to flee emerging markets and worries that the I.M.F.'s emergency reserves must be carefully conserved.
Brazilian officials say they have not asked the I.M.F. for direct help. But on Tuesday night, the Finance Minister, Pedro Malan, said that his Government was talking to the I.M.F. and the Group of Seven countries about ways to bolster the confidence of investors. He hinted that the I.M.F. would put together a line of credit, probably more than $25 billion, that Brazil and its neighbors could draw on to defend their currencies and pay their international debts.
But this morning, hours after President Fernando Henrique Cardoso talked to President Clinton by telephone in a discussion that neither government described in detail, Mr. Malan backed away. "It is not for Brazil to speak for the I.M.F. or any G-7 country or make comments on the terms, volumes and conditions upon which international cooperation could or would be made available to countries if the need arises," he said. Other officials said that there had not been any discussion of the size of the package.
"He was out ahead of himself," one person close to the negotiations said, insisting on anonymity, "but he wasn't entirely blowing smoke."
Mr. Malan, much like officials in Thailand and Korea late last year, may have been dangling the possibility of international help to encourage the recent run-up in the Brazilian stock market -- which could help stave off the need for help. He did not discuss the conditions that Brazil would have to meet in return for the commitment of backup financing because they are likely to create trouble for Mr. Cardoso as his re-election campaign enters its final weeks.
The I.M.F., officials say, would insist that Brazil cut its huge budget deficit, which currently runs about 7 percent of the country's gross domestic product. That would mean pushing cuts in social programs or military spending through a notoriously undisciplined Congress, a task that the Government would prefer to tackle after the elections.
"It's a very, very slow mating dance," an official involved in the discussions said. "The Brazilians don't want to acknowledge that they need help, but they also don't want to risk a meltdown of their economy in the next few weeks."
Putting together a rescue package would almost certainly involve committing the last $15 billion left in the I.M.F.'s "emergency fuel tank," a fund called the General Agreement to Borrow. It is essentially a loan from the world's major economies, which used the same fund in July in a failed effort to prop up Russia.
Russia has used only $4.8 billion of the money it was promised, but billions more are committed to Moscow should it meet the I.M.F.'s conditions of collecting more taxes and keeping the money supply under control. So far, the new Russian Government, appointed just days ago, appears to be moving in the opposite direction.

No Plans for Coordinated Interest Rate Reductions
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said there were no plans for a coordinated interest rate reduction by the world's major powers. Investors had been hopeful that President Clinton's call on Monday for a concerted push to contain the fast-spreading economic crisis would lead to quick action to shore up the increasingly embattled economies of Latin America.
Talks between Brazil, the International Monetary Fund and the major industrial nations over a multibillion dollar rescue package also ran into difficulties. Page A1. 

Stocks Up for 4th Consecutive Day
Stocks rose for the fourth day, the longest string of consecutive gains since June. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 65.39 points, or eight-tenths of a percent, to 8,089.78. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 7.80 points, to 1,045.48, while the Nasdaq composite index increased 11.80 points, to 1,689.91. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 5.22 percent from 5.25. C8.
 
NBC Set to Cut 200 to 300 Workers
Robert C. Wright, the president of NBC, is expected to announce the layoff of 200 to 300 workers in all divisions of the network in a memorandum today. The reductions are between 4 percent and 5 percent of NBC's 6,500 employee work force. The cuts at NBC, a division of General Electric, follow moves by both CBS and ABC to cut costs. CBS hopes to save $180 million by cutting 200 to 300 employees. ABC has not ordered layoffs, but it is trying to reduce expenses. C6.
 
Japanese Reform Still Bogged Down
Japan does not seem to be closer to passing a landmark series of bills to stabilize its financial system. C4.
 
T.W.A. Chief Critical of Alliances
The chief executive of Trans World Airlines has denounced proposals by the country's six largest carriers to pair off into three alliances as "anti-competitive schemes" that the Government should block. C4.
 
F.D.A. Panel Backs Arthritis Drug
An advisory panel to the F.D.A. has recommended approval of Enbrel, a drug created by genetic engineering to treat rheumatoid arthritis. It is made by Immunex, a Seattle-based biotechnology company. A24.
 
Factory Production Jumped 1.7%
Production at American factories soared 1.7 percent in August, the biggest gain in more than 14 years, but virtually all of the strength reflected increased auto output after the strike at General Motors ended. Factory production was up one-tenth of a percent when auto output was excluded. July business inventories were unchanged. C23.

The Clinton Administration is relaxing export controls on data-scrambling technologies, despite the Justice Department's insistence that controls remain tight. C5.
 
Bayer Plans to Spin Off Imaging Unit
The German chemical company Bayer is expected to announce today that it is spinning off Agfa-Gevaert, its imaging unit. C4.
 
An Alliance for Netscape and Qwest
Netscape Communications and Qwest Communications International plan an alliance that will let consumers manage voice mail, E-mail and fax communications through a single site on the World Wide Web. C2.

LENGTH: 364 words

HEADLINE: Jump in Factory Output Is Linked to End of G.M. Strike

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
Production at American factories soared 1.7 percent in August, the biggest gain in more than 14 years, but virtually all of the strength reflected increased auto output after the end of the General Motors strike.
Other than that, production was up a much more modest one-tenth of a percent in August, less than the two-tenths of a percent July gain, the Federal Reserve reported today. 
 Economists believe the economy will grow much more slowly in the second half of this year, held down by a widening global financial crisis that has cut sharply into American companies' ability to sell overseas.
A survey of regional economies, also released today, indicates the crisis overseas has begun to hit some regions hard, particularly around Dallas and New York, according to the Fed. And consumers and businesses in some areas are beginning to express concerns about the economy's future, the survey found.
The Fed found growing signs that Asia's troubles are cutting into demand for American manufactured goods and depressing the prices that many farmers receive.
Despite those problems, the economy over all is continuing to expand at a moderate pace, the Fed said: Consumers continue to spend, prices continue to be low and the job market continues to be tight.
The Fed said the 1.7 percent jump in industrial production was the largest gain since a 2.1 percent surge in January 1984. The August increase followed back-to-back declines in production of 1.1 percent in June and four-tenths of a percent in July, the biggest setbacks in eight years.
The rebound in factory output reflected a 3.8 percent surge at manufacturing plants and a smaller, four-tenths of a percent rise in output at the nation's utilities. Output in the mining sector, which includes coal production and oil and gas drilling, dropped six-tenths of a percent in August. The big rise in output at auto plants meant that United States factories were operating at 81.7 percent of capacity in August, up from 80.6 percent in July.
In a separate report, the Commerce Department said the level of business inventories on shelves and backlots remained frozen in July for a third consecutive month.

GRAPHIC: Chart/Map: "Inflation at Bay; Economy Holds Amid Signs of Weakness"
A roundup of regional economic conditions in recent months for the Federal Reserve's 12 districts, according to the beige book report issued by the Fed yesterday.
 
Minneapolis -- Economic growth continued at a moderate pace. Concern about the future was expressed.
 
Chicago -- Manufacturing was mixed due to softening in foreign markets. Highway projects led brisk construction activity.
 
Cleveland -- Business activity remained strong and reported no inflation. Wages increased, some 20 percent since last year.
 
Boston -- Businesses reported growth. Inflation was generally level or declining. Worker shortages persisted.
 
New York -- Production slowed, except in construction and real estate. Lean inventories weakened retail sales.
 
Philadelphia -- Business improved slightly, but slower activity was reported in some sectors.
 
Richmond -- Economic growth moderated while auto sales, services, and manufacturing weakened.
 
Atlanta -- A weaker outlook was reported, despite recent economic growth. Retail sales improved.
 
St. Louis -- Strong chain-store and auto-dealer sales fed healthy economy. Housing and construction rose. Labor shortage persisted.
 
Kansas City -- Crop and manufactured material prices continued to decline due to new products and competition from Asia.
 
Dallas -- Economic activity decelerated. Manufacturing decreased. Overall sentiment weakened considerably.
 
San Francisco -- Commodity prices remained stable or fell. However, prices for some services rose noticeably. Real estate and construction were described as "vigorous," especially in California.

HEADLINE: Republicans See Chance To Push Their Agenda

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
Eager to appear focused on the people's business and not just on President Clinton's, Republicans are pushing ahead with their agenda of economic and social issues in Congress. Today's message, laid out by Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, was that projections of a big Federal budget surplus justified a tax cut.
"So long as there's a Republican majority," Mr. Archer said at a news conference, "we're going to have a tax cut every year." On Thursday, the Ways and Means Committee will vote on an $80 billion tax cut, and a number of Democrats have hinted that they will go along with the Republican plan. 
 Yet as they move ahead on an array of issues, Republicans remain wary of setting off ideological battles that would allow Mr. Clinton to shift the focus away from his own woes.
As the pressure on Mr. Clinton has mounted and attention on Capitol Hill has been riveted on questions of impeachment, Republicans have pledged to press for action on tax cuts, the budget, abortion, drug use and national security, all with an eye to exploiting the Administration's weakness without provoking a political or popular backlash.
In part, they said, they were motivated by a desire to avoid appearing overly partisan as the House considers impeachment hearings. But they also said voters wanted them to have a positive message heading into this fall's elections and not just to capitalize on Mr. Clinton's problems.
"The best way to expand our majority is to do the business of the people, not to expect the problems of the Democratic side to carry us forward," said Senator John Ashcroft of Missouri. "Their liabilities are not necessarily our assets."
The way the Republicans handle their legislative agenda in the weeks before Congress adjourns is likely to determine how much opportunity Mr. Clinton has to change the subject or put Republicans on the defensive. Most obviously, Republicans will have to decide whether to risk a showdown over their spending priorities and a repetition of the Government shutdown in 1995 and early 1996 that played out to Mr. Clinton's tremendous political benefit.
While some Republicans in Congress want to press as hard as possible at a time when the White House is struggling to stay politically relevant, other Republicans are counseling restraint, saying the party should compromise and avoid ideological battles that Mr. Clinton could use to rally his core Democratic base.
"There's the view that says that from a political standpoint things seem to be breaking in the direction of the Republicans and we should not engage in efforts to pursue our policy agenda that are not consensual and should let the election be about the President and his conduct," said Representative David M. McIntosh of Indiana.
"Then there's the argument that the American people want us to do our job on the Starr report, but they really want us to do our job on cutting taxes, balancing the budget and maintaining a strong national defense," Mr. McIntosh said. "People are evenly split between those two views."
Mr. McIntosh said he came down on the side of pursuing an ambitious agenda, although not to the point of shutting down the Government over differences with Mr. Clinton about spending priorities for the new fiscal year that starts on Oct. 1.
A memorandum circulating among Republican members of Congress last week from Frank Luntz, a consultant who is influential with many conservatives, said Mr. Clinton was much weaker than during battles over changing the health care system in 1994 and balancing the budget in 1995.
But Mr. Luntz said shutting down the Government over spending bills would be going too far, with voters saying they would blame Republicans rather than Mr. Clinton, by a margin of 42 percent to 32 percent, if such a showdown occurred.
Still, Republicans said, Mr. Clinton's troubles have created new opportunities for legislative victories. Republicans said they now had a realistic hope of passing a substantial tax cut this year, believing that Mr. Clinton had lost some of his ability to convince voters that a tax cut, by dipping into projected Federal budget surpluses, would endanger the future of the ailing Social Security system.
Until Mr. Clinton's situation started deteriorating in the last week, most Republicans viewed their tax-cutting effort this year primarily as a way to force Democrats to cast votes that could be used against them on the campaign trail this fall.
"Now the Democrats see a President who's losing his voice," said a House Republican aide. "For Democrats who are caught in a squeeze about voting for a popular tax cut, they have to decide whether to vote with their district or hope that the President can scare people by demagoguing Social Security."
White House officials said the assumption that the President's power and influence were in terminal decline vastly overstated his loss of ability to shape the outcomes of many policy disputes. And with the country still likely to face crises having nothing to do with Mr. Clinton's sex life, they said Mr. Clinton would play as central a role as ever.
"He still has the veto pen," said a senior Administration official. "He still has the microphone."
Along with taxes, the biggest policy fights in coming weeks will be over the spending bills that Congress must pass to finance the Government's operation in the new fiscal year that starts Oct. 1. Mr. Clinton issued veto threats against many of the bills during the summer, objecting both to the spending levels for many programs and to language dictating the way some programs are run.
But although they said they would almost certainly not allow the Government to be shut down -- Congress can pass temporary spending measures if Mr. Clinton should veto any of the appropriations bills -- Republicans said they might prove less willing to compromise than if the President was not fighting for his survival.
For their part, Democrats said Mr. Clinton's limited ability to rally support could thwart any chance of getting their legislative initiatives through this year.
Already, they said, the President's problems have left them with little hope of mounting a last-ditch effort to push new regulations on health maintenance organizations through the Senate this year.

HEADLINE: NEWS WATCH;
Computer Buyers' Ranks Keep Getting Broader

BYLINE: By Matt Richtel 

 BODY:
A new survey indicates that 1999 will bring a marked shift in who first-time home computer buyers will be. The study, by Forrester Research of Cambridge, Mass., found that low-income households, defined as those earning less than $35,000 a year, would become the leading source of first-time home computer purchasers.
Among those first-time buyers, only 37 percent will have attended college and 59 percent will be women, the study concluded. 
 Those figures run counter to the stereotype of a computer buyer as an affluent man with enough graduate degrees to wallpaper the inside of his Lexus. But the Forrester survey indicated that in contrast with first-time buyers, the majority of repeat home computer buyers in 1999 would be men and that 65 percent of them would have attended college.
Shelley Morrisette, a co-author of the study, said two factors behind the demographic shift were a drop in the price of home computers, which has made them more affordable for people with lower incomes, and the simple fact that a growing number of Americans want to own a computer. "People may not know what the Net is, but they know something is out there and it seems to be exciting," Mr. Morrisette said.
Meanwhile, he cautions computer makers and Internet access companies that they will have to be ready to deal with consumers who know little about technology. Forrester reports that 72 percent of first-time buyers do not use a computer at work, a shift away from more technologically adept consumers of the past. Translation: tech support budgets will need to rise, he said.
"The downside is these people are going to require a whole lot of hand-holding," Mr. Morrisette said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
STOCK SLUMPS ON SALESOUTLOOK FOR THIRD QUARTER

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Shares of the Gillette Company fell 10 percent yesterday as the company, the razor blade maker, said its third-quarter sales would be lower than a year earlier because of the economic problems in Asia and Latin America. Shares of Gillette dropped $4.8125, to $40.1875, in trading of almost 14.4 million shares. It was the stock's biggest one-day drop in 11 years. Gillette gets a third of its revenue outside the United States and Western Europe from sales of its razors, Duracell batteries, Papermate pens and other products. Third-quarter earnings will probably be lower than expected as international demand drops and falling currencies generate fewer dollars from local sales.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Survey of Businesses Assesses Connecticut

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Business owners think Connecticut is a good place to do business, but high costs, a lack of skilled workers and looming preparations for the year 2000 pose obstacles to further growth, a survey for a business group showed.
In the survey, conducted by the Connecticut Business and Industry Association and the accounting firm Arthur Andersen, 62 percent of small and midsize businesses said they would expand or relocate in Connecticut instead of moving to another state. Last year, 54 percent of businesses surveyed said they would stay, the association said yesterday. 
 Of the businesses surveyed, 58 percent said their profits had risen since last year and 69 percent said they thought their profits would rise this year.
The strong business growth has benefited workers, the survey said. About 77 percent of business owners said they were paying their employees more this year than last year, and 72 percent said they expected wages, bonuses or other compensation to increase over the next year.
The survey was done in June and included results from 594 companies with between 5 and 500 employees. The association said that about half of the state's work force was employed at such small and midsize companies.
The business survey was released the day after a Hartford-based think tank said the state's poverty rate increased to 11.7 percent in 1996, the most recent year for which statistics were available, from 9.4 percent in 1992. The think tank, the Connecticut Policy and Economic Council, said those poverty figures could hurt Connecticut's economic competitiveness.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Ice Cream Factory to Close

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Baskin-Robbins Inc. has notified 78 workers that it will close its ice cream factory in Southbury, Conn., by the end of the year.
The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which represents the plant workers, has scheduled a rally for today in an effort to keep the plant open. 
 The employees received letters in their paychecks last week notifying them that ice cream production will end Nov. 4, although distribution will continue through the end of the year.
The State Department of Economic and Community Development has offered to work with the company in an effort to keep the plant in operation, said Chris Cooper, a department spokesman.
Allied Domecq, a British liquor conglomerate that owns Baskin-Robbins, has told state officials that the plant is too inefficient to continue operation, the Waterbury Republican-American reported on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Serbs in Bosnia Appear to Shun Favorite of U.S.

BYLINE: By MIKE O'CONNOR 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Sept. 16

 BODY:
A key player in American strategy in Bosnia, the Bosnian Serb leader Biljana Plavsic, appears to have been voted out of office in the elections last weekend, according to international officials who are monitoring preliminary results.
Mrs. Plavsic, president of the Serbian republic in Bosnia, was apparently defeated by Nikola Poplasen, the officials say. Mr. Poplasen, the leader of the Serb Radical Party, is considered an extreme nationalist, and his election would be a clear repudiation of Western goals of integrating Serbs, Croats and Muslims in Bosnia. 
 "If Poplasen has won, it means the Bosnian Serbs are telling the West, 'We don't care about you or your money or your quaint ideas about reconciliation with Muslims and Croats,' " said a European diplomat, who termed the unofficial results "staggering."
Results for the Bosnian Serb legislature indicate that moderates may be able to hold their slight majority. Officials said that major races in the other half of Bosnia, the Muslim-Croat Federation, were too close to call, but that the Muslim leader, Alija Izetbegovic, was certain to be returned to the federation's three-member presidency.
The Western strategy of isolating nationalists and supporting moderate politicians was taken the furthest with Mrs. Plavsic, whom Western leaders have praised extravagantly for more than a year and whose Bosnian Serb republic was saved from economic chaos by Western aid.
She rose to the Bosnian Serb presidency two years ago as an ally of her predecessor, Radovan Karadzic, who stepped down under pressure from NATO after his indictment on war crimes charges. But once in office, she broke with Dr. Karadzic and hard-line associates of his whom she accused of corruption.
Mrs. Plavsic was then identified as a leader with nationalist credentials who could be persuaded that if she acted more moderately, she and her people would benefit from Western aid and acceptance.
The strategy was to strengthen her and use her to break the control that hard-core nationalists had over the half of Bosnia that the 1992-95 war left almost exclusively Serbian.
The strategy seemed to be working. Mrs. Plavsic won a majority in the republic's legislature and was able to gain control over most government ministries. Gradually, the hostility between the Bosnian Serb republic and the Muslim-Croat federation lessened.
But the unofficial results of the election seem to show that Bosnian Serbs are still very fearful of Muslims and Croats, and mistrustful of the West.
"The West offered an implicit deal to the Bosnian Serb people," said a senior European diplomat. "The deal was: Life will get much better for you. You won't be an isolated, hated gang on the edge of Europe. You can keep this thing called the Serb republic if that makes you feel better, even though it is the bankrupt half of a poor country. But in return you have to start thinking like modern Europeans.
"It looks as if they have rejected that deal, and things are going to get bad for them and for us."
A European official in the Bosnian Serb republic said he expected most European countries to scale back or end aid projects there.
"How can we possibly justify doing otherwise if a man like Poplasen is in charge?" he said. "Let them have a year or two of suffering to see if they change their minds."
There are about one million voters in the Bosnian Serb republic, and officials said that with up to 80 percent of the votes counted, Mr. Poplasen was ahead by 40,000 votes. "It is not impossible for him to lose," said a Western official monitoring the returns, "but given the consistency of the results as they are coming in, it is almost impossible."
Western diplomats thought Mrs. Plavsic would get a wave of support in the form of absentee ballots from among the 200,000 Muslims who were expelled from what is now the Bosnian Serb republic during the war. But perhaps as a sign that many Muslim refugees still feel too battered by the war to vote in a way that might benefit them, international officials said, they apparently remembered that Mrs. Plavsic used to be one of the ideologues of Bosnian Serb nationalism and passed up the chance to keep her in office.
"There are very few Muslims who could tick a box next to her name," one foreign official said.

Results Incomplete, U.S. Notes
 WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (Reuters) -- The final outcome of many races in the Bosnian elections hinge on the ballots not yet counted, the State Department said today. The deputy spokesman, James Foley, said the United States accepted as prudent a decision by international monitors not to release preliminary results on Tuesday as planned.
The ballots counted are those cast at polling stations and represent 85 percent of the 2.4 million people who voted in the two sectors of Bosnia. The remainder covers 132,000 absentee ballots and about 200,000 ballots cast by displaced Bosnian voters at stations where they are not registered, Mr. Foley said. "We do not know who may have won," he said, "and this will not be known until the other 15 percent of the votes have been counted and validated."
 

CORRECTION-DATE: September 19, 1998, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about elections in Bosnia and Herzegovina referred incorrectly to the office held by Alija Izetbegovic. He is one of the three members of the country's presidency, not the president of the Muslim-Croat Federation, a constituent part of Bosnia that is led by a prime minister.

ATTRACTIONS
 
Museums and Sites
 
AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West at 79th Street. The Hall of Biodiversity focuses on the variety and interdependence of earth's living things. "Spirits in Steel: The Art of the Kalabari Masquerade" features 13 steel sculptures by Sokari Douglas Camp, drawing on themes from her homeland in Nigeria, and 25 Nigerian masks from the museum's collection. "Cave of the Warrior" exhibits rare funerary objects from an intact burial site about 6,000 years old in the Judean desert near Jericho. On view through Dec. 6. "Rare Beauty: America's Endangered Plants," large-format photographs of endangered plants in bloom by Maryl Levine. Through Oct. 4. The Imax films are "Cosmic Voyage" and "Amazon." In the Imax Theater on Friday and Saturday nights at 9, "U2 in 3-D" and at 10, "Pink Floyd's 'Dark Side of the Moon' " in 3-D. Tickets: $9. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 A.M. to 5:45 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 8:45 P.M. Suggested admission: $8; students and the elderly, $6; children 12 and under, $4.50; under 2, free. A combination ticket including museum admission and one film: $12; students and the elderly, $8.50; children 12 and under, $6.50; under 2, free. Information: (212) 769-5100; to buy tickets by phone: (212) 769-5200. 

AMERICAN NUMISMATIC SOCIETY, Audubon Terrace, Broadway at 155th Street, Washington Heights. The society has the most extensive coin collection in North America; its library is open to the public. On permanent display is "American Numismatic Design, 1892-1922," which includes all coins issued during this period. Also on view is "The World of Coins," a history since 600 B.C. Free. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 9 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 4 P.M. Information: (212) 234-3130.
 
 MUSEUM OF JEWISH HERITAGE: A LIVING MEMORIAL TO THE HOLOCAUST, 18 First Place, at West Street and Battery Place, Battery Park City. Artifacts, documents, photographs, videos and film clips are included in exhibitions on the Holocaust and on Jewish life before and after World War II. Exhibitions include "Jewish Life a Century Ago," with memorabilia from Jewish rituals and celebrations in Europe in the early 1900's; "War Against the Jews," detailing events from 1933 to 1945, and "Jewish Renewal," focusing on life after the Holocaust. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Thursdays, 9 A.M. to 8 P.M.; Fridays and the eves of Jewish holidays, 9 A.M. to 2 P.M.; closed Saturdays. Admission: $7; students and the elderly, $5; 5 and under, free. Some same-day tickets are available at the museum; because of heavy attendance, tickets may be purchased in advance through Ticketmaster: (212) 307-4007. Information: (212) 968-1800.
 
 NEW YORK CITY FIRE MUSEUM, 278 Spring Street, SoHo. In a renovated 1904 firehouse, a collection of fire-related art and artifacts from the 18th century to the present, including a fire engine, hose wagons, hats, toys, paintings, memorabilia and hand-drawn pumpers. Also, an exhibition, "Fire Marks: Emblems of Insurance," features 18th- and 19th-century British and American fire marks from the museum's collection. Insurance agencies would give bonuses to firefighters when they saved the premises of a policyholder. The decorative emblems were used to distinguish policyholders from the uninsured. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Suggested admission: $4 for adults; $2 for students and the elderly; $1 for children under 12. Information: (212) 691-1303.
