HEADLINE: Inside Art;
The Hermitage Gets Some Help

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:
The State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg is so beloved in this country that a group called the American Friends of the Hermitage is presenting the museum's director, Mikhail B. Piotrovsky, with a $100,000 gift when he comes to New York next week for the opening of "Master Drawings From the Hermitage and Pushkin Museums," at the Morgan Library.
The gift will go toward the formation of a new decorative arts department at the Hermitage, the first new department to be established there since 1852. In it the Hermitage plans to display its extraordinary collection of furniture, porcelains, costumes and other decorative artifacts, which have been languishing in storage for lack of exhibition space. 
 But just how far can $100,000 go?
"We need millions," said Dr. Piotrovsky in a telephone interview. "This is part of a larger project which we are calling 'The Great Hermitage.' "
If the project proceeds as planned, the museum will expand significantly, moving its precious collection of Impressionist and post-Impressionist paintings, along with its sculpture, costumes, arms and armor, jewelry and decorative arts collections, into what is called the General Staff Building, a sprawling neo-classical structure directly opposite the Winter Palace in Palace Square, where the Hermitage is located. Dr. Piotrovsky said the project should cost more than $150 million.
The Russian Government owns the building and has agreed to give it to the museum. And so the Hermitage is accepting proposals from developers, becoming involved in feasibility studies and looking for private support. A Russian bank that has survived the recent financial crisis has promised to help, Dr. Piotrovsky said. He added that he was planning to hold an architectural competition for the renovation of the building.
The director also envisions transforming the entire square, including the General Staff Building, into an arts complex with interactive displays, theater, cafes and shops.
"The idea is to make this the center of cultural life here," he said.
Dr. Piotrovsky admits that the museum's original building is antiquated and not up to the highest standards in areas like climate control. But he is determined to think beyond the immediate future.
"If we just try to cover the holes, we will never move forward," he said, adding that the museum also hopes to make improvements in the Winter Palace. "So far we have donations for a new roof and improved lighting. But we have big visions. We are working in all directions."
The museum plans to hold some temporary exhibitions in the new building some time next year.
 
 Two for Sotheby's
 Sotheby's has been on a roll recently.
Earlier this week the auction house obtained about $100 million worth of Impressionist and modern art owned by the Reader's Digest Association. The collection, which includes major paintings and sculptures by Monet, Cezanne, Matisse, van Gogh, Modigliani and Giacometti, was amassed by the company's founders, Lila Acheson Wallace and her husband, DeWitt Wallace. It is to be sold on Nov. 16.
In addition, the auction house has been chosen to sell modern art from the collection of Mr. and Mrs. Morton G. Neumann. Mr. Neumann, who died in 1985, was a Chicago industrialist who, with his wife, Rose, began buying art in the late 1940's. Over the years, they amassed works by Picasso, Miro, Dubuffet, Klee, Giacometti and other artists.
In 1980 the National Gallery of Art in Washington devoted an entire exhibition to the Neumann collection, in the hopes of being given some of the art. But when Mrs. Neumann died earlier this year, the works went to the Neumann family, who chose to sell 27 pieces, expected to bring in between $16 million and $23 million.
The sale is to be held as part of Sotheby' contemporary art sale on Nov. 17.
By far the star of the collection is a Cubist Picasso, "Nude" (1909), which depicts the artist's mistress Fernande Olivier wrapped in a cloth, and is expected to sell for $10 million to $15 million. It had been on loan to the National Gallery in Washington for the last 10 years.
 
Gallery Is Closing
When "Kenneth Noland Circles" closes at the Andre Emmerich Gallery on Oct. 17, so will the 45-year-old gallery, at 41 East 57th Street. Two years ago, Sotheby's bought the gallery and made its staff Sotheby's employees, saying at the time that the gallery would remain open under Mr. Emmerich's direction.
But last year, when Sotheby's bought 50 percent of Deitch Projects, the SoHo gallery started by Jeffrey Deitch, Mr. Deitch was put in charge of Sotheby's 20th-century art program, which included overseeing the Andre Emmerich Gallery. (Mr. Emmerich was made a senior adviser.) And now Sotheby's is closing the gallery.
"In an effort to consolidate our business operations we are moving everything to Deitch Projects on Grand Street," said Matthew Weigman, a spokesman for Sotheby's. "Meanwhile, we are looking at possible spaces to hold exhibitions downtown."
 
Change at Guggenheim
Peter B. Lewis, president and chief executive officer of Progressive Corporation, the Cleveland-based auto insurance company, has been named chairman of the board of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, which administers five Guggenheim museum sites worldwide. Mr. Lewis, a foundation trustee since 1993, succeeds Peter Lawson-Johnston, who will become the foundation's honorary chairman.
In April, Mr. Lewis gave the Guggenheim a cash pledge of $50 million, one of the largest cash gifts ever made to any visual arts institution and the largest the Guggenheim, founded in 1937, has ever received.
"This strengthens our leadership a lot and gives us a powerful triumvirate," said Thomas Krens, the Guggenheim's director, referring to Mr. Lewis, Mr. Lawson-Johnston and Ronald O. Perelman, the foundation's president since 1995.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
A Great Chinese Leap Into a New Sort of Cultural Revolution

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:
China has changed more quickly and radically in the past few decades than at almost any time in its history. Video installations are being produced in cramped Beijing apartments. Gender-bending performances are taking place in out-of-the-way spots. Calligraphy, that most venerated art, is being put to perverse, absurdist ends. A brash Pop Art is tipping every sacred cow in sight, from Maoist ideology to Western market culture.
Yet scant evidence of this work has found its way to New York. Only a few public institutions -- the Bronx Museum of the Arts, the Alternative Museum, the New Museum of Contemporary Art -- have stayed on top of the news. And commercial galleries have just begun to play catch-up, mostly with samplings of Pop-oriented work. Last year's show at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, "China: 5,000 Years," might have been a watershed. The show was supposed to include 20th-century vanguard work, as an integral part of a historical picture of Chinese culture, but at the last minute the museum canceled that section. Responding to accusations that it was kowtowing to the Chinese Government, the museum said a lack of space prompted the change. 
 But this fall the Asia Society has come to the rescue with "Inside Out: New Chinese Art," an ambitious and stimulating selection of experimental work from the mid-1980's to the present. Spread over two locations -- the Asia Society and the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City, Queens -- the exhibition includes more than 60 artists from mainland China, Taiwan and Hong Kong, as well as from the United States and Europe.
The stylistic range of the material, from ink paintings to videos, is daunting; the messages complex and contradictory enough to defy any ready cultural translation. Attention to the exhibition's wall texts is recommended, and even a little knowledge of China's recent political history, which has done so much to shape its art, will go a long way.
With the Cultural Revolution, which began in 1966, traditional forms like ink painting, long associated with an intellectual elite, and Western modernism were suppressed in favor of Soviet-style Socialist Realism. Both styles were revived when the Maoist era ended in 1976. And with the development in the 1980's of a market economy, already in place in Taiwan and Hong Kong, experimental art flourished.
That robust trend culminated in a huge exhibition at the National Gallery in Beijing in February 1989, titled "China/Avant Garde." But just then the political winds were shifting. The show was closed twice by the Government; the Tiananmen Square crackdown came a few months later. Some artists left the country; others went underground.
The organizer of that show, the critic and art historian Gao Minglu, is also the curator of "Inside Out." Working with Colin Mackenzie, the assistant director of the Asia Society, and Gary Garrels, a curator at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, he has assembled a bracingly eclectic sampling of work arranged loosely by genre or geography.
A good place to begin is at the Asia Society, where a gathering of Pop-inspired paintings opens, appropriately enough, with a triple portrait of Mao Zedong. This 1988 work by Wang Guangyi, an early exponent of Political Pop, is rendered in the blandly realistic style, though in each panel his face is painted over with a black grid.
This irreverent approach to an icon who is still a tremendous presence in Chinese culture caused a sensation when it was exhibited at the Beijing show. But as with so much Chinese work, the attitudes it embodies are elusive, oblique and mutable. Is Mao-behind-bars a prison warden or a captive? A symbol of harsh, bitter experience or of a lost innocence?
Whatever the answer, one certainly picks up the impression of idealism fading fast in the paintings that surround it, and in those produced after 1989, the pessimism seems to deepen. Few if any clear references are made to the Tiananmen catastrophe, but the disorienting impact of a new consumerist economy is evident.
A second painting by Wang Guangyi, a high-colored Warholian concoction from 1993, catches the brittle, black-humor mood. The picture's titanic proletarian figures are lifted straight from Marxist propaganda posters, but are here accompanied by a sleekly calligraphic Coca-Cola logo. In a stroke, two ostensibly irreconcilable though avidly self-promoting ideologies are combined in a style that the show's curator calls Double Kitsch.
The same dynamic is at work elsewhere. In a 1990 painting by Wang Jinsong, middle-class Chinese tourists in Western clothes pose and preen at the Tiananeman gate, where Mao declared the founding of the People's Republic. And in a tragical-comical-historical exercise titled "Tower of the Century" (1996), by Su Xinping, Mao joins peasants, clerks and bathing beauties in a frantic scramble to get to the top of some undefined societal heap.
Another recent pop style, dubbed Cynical Realism, uses grotesque scenarios to indict a society on the slide. But the most memorable pictures defy easy labels. Mao Xuhui's hermetic vision of his windowless apartment looking as pink and moist as an internal organ is one. Another is Zhang Xiaogang's painting of a blank-faced couple holding their infant child. Father and son both wear Mao badges, and all three figures are linked by thin catheters carrying arterial blood in a cross-generational transfusion that suggests both nurturing and depletion.
Pop painting like this has garnered much attention of late; some critics have grumbled that its main purpose is to appeal to an international market. But Chinese art has never run on a single track and it certainly doesn't in this exhibition, in which painting proves to be a multifaceted medium.
In a section devoted to ink-and-brush work at P.S. 1, for example, the artists Fang Tu, Yan Binghui and Zhang Yu explore the delicate line between landscape and abstraction. And in a room-filling ink scroll by Ren Jian titled "Primeval Chaos" (1986-87), the time-honored mountain-and-stream motif is turned into a mutating universe of fantastic grandeur.
A mix of Dada and Chan (Zen) Buddhism reigns in the work of the conceptual artist Huang Yong Ping, who lives in Paris and was short-listed for this year's Hugo Boss Prize. In a piece recreated from the 1980's, he responds to the Chinese faith in the expressive power of the artist's hand with a roulette-wheel method for composing paintings entirely by chance. (Zhang Peili, another influential early figure, is also included in the conceptual-art section of the show.)
Calligraphy, from which Chinese painting stems, and language are similarly challenged and transformed. Wenda Gu and Xu Bing, who live in New York City, contribute spectacular installations based on invented scripts and words. Wu Shan Zhuan, a Beijing artist, plasters a room with political texts, Buddhist scripture and advertising slogans to create a disjunctive found poetry. And Qiu Zhijie copies a passage of classical calligraphy 1,000 times on a piece of paper, blackening the page in a cultural homage that is also an act of obliteration.
Among the several disciplines that Mr. Qiu's piece touches on is performance art, which finds many exponents in the show. Most of their work is represented by photo-documentation, though two provocative figures, Zhang Huan and Ma Liuming, are scheduled to make appearances at P.S. 1 on Oct. 18.
The androgyny that Mr. Ma projects in his nude performances typify an infusion of overtly sexual content in recent Chinese work, very much against the puritanical Maoist grain. It shows up not only in paintings, but also in homoerotic videos by the Long-Tailed Elephant Group (Xu Tan, Chen Shaoxiong, Liang Juhui and Lin Yilin) and in the X-rated soundtrack for an installation of Cultural Revolution-era wedding pictures by Wang Peng.
Mr. Wang's multimedia piece appears in a section at P.S. 1 devoted to "apartment art," a label for underground work made and exhibited in artists' homes. The results are often modest in scale, portable (as is an ephemeral installation by Liu Xiangdong and a series of Buddhist-inspired photographs by Song Dong) or, in some cases, composed of domestic materials.
Such is the case with work by two of the exhibition's few women. One of them, Lin Tian-miao, wraps everyday kitchen utensils in endless layers of twine. The other, Yin Xiuzhen, who is a high school teacher as well as an artist, has unraveled yarn from two piles of mass-produced sweaters, one made for men, the other for women, and re-knitted them into unisex garments.
All but one of the other women in the show are from Taiwan. (The exception is Phoebe Man, who also goes by Man Ching Ying, from Hong Kong.) They include Yuan Jai, at 60 the show's senior contributor, who gives traditional floral scroll painting a Cubist twist; Chen Hui-chiao, with an installation of roses pierced with acupuncture needles, and Wu Mali, whose installation in the second-floor gallery at the Asia Society uses text and video to turn a tragic moment in Taiwan's history into a feminist lament.
The distinctive quality of Taiwanese work was explored last year in a New York show organized by the late art historian Alice Yang, and it is borne out here. One sees the influence of local folk art and myth in the raucous figurative paintings of Hou Chun-ming and Huang Chih-yang. Wu Tien-chang's portraits surrounded by kitschy light-up frames are reminders of Taiwan's Western ties, while Chen Shun-chu's collection of hundreds of photos of family and friends underscores the desire of an island culture to confirm a rooted identity.
Self-identity is also a force behind Hong Kong's avant-garde, which was galvanized by the colony's shift to Chinese control last year. And much of the art on view -- an installation by Kum Chi-keung of mechanized birds flying between cages; a video by Ho Siu-kee of the artist balancing precariously atop two rubber balls; a set of ornamental boxes labeled "gifts from China" by Danny Ning Tsun Yung -- seems to be a direct response to that event.
And "seems to be" is an essential qualifier in the context of this show. Nothing is simple; apparently straightforward pieces carry specific histories, meanings and emotions that are difficult for outsiders to access. But visual delights abound and they speak for themselves: from an ornamental robe cast in translucent plastic by Wang Jin to Hong Hao's daft transcultural guidebook for 21st-century life to an installation by Cai Guo-qiang in which a full-size fishing boat, bristling with arrows, floats in midair.
There is a story behind Mr. Cai's piece, explained in a wall text, and suffice it to say, the work's ingredients of myth, humor, global consciousness and possibly nostalgia create an arresting but unanswering blend. The same can be said of this tip-of-the-iceberg show as a whole. By design, it represents only one side of contemporary work in China (traditional art forms are still practiced), and it poses as many questions as answers. But there is no question that it is a benchmark achievement on which future exhibitions will build.

HEADLINE: U.S. Cites Lower Bank Loan Standards

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Banks are exposing themselves to increased levels of risk as 1998 loan underwriting standards declined for the fourth consecutive year, a Federal regulator said today.
The slackening standards were led by commercial loans that typically make up 55 percent to 60 percent of a bank's balance sheet. 
 "Banks are leaving themselves with fewer options to control the risk associated with commercial lending should the economy falter," the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency said.
The annual survey of Office of the Comptroller of the Currency examiners at the 77 largest banks taken in the second quarter found easier commercial loan standards at 69 percent of banks compared with 59 percent in 1997.
"Examiners said they expect the level of risk inherent in bank loan portfolios to increase over the next 12 months," the survey found.
Edward Kelley, a Federal Reserve governor, said loans that were appropriate during good times might not be appropriate if the economy soured.
"We have to be careful as this expansion is now seven years old," Mr. Kelley said after a Congressional hearing on year 2000 computer problems in the banking industry.
The office said there was pronounced easing of standards in syndicated loans, middle-market lending and real estate portfolios.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Stage a Rally As Investors Seek Safe Havens

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices rallied yesterday as investors sold stocks and sought the safety of United States Government securities.
The 30-year bond rose 22/32 , to 104 29/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, dropped to 5.18 percent, from 5.22 percent on Wednesday. 
 In the last three months the 30-year bond's yield has fallen more than half a percentage point, or 50 basis points, as global stock markets tumble, Russia's economy falters and investors grow more concerned that the financial crisis might spread to Brazil. They are now at their lowest level in 30 years. (A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.)
Bonds were bolstered by a Government report showing that consumer prices were little changed during August and a regional Federal Reserve survey indicating that manufacturing activity is beginning to slow.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said, "The rally in the bond market continues, spurred by increasing evidence of an economic slackening, a continued auspicious inflation outlook, a flight to quality resulting from declining stock prices, and the growing market perception that a near-term Fed easing move is clearly on the horizon."
He said that testimony by the chairman of the Fed to the House Banking Committee on Tuesday did not add much to previous comments about the vulnerability of the nation to the global crisis, nor shed any light on whether the policy-making group will change interest rates when it meets Sept. 29. Mr. Fine predicted that at that meeting the Federal Open Market Committee will adopt a bias toward easing from a neutral stance. Whenever the Federal funds rate, which has remained at 5.50 percent since March 1997, is lowered, Mr. Fine said it would in all likelihood be a 25-basis-point cut, as the Fed tends to move slowly.
In the junk-bond market, the Cal energy Company, an electricity generation and distribution company, sold $1.4 billion of senior notes in four parts, breaking a monthlong drought of new sales in the junk-bond market.

HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Deficit Widens; Consumer Prices Up 0.2%

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
The trade deficit widened 2 percent in July as exports fell for the fourth consecutive month, while consumer prices changed little in August, Government figures released today showed.
Those findings, together with two other reports that showed a decline in jobless claims and a rise in workers' incomes, suggested that -- outside of a slowdown in manufacturing -- the economy was holding up well in its eighth year of expansion, analysts said. 
 "There's enough momentum to keep the economy going despite the weakness in manufacturing," said Cynthia Latta, an economist at Standard & Poor's DRI in Lexington, Mass.
The Commerce Department said today that the trade deficit in goods and services grew to $13.9 billion in July after having narrowed in June to a revised $13.6 billion. Exports fell 1.3 percent, to $75.4 billion, the lowest level since February 1997, reflecting a drop in shipments of auto parts, industrial supplies and consumer goods. Imports fell eight-tenths of 1 percent, to $89.3 billion, the lowest since November, as purchases of autos, foods and industrial supplies declined -- and prices paid for imports of crude oil dropped to their lowest level since 1986.
In a separate report, the Labor Department said that consumer prices rose only two-tenths of 1 percent last month, the same as the July increase, as higher apparel prices were almost offset by a decline in gasoline costs. In the first eight months this year, consumer prices rose at a 1.6 percent annual rate, the same as in the first eight months of 1997.
Another report today showed that 299,000 workers filed for state unemployment benefits last week, down from 314,000 a week earlier, in part because government offices were closed for the Labor Day holiday on Sept. 7.
Workers' average weekly earnings, adjusted for inflation, rose half a percent in August, the Labor Department said, suggesting that there was little reason to expect a falloff in consumer spending. The increase in August was bigger than July's gain of one-tenth of 1 percent and was the largest since May.
Today's trade report showed that the deficit stood at $92.5 billion in the year's first seven months, up from $63.24 billion a year earlier. For all of last year, the deficit was $110.21 billion. At the current pace, the trade shortfall for all of 1998 is on target to reach $158.6 billion, exceeding the record $153.3 billion in 1987.
The deficit with China, a major source of clothing and household products for American consumers, increased to $5.42 billion in July and exceeded the deficit with Japan for the first time since September 1997.
The merchandise deficit with Japan, the United States's second-biggest commercial partner behind Canada, narrowed to $5.17 billion in July from $5.25 billion in June, as exports grew at a faster pace than imports.
The deficit with Hong Kong, Singapore, Taiwan and South Korea rose to $2.62 billion in July from $2.41 billion in June and $806 million in July 1997.
The deficit with Western Europe increased to a record $5.12 billion in July. The deficit with Canada increased to $1.91 billion.
The inflation report showed that energy prices, which account for about one-tenth of the Consumer Price Index, fell 1 percent in August. Energy prices were unchanged in July.
Apparel costs increased 1.1 percent in August, the largest rise since a 1.5 percent gain in March 1990, as clothing retailers introduced fall and winter merchandise.
Food prices, which make up about one-fifth of the index, increased two-tenths of 1 percent in August, the same as in July. Transportation costs were unchanged, housing costs rose one-tenth of 1 percent, medical-care costs grew four-tenths of 1 percent and new-car prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent.
The slowdown in Asia has helped curtail demand for most raw materials and driven prices down. The Commodity Research Bureau index, which tracks the prices of 17 commodities, fell in August to the lowest level in nearly 21 years.
That has been a boon to consumers in this country because domestic companies are better able to hold the line or even reduce prices for the merchandise they sell.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Declines by216.01 as Part of a Global Downturn

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Stock prices tumbled around the world yesterday after overseas investors digested word that central banks are planning no coordinated cut in interest rates to quell financial and economic turmoil in Asia, Latin America and Russia.
The prospect of the release of President Clinton's videotaped grand jury testimony in the Monica S. Lewinsky matter and Japanese banking problems also weighed on stock markets, which skidded to a 12 1/2-year low in Tokyo and finished nearly 5 percent lower in Brazil after a plunge twice that much halted trading. 
 Foreign turmoil quickly spread to the United States, where the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 200 points in the first half-hour before steadying for the rest of the day. It closed down 216.01 points, or 2.67 percent, to 7,873.77. The loss broke a string of four straight gains, the first since late June, and pushed the blue-chip indicator back into negative territory for the year.
Although Wall Street seemed only mildly disappointed when Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, told Congress on Wednesday afternoon that there were no current efforts to coordinate an interest-rate cut, overseas markets reacted by selling off sharply, and this pressure spilled over into the United States markets.
Some analysts here said they thought Mr. Greenspan, along with the Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, had sought to avoid comments that could have reduced pressure on the House to approve $18 billion to replenish depleted aid coffers at the International Monetary Fund.
The House refused to consider the full amount anyway. Instead, it approved only $3.4 billion.
Sooner or later, predicted Alfred E. Goldman, chief market strategist at A. G. Edwards in St. Louis, "The I.M.F. will get their funding. We have no choice."
Still another factor affecting trading was today's quarterly "triple witching" phenomenon, when options and futures contracts expire.
European markets slumped across the board, but the greatest fall was in France, where the CAC 40 index fell 5.47 percent after Alcatel, the communications giant, warned of lower profits, citing the crises in Asia and Russia. Shares dived 12 1/16 , to 19 1/4, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Leading indexes tumbled 4.99 percent in Germany and 3 percent in London, also reflecting fears of lost business with economically distressed countries.
In Japan, the Nikkei index fell 338.56 points, or 2.38 percent, to 13,859.14, its lowest point since March 1986. Government leaders worked deep into the night to find a way to reorganize the debt-laden Japanese banking system. Stocks fell 3.61 percent in Hong Kong.
After absorbing the early selling, United States markets fluctuated in a relatively narrow range by recent standards, but almost nothing escaped the downdraft. All 30 Dow stocks posted losses, as did 424 of the issues in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which dropped 2.55 percent for the day.
The Nasdaq composite index, dominated by technology stocks, slumped about the same amount, 2.58 percent, with Microsoft down 3 1/4, to 104 15/16 , and Cisco Systems down 3 1/8, to 61 1/2.
Without minimizing the buffeting from overseas forces, many analysts said they were not surprised by yesterday's retreat after four sizable advances and said they remained upbeat.
"It's pulling back into its recent bottoming pattern," said Richard T. McCabe, chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch. "It was probably entitled to give some back after the nice bounce off 7,500" on the Dow. He said the index could reach the mid-8,000's within a month.
Financial stocks were pummeled once again, especially major banks with big exposure to emerging markets. Citicorp slumped 6 1/4, to 96 1/2, and J. P. Morgan was the biggest contributor to the Dow's decline, falling 5 1/2, to 89 3/4. American Express lost 3 3/16 , to 83 7/8.
Gillette, which warned of lower sales on Wednesday, saw its stock skid 3 5/16 yesterday as Merrill Lynch trimmed its estimate of the company's earnings to between $1.30 and $1.35 a share for this year and $1.55 for 1999, 5 cents less than before. The shares closed at 36 7/8 after trading as high as 62 21/32 in early April.
Procter & Gamble, another blue chip that warned recently of weaker results, fell 3 yesterday, to 67. Other prominent decliners were Lucent Technologies, which dropped 4 7/16 , to 72 1/8, and Northern Telecom, which fell 6 1/16 , to 39 1/2.
Declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange swamped gainers by nearly 5 to 1 as 255 made new lows compared with only 21 new highs.
Volume was moderate at 692.56 million shares, well below that of most recent sessions. Traders said they spotted no surge of activity related to the unwinding of positions in advance of today's triple-witching expiration of futures and options.

HEADLINE: Russia's New Leaders Plan to Pay Debt by Printing Money

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Russia's new Communist-influenced Government indicated today that it plans to satisfy old debts and bail out old friends by printing billions of new rubles, a decision that drew a swift and strong reaction from President Boris N. Yeltsin's old capitalist allies.
The deputy head of the central bank said today that the bank intends to bail out many of the nation's bankrupt financial institutions by buying back their multibillion-ruble portfolios of Government bonds and Treasury bills. The Government temporarily froze $40 billion worth of notes when the fiscal crisis erupted last month because it lacked the money to pay investors who hold them. 
 Asked by the Reuters news service how the near-broke Government would find the money to pay off the banks, the deputy, Andrei Kozlov, replied: "Emissions, of course, emissions." "Emissions" is a euphemism for printing money.
Hours later in Washington, Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers told a House subcommittee that Russia was heading toward a return of the four-digit inflation rates that savaged consumers and almost toppled Mr. Yeltsin's Government in 1993.
Russia's new leaders cannot repeal "basic economic laws," he said.
"They must resist pressures to spend and lend which will doom the economy to another bout of high, perhaps hyperinflation," Mr. Summers said. "Just as important, they need to take on the failings of the financial system and finally put in place the core institutions and policies of a private market economy."
Perhaps most pointedly, Mr. Summers spoke out against what he said was the pervasive corruption hobbling not just the economic system, but the evolution of democracy. It is up to Russia, he said, to show that its fiscal policies will affect the lives of ordinary people, and "not just enrich offshore bank accounts."
Today's actions, against the backdrop of continued jockeying between Communists and capitalists in the new Government, suggested that actions favored by Mr. Summers and other free-market economists are increasingly a long shot.
Mr. Summers also said that it was unlikely that the $4.3 billion second tranche of an International Monetary Fund bailout package for Russia would be paid as planned.
In contrast to the dire warnings of Mr. Summers and Russian reformers, however, a team of western European government ministers in Moscow today said that the West should wait before passing judgment on Mr. Primakov's economic intentions.
"We have the impression that the Russian Government has absolutely no intention to engage the reverse gear in any shape or form," said Germany's Foreign Minister, Klaus Kinkel, at a news conference with Austrian and British officials.
Mr. Kinkel said Mr. Primakov fears, "not entirely without grounds," that failure to deal with social spending could lead to a political explosion here.
Austria's Foreign Minister, Wolfgang Schuessel, also advised caution. "Give them a chance," he said. "I have the impression there is a readiness on their side to act."
The central bank's proposed bailout would offer a special deal to bankers, including the so-called oligarchs who frequently built vast financial empires around banks that have since fallen on hard times.
Under the plan, banks would move to the front of a long line of domestic and foreign investors who bought Government bonds only to see their prices collapse when the crisis struck.
Western experts generally argue that the major beneficiaries of such a bailout would be financiers, not the economy, since almost none of Russia's banks have built the extensive network of checking, savings and consumer-lending services that are a building block of western trade. Instead, most have plowed their money into buying industries or speculative investments.
The central bank's statement was not the only suggestion today that Russia's Government is about to embark on a serious spending program. President Yeltsin told his defense advisers to prepare to pay soldiers and other military workers half of the 16 billion rubles in back wages that they are owed. At today's exchange rates, that totals about $500 million.
Some of the reformers whose hopes for free-market capitalism here collapsed with the August fiscal crisis were acid in their criticism of the new Government today. Boris Y. Nemtsov, a Deputy Prime Minister until recently, greeted the apparent turn in fiscal policy with sarcasm.
"To print a lot of money, that's the first message," he said. "To print money, that's the second message, and to print money, that's the third message," he told Reuters Television.
And in Moscow, the head of the American Chamber of Commerce in Russia said American companies already have lost a half billion dollars during this crisis -- and are heading for the exits because they do not like the look of the new financial scene. The same tensions over the fiscal policy of the new Communist-capitalist Government hobbled efforts today to fill out the last positions in President Yeltsin's new Cabinet.
Mr. Yeltsin said he may miss the legal deadline of Friday for finishing selection of his new Cabinet because he needs more time to choose a Finance Minister. The acting Finance Minister, Mikhail M. Zadornov, was a leader among the free-market advocates in the last Cabinet whose push for full-fledged capitalism broke down with the financial crisis.
Few believe that Mr. Yeltsin's new Prime Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, will keep Mr. Zadornov in the Government, and there were fresh indications today that Mr. Primakov's men may nudge other reformers out as well.
The new Deputy Prime Minister, Aleksandr Shokhin, repeated his statement of Tuesday that Boris Fyodorov, another key reformer who was a Deputy Prime Minister and head of the state tax service, had quit. Mr. Fyodorov, who developed a reputation for pugnacity as tax collector, was quiet after Tuesday's announcement. But today he dispatched an aide to effectively dare Mr. Primakov to fire him.
"I have strong nerves and will not resign," he said.
If he does go, it will be viewed by many as an indication that the new Government is moving further from western-style economic policies that encourage competition and fiscal restraint and toward Communist tenets such as state control of industry and greater spending on welfare, even at the cost of inflation.
The flip side of those concerns, however, is that failure to spend money on such pressing demands as back wages for soldiers will only increase the already mounting prospects for social or political upheaval.
One of the major reasons Russians have diminishing confidence in their Government is that it has failed to provide basic services such as pensions, welfare and wages to state employees. At least some of those payments have gone by the wayside because Mr. Yeltsin's last two Governments, committed to keeping inflation low, have refused to print money to pay for services the Government could not otherwise afford.
The Communist Party is organizing what it promises will be a peaceful mass protest against the Yeltsin Government for Oct. 7. But its leaders have said they cannot keep a lid on popular anger if the Government does not begin to respond to citizens' demands. Today Mr. Yeltsin ordered his Interior Ministry to make preparations to keep public order during the protest and to prevent certain types of actions, such as blockades of railways, that could disrupt the economy.

Also testifying were Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott, right, and former Secretary of State George Shultz, who spoke from California. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
A 48-Story Tower for a Low-Rise Neighborhood

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
A luxury rental apartment building that will be a commanding presence in its low-rise East Side neighborhood is now under construction and will eventually rise 48 stories above the pavement at 10 East 29th Street.
The $105 million building, known as the Madison Belvedere, will have 400 studio to two-bedroom apartments, many with balconies and unobstructed city views. It will take shape on a vacant midblock lot between Madison and Fifth Avenues opposite the landmark 19th-century Church of the Transfiguration, also known as the Little Church Around the Corner. 
 Rose Associates is developing the project, which is scheduled to be completed in January 2000. It is being financed with a construction loan from Fleet Bank as well as the developer's own money.
"The site had the Rose name scratched in the dirt," said Adam R. Rose, executive vice president of Rose Associates. "It was empty and ready to go, allowing us to buy and build immediately, which we love to do."
Rose Associates bought the site, which extends to 28th Street, in December for $15 million from the Sisters of Mary Reparatrix. The sisters, a Roman Catholic order of nuns who once lived in a convent on the site, had contracted to sell it in 1984 to an earlier development team led by Richard N. Kalikow, said Edmund J. Burns, a Manhattan lawyer who represents the sisters.
In 1985, the 29th Street convent was demolished. Then the recession hit, and over the years, the previous developers, unable to secure financing, never moved forward with development plans, Mr. Burns said.
The project, between the Flatiron and Murray Hill residential neighborhoods, represents the return of Rose Associates to the area, where the company helped start a revival in 1981 with the construction of Madison Green, a 423-unit condominium at 23d Street and Broadway. The site is also close to the midtown business district, which Mr. Rose described as "underserved" in housing.
Zoning rules permitted a 28-story building on the site, which is flanked by the 12-story Carlton Hotel and a 26-story office building. By buying the air rights from nearby buildings, Rose Associates was able to increase the tower by 10 stories, to 38 floors. The developer was allowed to add 10 more stories by agreeing to create a public plaza along 28th Street. Designed by the landscape architect Thomas Balsley, the quarter-acre plaza is to include a large circular lawn at its core, two seating areas and a garden.
The air rights and plaza bonus "allowed us to set the building 15 feet from the street and go straight up," resulting in a slender rather than a broad tower, said Peter Claman, who, with James Davidson, designed the project. Both are with the Manhattan architectural firm of Schuman Lichtenstein Claman & Efron.
"The extra height," Mr. Rose said, "made the project more economically desirable and gave the building more stature in the skyline."
Rose Associates initially considered building the Madison Belvedere using state financing as a mixed-income rental -- in which 80 percent of the units would be rented at market rates and the remaining 20 percent would be rented to low-income tenants.
As with any project that would use state funds, the building was reviewed by the New York State Office of Historic Preservation for its affect on state and national historic resources in the area, in this case the Little Church Around the Corner. The concern centered on the shadows to be cast by the taller building onto the 1849 Gothic Revival-style Episcopal church.
The state's review concluded that the new building "will not significantly increase the shading of the church above that historically found at that location," said Julian W. Adams, historic sites restoration coordinator at the State Historic Preservation Office.
"The trade-off," he added, "is the building of one tower rather than a forest of towers, securing the preservation of the entire neighborhood."
Rose Associates ultimately received private financing for the project, allowing all 400 units to be rented at market rates. Mr. Rose said he expected the Madison Belvedere to draw tenants who want a Manhattan pied-a-terre or an apartment close to where they work, mainly business executives and professionals, as well as some foreign renters. It will have mostly studio and one-bedroom units as well as some two-bedroom units; apartments will range from 524 to 1,335 square feet.
Amenities planned include a health club and garage parking. Monthly rents have not yet been set, but Mr. Rose said that if leased today the units would rent for about $45 a square foot a year.
That is competitive with new and existing apartment buildings in the 20's and 30's, where rates range from $36 to $50 a square foot, said Andrew Heiberger, president of Citi Habitats, a rental brokerage concern. A typical 650-square-foot one-bedroom costs $2,383 a month, or an average of $44 a square foot a year, he said.
The Madison Belvedere has been designed to fit in with its historic neighbors. The building's five-story base will have accents of granite and limestone, "recalling, without mimicking, the sensitive detailing of the church across the street," said Mr. Davidson, the architect.
The rest of the building will be brick with occasional horizontal bands of decorative limestone, or limestone-colored brick, and topped by a gold-domed crown that will be lighted at night.
"Because the tower is going to be seen, accentuating it seemed the appropriate solution," Mr. Davidson said.
The building, he said, will join the company of nearby prewar office towers with distinctive crowns, including the Metropolitan Life Building, the New York Life Insurance Building and the Empire State Building.

GRAPHIC: Photo: An architect's rendering of what the new apartment tower will look like on 29th Street. (Schuman Lichtenstein Claman & Efron)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: MARKET PLACE;
The Man Who Moves, and Scares, Markets

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
When Alan Greenspan talks, the market listens. And most of the time it doesn't like what it hears.
In the last two years, on 31 occasions, the Federal Reserve chairman has testified before Congress on a variety of matters. On 21 of those dates, almost 70 percent of the time, the market fell immediately after his testimony. 
 Make that 22. The markets fell drastically in the United States and around the world on the first full day of trading after Mr. Greenspan's testimony on Wednesday, in which he told the House Banking Committee that there was no coordinated effort among the world's central banks to cut interest rates.
Investors were clearly disappointed that Mr. Greenspan presented no solutions to the economic problems that have terrified many of the world's markets. "I was disturbed that the comments Mr. Greenspan made about the changes that need to be made were all in the future tense," said M. Cary Leahey, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics Ltd. in Valhalla, N.Y. "He gave the impression that he was no closer to solutions than he was in December."
Mr. Greenspan's comments were just the latest in a long line of disappointing utterances, at least where investors are concerned. That the stock market falls fairly consistently when the Fed chairman speaks is an indication that stock buyers think he's the market's version of a wet blanket.
To be sure, investors have come to love Mr. Greenspan for his ability to keep the economy on course. Until this summer, negative reactions to his comments were temporary, usually lasting less than a week. But his testimony before Congress on July 21 came only two trading days after the broad stock market averages reached their peaks. Since then, it's been rough sledding for shareholders.
Tracking what happens to stocks after the Fed chairman's testimony -- what might be called the Greenspan effect -- comes courtesy of Tom McClellan, of The McClellan Market Report, a technical analysis investment advisory service based in Lakewood, Wash. Mr. McClellan went back to 1996 for his research and included only those occasions when Mr. Greenspan addressed Congress.
"It seems to be his personality that he has been able to talk down the market with words rather than actions," Mr. McClellan said. "But it is funny how the market and investors hear what they want to hear in the words that cross his lips."
Mr. Greenspan's speech at the University of California at Berkeley two weeks ago, which ignited the market on Sept. 8, is a prime example of investors' hearing in the Fed chairman's comments exactly what they want to hear. Even though the speech gave only the hint that a rate cut might be forthcoming, the market rallied by 380 points.
Most of the time, though, Mr. Greenspan drives the market down with his talks. For example, on July 18, 1996, he appeared at his twice-yearly question-and-answer session with Congressional committees -- known as Humphrey-Hawkins testimony. He reminded the lawmakers that even if the nation was indeed in a new economic era, as many were arguing, inflation could still threaten economic stability and growth. For the next three days, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 2.1 percent.
On Jan. 21, 1997, Mr. Greenspan addressed the Senate Budget Committee. The only fretting he did in this talk was to worry about a possible pickup in wage costs. The Dow lost 3.3 percent of its value in the next five trading days.
This year, the chairman has been especially talkative. He has testified before Congress 15 times to date; in all of 1997, he spoke on 14 occasions.
So far in 1998, on nine occasions investors have reacted negatively to Mr. Greenspan's testimony; on three occasions, they liked what they heard. Twice, the market had no reaction at all.
Mr. McClellan has limited his research to Congressional testimony. "When I looked at the dates of his speeches that were not testimony," he said, "there wasn't as good a correlation for what the market did afterward. Routine speeches to the Rotary Club or the University of California don't have the same effect on the market."
The Greenspan effect could, of course, be a calculated one. "He's been trying to let air gently out of the balloon for nearly two years now," Mr. Leahey said, referring to inflated stock prices. "The market has listened to him for a day and then has forgotten what he said two days later."

HEADLINE: Travelers and Citicorp Plan To Cut Jobs

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
In the first of what is expected to be major layoffs at financial companies, Citicorp and Travelers Group Inc. -- which plan to merge into Citigroup Inc. -- confirmed yesterday that they would eliminate several thousand jobs, many in New York City.
The cuts, which the two companies declined to specify either by number, percentage, or location of jobs, are expected to be spread across the combined company, which currently employs more than 160,000 people. 
 Citicorp and Travelers executives who declined to be identified by name said that the cuts were likely to fall particularly hard on businesses that have been hit by the recent decline in financial markets, such as the issuing and trading of bonds and equities, and in areas that overlap such as foreign exchange trading, credit card services, data processing, headquarters' staff and human resources.
Many of these businesses are based in and around New York City -- where the two companies now employ 28,000.
Several New York companies, including Merrill Lynch & Company and other big banks and brokerage houses, were also expected to announce layoffs, crimping, or even halting, a run of several years of prosperity for New York, where financial services had become an increasingly important part of the economy.
Furthermore, 100,000 of the projected Citigroup work force is based in this country, so the brunt of the expected retrenchment at the financial behemoth is likely to fall on Americans.
And the cutbacks will not stop with Citibank and Travelers if the global economic turmoil continues.
"If this environment continues I would expect all the companies I follow -- the banks with big broker dealers -- to rethink their staffing," said Diane B. Glossman, bank analyst at Lehman Inc., referring to the recent downturn in financial markets. "J. P. Morgan already announced a program earlier this year; Bankers Trust is already revamping its business; Bank of Boston already restructured in Europe and Asia."
The swoon in financial markets had led to frequent speculation that Citibank and Travelers might even call off their pending merger, which had yet to obtain the required approval from the Federal Reserve Board. The company they are proposing to create would offer banking, insurance, brokerage and other financial services to companies and individuals in 100 different countries.
"The company is being very circumspect," said Judah Kraushaar, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. "They're saying it's up to the Fed. He added, "From my own point of view, there's a high probability the deal will close in October."
Citibank and Travelers refused yesterday to confirm various reports, first carried on CNBC television, that the two companies would eliminate 5 percent of their combined work force, or about 8,000 jobs, by the end of this year. But John M. Morris, a spokesman for Citibank who said he also spoke for Travelers, acknowledged the cuts "may be as much as that." He said that he could not confirm the 8,000 number, which he said had been "plucked out of the air," or the related report that 5 percent of the companies' combined work force would be cut by the end of the year. But the spokesman said those numbers were "directionally correct."
Analysts said such cuts were to be expected and that they might well involve more than 8,000 jobs, or 5 percent of the combined companies' work force. "My own hunch is that this is a piece of something that'll be broader," Mr. Kraushaar said, adding: "I don't find this surprising at all. There is a lot of bureaucracy in a bank that you don't find in a company like Travelers."
Ronald I. Mandle, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, the brokerage firm, said, "We thought the cost saves were going to be greater than what the companies were talking about" at the April merger announcement. "We thought it was more like $600 million, rather than the $400 million they were talking about," he added.
Ms. Glossman, the Lehman analyst, said: "There are clear opportunities to cut spending and cut right up front. I would not be surprised to see more than 5 percent of the staff involved."
Seeking to play down yesterday's speculation of layoffs, Mr. Morris said: "There is no companywide goal. Each manager has been asked to look for efficiencies, and to see that their costs are in line with any revised business expectations they would have."
As far as specific numbers are concerned, Mr. Morris added, "We are not prepared to say that, because it's vague at the moment." He also stressed that the cost-cutting was not a single program but a host of different initiatives, some dating from before the announcement of the merger. About a year ago, Mr. Morris said as an example, Citicorp announced a program of 7,500 layoffs, which he said is now "about half done."
Sanford I. Weill, the chairman of Travelers, and John S. Reed, the chairman of Citibank, made no comment yesterday.
But Mr. Weill addressed a gathering of investors and analysts at the St. Regis Hotel in Manhattan on Wednesday. The financier -- who rose through the brokerage business to build up a huge insurance, brokerage and financial services conglomerate -- made no bones about the combined companies' intention to cut costs. According to Mr. Morris, he told the conference: "We all get spoiled in good times. We probably say 'yes' too many times. And we'll probably be saying 'no' too many times and that will be good. It's time to plan for the worst and pray for the best instead of the reverse."
The company's top executives seem to have been preparing its employees and the markets for more austerity. "We have to operate a company in bad weather as well as in good weather," James Dimon, Travelers' president and chief operating officer and a key lieutenant of Mr. Weill's, told investors recently, according to Mr. Morris. "A company should be successful in adverse conditions."
"No one has had an opportunity to be ebullient for very long in this environment," Mr. Morris said. "Business conditions are not what they were on April 6 when we announced our merger."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
House Votes Small Fraction Of Money Sought for I.M.F.

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
The House tonight approved only a fraction of the nearly $18 billion that President Clinton is seeking for the International Monetary Fund.
The action, which prompted a Presidential veto threat, left the agency in limbo as the I.M.F.'s reserves dwindle and economic crises spread. 
 The Senate has approved the full amount, and there is still a chance that when both houses meet in the next few weeks to iron out their differences on this and other issues, they will agree to provide the Clinton Administration's full request.
But even if they do, the lending agency's financing is tied up with other contentious matters, such as restrictions on international family planning, that have also drawn veto threats. So, full funds are by no means certain.
Many in the House say they have doubts about the I.M.F.'s internal integrity and the use of American taxpayer money for what they say are risky overseas investments the agency makes without proper accountability.
Republican leaders had blocked the House from considering the $17.9 billion requested as it took up a $12.5 billion bill that finances many of the nation's overseas assistance programs. The G.O.P. leaders wrote rules to include only $3.4 billion for the agency, procedurally blocking an attempt by Democrats to provide the additional $14.5 billion sought by the President.
The overall foreign operations bill provides economic assistance for international groups such as the World Bank and the Export-Import Bank, aid to former Soviet republics and money for the Peace Corps.
The legislation includes language barring United States assistance to foreign groups that perform abortions or violate abortion laws of foreign countries.
There was no separate vote on the agency financing, but the overall bill passed tonight, 255 to 161.
Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, who is leading the opposition, said that the bill, which provides $316 million less than this year's levels, reduced the President's flexibility and in terms of vision and money, failed to fulfill the nation's role as a global power.
Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, Republican of New York, speaking of the I.M.F. legislation, said the public resents giving money to countries like Russia that are bad investments, where the money will "go in the front door and out the back door."
Arguing for the full amount, Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin, said: "How long do people in this House think we can survive as an island of economic success in a world of economic chaos? The answer is, not very long."
The Administration said in a statement that failure to provide the full amount would undermine the United States' global leadership and expose workers, businesses and farmers to unacceptable economic risks.
"The President would veto the bill if it were presented to him in its current form," said the statement, a carefully calibrated phrasing that carries less weight than a quotation from the President himself but is more forceful than the more typical statement, which couches such threats as recommendations by advisers.
The veto threat is only the latest of several issued by the Administration on 13 spending bills now moving through Congress. The bills are supposed to be passed and signed by Oct. 1, the start of the new fiscal year. Both the House and the Senate bought themselves some extra time today, voting to finance all Government programs at the current year's levels through Oct. 9. The action puts off Congress's annual confrontation with the White House for nine days.
In the daylong debate in the House, members argued most heatedly over whether to repeal a ban on all American assistance to the former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan. The Administration wanted Congress to lift the ban, saying it had hindered United States negotiators in appearing neutral in the conflict between Azerbaijan and Armenia.
Opponents, who prevailed, argued that lifting the ban would reward a corrupt regime that has engaged in ethnic cleansing.
Most strenuous in favor of the repeal was Representative Bob Livingston, Republican of Louisiana and chairman of the Appropriations Committee. Some members suggested that Mr. Livingston seemed to be carrying the banner for American oil companies, which are seeking a share in a hugely lucrative pipeline through the Caspian Sea region -- and are also a vital force in Mr. Livingston's New Orleans district.
Mr. Livingston conceded during the debate that oil companies "might" benefit from lifting the ban, but, he said, so would the industrialized Western world.
Representative David E. Bonior, Democrat of Michigan and the minority whip, declared, "The big oil lobby has dollar signs in its eyes."
The House voted 231 to 182 to keep the ban in place. The measure is not part of the Senate's foreign operations bill, and its fate in the eventual House-Senate conference is uncertain.

HEADLINE: City's Jobless Rate Shrinks to 7.3%, Lowest Since 1990

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
With the booming economy creating more jobs than at any time since the 1950's, New York City's unemployment rate tumbled to 7.3 percent in August from 9.3 percent a year ago, the State Department of Labor said yesterday.
The city unemployment rate, which edged down again last month, is now at its lowest level since 1990. While the unemployment rate in the city remained higher than the national average, its 2-percentage-point drop far outpaced the dip of three-tenths of 1 percent in the national average in the last year. 
 Nationally, unemployment in August averaged 4.5 percent, down from 4.8 percent in August 1997. Statewide, unemployment fell to 5.1 percent from 6.2 percent in the same period.
In the last year, the city has added more than 87,000 new public and private sector jobs, an increase of 2.6 percent. "To find that, you'd have to go back to the 50's," said Jim Brown, a labor market analyst for the state. The survey did not include self-employed workers, agriculture workers or domestic workers employed by private households.
While commuters have accounted for some of the city's gain in jobs, city residents have also increasingly found employment -- 54 percent of the adults who live in the city were working last month, Mr. Brown said. The last time so many people were working, as a percentage of the population, was in late 1989, he added.
The new jobs came in almost every sector except manufacturing, Mr. Brown said. Employment grew on Wall Street and in services like accounting, and new jobs were also created at construction sites, stores, hotels and airlines.
City officials hailed the strength and breadth of the expansion. "It's an explosion of jobs in New York," said Deputy Mayor Joseph J. Lhota. And, he contended, the numbers show "that we have a very diversified economy -- this is not being fueled just by Wall Street."
As the stock market continues to fluctuate, charges that the city relies too much on Wall Street have become an increasingly sore point for city officials, particularly since some securities firms have recently announced big losses in overseas markets.
Last month, the State Comptroller's office issued a report warning that the city had "to an unprecedented extent" become dependent on Wall Street in the 1990's. While securities firms employ only about 5 percent of the people who work in the city, these workers account for more than 17 percent of total earnings.
And some critics of city policies say that the surge in jobs is leaving behind many people without college degrees, especially women who have been forced off welfare. The current unemployment rate "still leads other urban areas, and it's a significant problem for us because this is the top of the boom," said David R. Jones, president of the Community Service Society of New York, which has just published a report on the city's labor market.
The society's report said that fewer people of working age had jobs in New York than in other urban areas, although Mr. Jones conceded that this had been the case for two decades. "Merely saying, 'That's the way it's always been' may not be a sufficient guide for economic policy," he said.
Among the fastest-growing areas of the state were Putnam and Rockland Counties, where jobs surged by 6,400, or 5.3 percent, in the last 12 months, state data show. On Long Island, 24,000 jobs were added over the last year, 2.2 percent rise.
By contrast, Rochester lost jobs, as did several rural areas, including Greene and Sullivan Counties.
The unemployment rate was lowest in upstate Tompkins County, which includes Ithaca, at 2 percent. It was highest in the Bronx, where unemployment was at 9.2 percent, down from more than 11 percent a year ago.
The other boroughs reported similar percentage drops over the 12-month period to August. The jobless rate dropped to 8.6 percent from 10.6 percent in Brooklyn, to 6.2 percent from 7.7 percent in Manhattan, to 6.3 percent from 8.3 percent in Queens and to 6.9 percent from 9.2 percent on Staten Island.

HEADLINE: House Panel Approves Republicans' $80 Billion Tax Cut Plan

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
The House Ways and Means Committee passed an $80 billion Republican tax cut today, setting up a confrontation with President Clinton over how the nation should take advantage of its return to fiscal health.
Defying Mr. Clinton's insistence that projected Federal budget surpluses be set aside until Congress and the Administration have settled on a plan to shore up Social Security, the committee voted 23 to 15, largely along party lines, to dip into the surplus to pay for a package of tax reductions likely to have broad appeal to the middle class. 
 Amid a rancorous debate over how to use the surplus, Democrats admitted that they were sorely tempted to support the tax cut, both because it has many provisions they have pushed for and because it is less than two months before a Congressional election. But in the end only one of the committee's 16 Democrats, Representative Barbara B. Kennelly of Connecticut, who is running for governor and lagging in the polls, sided with the Republicans.
Despite a vow today by Mr. Clinton to veto it, the tax bill is expected to pass the full House as soon as next week. It will then go to the Senate, where its prospects are uncertain. The bill has the support of most of the Senate's 55 Republicans and could attract some Democrats. But under the Senate's procedures it will need 60 votes to pass because it will require a waiver of budget rules to permit use of the surplus.
Today's committee vote was an important test of Mr. Clinton's ability to hold his party together on politically difficult issues as he struggles to avoid impeachment.
His call to preserve the surplus has been the centerpiece of Mr. Clinton's domestic policy agenda this year, and any widespread defections by party members on the issue would have signaled concern among Democrats that the President could no longer provide them the cover they need to vote against popular tax cuts in favor of the more nebulous benefits of fiscal restraint.
The bill was tailored by Republicans to have broad middle class appeal, and its main provision is a break for married couples. It would raise the standard deduction for couples filing jointly to $8,600, from $7,200. The change is intended to address the so-called marriage penalty, the quirk in the tax code that leads many two-income couples to pay bigger tax bills than they would if single.
The bill would exclude from taxation the first $400 of interest and dividend income for couples filing jointly, and $200 for single filers. It would accelerate the timetable under which self-employed people will be able to deduct their health insurance costs and speed a gradual increase in the amount of an estate exempted from Federal taxation.
It would make changes intended to insulate moderate-income families from the effects of the alternative minimum tax, which was designed to apply to wealthy taxpayers but increasingly results in a tax increase for working families. To appeal to farm-state legislators, the measure would provide tax breaks to farmers and ranchers who have been hit by a downturn in agriculture. And to address the concerns of lawmakers from poor districts, it would create tax incentives for redevelopment programs.
Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who heads the committee, said the bill would preserve nearly 90 percent of the coming budget surpluses -- projected by the Congressional Budget Office at $1.55 trillion over the next decade -- while trimming a tax burden that by some measures is the highest since World War II.
"It sets money aside to save Social Security and it gives middle-income Americans the tax relief they need and deserve," Mr. Archer said, adding that the tax cut might also boost the economy at a time when the global financial crisis threatens to slow growth in the United States.
Republicans also said Mr. Clinton's demand to save the surplus for Social Security was hollow since the Administration had proposed using the surplus to pay for emergency spending for the peacekeeping mission in Bosnia, strengthening security around American embassies and preparing for the year 2000 computer problem.
Democrats said it would be irresponsible to start spending the surplus on tax cuts before the nation determines how to deal with the coming financial shortfall in the Social Security system.
Moreover, they said, nearly all of the surplus for the next 10 years will come from the payroll taxes that are supposed to be earmarked for Social Security. Not until 2006 will the Government start to run a significant surplus without counting the excess Social Security payments.
"If it wasn't for the Social Security trust fund, we wouldn't even be showing a budget surplus," said Representative Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan, the committee's senior Democrat. "The surplus belongs to Social Security. It's not a spare cookie in the bottom of the jar there for the taking."
Several hours before the vote, Mr. Clinton, in a speech to a labor union group, said using the surplus would send the wrong signal to the world about the nation's fiscal and economic stability at a time of increasing global financial turmoil. But mostly, he said, it would make it more difficult to make up the looming shortfall in Social Security, which although healthy now will run short of money in about 30 years after the baby boom generation retires.
"Some of our friends in the other party say that, well, we're projecting a surplus and it's close to the election, so let's give everybody a tax cut," Mr. Clinton said.
"I don't care how close it is to the election," he added, "it is wrong to do that until we have solved this problem."
Although the Republican leadership continues to hope that it can win over enough Democrats to push the bill through the Senate, White House officials said Mr. Clinton was trying to signal to his party today that whatever his other problems he was not going to back down or compromise, burning Democrats who have stuck with him on the issue.

HEADLINE: Spending Bill Hurt by Bid on Foreign Farm Hands

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
A proposal to ease the hiring of foreigners at harvest time is clouding prospects for Congressional approval of a spending bill for the Commerce, Justice and State Departments.
An amendment to the $27.4 billion spending bill is being pushed by farm-state senators who say the process for hiring foreign farm workers, most from Mexico, is slow and burdened by red tape. As a result, some lawmakers say, farmers face the dilemma of seeing their crops go unharvested or hiring foreigners who lack permission to work. 
 One expected result of the amendment would be more foreign workers, and therefore pressure to keep wages low. While the amendment would require growers to pay American farm workers the prevailing wage in a given area, critics contend that those wages could drop if the legislation is approved.
The amendment would also require American farm workers to list themselves in a central job registry and get their jobs through a referral from that registry. And it would eliminate the requirement that growers provide housing for guest workers, although farmers would have to give these workers a housing allowance. This would mean that rural communities would have to build housing for workers.
Opponents of the measure, including labor unions, Hispanic civil rights groups and the Labor Department, say it is an effort to hold down wages of migrant workers by bringing in low-income Mexican field hands. The opponents also argue that the measure weakens guarantees that American farm workers would still be provided jobs, good housing and a decent wage. And opponents point to studies by the General Accounting Office and private economists indicating that there is no agricultural labor shortage.
Critics of the measure have urged the White House to threaten a veto of the spending bill if the amendment is enacted. They hope the threat would persuade House-Senate conferees to drop the amendment to help gain support for the spending bill.
The amendment's chief sponsor, Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, said he was willing to modify his bill to address some of the opponents' concerns, and Clinton Administration officials met with him on Tuesday in an effort to work out their differences. But a White House official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said that "people are still far apart."
Passage of the bill is already jeopardized because of controversy over preparations for the 2000 census.

HEADLINE: Time for Central Bank Action

 BODY:
With the world economy growing at the slowest pace in decades -- and many countries in recession -- only the countries that are growing the fastest are in a good position to help the world economy before the problems engulf us all. But there is a great reluctance to act.
This week there was brave talk of coordinated action among the G-7 countries to stimulate world growth, and it appears that finance ministers in many of those countries are persuaded that action is needed. But the two most important central banks in the world -- the Federal Reserve and Germany's Bundesbank -- do not appear ready to take coordinated action to reduce interest rates. 
 That hesitation is understandable considering that each central bank's legal duty is to help its own national economy, and neither Germany nor the United States appears to be in imminent danger of recession -- at least based on their own domestic economies. The greatest problems are in countries whose central banks cannot cut interest rates to stimulate growth, simply because to do so would be to invite the collapse of their own currencies.
Were there a world central bank, there is little doubt that it would be leaping to action in an effort to spur growth. Bridgewater Associates, a Connecticut-based economic consulting firm, reports that world growth is now at a 30-year low, despite the fact the American economy has grown 3.6 percent over the past year. The figure for the rest of the world was a scant 0.3 percent.
Countries that are doing well are likely to see a flood of cheap imports from those economies that are in trouble, raising the threat that developed countries will retreat toward protectionism. Already, with the trade deficit growing, the American steel industry is demanding that duties be placed on low-cost steel arriving from Asian and Russian producers who have seen their former Asian markets dry up. The state of South Dakota, reacting to the complaints of farmers, is trying to hamper the importation of Canadian grain and livestock.
In an atmosphere of low commodity prices around the globe, inflation is not the threat it was even a few years ago. Fears of inflation should not now prevent interest rate cuts by central banks. Such moves could help to offset the decline in global economic growth.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Three Questions

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
President Clinton has forced the members of Congress to face three questions, whether or not the American people will like the answers:
Two of them have already been answered. Like most Americans I have been struggling with my own answer to the third question, or was fleeing it. 
 The first question: Is Mr. Clinton fit to remain President? There may be reasons that Congress considers important enough to allow him to serve out his term -- but fit, no.
A man who risks the Presidency of the U.S., its moral and political worth in American life, the confidence of the people in it, its very ability to function under his direction, all to satisfy himself sexually for the moment, is not stable enough within himself to be entrusted with America.
Perhaps we would all lie to save ourselves from deep sexual embarrassment and trouble. But if we did so under oath and then lied again and again about it, we would know we would have to do more to escape jail than tell the judge we were real sorry.
Still, if this were his first lie . . . But it isn't. He has lied so often that it has become another sign of a broken rudder.
He lied during the Presidential campaign -- the draft notice matter. Then he went on to lie to the American people about their own national interests -- how he would fight for human rights against the Communist Chinese dictatorship, how Saddam Hussein was complying with U.N. inspections at the very time Iraq was preparing to end inspection, whether high-tech missile sales to Beijing could compromise U.S. security.
Jesse Jackson said in 1992: "I can maybe work with him but I know now who he is, what he is. There is nothing this man won't do. He is immune to shame. Move past all the nice posturing and get really down in there in him, you find absolutely nothing . . . nothing but an appetite."
Senator Bob Kerrey, the Nebraska Democrat, was a bit gentler: "Clinton's an unusually good liar, unusually good."
Both quotes come from William J. Bennett's solidly valuable new book, "The Death of Outrage -- Bill Clinton and the Assault on American Ideals" (The Free Press). Read it, particularly if you are sure you won't agree.
Second question: Has Mr. Clinton's risk-taking already so deeply damaged the Presidency that it cannot be repaired while he is in office?
This week I heard him give a speech at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York about the world's economic crisis and how "it is time for us to rise to our responsibility."
I thought: You call on us to rise to our responsibility? Other members told me they had the same thought. One just snickered and made a dirty joke out of the sentence.
The military cashiers or imprisons members who commit adultery, particularly with subordinates. How in decency will William Clinton take the salute from the men and women he commands while he whines not to be punished for the same offense, repeated and repeated?
Millions of Americans still want him in office. That does not change the truth that he has made the Presidency a bottle of cynical poison for many of us and a dirty joke for the country. Damage enough.
Third: How do we repair the damage as best we can?
A motion of Congressional censure would endorse Mr. Clinton's definition of responsibility. Take the chance whatever the risk. If caught, plead for compassion. If handed an act of censure, bite your lip in sorrow. Then when you pass the troops in parade keep a straight face.
The final choice, impeachment by the House of Representatives and a removal trial by the Senate -- that's frightening to most of us.
For about two years, a new President would be in office while Russia fell apart, Saddam incited war and terrorists scouted America. How strong would he be?
We do not know if Al Gore would be any better in office than Mr. Clinton. But then we never do know about a Vice President who becomes President, do we? Maybe he will stop echoing Mr. Clinton's apologies and evasions. Maybe he will be Truman!
But we would know that under the Constitution we removed an unfit man who risked and soiled the Presidency while shaming himself personally. And we will have given Bill Clinton what he needs most -- the choice in private life to keep rocking in waves of his own making or recover the stability he has so long lost.
