HEADLINE: Clinton Issue Encroaches on Schumer's Senate Run

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: SYRACUSE, Sept. 17

 BODY:
In Washington today, the House Judiciary Committee debated whether to release to the public videotapes of President Clinton's grand jury testimony in the Monica Lewinsky case. Here in central New York, one of the committee's most prominent Democrats, Representative Charles E. Schumer, was touring a factory that makes cat litter, soberly noting the economic distress of this downtrodden region and proposing a series of measures to create jobs.
Two days after Mr. Schumer won the Democratic nomination to challenge Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, the Judiciary Committee deliberations served as a reminder of a major complication Mr. Schumer is facing in his campaign to become New York's next junior Senator. And it goes beyond the man currently holding that job. 
 As President Clinton's difficulties escalate, Mr. Schumer finds himself balancing the conflicting demands of his campaign, which Democrats consider one of the most promising in the nation, and his obligations as one of 15 Democrats on a committee on the verge of historic deliberations. The situation is potentially more perplexing because Mr. Schumer has long been close to Mr. Clinton and has viewed his association with the President as a political benefit.
Mr. Schumer said today that he had no regrets about missing today's debate. He noted that the Judiciary Committee was divided along party lines over whether to disclose the tapes. Mr. Schumer also contended that the debate in Washington did not involve great constitutional issues, but rather partisan maneuvering by Republicans out to embarrass a Democratic President.
"Those are a bunch of shenanigans down in Washington," Mr. Schumer said, standing on the rooftop of an Arm and Hammer factory here with a sweeping view of industrial New York at his back. He said he would oppose the release of the videotapes of Mr. Clinton's grand jury testimony. "We certainly should have the process go forward," Mr. Schumer said. "But releasing these tapes with these salacious-type materials is not moving the process forward.
"You know what moving the process forward is?" Mr. Schumer continued. "Talking about creating jobs in central New York. Talking about fighting crime."
Mr. Schumer declined to say what he would do if the Judiciary Committee moved to being impeachment proceedings. Asked if he might step down from the committee so he could press on with his campaign, he responded, "I'll cross that bridge when I get to it."
Even today's debate, though, happened at a less than propitious time for Mr. Schumer, who is enjoying what is unquestionably the best political week of his career. The 48 hours after a primary victory -- especially for a victor who had faced long odds, as Mr. Schumer did in defeating Geraldine A. Ferraro and Mark Green -- are usually a guaranteed burst of free and almost invariably good publicity.
Tonight Mr. Schumer introduced a series of strikingly harsh television advertisements attacking Mr. D'Amato. They accuse the Senator of lying in asserting that Mr. Schumer was a proponent of big tax increases. Each advertisement ends with this line: "D'Amato: too many lies for too long."
In Washington, Mr. D'Amato left little doubt that he would try to make the most of Mr. Schumer's predicament with the Judiciary Committee. Even as the panel began its deliberations, Mr. D'Amato, who spent the day in an unsuccessful effort to push for passage of his bill to restrict automated teller machine fees, issued a news release saying that Mr. Schumer had missed 100 votes this year.
Asked the Senator's position on releasing the videotapes, Mr. D'Amato's press secretary, Harvey Valentine, responded: "This is a matter properly before the Judiciary Committee, which has all the facts. Chuck Schumer should do his job. If and when this matter comes to the Senate, the Senator will do his job."
Mr. Schumer's advisers are, by all indications, just starting to assess how possible Judiciary Committee hearings could disrupt the campaign. One associate, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, suggested that Mr. Schumer might actually benefit from this, listing members of Congress -- from former Representative Elizabeth Holtzman to former Senator Howard Baker Jr. -- who became famous because of their televised roles in the Watergate hearings.
"Think about the potential to put a spotlight on him," this associate said. "These could be live, televised hearings."
But if Mr. Schumer's position on the Judiciary Committee could give him valuable television exposure, it also threatens to keep him out of New York for a good deal of time, and that could be a problem. One of the first questions posed by a Syracuse reporter to Mr. Schumer today was why he had campaigned so infrequently there.
There are other ways hearings could complicate Mr. Schumer's candidacy. More than most Democrats, Mr. Schumer has made clear that he wants Mr. Clinton to campaign with him in this state. It is hard to imagine that happening if Mr. Schumer is serving on the committee that is considering whether to recommend impeachment proceedings against Mr. Clinton.
And the prospect of hearings makes it likely that Mr. Schumer will be pressed to answer more questions about Mr. Clinton and Ms. Lewinsky, a situation that Mr. D'Amato's advisers said they welcomed. Today, for example, Mr. Schumer spent an hour touring the Arm and Hammer plant, which manufacturers cat litter and laundry detergent, and then climbed to the roof to offer a detailed review of his economic proposals. Those include using any money from a tobacco industry settlement to finance a property tax cut, deregulating the power industry to try to lower electricity costs here, and using part of a Federal surplus to reduce Social Security taxes.
But that is not what Brenda Tyler, a television reporter with WTVH, the CBS affiliate in Syracuse, wanted to ask about after Mr. Schumer finished his speech. "You are on the Judiciary Committee," Ms. Tyler said. "Why are you here instead of making that important vote?"

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

3 Ex-Archer Executives Convicted of Fixing Prices
Three former executives of Archer Daniels Midland -- including the son of its powerful chairman, Dwayne Andreas -- were found guilty of engaging in an international conspiracy to fix the prices of a widely used additive for animal feed. 
 The verdict by a Federal jury in Chicago marked an important victory for prosecutors and capped a six-year effort by the Government to crack an illegal cartel and to bring participants in the conspiracy to trial. The investigation and trial have been declared hallmarks by the Government, which said it upended a conspiracy that controlled the prices of $1 billion in commerce. Page A1.
 
$3.4 Billion Approved for I.M.F.
The House approved only $3.4 billion of the $18 billion that President Clinton is seeking for the International Monetary Fund. The action left the agency in limbo as its reserves dwindle and economic crises mount around the world. The Senate has approved the full amount, and there is still a chance that when both houses meet over the next few weeks to iron out their differences they will agree to provide the full request. C2.
 
Bond Yields Continue Their Slide
Treasury bond prices rallied as investors sold stocks and sought the safety of Government securities. The yield on the 30-year bond dropped to 5.18 percent, from 5.22 percent on Wednesday, its lowest level in 30 years. In the last three months the 30-year bond's yield has fallen more than half a percentage point. C5.
 
Bayer to Acquire Unit of Chiron
Bayer, the German drug and chemical giant, will buy the American diagnostics business of Chiron for $1.1 billion and 50 percent of the farm seed subsidiary of Crompton & Knowles. Bayer also said it would raise money for reorganization by selling to the public up to 75 percent of its Agfa-Gevaert unit. C16.
 
Amendment Slows Spending Bill
A proposal to make it easier for farmers to hire foreigners, most from Mexico, at harvest time is clouding prospects for Congressional approval of a spending bill for the Commerce, Justice and State Departments. A20.
 
House Panel Passes Tax Cut Bill
The House Ways and Means Committee passed an $80 billion Republican tax cut, setting up a confrontation with President Clinton. A20.
 
Banks More Exposed to Loan Risk
Banks are exposing themselves to increased levels of financial risk as 1998 loan underwriting standards declined for the fourth consecutive year, according to an annual survey by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency. C4.

Trade Deficit Grew 2% in July
The trade deficit widened 2 percent in July as exports fell for the fourth consecutive month, while consumer prices changed little in August, Government figures showed. Those findings, together with two other reports that showed a decline in jobless claims and a rise in workers' incomes, suggested that the economy was holding up well in its eighth year of expansion, analysts said. C5.

Nike Profit Drops 35% in Quarter
Nike, the world's top seller of athletic footwear, said its profit dropped 35 percent in the first quarter because of sluggish sales in Asia. C4.
 
Agencies Go on a Buying Spree
Several agencies and agency companies are making acquisitions, including Keroff & Rosenberg, Tempus Group, Hadtke Associates, Bozell Worldwide and Western International Media. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C4.

HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE SPEAKER;
Gingrich Dodges Spotlight, He Is in Charge

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
At a news conference on education legislation, the first question put to Speaker Newt Gingrich this morning involved the White House scandal.
Mr. Gingrich snapped at the questioner. "We in the Congress are actually focusing on substance," he said. "Yesterday, I spent less than 45 minutes total on the topic that interests you most." 
 That is the pose the Speaker has tried to assume all week: the impartial observer waiting for his lawyers on the Judiciary Committee to sort out the facts and set the policy on how to deal with President Clinton's transgressions, while he deals with the people's business.
But behind the scenes, other Republican lawmakers said, not a step is taken or a decision made without the approval of Mr. Gingrich, possibly the most partisan and certainly the most dominant Speaker in the last generation.
"Look, the Speaker is the Speaker," said the chairman of an important committee who insisted on anonymity. "He calls all the shots. If tapes are going to be released, it's his decision. If hearings are going to be held, he will decide. He consults with us. He listens to us. But he makes the calls."
At a closed meeting of House Republicans on Wednesday, Representative Nancy L. Johnson of Connecticut expressed concern about the release of sexually explicit portions of the videotape of the President's grand jury testimony.
Mr. Gingrich -- angry, according to the accounts of some who were there, or merely firm, according to those of others -- leapt to his feet and declared that the House had already voted to make the material public and that Republicans were not going to back down in the face of complaints from the White House and Democrats in Congress. Mr. Gingrich called the President a "misogynist," a person who hates women.
At the same meeting, Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon of upstate New York, the chairman of the Rules Committee, repeated a point Mr. Gingrich had made in a speech last week and reminded his colleagues that House rules did not permit language in floor debates that ridiculed or otherwise abused the President.
There was a smattering of boos, clearly in jest, from the back of the room, said people who were there. Mr. Gingrich, they said, declared sternly that decorum in the House was not a laughing matter and that he would not allow the rules to be abridged.
When Mr. Gingrich walked out of the meeting and into a gaggle of reporters and cameras, he made a conspicuous show of talking about other issues -- trade and the economy -- and even praised Mr. Clinton's efforts to renew world economic growth.
When reporters persisted in asking questions about impeachment and videotaped testimony, Representative John A. Boehner, Republican of Ohio, pushed the Speaker from the microphone so that staff members could usher him away.
"It is very important to us that Newt lie low," said a Republican representative from the Southeast. This Congressman explained that Mr. Gingrich often came across to the public as strident and even mean and that if the Speaker allowed himself to stand at the forefront of the Clinton inquiry, the President and his allies would benefit by making him a lightning rod for their criticism of Congress.
Mr. Gingrich is under conflicting pressures. The firebrands among the backbenchers want to go after President Clinton with all the artillery in the House's arsenal. But the Speaker's political advisers are telling him, a former staff assistant said, that if he has any ambition to become President, this is his opportunity to dispel a reputation as a hothead and adopt the mien of a statesman.
One Republican Congressman suggested half-seriously that the most advantageous step the Speaker could take would be to save Mr. Clinton's Presidency.
"It might not be best for the country," the Congressman said, "but they would have a cripple as President going into the next election, and Newt would go down as a profile in courage."
With all that in mind, Mr. Gingrich tended carefully this week to the ceremonial and legislative aspects of his job.
He spoke at a conference on missile defense, received a Hispanic Heritage Leadership Award and another award from the Community Antidrug Coalition, met with chief executives of some of the United States' largest companies, attended news conferences on education, agriculture policy and prayer in schools, appeared on the Capitol steps with representatives of Habitat for Humanity and taped an interview for a cable television documentary on the 100 people who have the most influence on American society.
For the most part, Mr. Gingrich stayed on message, but occasionally he let slip oblique mentions of the subject that must be on his mind, too.
Speaking extemporaneously at a news conference on Wednesday about a proposed constitutional amendment allowing organized prayer in public schools, he declared, "In this city today, we have the specter of a scandal large enough that it should be driving all of us to prayer."
And this morning, to mark the 211th anniversary of the signing of the Constitution, he gave a one-minute speech on the House floor during the period set aside for members to address any subject of their choice. Mr. Gingrich said the framers of the Constitution had been determined to show "once and for all that the age of kings was over, that all men and women are under the law -- none is above it, and none is below it."

HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: TEPID WELCOME;
In Cincinnati, the President Makes a Most Abnormal Visit

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: CINCINNATI, Sept. 17

 BODY:
On the surface, it was a perfectly normal Presidential visit, with all the symbols of power on display.
President Clinton landed at lunchtime at Greater Cincinnati Airport, across the Ohio River in Kentucky, in his imposing blue-and-white jet, Air Force One, with the big Presidential seal on its side. A pair of Air Force enlisted men snapped to attention as a ramp rolled into place. A long black limousine with flags flying from its fenders stood ready, along with a queue of local politicians. 
 Mr. Clinton chatted with each person in the group, smiling warmly if less broadly than usual. As usual, he was late -- 25 minutes.
But it was, in fact, a most abnormal visit. Back in Washington, the House Judiciary Committee was meeting to decide whether to release the videotape of the President giving testimony about Monica S. Lewinsky to a grand jury. Representative Steve Chabot of Cincinnati, a Republican, sits on the committee.
After a long debate within her campaign organization about whether being seen with Mr. Clinton today would help her or hurt her, Mayor Roxanne Qualls of Cincinnati, Mr. Chabot's Democratic opponent this fall, turned up at the airport. Mr. Clinton asked Mayor Qualls to ride into the city with him, and she did.
But she had told a reporter pointedly earlier this week, "I am not a close personal friend of the President in any sense of the phrase."
Other Democratic politicians in the region who might have found a way to be there, had the President not been in such deep political trouble, stayed away today, for whatever reason. Gov. Paul E. Patton of Kentucky sent the Lieutenant Governor, Steven Henry. Neither Mary Boyle, the former County Commissioner from Cleveland who is running for the Senate in Ohio this fall, nor Representative Ted Strickland, a Democrat whose district runs eastward from the Cincinnati exurbs, found their way to the airport.
In the best of circumstances, this would be a tough year for Ohio Democrats. Gov. George V. Voinovich, a popular Republican, is strongly favored over Ms. Boyle in the Senate race, and the Ohio Secretary of State, Bob Taft, the possessor of a magic Republican name, is running well ahead in the contest for Mr. Voinovich's job. But Democratic candidates are getting jumpier by the day.
If Mr. Clinton wondered why, he could have scanned the front page of today's Cincinnati Enquirer. There were photographs of six local residents, with comments they sent in response to the paper's invitation. Two were more or less supportive of the President, but the rest were highly critical. Two called on him to resign and another, Jennifer Weber of Oxford, Ohio, wrote: "How can you stand for a moral and ethical country and help people live the American dream when you are the epitome of America's problems?"
The paper received 1,464 messages and printed three full pages of them. It said 3 out of 4 who sent faxes and letters wanted Mr. Clinton to go; those who sent E-mail messages, mostly younger, were more forgiving.
In an editorial last Sunday, the paper itself was harsh.
"President Bill Clinton has lied his way out of the most powerful office in the world," The Enquirer declared. "To endure such a dishonest man as our national leader is more shame and humiliation than our nation can tolerate. He needs our prayers. But he cannot remain in the White House. If he lacks the basic decency, honor and sense of duty to resign, he should be impeached."
Despite national, regional and local polls showing that a majority of respondents want neither a resignation nor an impeachment, those calling the Washington offices of Ohio lawmakers obviously feel otherwise.
A "large volume of calls" to Senator John Glenn, a Democrat who said this week that it would be "reckless and injudicious" for him to join "the rush to judgment" in the Lewinsky matter, have run 2 to 1 in favor of resignation or impeachment. Mr. Chabot's office said the tally there was 425 to 15 against Mr. Clinton since Kenneth W. Starr issued his report a week ago.
Not that the President lacks vocal supporters in this state. The Ohio Democratic chairman, David J. Leland, said, "The vast majority of Ohio Democrats want to see this President continue in office, because they know a political lynching when they see one."
Even conclusive proof that Mr. Clinton lied to the grand jury in the Lewinsky case "wouldn't change anyone's minds here," Mr. Leland said in a telephone interview.
Mr. Clinton got an equally fervent vote of confidence this afternoon from Stanley Chesley, the host of a fund-raising luncheon at his house in the city's northern suburbs. Mr. Chesley praised the President for "monumental" courage in the face of repeated attacks and added: "We need you. I need you."
Mr. Chesley, one of the nation's leading trial lawyers, who has made a fortune from contingency fees in cases like the Bhopal chemical disaster in India, has raised millions of dollars for Democratic candidates in recent years. Today's goal was $500,000 for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. Considerably more than that was raised last March at a similar event for the Democratic National Committee at Mr. Chesley's house.
The President contrasted his stands on Social Security, the world economy, public education and health care with those of the Republicans on Capitol Hill. He urged his listeners to "look your friends dead in the eye" and tell them: "It's not about Washington. It's about America and these issues."
Washington, he said, is "obsessed with itself instead of America."
On the way to the luncheon, Mr. Clinton passed a small group of supporters and a larger group of opponents calling for him to resign.
But he talked to no ordinary voters. Mayor Qualls invited him to visit one of the Cincinnati neighborhoods that have applied for a Federal "empowerment zone" grant. But the Mayor said White House officials had rejected the idea on the ground that a visit to one applicant would be unfair to others.

HEADLINE: What Happened to Those Global Rate Cuts?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
On Monday President Clinton declared that in the midst of the greatest economic turmoil in a half-century, "the industrial world's chief priority today, plainly, is to spur growth." The markets soared, figuring that the combination of a Presidential call to arms and a statement issued the same day by the seven largest industrial economies meant coordinated action was on the way -- chiefly a cut in interest rates.
By Wednesday afternoon, that hope was dashed. First Germany, then the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, said that "there is no endeavor to coordinate interest rate cuts." 
 Was this a case of miscommunication? Of a weakened President trying to address a global crisis with a strong speech instead of an immediate action plan? Or at a moment of maximum financial peril, is the world relying on four leaders -- in Japan, in Germany, in the United States and in Russia -- who see the unfolding crisis in very different terms, and are each holding on to power by a thread?
A miscommunication case seems unlikely. Mr. Greenspan, White House officials note, helped draft the statement that the Group of Seven nations turned out on Monday. It was no accident that the language Mr. Clinton used in his speech the same day closely paralleled the wording the countries had agreed to over the weekend.
Moreover, Mr. Greenspan seemed to hint that the crisis could lead the Fed to cut rates in the United States, even if it acted alone. He noted that the forces of deflation -- not a word Mr. Greenspan uses lightly -- were moving toward American shores. And if Mr. Greenspan's colleagues around the world were planning a cut, the last thing he would do is telegraph the punch.
That leaves the two other options. By all accounts, Mr. Clinton's six-point plan for global recovery is still vague, at best. And even Mr. Clinton's own advisers, speaking on condition of anonymity, concede that its execution depends on a display of raw power by leaders who are hardly in a position to swing for the fences.
"You have to give the President credit and support for trying to get the country focused on this issue," said Robert B. Zoellick, the president-designate of the Center for Strategic and International Studies, who tried to manage the competing interests of the world's economic powers when he worked for James A. Baker 3d at both the Treasury and State Departments.
"But it should have come months ago, and you have this sense -- as you often have in the Clinton Administration -- that they were putting it all together at the last moment."
In fact, some of the aides surrounding Mr. Clinton acknowledge that the speech, and the actions that follow it, should have come before Russia was in full collapse, and before Latin America was threatened. But they argue that now that Mr. Clinton has entered the fray, he intends to push through his agenda for world recovery -- despite the calls for his resignation or impeachment.
"There is no question that American leadership is indispensable if things are going to actually happen," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said Wednesday. "And there's equally no question that the President has provided that leadership, and the world looks to him for that leadership."
Still, the central conundrum in calling for concerted action against the economic contagion is that no country sees the problem -- or the solution -- through the same prism. In times of world prosperity, that is rarely a problem. At times like this, it can be disastrous.
In Germany, there are two dominating issues: the coming election that will decide if Chancellor Helmut Kohl wins another term after 16 years in power, and the imminent creation of the European Monetary Union.
Mr. Kohl's aggressive moves to aid Russia since the fall of the Soviet Union is a sore point with voters. He is not about to worsen his already-pessimistic poll numbers by suggesting that Germany should set aside its own domestic imperatives to act as one of the locomotives to pull the rest of the world out of trouble.
A senior official who deals with Germany daily on the economic crisis notes that "you get the sense that they think all this would go away if the world would just pull up its socks." Put simply, a crisis that began in Asia still seems distant to most people in Germany, even more distant than it seemed to many Americans before its impact here began to affect farmers in Idaho and chip makers in Silicon Valley.
There is another reason for German reticence: Lowering interest rates now, even as part of a global cut, might signal a diminishment of the country's postwar vow to eradicate inflation. That is hardly the message Germany wants to send as it is about to adopt the common European currency, the euro.
In Japan, there are different preoccupations. The country's weak Prime Minister, Keizo Obuchi, arrives in New York on Sunday, and had hoped to bring at least modest evidence that the country's Parliament was closer to solving its huge banking problems and stimulating an economy that is shrinking at an alarming rate. Right now Mr. Obuchi is stuck in the mud, without the power to strike a deal with the opposition, and stunned by the mounting criticism around the globe that Japan is responsible for much of Asia's problems.
"The way the Japanese see it, the only crisis is their internal one," said Jeffrey Garten, a former top Clinton Administration official and now dean of the Yale School of Management. The result is that Mr. Obuchi, who meets Mr. Clinton on Tuesday, is in a position to promise nothing in the way of bank reform and fiscal stimulus beyond what Japan has already announced -- a plan the markets and the Treasury view as insufficient.
In Moscow, Boris N. Yeltsin is presiding over a Government that today announced it was going to do exactly what the world had warned it not to do -- print rubles to pay off its debts, even if it touches off hyperinflation.
And then there is Mr. Clinton, trying to convince the world that he can save his job and remake the world's financial architecture all at once.
Perhaps he can: His top aides have fanned out across Washington this week to make the argument that Mr. Clinton is dealing with the calls for his resignation or impeachment by digging even deeper into major issues on his plate, starting with steering clear of the huge icebergs that could rupture the sleek economic vessel the United States has become. It is a tough case to make. Clearly the only issue focusing White House aides now is the President's survival in office.
"Are we distracted?" one White House aide asked rhetorically this week. "Well, it's fair to say there are more people in this building working to save the President than there are to save Brazil."

HEADLINE: For Affluent Blacks, Harlem's Pull Is Strong

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
Howard Sanders had garnered the trappings of American success: a degree from Harvard Business School, a position with a high-powered Manhattan investment firm and an apartment on Central Park West.
But Mr. Sanders, who is black, felt so strongly about one day owning a home in Harlem, where he had grown up, that it became a condition of his marriage proposal. Today, he and his wife, Karen, and their daughter, Samantha, live in a five-bedroom brownstone with a Japanese garden on West 147th Street. 
 "I don't have to live next to a white family," Mr. Sanders, 32, said. "I effectively have integrated. I've gone to predominantly white schools. I work in a white firm, and I can live anywhere I want. It really is psychologically soothing for me to be in Harlem."
What started in the early 1990's as a trickle of young African-American lawyers, doctors, professors and bankers moving back to Harlem and other historically black neighborhoods seems now to have reached the flood stage.
Black professionals are snatching up 5,000-square-foot brownstones off avenues named for black leaders. And their financial commitments extend beyond new boilers and restoring woodwork; they are also looking to bring the amenities they had found in SoHo and the Upper West Side to neighborhoods that, while on the upswing, are still marked by abandonment and a dearth of shops and restaurants.
Falling crime rates, relatively low housing prices, striking residential architecture and signs of economic renewal are all factors in the influx of affluent young black people to historically black neighborhoods. But certain intangibles -- Harlem's storied place in the black consciousness, a new generation's changing sensibility about integration, simple idealism -- have played a role as well, scholars and new arrivals say.
"There's an economic incentive because you can basically get housing for 30 to 40 percent of what you'd pay 25 blocks away," said Darren Walker, who gave up a doorman building in midtown Manhattan and a career in the bond department of a Swiss bank to move to Harlem and become a vice president of the nonprofit Abyssinian Development Corporation.
"But I have always had a fascination with the Harlem of legend and folklore," he said. "Reading the writers of the Harlem Renaissance created a lot of mythologies in our heads. I just feel this visceral kind of connection that I don't know how to describe."
Real estate brokers say there has also been a parallel increase over the last five years in buyers without those connections -- white families and a small number of Asian-Americans -- who are simply attracted by the amount of space and bygone splendor their money can buy.
"We've got houses up there with Honduran mahogany and 24-karat gold leaf molding in the dining rooms," said Willie Kathryn Suggs, a broker who estimates that buyers who are not black now account for about 30 percent of her clients for row houses and condominiums. "To be able to have that kind of house in the city is attractive to all kinds of people."
Other brokers say that the percentage of new buyers who are not black is probably lower, between 10 and 15 percent, but that the number is increasing more rapidly than the number of black buyers.
Ms. Suggs cited as one example a white couple -- a lawyer and a business consultant -- who closed last month on a row house in the Hamilton Heights neighborhood, and who told her they wanted to attract theater companies to the area.
 
Planting the Seeds For a New Renaissance
Brokers say they have seen the effects of Harlem's pull. Housing prices in West Harlem have risen 20 percent in five years, according to R. Kenyatta Punter, a broker with the Harlem-based Myers, Smith & Granady realty agency. Hard to market in the early 1990's, brownstones are now selling briskly, at prices ranging from $80,000 for an abandoned shell to $450,000 for a house in perfect condition.
Many of the homes predate the Harlem Renaissance of the 1920's, which is when many black people moving to New York chose to live in Harlem, in part because it had a surplus of rental apartments.
Beginning in the 1930's and accelerating through the 40's and 50's, large numbers of black professionals left Harlem, although a small middle-class presence remained through the decades, said Winston James, an assistant professor of history at Columbia University who specializes in the Harlem Renaissance. Their departure followed the decay of apartments during the Depression and new opportunities for integration in places like Brooklyn and Queens.
Professor James said the recent return of well-to-do blacks began in the early 1990's and now seems "to be expanding tremendously."
"There is a sense of idealism among a large number of black professional young people," he said. "There is a terrible frustration about the condition of black people in the society despite the progress of many members of the professional class. I suppose one of the ways people attempt to make some kind of contribution is by their physical presence."
That is certainly true of Dr. Michael E. Jones. A 29-year-old ear, nose and throat resident at Mount Sinai Medical Center, Dr. Jones decided to move to Harlem after receiving undergraduate and medical degrees from Columbia University.
"It was important for me to be in Harlem because I needed a sense of purpose," he said. "Being in Chelsea or TriBeCa or the Upper East Side, I wouldn't feel that my presence could make a difference. Children on my block say, 'Hey, Doc.' They see me working hard. And because they can see it and touch it, they may feel it's something they can attain."
His home, on West 147th Street between Convent and St. Nicholas Avenues, is a handsome 6,000-square-foot brownstone in the leafy section known both as Sugar Hill and Hamilton Heights.
With Dr. Jones's BMW parked out front and his carefully tended impatiens in back, the house has become a beacon for young people tempted to give Harlem a try. "I started having networking parties and became a funnel for a lot of young black professionals who wanted to find brownstones here," he said.

A Lack of Amenities Draws Entrepreneurs
One drawback is the lack of stores and services. Although ground was recently broken for Harlem USA, an ambitious retail and entertainment complex on 125th Street that is to include the area's first Gap and Disney stores, commercial development farther north has been spotty.
"When friends come to visit or when I'm tired and want to grab a quick cup of gourmet coffee, I absolutely wish those amenities were here," Dr. Jones said. "But it's my dream to make them happen. It's up to us to do it."
Having already carved out a busy sideline in real estate development by buying, renovating and selling old brownstones and boardinghouses, mostly in Hamilton Heights, Dr. Jones is now determined to fill the void of stylish restaurants with his latest venture, the Sugar Hill Cafe. The plan calls for a combination coffeehouse, restaurant and jazz club on three floors of a brownstone at 458 West 145th Street.
Dr. Jones bought the building in June for $300,000 with two partners who are also Harlem residents: Dineo Khabele, a fellow in gynecology-oncology at Montefiore Medical Center, and her husband, James Hunter, an engineer. The three plan to spend $450,000 to renovate the tattered turn-of-the-century building, where the original oak floors and carved mantelpieces are still intact. They are now seeking financing.
"You have the most affluent neighborhood in Harlem," Dr. Jones said, "without any quality dining establishments within walking distance."
Other black professionals are considering buying franchises to open businesses like florists and copy centers. The franchise chains are expanding into Harlem and four other city neighborhoods through a new program sponsored by the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, a nonprofit group in Manhattan, and the Bankers Trust Company.
The sponsors are recruiting entrepreneurs to team up with local community development groups to buy the franchises, benefiting from below-market financing and looser equity requirements. The first such franchise, a Sterling Optical store, opened in Harlem on Sept. 2 on the corner of 125th Street and Malcolm X Boulevard.
 
Moving In With Money And Fresh Ideas
While no hard numbers exist to document the movement of black professionals to Harlem, the higher real estate prices speak volumes.
"In the last five years, it has really gained momentum," said Sherman Edmiston, a Harlem real estate agent whose wife, Essie Green Edmiston, owns an art gallery there. "We are getting more of the younger people coming here with the idea that they want to be part of the rebuilding of Harlem. They've got fresh ideas and a considerable amount of money."
In some ways, the Edmistons were pioneers in deciding 10 years ago to move their home and art gallery from Park Slope in Brooklyn to Harlem. Like many parts of the city, Harlem was then in the throes of the crack epidemic, and art meccas like SoHo or 57th Street would have seemed a more likely choice for their gallery, which sells the art of such black masters as Jacob Lawrence and Romare Bearden.
"But we felt that our concentration is really on developing the collections of black collectors, and there's a poetry to our being in Harlem as opposed to being downtown," said Mr. Edmiston, who also works in the gallery.
The couple might have also considered Bedford-Stuyvesant, a historically black community in Brooklyn that has plenty of scruffy bodegas and garish beauty parlors but is known for its beautiful brownstones. It, too, is drawing black professionals.
Lewis A. Watkins, district manager of Community Board 3, which covers Bedford-Stuyvesant, attributes the trend to rising housing prices in Brooklyn neighborhoods like Park Slope and Brooklyn Heights. "You can buy the same town house in Bed-Stuy for $250,000 that would sell for a half-million dollars in Park Slope," he said.
But for Monique Greenwood, the executive editor of Essence magazine, and her husband, Glenn Pogue, a broadcast engineer for WNBC-TV, money was not the only motivator. "We could easily go to the suburbs," she said, "but we're about rebuilding our communities and living in them."
One concern the couple had was the public schools. Ms. Greenwood said that while she wanted her 6-year-old daughter, Glynn, to attend a public school, "I wasn't convinced that I wanted my child to suffer because of my political beliefs."
After checking out several private schools in Brooklyn, as well as the public elementary schools, the couple decided that Glynn could receive as good an education in the gifted program in their neighborhood school as in private school. But they knew it would mean more involvement on their part.
During the last school year, the couple met weekly with other parents, teachers and administrators as part of the school-based management team to discuss issues, from the curriculum to grant money. In the spring, they sat on the selection committee responsible for hiring the new principal.
Like Dr. Jones in Harlem, Ms. Greenwood also missed the smorgasbord of services in wealthier New York neighborhoods. So she, too, took matters into her own hands. Three years ago, she and her husband opened Akwaaba Mansion, a lavish bed-and-breakfast in the 18-room house that is also their home. (Akwaaba means welcome in Akan, a language spoken in Ghana.)
Last month, they opened Akwaaba Cafe, a restaurant with burgundy banquettes and light fixtures of copper wire, parchment paper and colored glass beads. "I realized I had to be involved in economic development," Ms. Greenwood said, "because the amenities I would want in a neighborhood just weren't there."
While the commercial life of Harlem may never be as abundant as points south in Manhattan, that's fine with Mr. Sanders, the investment banker. (It's easy enough, he said, to drive five minutes south for Sunday brunch on Amsterdam Avenue.) Harlem, he says, feeds his soul in a way that other Manhattan neighborhoods never could.
"To be quite honest, there are cultural differences, and when you live in your own community, there's not that pressure to assimilate," he said.
"I'm basking in my own culture when I go to the Schomburg Center," he said, referring to the New York Public Library's Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture. "If I lived in the West Village I couldn't do that. I'd have to seek out activities that brought me into contact with black professionals."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Capital Spending Takes a Break;
Asia Crisis and Overcapacity Threaten Pillar of Growth

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Having just built one new factory and expanded another, the Chrysler Corporation is cutting back on capital investment. AT&T has also shaved its capital spending, but for a different reason: It purchased an existing phone network, rather than spending the money to build a new one. And Motorola Inc., its sales hurt by the Asian crisis, is postponing investments in new factories and machinery, even going so far as to halt construction of a huge $3 billion semiconductor plant in Virginia.
Capital spending, a pillar of the nation's strong economic growth over the last three years, is beginning to fade. First falling exports, then falling stock prices and now a slowdown in capital spending are chipping away at the vigorous economy, watering down growth in the second half of the year. Despite these hits, the economy appears to be strong enough to stay out of recession for now, thanks to robust consumer spending. 
 "The economy is not falling apart," said David Wyss, chief economist at Standard & Poor's DRI, a data gathering and forecasting service. "What you are seeing is some evidence of a weakening in capital spending, partly in response to Asia and partly because, in most industries, we have already added as many new facilities as we are likely to need for a while."
Capital spending is the investment that companies and individuals make in the machinery, equipment and buildings to operate their businesses and make them more efficient. The cumulative result is a more vigorous and productive economy. In the 1990's, robust capital spending has been a huge contributor to the economy's overall growth, accounting for 25 percent of the total expansion in output in this decade -- substantially more than in either the 1970's or the 1980's.
While the falloff in sales to Asia has played a significant role in discouraging capital spending, a bigger obstacle -- one only partly a result of the Asian downturn -- appears to be overcapacity. In interviews with officials at 15 corporations, many said that after having made huge investments in recent years to increase production, they were pausing while sales caught up.
Even without an outsized crisis like the one emanating from Asia, corporate America normally goes through cycles of robust capital spending followed by pullbacks. And more than seven years into the current economic expansion, this appears to be a time for pullback.
"Until we see that more demand is likely to occur, we are not going to go into another cycle of capacity expansion," said Wynn Van Bussman, the chief economist at Chrysler, which recently completed a new engine factory in Detroit and expanded a transmission factory. "We don't expect sales in North America to be higher in the next year or two than they already are this year."
Like Chrysler, Levi Strauss & Company worries about overcapacity. Even after closing 11 factories in the United States in recent months, the company still has the capacity to manufacture more jeans than it can sell in this country. So it is shifting money out of its capital spending budget and into marketing. "In the United States in the next year, we will come close to doubling our advertising and promotion budget," Clarence Grebey, a Levi Strauss spokesman, said, "and part of that is coming from capital expenditure."
Capital spending at Motorola, the communications giant, has been curtailed because of a worldwide downturn in semiconductor sales and falling prices for these computer chips. The downturn is partly a result of recessions in Asia and partly a result of overcapacity domestically.
Whatever the balance of those reasons, Motorola's $4.5 billion capital spending budget for this year, much of it earmarked for the United States, has been slashed to $2.9 billion. Nearly half the cutback involves semiconductor operations. Motorola announced on Wednesday that while construction continued at a huge semiconductor plant in Chandler, Ariz., ground-breaking for another equally large one near Richmond, scheduled for next month, had been postponed -- "until the market for semiconductors justifies new construction," Scott Stevens, a Motorola spokesman, said yesterday. "Do I have any idea when that will be? No. This is an unprecedented downturn, the worst in semiconductor history."
The incipient pullback in capital spending is developing rapidly. After having shot up at an annual rate of 16 percent from January through June, the growth rate for capital outlays will probably shrivel to 5 percent or 6 percent in the second half, some forecasters say. That would subtract at least one-quarter of a percentage point from the growth rate for the economy as a whole. Even without the hit from capital spending, economic growth is likely to be under 2 percent, as it was in the second quarter. During that quarter, falling exports and excessive stockpiles of unsold goods forced a variety of cutbacks in production.
Shrinking profits are also playing a role in corporate America's decision to go easy on capital spending. And falling prices have had their impact, particularly in such industries as steel, copper, oil and agriculture. The Case Corporation, for example, announced last week that it was curtailing production of tractors and combines, which are capital expenditures for farmers. The Phelps Dodge Company has responded to falling copper prices by cutting capital outlays to less than $180 million in the second half from $280 million in last year's first half.
"The supply of copper and the demand for it are in pretty good balance," Thomas M. Foster, a Phelps Dodge vice president, said. "But we have seen lower copper prices for some time, and they appear to be related to the perception that the Asian crisis will precipitate a worldwide slowdown. So we have not initiated new projects at any of our plants."
In some cases, acquisitions have become a substitute for capital spending. AT&T took this route. Rather than invest huge sums in local lines to connect business customers to AT&T's long-distance network, the company in July acquired Teleport Communications Group, which already owns local networks in major cities. The acquisition was a factor in AT&T's decision to hold capital spending to $7 billion this year, roughly the same as last year -- after four years of rapidly rising investment.
"Without this purchase, we might have invested more to create infrastructure," said Eileen Connolly, an AT&T spokeswoman.
Detailed economic data for the third quarter will not be available until next month, but various statistics are signaling the turn in capital spending. For example, spending on commercial construction, particularly factories but also office buildings, has begun to fall, the Commerce Department reports. Orders for nondefense capital goods, which are most of the equipment and machinery purchased by American companies, leveled off in the first half, after having risen sharply in 1996 and 1997. And corporate America is operating its productive facilities within the United States at a relatively moderate 81.7 percent of full capacity, which is slightly below the long-term average.
The National Association of Purchasing Management, in a monthly survey of American manufacturers, found that capital spending projects currently in progress would take only 119 days on average to complete -- down from 130 days last summer. The 119 days is the lowest level in the nearly 11 years that the association has compiled this statistic, suggesting that companies are commissioning fewer new projects.
The association also surveys companies in the service sector. Although this survey lacks a specific question about capital spending, answers to questions that are included give the strong impression that service-sector companies are also cutting back. "Capital spending at service companies is certainly not increasing; at best it is flat," said Ralph Kaufman, a University of Houston management professor who runs the service-sector survey.
There are bright spots. Although Asian recessions have cut into Caterpillar Inc.'s sales of earthmovers and construction equipment, the company says it is increasing capital spending anyway. "We are moving into new products," said Douglas R. Oberhelman, Caterpillar's chief financial officer, "including electric power generation from diesel engines and the manufacture of very small combines and tractors, which is a good business at the moment."
Consumer spending, far and away the largest single outlay in the American economy, is still quite strong, and that helps to sustain capital investment, which in the second quarter reached $958 billion, adjusted for inflation, or roughly one-fifth of consumer spending. Low interest rates have helped by encouraging store purchases on credit and home building.
Responding to brisk retail sales, Gap Inc. has set aside $700 million for capital spending this year, up from $450 million last year -- earmarking most of the money for new Old Navy and Gap stores. Federated Department Stores Inc. is similarly engaged in store investment: $750 million a year over three years, but mainly to remodel existing stores, not to expand the total number. Hotel and theater construction is still robust, and so is investment in fast-food restaurants.
Wendy's International Inc., trying to catch up to the McDonald's Corporation and Burger King, a unit of Diageo P.L.C., says it will add 675 new restaurants next year, mostly in the United States, up from 550 openings this year. "Ever since we opened our first restaurant 30 years ago, experts have told us that the hamburger restaurant market is oversaturated," Jack Lynch, a Wendy's spokesman, said. "Despite that warning, we now operate 4,600 restaurants in the United States and 600 more abroad. An economic slowdown won't change our plans; we do fine in a recession."
Still, these are exceptions. The Eastman Chemical Company is more the rule.
When the Asian crisis struck, Eastman, which produces ingredients for the manufacture of plastics, paint and other coatings, was in the midst of an investment surge aimed at expansion. The spending is winding down now, more quickly than anticipated because of events in Asia, said Earnest J. Davenport Jr., the chairman at Eastman. That is partly because foreign chemical companies are shipping products to the United States they can no longer sell in Asia, and that cuts into Eastman's sales volume.
"We have delayed some planned capital spending projects in this country," Mr. Davenport said, "and we may delay others."

HEADLINE: UAL President, Pressured by Unions, Quits

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 18

 BODY:
John A. Edwardson, the president and chief operating officer of the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, resigned today because unions at the company would not support his promotion to chief executive next year.
Mr. Edwardson, 49, who joined UAL in July 1994 as president, resigned when it became apparent that he would not have the support of the leaders of the employee-owned airline's machinists', pilots' and flight attendants' unions, said Gerald Greenwald, UAL's chief executive. 
 Mr. Greenwald, 62, is expected to retire from the company's top position next year when his contract with the airline ends. Mr. Edwardson, who became the company's chief operating officer in April 1995, was considered the probable successor.
But Madison Walton, a spokesman for pilots' union, said that after working with Mr. Edwardson "for more than four years, we've determined that his idea of a culture for a majority employee-owned company is different from ours."
The airline, based in Chicago, said it would announce a successor to Mr. Edwardson in a few days. Mr. Greenwald said he and the board had supported Mr. Edwardson, despite the employees' growing concerns.
"I believe it is in everyone's best interests -- our employees', the company's, and mine -- for me to step aside and clear the way for Jerry's eventual successor," Mr. Edwardson said in a statement.

HEADLINE: Will Germany Deny The Past?

BYLINE: By Jacob Heilbrunn; Jacob Heilbrunn is a senior editor at The New Republic

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
With the German election a week away, Gerhard Schroder, the Social Democrat who is favored to defeat Chancellor Helmut Kohl, has been modeling his campaign on Bill Clinton's 1992 strategy of promising economic innovation and generational change.
Unfortunately, Clinton-style opportunism appears to be Mr. Schroder's dominant trait, particularly in his recent denunciation of Mr. Kohl's support for a Holocaust memorial in the center of Berlin, near the Brandenburg Gate and the American Embassy. In so doing, Mr. Schroder has recklessly politicized the Holocaust. 
 The issue had been dormant. Now Mr. Schroder, encouraged by Michael Naumann, a former book publisher whom Mr. Schroder has recruited as a possible culture minister, has said that Germany should become a "self-assured" nation and that a memorial would set the wrong tone. He wants German-American ties to be "more strongly determined by visions of the future than by the burden of the past."
Mr. Naumann has gone even further. Picking up on a pet project of German neo-conservatives, he has said that instead of constructing a memorial, Germans should rebuild Kaiser Wilhelm's palace, which was demolished by East German Communists after World War II.
Such demagogy is a remarkable change for the Social Democratic Party. Traditionally it has emphasized contrition and repentance for the German past. When Willy Brandt, a Social Democrat, was Chancellor, his most famous act was to fall to his knees at the Warsaw ghetto in December 1970.
Neither Mr. Schroder's nor Mr. Naumann's stated reasons for, in effect, abandoning this tradition are remotely persuasive. The memorials at concentration camps far from Berlin do not serve the same purpose that a memorial in the center of the new German capital would.
Dodging confrontation with the Nazi era is hardly a way of displaying "self-assurance." And calling for the reconstruction of Kaiser Wilhelm's palace is childishly provocative.
Yet Mr. Schroder's position has received the support of many intellectuals on the left as well as the right.
Gunter Grass and other left-wingers who signed a manifesto to Mr. Kohl saying that a memorial was "indispensable" in 1989 have now signed a new letter opposing it.
For these intellectuals Mr. Kohl's strong support of the project is one reason to oppose it.
Another is that they want Mr. Schroder to be elected, and a recent poll indicated that a majority of Berliners are against the memorial.
Young intellectuals on the right oppose the memorial because they want to create a self-confident Berlin republic that dispenses with the self-effacement of the defunct cold war Bonn republic. Writing in the daily Die Welt, Tilman Krause, an essayist for the paper, hailed "an end to leftist national masochism."
"What nation would come up with the idea of putting the most horrible acts of its own history in such an exposed position in gigantic dimensions in its capital?" Mr. Krause asked.
In denouncing the memorial, then, Mr. Schroder and Mr. Naumann are exploiting the worst sentiments on both sides of the spectrum. If Mr. Schroder becomes Chancellor, he should think hard about whether the founding act of the new Berlin republic should be to repress the memory of the destruction of European Jewry.

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
On Oct. 16, 1978, 20 years ago next month, Karol Cardinal Wojtyla, the Archbishop of Cracow, became Pope John Paul II. Evaluations of his event-studded pontificate -- already one of the longest in the history of the Roman Catholic Church -- and of his remarkable personality will soon be sprouting left and right (and no doubt reflecting different predispositions, left and right). Such evaluations will obviously require political insight, knowledge about Catholic teaching and a good deal of nuance.
On a less elevated level, they may also benefit from some numbers, and not only how many times the Pope has visited how many countries and how many major church documents he has issued or how many copies of his books have been sold. Here are some other pertinent data, drawn largely from the Vatican's Statistical Yearbook of the Church. 
 From 1978 to 1995, the Roman Catholic Church grew to almost 990 million baptized members from 750 million. At the same time, it shrunk slightly as a proportion of the world's population, to 17.4 percent from 17.8 percent. It especially grew, as has often been reported, in Asia and Africa, both in absolute numbers and as a percentage of the population. In the United States and Western Europe it continued to grow in numbers but, as elsewhere, to shrink slightly as a percentage of the population.
Of course, all these numbers are approximations that blend local reports of varying precision. Comparisons are further complicated by the fact that halfway through John Paul's pontificate, the collapse of Communist regimes allowed new statistics where data had been unavailable. And one wonders how meaningful some of the figures are.
It may be that 97 percent of the Italian population continues to be baptized as of 1995, the same percentage that the Vatican reported for 1978. But that figure scarcely registers the two decades of secularization that Italy's church officials regularly lament.
More reliable indicators of the church's health may be found in the statistics on its "work force," as the yearbook puts it, primarily the numbers of priests and sisters. Here the general impression is that John Paul's papacy has put an end to the hemorrhaging of the church's mid-level leadership, which followed the Second Vatican Council's recasting of church roles in the 1960's and the subsequent debates about celibacy.
The numbers tell a more complicated story. From 1978 to 1995, for example, the numbers of priests grew by 42 in Africa and 48 percent in Asia, but the decline in North America (13 percent) and Europe (12 percent) continued. Because North America and Europe still harbor most of the world's Catholic priests, the overall picture for the world remained a decline of 2.8 percent.
Those are absolute numbers, however, and because the numbers of Catholics have been growing, the ratio of priests to people has become even more strained. In Africa, there were 3,251 Catholics for every priest at the beginning of this pontificate; in 1995 there were 4,476; in Asia the figure went from 2,223 Catholics per priest to 2,620. (In the United States, the figure went to 1,117 from 833.)
The pattern is similar for sisters. The numbers have gone up sharply in Africa and Asia since 1978, but they have gone down so sharply in North America and Europe that by 1995 there were 15 percent fewer nuns worldwide serving a much larger church than at the beginning of John Paul's reign.
It is also interesting to compare such statistics under Pope John Paul II with those under Pope Paul VI. Pope Paul's pontificate, from 1963 to 1978, is often considered a period of extreme postconciliar turmoil and disarray. Yet it is striking how similar the overall score is for both pontificates. Under Paul VI, Catholicism grew in absolute numbers and as a proportion of the population in Africa and Asia, as it would under John Paul II, but still shrank slightly as a percentage of the world's population.
During the 15 years of Pope Paul VI's reign, the number of priests declined 2.7 percent, a loss slightly less than that suffered during the 17 years, from 1978 to 1995, under John Paul II.
In the United States, the number of Catholics who had to be served by each priest grew by 23 percent under Paul VI. Under John Paul II the number has increased by more than 25 percent. And the decline in the number of sisters has been much sharper under the present Pope than the earlier one.
One could tweak these figures in different ways. For example, one could assume a "lag," as economists often do. Thus the first five years of John Paul II's papacy might be chalked up to Paul VI's leadership, and the numbers would almost certainly show that under the current Pope, many of the negative trends that seemed to build in the decade after 1973 were slowed if not completely reversed. In some cases, that was probably because John Paul II's policies were taking effect. In other cases, it was probably a natural settling down -- for example, the priests most likely to leave the active priesthood had already done so.
And one always needs to remember the shortcomings of the data. It would take a major scholarly study to make truly accurate comparisons. Still, one might risk a few very broad conclusions:
First, as witnessed by the similarities in trends under two very different Popes, the major forces affecting the church's health may be well beyond papal leadership -- forces like birth rates and social, economic and cultural changes in both non-Western nations and the church's European-based heartlands.
Second, while some church leaders hail a shift in the church's center of gravity from Europe and North America to Africa and Asia (with traditionally Catholic Latin America partaking of some of the weaknesses of the Old World Catholicism from which it sprang, along with the indigenous religious vitality it shares with other third world regions), it will be a long time, and a hard time, before the new growth can compensate for the apparent loss of morale, which this pontificate does not seem to have arrested, in the church's European and North American territories.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Bond Prices Gain as Stocks Also Post Rise

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Strange things happened on Wall Street yesterday. Prices of both bonds and stocks rose.
A bond rally pushed the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond closer to 5 percent, the lowest level for long-term Government yields in 30 years. 
 But surprisingly, this flight by investors to the Treasury's safe harbor did not come at the expense of stock prices, as has been the case recently. Instead, stocks rallied too, as the Dow Jones industrial average inched up 21.89 points to recover part of its 216-point slide Thursday. The broader Nasdaq index jumped 1 percent.
Altogether, it made for one of the calmest days on Wall Street and in other markets in weeks.
The problems for the American stock market -- weak corporate earnings, a recession in Asia, the threat of one in Latin America and the spillover into the United States -- all remain.
The forecast of I.B.E.S. International, which collects analysts' earnings estimates, for third-quarter earnings of the companies that make up the Standard & Poor's 500 index is now a decline of 1.1 percent, compared with the third quarter a year ago. That would be the first quarterly drop in earnings since 1991.
But Douglas R. Cliggott, the United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities, sees something positive. Earnings forecasts, which two months ago were for 8 percent growth in the third quarter, have come into line with reality, he said.
Given no growth in earnings and the yield on the 30-year bond at 5.25 percent, he said the stock market is now about 9 percent undervalued. "That is a very good cushion for an uncertain world," he said.
The Dow finished at 7,895.66, up three-tenths of 1 percent for the day and 1.3 percent for the week, while the Nasdaq index jumped 17.52 points, to 1,663.77, up 1.1 percent for the day and 1.3 percent for the week. The S.& P. 500 rose 1.22 points, or 1.2 percent, to 1,020.09, putting its gain for the week at 1.1 percent, while the Russell index of 2,000 smaller-company stocks climbed 7.97 points, or 2.2 percent, to 363.26, finishing the week up 2.7 percent.
It is the second consecutive week that all the major indexes have climbed, and this week's rally came despite the deflating comments Wednesday from the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, who told Congress that "at the moment there is no endeavor to coordinate interest rate cuts."
A statement from the finance ministers of the Group of Seven, which comprises the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada, and a speech Monday by President Clinton both raised expectations of an immediate global rate cut to help stabilize world financial markets.
The rush of worried investors into the Treasury market, which may have been accelerated by Mr. Greenspan's comments, is threatening to drive the yield on the 30-year bond below 5 percent, to levels that have not been seen for 30 years. Yesterday the yield fell to 5.14 percent, from 5.18 percent Thursday, while the price, which moves in the opposite direction, rose 18/32 , to 10515/32 .
Analysts, however, are still split over whether the 5 percent barrier, which has stood for the entire careers of most traders on Wall Street, will be breached. Kevin Flanagan, a money market economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said it would take a deepening of the present global financial crisis to bring yields below 5 percent.
He argued that the Fed will not cut its short-term interest rate target when policy makers meet Sept. 29 because there is no clear sign yet that the American economy is slowing down enough. But he is still forecasting a Fed move by the end of the year, by which time he expects the appearance of clear signals that the collapse of economies abroad has begun to sap growth here.
The yield on the 10-year Treasury note, a benchmark for home mortgage rates, dropped to 4.69 percent, from 4.76 percent, presaging a continuing decline in mortgage interest rates. Thirty-year mortgage rates at 6.66 percent are now the lowest they have been in about 30 years and should help stimulate the housing market.
But interest rates on mortgages and high-grade corporate debt have not fallen nearly as much as Treasury yields, and the interest rates on junk bonds have risen. Because of this, the stimulus to the economy from lower Government rates will be muted.

HEADLINE: A Little Town and the Big Top;
After Months of Traveling, Circus Settles in New Home

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

DATELINE: WALDEN, N.Y.

 BODY:
"Here's the town the circus came to, when it came to town," said Darren Hernandez, the Village Manager of this postage stamp-size community straddling the Wallkill River in the Hudson Valley.
He smiled with satisfaction. "And then it decided to stay." 
 Now, 12586, the Walden ZIP code, is the first permanent address of the Big Apple Circus, a 21-year-old icon of street-smart entertainment that is celebrated for pitching its one-ring tent in the urban wilderness.
The circus's new home is far from Gotham -- nearly 70 miles to the north, actually -- in a former wire-extruding factory on 30 woodsy acres. In a cavernous, 50,000-square-foot industrial space, the circus has created a place to mount its new shows, including "Happy On," scheduled to make its debut in Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center on Oct. 22.
So this all-American Orange County village, once trumpeted as "the Sheffield of America" for its knife manufacturing before the factories closed and the jobs left, has been learning to live with an exotic, extravagantly international invasion of more than 100 circus tummlers, tumblers and big-top eccentrics, not to mention 3 elephants, 27 dogs, 8 horses and 8 parakeets.
There are, of course, a few residents who have made it known that they think Big Apple should be contributing more to Walden's diminished local tax base. Economic development aside, though, few people would disagree that the arrival of the circus has done wonders for Walden's communal self-esteem, which suffered mightily not long ago when a radio shock jock from the other side of the Hudson decided to make the village the butt of a bizarre guerrilla war of the airwaves. The circus people might be a bit odd, but any discomfort along those lines tends to pale against being known in radioland as New York's version of Dogpatch.
For the most part, village residents say, they have grown accustomed to the sight of a dozen Chinese acrobats carrying off 35-pound bags of rice from the supermarket, to encounters with juggling troupes in the laundromat, and to glimpses of elephants and horses taking their exercise.
But grocery schleppers in the Thruway Shopping Center, near the circus headquarters, still do a double take when they catch sight of Bello Nock, the Big Apple's star clown, with his four-inch-high, er, platform of stiffly sprayed reddish-blond hair.
"Sometimes," he said, "they ask to touch it." He lets them.
"At first we were concerned that they'd be carnival types, who are pretty tough," said June DeBates, a waitress at the Walden Diner. "But we learned that circus people are really the salt of the earth."
Scott Hecht, a Walden tow truck operator who has come to the aid of Big Apple vehicles, put it this way: "You know how some people have dogs in their backyards? Well, these people have elephants."
And a lot of other stuff, too. While the clowny red and white tent on Edmunds Lane is visible to any of the 6,500 townsfolk who drive by, hidden away on the property is a tiny circus village of 40 house trailers and dozens of vehicles, including cars, trucks, generator vans and the communal dining trailer that serves more than 300 meals a day.
Behind the old factory, the performers have arrayed their mobile homes in a tidy grid of brand- new streets. (One, named after circus benefactors Belle and Murray Nathan, has a yellow street sign proclaiming it "Nathan Lane.")
This is the troupe's first season in the fully renovated $4 million building, although Big Apple first began leasing space in Walden in 1995 before buying the factory last year and producing a show in the unfinished space.
For two decades "we'd been creating the show under primitive conditions," said Paul Binder, Big Apple's 55-year-old founder and artistic director. The first performances of the fledgling circus in 1977 were mounted in the tiny Synod House at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in Manhattan.
Then, Big Apple shuffled off to makeshift rehearsal spaces in East Harlem and SoHo in Manhattan and Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn, "where helicopters took off in the middle of the night and the Concorde swooped over us twice a day," said Katja Schumann, the show's star equestrian. "Now that was noise."
Frustrated by high city prices, and guided by a circus friend of Mr. Binder who trains bears and lives in nearby Middletown, Big Apple made the connection to Walden, where lower-priced properties were available.
The compound is formally designated the Slifka Family Creative Center (after the major donor) and has five indoor practice spaces as well as workshops to restore the show's infrastructure, which takes a beating when the show is on the road.
"Wherever we traveled, we were always at home in the ring surrounded by the family of the circus," said Michael Christensen, creative director. "But now, for the first time, we can feel at home in a place."
Around Walden, the feeling is mostly mutual. "They've been good neighbors, and Big Apple has been a good thing for Walden," said Carl J. Aiello, editor and publisher of the local weekly, The Wallkill Valley Times on East Main Street.
For several years now, Big Apple has lent its performers to the annual Walden Day celebration in the village square. And it has welcomed as many as 1,500 local residents to its annual open house. When new shows are ready, the circus also holds a dress rehearsal for 500 invited guests, many of them suppliers and area residents.
And then there is Walden's redemption from that nasty business with the disk jockey, Bob Wohlfeld, a.k.a. "the Wolf," who made the village the target of several years' worth of jokes on his morning radio show. Despite complaints to the radio station, WPDH in Poughkeepsie, and threats against Mr. Wohlfeld, the assault on Walden's reputation subsided only a year ago, when Mr. Wohlfeld left WPDH for a station in Albany.
If Walden's reputation is on the rebound, its economy had already been doing a bit better when the circus settled in. It is a hub for the region's dairy and apple farmers and has a mix of manufacturing, retail and service businesses. And commuters from New York City and from I.B.M. country across the Hudson have spied bargains in the village's rich stock of picturesque 19th-century buildings.
Still, a vocal minority is resentful that the circus, which enjoys nonprofit status because of its children's educational programs, is likely to remove a building that once represented the village's sixth-largest source of property tax income from the local, county and school district tax rolls.
"I'm not opposed to circuses -- why, I even went to the circus in Moscow a few years ago," said David C. Lustig Jr., 76, the owner of Lustig Realty on Main Street and a longtime member of the village Planning Board. "But that building could have accommodated another industrial plant."
Furthermore, he said, the wire factory employed more than 100 local workers who spent money 12 months a year in the community. The circus occupies the property for two months with up to 140 performers and crew members before it goes on tour. Three box office staff members and a caretaker remain.
For now, Big Apple is still paying $45,000 in annual real estate taxes to the Town of Montgomery, Mr. Binder said, although the circus has challenged the payment under its tax-exempt status. Besides, he said, "the factory had been closed for years," adding, "There was little hope of reviving the site."
Mr. Lustig is hardly the only circus critic in Walden. "Given their tax-exempt status, the least they could do for the town is to put on a show for us," said Frank Ciliberto, owner of a Walden plumbing and heating business for 30 years. "Big Apple travels all over the country, but their hometown never gets to see the show."
The invitation-only dress rehearsal is limited to 500 because Big Apple does not have on-site parking spaces for enough guests to fill the 1,980-seat tent, Mr. Binder said.
But beyond this, the circus people say, the point is that they are not in Walden to entertain; they are there to build new shows.
And so, in one of the rehearsal spaces on a recent afternoon, under the harsh factory lights, Todd Robbins, the comedic soloist with the seven-member circus band, was giving a virtuoso performance on washboard, cowbell, klaxon, duck call and, at one point, the Knall 9-millimeter starter pistol. Mr. Robbins explained that he is capable "of the full range from high hokum to the lowest form of hokum."
Living in Walden "is really a dream come true for us," Mr. Christensen said. He recalled a time when all Big Apple practice sessions were scheduled in one tent. "It's such a wonderful problem to have -- to try to figure out which of five rehearsal spaces to put something in."
