HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Global Turmoil Leaves Europe Wondering How to Shield Economy

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: ROME, Sept. 18

 BODY:
As dismal news accumulates around the globe, European economies are proving remarkably resilient. But evidence is multiplying that the Continent's two-year-old recovery is at risk, fueling debate about how to shield Europe from the effects of turmoil elsewhere.
With exports to Asia, South America and Russia flagging, corporate profits are under growing pressure. In Britain, two major semiconductor makers, Japan's Fujitsu and Germany's Siemens, announced plans to close factories, citing cheap imports from Asian countries where currencies have collapsed. In Germany, national elections later this month have markets unnerved by the possibility, for the first time in 16 years, that a Socialist-led government might be returned to power. 
 Wim Duisenberg, head of the new European Central Bank, acknowledged this week that international financial turmoil would have a "dampening effect" on global growth, and that Europe would not be spared. Several major banks and brokerage firms have already trimmed their European growth projections.
"We'd gladly be an isle of the blessed," said Werner Becker, senior economist at Deutsche Bank Research in Frankfurt. "But we're not."
Still, Europe is expected to sustain reasonable growth. While Mr. Becker is among a number of economists calling attention to the region's vulnerability, even he sees no major crisis brewing. He recently predicted that growth for the 11 countries that will adopt the euro on Jan. 1 should be around 2.6 percent for next year, scaling back modestly from his earlier prediction of 3.1 percent.
But the Continent will not escape unscathed from the turmoil raging in Asia and Latin America, and there is fear that things will get worse.
"The contagion effect," he said, "poses a considerable risk for Western Europe."
Similarly, J. Paul Horne, European equity market economist at Salomon Smith Barney in London, trimmed his European growth forecast for 1999, to 2.6 percent from 3.2 percent. For Britain, he projects under 1 percent growth and calls a recession a possibility.
Particularly unsettling, Mr. Becker said, is the slowdown in Britain, which buys roughly 20 percent of the goods and services exported by Continental Europe.
Other leading countries, like Germany, are heavily exposed in Eastern Europe. Though Russia accounts for a mere 2 percent of German trade, Central European countries like Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic now absorb fully 10 percent of German exports, more than the United States. Thus, any spillover of the collapse of Russia's already weak economy into Central Europe would indirectly hurt Germany.
Still, by many measures, Europe is in enviable shape.
Though Britain may be on the brink of recession, other leading countries, like France, Germany and Spain, still show robust growth. Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank has signaled that it continues to see inflation as a threat, and officials from other nations have played down the possibility of quick action on interest rates or other responses to the global economic woes.
Indeed, the Bundesbank, in its September monthly report, depicted Europe's economies as havens of calm and stability amid the turmoil disrupting many of the world's financial markets.
Mr. Duisenberg said that broad indicators showed Europe can expect to be still on track, with "continued expansion in the second quarter, albeit at a possibly more moderate pace" than in the first. Taken together, the data showed inflation growing in Spain, Portugal and Ireland, and an unaccustomed shift in France and Germany, where domestic consumption, rather than exports, fueled growth and progress was made in job creation. In the first eight months of 1998, 320,000 people were taken off Germany's jobless rolls.
European markets have revived since hitting lows in early September, and business investment is expected to get a further lift after the euro is introduced.
"If you look at the four or five channels of transmission between emerging markets and Western Europe, then the real effects have been pretty moderate," said Eric Barthalon, chief economist at Paribas in Paris.
Trade among the 11 euro-zone countries is so extensive, he said, that trade with the rest of the world now accounts for only about 11 percent of the region's total gross domestic product, less than the share in the similarly sized United States, where it is about 14 percent.
Moreover, falling prices for commodities, like oil, benefit European manufacturers, and the collapse of stock markets in Asia, Latin America and Eastern Europe has bolstered Europe financially, by attracting capital in a "flight to quality," he said.
Unlike in the United States, European personal and corporate indebtedness has not grown substantially in recent years, and because Europeans invest in stocks at a lower rate than Americans, less money was drained from the pockets of European consumers by this summer's global market decline.
"We are confident domestic demand will remain strong," Mr. Horne said.
One significant problem for Europe is the weakening of the dollar against European currencies, which makes products sold to the United States more expensive. And while a weakened dollar tended in the past to drag fragile European currencies like the Italian lira down with it, the euro agreement reached last May has forced the dollar to move more or less uniformly against all 11 currencies.
Leaders in several European countries, echoing President Clinton's appeal earlier this week, are raising their voices for some kind of concerted push to contain the fast-spreading global crisis.
Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain has been canvassing leaders of the Group of Seven industrial nations for proposals. In Italy, Prime Minister Romano Prodi, addressing Parliament Wednesday, said the seven must find a "common neo-Keynesian or expansion policy to stimulate the economy" in response to the world's problems. Both leaders are scheduled to meet with President Clinton in New York on Monday.
While Mr. Prodi appeared to be calling for lower interest rates, European central bankers, like Alan Greenspan of the Federal Reserve Board, are clearly not yet ready to act.
Many European economists are not convinced a rate cut is even necessary. Europe's long road to acceptance of the euro, which required governments in the 11 subscribing countries to rein in their fiscal policies, has had a lingering effect akin to monetary easing, from which Europe's economy will continue to benefit for a while.
With the Jan. 1 adoption of the euro by the 11, the new European Central Bank must set a Europe-wide "convergence rate" for short-term interest rates, and a growing number of economists believe it will be pegged to the Bundesbank's current short-term rate of 3.3 percent. Germany and neighboring countries with low interest rates will "doubtless play a type of benchmark role" in setting interest rates for all of Europe, Hans Tietmeyer, the Bundesbank president, said today.
Mr. Tietmeyer said that despite economic turmoil in Asia and Russia, Europe's economy had "remained relatively robust -- at least so far."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Japanese Parties Agree On Economic Strategy
Japan's governing party said that it had reached agreement with the political opposition on how to bolster the jittery financial system and begin reviving the ailing economy.
 The agreement announced by Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi ended weeks of deadlock that had intensified criticism of Japan for dithering over how to solve its problems as economic turmoil spread to financial markets around the world. Page A1. 

U.S. Consumers Are Still Upbeat
Since the financial troubles in Russia, the tumble in stock prices in the United States and elsewhere and the release of Kenneth W. Starr's report, consumers have turned only slightly more cautious, according to a major poll of consumer attitudes. The willingness of consumers to spend is viewed as good news for the economy and President Clinton. A1.
 
Central Bank Frees Ruble Reserves
The Russian central bank said that the country's insolvent banks could use $1.65 billion in precious ruble reserves to enable them to make good on customers' bills and debts that are going unpaid. The Government hopes freeing up the reserves will grease the wheels of the payment system and get financial activity moving again. A4.
 
Right to Sue H.M.O.'s Upheld
A provision in a new Texas law allowing patients to sue health maintenance organizations and other insurers for malpractice was upheld by a Federal judge in Houston, but a second provision allowing patients to appeal to an independent panel when their health plan denies coverage for treatment was struck down. C14.
 
Shareholders Back Chrysler Merger
Chrysler shareholders strongly endorsed forming a huge new international auto maker by merging with Daimler-Benz of Germany. Following their lead, Daimler-Benz's shareholders, meeting well into the night in Stuttgart, overwhelmingly approved the combination. C2.
 
President of UAL Steps Down
John A. Edwardson, left, the president and chief operating officer of UAL, the parent of United Airlines, resigned under pressure from the company's machinists', pilots' and flight attendants' unions, which opposed him as the eventual successor to Gerald Greenwald, the chief executive, who is expected to retire next year. C2.
 
B.P. Sets Target for Emissions Cut
British Petroleum announced today a "firm overall target" to cut emissions by 10 percent of their 1990 levels by 2010, setting a figure for the first time. C2.
 
S.E.C. Drops Insider-Trading Case
The Securities and Exchange Commission has dropped a three-year inquiry into accusations of insider trading by ICN Pharmaceuticals and its chief executive, Milan Panic. But the S.E.C. will start an enforcement action against the company and Mr. Panic for failing to disclose adverse information about its viral drug, ribavirin, the company said. C3.
 
AMP Bolsters Defense Against Bid
AMP stepped up its defense against Allied Signal's hostile bid of $44.50 a share by lowering the threshold of its shareholder rights plan, which makes it prohibitively expensive for Allied to buy more than 10 percent of AMP's stock. C3.
 
Guilty Plea in Trading Scheme
A brokerage employee who worked on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange has pleaded guilty to conspiring with exchange floor brokers to cover up an illegal trading scheme. C14.
 
Alcatel to Consider Share Buyback
Seeking to contain the damage done by its warning on Thursday that its profit would not meet forecasts this year, Alcatel said that it would consider a significant share buyback program. C2.

HEADLINE: Court Backs Giuliani's Way Of Assigning Workfare Hours

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER 

 BODY:
A state appeals court has upheld the way New York City calculates the number of hours that welfare recipients must work in its workfare program to receive benefits.
The State Appellate Division in Manhattan, in a ruling released on Thursday, overturned a lower court decision that said the city's method of calculation, which is based on the minimum wage, was unfair. 
 Since the Giuliani administration created its version of workfare in 1995, city officials have been calculating participants' hours so that their benefits are roughly equal to the minimum wage. A welfare recipient who receives the equivalent of $100 a week in benefits, for example, must work about 20 hours a week in workfare. The minimum wage is $5.15 an hour.
Lawyers for several workfare participants challenged the city's approach in court. In May 1997, Justice Jane S. Solomon of State Supreme Court ruled that the city must base its calculations on what it pays regular city workers for similar tasks, as much as $8 to $10 an hour.
More than 32,000 New Yorkers are enrolled in workfare, known formally as the Work Experience Program. Most of them sweep city streets, clean parks or perform clerical tasks in return for their welfare benefits.
Lawyers for workfare participants had praised Justice Solomon's ruling as a breakthrough that might mean workfare participants would be treated more like other workers. They also said that if the ruling was upheld the city would either have to reduce sharply the number of hours workfare participants put in each week or increase welfare benefits.
But in its unanimous decision, the Appellate Division noted that state law specifically authorizes paying the minimum wage to workfare participants. "Moreover, there is a historical recognition that public-assistance recipients performing tasks in exchange for benefits are not public employees," the court said.
Randy L. Levine, the Deputy Mayor for economic development, praised the decision yesterday. "It's a very sound ruling, a common-sense ruling, because it recognizes what the Mayor has been saying for a long time: welfare is a temporary situation, unionization is a permanent situation," Mr. Levine said. "It's like apples and oranges."
Marc Cohan, the lawyer representing workfare participants in the case, could not be reached for comment late yesterday.
In another court ruling on workfare, a state judge has temporarily blocked the city's Human Resources Administration, which oversees welfare, from changing its rules determining which welfare recipients enrolled in college can be ordered into workfare.
The city agency recently decided that welfare recipients enrolled in college work-study programs -- some of whom had been exempt from workfare -- would now have to participate. Lawyers for welfare recipients challenged the new rule, and on Wednesday, Justice Richard F. Braun of State Supreme Court issued a preliminary injunction against the city. Justice Braun said the city must individually assess students' skills and work history before assigning them to workfare.
The city will appeal the decision, said Debra Sproles, a spokeswoman for the city agency.

LENGTH: 1439 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
JAPANESE PARTIES HAMMER OUT DEAL ON AIDING ECONOMY

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Ending weeks of bitter deadlock, Japan's governing party said it had reached a landmark agreement tonight with the political opposition that could lay the groundwork for revamping the nation's teetering financial system and reviving the recessionary economy.
The deadlock had intensified international criticism of Japan for dithering in dealing with its enormous banking system and bad debts even as financial instability has spread through markets around the world. 
 "I have decided that as the world's second-largest economy, Japan should not become the source of a global financial meltdown," Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi told reporters this evening.
The worry that Japan could be blamed for a global slowdown underscores the critical challenge facing the country as it tries to adopt legislation that will bring about lasting stability in the financial system.
The last-minute agreement was vague, glossing over crucial questions. The deal also could unravel, as have many other efforts aimed at stimulating the economy, which is in the midst of its worst performance since World War II. But the agreement gave Mr. Obuchi something to show President Clinton when the two meet Tuesday in Tarrytown, N.Y.
To obtain a deal, Mr. Obuchi appeared to have made significant concessions, adopting key planks of the opposition, a coalition of parties that controls the upper house of Parliament and has blocked movement in financial legislation for weeks.
These include sharply reducing the power of the Finance Ministry to set financial policy and supervise the liquidation of banks, and the "temporary" nationalization of the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, one of the nation's largest and most enfeebled banks. He also appears to have agreed to abolish a $100 billion pool of public funds set up to rescue banks.
It is therefore not clear how much money the Government will make available to help resolve the bad debts held by Japanese banks.
The long tussle over the financial legislation reflected a subtle political joust among the parties. The opposition wanted to discredit the Government and weaken its authority so that new general elections might be called, not immediately, but in the next year or so, when the opposition has built up its local organizations. And Mr. Obuchi wanted to show that he could get things done and take steps toward economic recovery.
It is not clear who won, and it may not be clear for months. The political consequences may simply depend on whether these measures restore some vitality to the economy by next year and thus improve the popularity of the Government.
Key opposition figures were exultant tonight, declaring that the Government had capitulated to their demands. In Washington, United States officials said they could not assess the plan because they did not expect to be fully briefed on it until Monday. They appeared particularly focused on the question of whether the plan would commit Japan to inject billions in public funds to improve the capital base of banks after they were nationalized.
The national security adviser, Sandy Berger, who said he had not seen the plan, said, "I think we have a strong sense of urgency that the Japanese Government move as quickly as possible to stimulate its economy, restore growth to deal with its banking problem, open its markets, to deregulate."
Movement on the banking legislation has been viewed as crucial because it would allow Japan to proceed with the task of grappling with its frail banking system, which many economists regard as the key to restoring its vitality.
Earlier this week, Standard & Poor's, a major credit rating agency, said that Japan's bad debts could climb to as high as 30 percent of the country's total economic output.
The debt has been an enormous drag on the entire economy for nearly eight years, and has prevented Japan from acting as an engine of growth for both Asia and the rest of the world.
The agreement was released after the close of Tokyo's long-battered stock market, which now stands about where it was 12 years ago. Bond yields, a barometer of economic weakness, have plummeted, with the benchmark 10-year bond touching a record low of 0.64 percent at one point in trading today.
The Government has begun carrying out a giant fiscal stimulus package, worth about $126 billion in real spending and loans, along with big tax cuts. But it has also acknowledged that even with this program, the economy is expected to contract by more than 1 percent this fiscal year. Some economists say the spending package focuses too much on white elephant public works and will prove difficult to carry out as swiftly as planned.
Government officials denied that the deal was cemented just so that Mr. Obuchi would not go empty-handed when he met Mr. Clinton.
"Japan's policies are not formulated as gifts for the President," said Koji Tsuruoka, a Foreign Ministry official. "It could become a turning point in promoting change and reform in the banking system."
Because the ruling Liberal Democratic Party appears to have achieved the deal mainly by acquiescing to the opposition, most of the opposition parties seemed reasonably satisfied. They can claim that their own proposal will become the basis for the new legislation.
"We reached an agreement in principle with the Government," said Naoto Kan, head of the Democratic Party, the main opposition group, after he emerged from a meeting with Mr. Obuchi. "Now it is time to put it in place."
It appears that the Government will have to rewrite its bill for establishing "bridge banks," the original centerpiece of its financial legislation now before Parliament. The idea was to create a bridge bank to take on the bad debts of failed banks and collect on those debts or sell them off at cut-rate prices. But the Government resisted using the plan with the big, frail banks, while the opposition demanded a mechanism to deal with such institutions.
"We had to compromise quite a bit," said Yasuhisa Shiozaki, a member of Parliament and one of the negotiators for the Liberal Democrats. But he added that the deal was still "broad" and the two sides "have to work on it to clear up the details."
The new, rewritten bills are expected to pass Parliament as early as mid-October.
Mr. Shiozaki and others said they did not expect the agreement to fall apart. Still, the wording was vague enough to allow multiple interpretations, enabling each side to claim that it was comfortable with the deal.
"It's a very broad framework, so the real negotiations will come," said Motohisa Furukawa, a Parliament member for the Democratic Party and one of the negotiators. He described the deal as "chameleon-like" -- that is, it can be "read sometimes in two ways" or more.
Under the deal, the Government is expected to temporarily nationalize the Long-Term Credit Bank, an institution with 25 trillion yen, or $186 billion, in assets and a capital base so weak that opposition groups have deemed it insolvent.
But the two sides still need to thrash out exactly how Long-Term Credit will be taken over by the state and whether it will be declared technically bankrupt. The Liberal Democrats have resisted declaring such a large institution bankrupt, partly out of fear that doing so would provoke financial instability.
"Also as part of the deal, the opposition will help draw up a new mechanism to deal with hobbled, weakly capitalized banks under the supervision of a bankruptcy administrator.
An official at the Bank of Japan, the nation's central bank, ruled out the possibility of a default by Long-Term Credit if it was put under state control, according to Japanese news media, and he said the Bank of Japan would provide loans, even without collateral, to Long-Term Credit to prevent a credit squeeze.
While many economists agree that the Liberal Democrats may have a point in worrying about instability in the overall system, some have criticized the emphasis that politicians have put on the problems of Long-Term Credit, or LTCB, an institution set up after World War II to provide long-term loans to help finance economic rebuilding. They fear that once a solution to that bank's crisis is reached, officials may feel that they have finished their work and relax their resolve to overhaul the financial system at large.
"The world will closely watch LTCB and shift its focus to the next phase of banking consolidation and restructuring," said Charles H. Dallara, managing director at the Institute of International Finance. "The issue is: Can they pull the entire banking system through consolidation?"

HEADLINE: Summer of Trouble Still Doesn't Furrow Consumers' Brows

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
The financial and political blows of recent weeks have yet to shake Americans' basic faith in the United States economy or their own finances -- good news for the seven-and-a-half-year-old expansion and for the President.
Since the Russian economy's collapse, the tumble in stock prices and the release of the Starr report, consumers have turned only slightly more cautious, according to a major poll of consumer attitudes disclosed yesterday. The University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index, a barometer of influences on spending, slipped to 100.1 in September, from 104.1 in August -- mostly because consumers' expectations for the economy in the next year or so are somewhat less upbeat. 
 By past measures, confidence remains exceptionally high. Between the late 1960's and early 1997, the Michigan index hit 100 or higher only three times, even during the long, strong expansion of the 1980's. Its average value since 1947, when the survey began, is 85.
"Consumers are demonstrating a remarkable degree of resilience," said Richard Curtin, director of the Center for Consumer Surveys at the University of Michigan. "If this is all the decline there is, the consumer sector will be the strongest part of the economy."
Consumers account for two-thirds of the $8-trillion-a-year United States economy. With other sectors, like business investment, slowing, a sharp retrenchment by consumers could tip the economy into recession.
"Consumers perceived that the economy slowed significantly in the third quarter and they expect the slowdown to continue in the year ahead," Mr. Curtin said. "But they still do not expect a recession."
That, of course, is especially good news for President Clinton, whose popularity has always been entwined with the health of the economy. As Congress considers what action, if any, to take against the President in coming months, public opinion will carry great weight.
A poll released Wednesday showed that a near-record portion -- more than two-thirds -- of households rate the condition of the economy and their own finances as good to excellent.
"That tells us what the average American is experiencing," said Gary Langer, who updates that personal financial survey each week for Money magazine and ABC. "What they're experiencing influences decisions they make and what decisions they make influence the economy."
Although spending is no longer growing rapidly, consumers are still in a buying mood. With the General Motors strike settled, car dealers are reporting brisk sales. Despite a wait-and-see attitude among prospective buyers of luxury homes in some parts of the country and a drop in housing starts in August, most builders are reporting strong traffic and a jump in permits. And retailers posted excellent results on the Labor Day weekend.
The big fear lately has been that fear itself will turn into a self-fulfilling prophecy. Consumers could take one look at the declining Dow Jones industrial average, conclude that the economy will follow stocks downward, and retrench in a hurry. Something similar happened in July 1990 after Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait: worldwide oil prices doubled and the economy slid into recession.
The Michigan poll is reassuring on this score. Back in 1990, confidence, which had been hovering at 90, plunged by 10 points in the month after the Kuwait invasion and by 25 points within three months.
"In June and July 1990, we were jumping up and down yelling about the way consumer confidence was cratering," Mr. Langer said. "We're not jumping up and down right now."
The Michigan report is a preliminary one. Conducted over the first two weeks of the month, it is based on telephone interviews with roughly 325 people, out of a total monthly sample of 500 households, chosen to be representative of the nation's consumers. One encouraging sign is that the tenor of responses did not deteriorate over the polling period, despite the avalanche of bad news from Washington.
The September reading seems to confirm what pollsters have long suspected: that the stock market and Washington do not loom as large in consumer consciousness as do everyday pocketbook issues. "People don't look to the stock market for cues about the condition of the economy," Mr. Langer said. "They look to their own experience, especially their pay, their job prospects and the cost of things they have to buy."
Mr. Curtin said that it would be surprising if the President's troubles affected confidence much. "In Watergate there wasn't a direct effect," he said, "but rather an indirect one, as consumers eventually concluded that the President was too preoccupied to deal with the growing economic problems."
It is not hard to come up with reasons consumers might continue to feel good. Prices are remarkably tame, rising 1.6 percent in the last year, compared with 1.7 percent the previous year. Consumers are paying more for clothing and many services, but they have rarely seen lower gasoline prices. Home mortgage rates have plummeted to a 30-year low.
Consumers' moods are most sensitive to their incomes and job prospects. After-tax income is growing handily, and the economy is still adding an average of 200,000 jobs a month. Consumers' biggest concern, Mr. Curtin said, is that economic troubles abroad will result in layoffs and higher unemployment at home. Outside of a few manufacturing industries, such cutbacks have not yet materialized. This week, the Government reported that first-time unemployment claims fell below 300,000 in the second week of September, a 10-year low.
To be sure, consumer spending was expected to slow from its red-hot pace in the first half of the year. Spending then grew 5 percent, outpacing the 3 percent growth in after-tax income. Spending was so strong, in fact, that the saving rate -- the difference between income and spending -- narrowed to nearly zero by summer. "Obviously, that couldn't last under any circumstances," said Bruce Steinberg, the chief economist at Merrill Lynch.
The drop in the stock market -- nearly 20 percent from the July high until the end of August -- means that well-to-do households that own stock can no longer count on automatic portfolio growth to do their saving for them. The extra kick in consumer spending during the previous three and a half years as stock prices soared will now evaporate. The wealth effect -- how much extra spending consumers do as their wealth grows on paper -- contributed about $75 billion to overall consumer spending in three years.
In short, most economists expect spending to grow no faster than income -- about 2 to 3 percent in the next year. That is half the pace of earlier this year, but still solid.

HEADLINE: Clinton Likely To Delay Trip To Pakistan And India

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18

 BODY:
President Clinton will probably postpone traveling to India and Pakistan because both countries tested nuclear devices in May and have shown little inclination to defuse their arms race, officials with knowledge of plans for the trip said today.
"A Presidential trip to South Asia remains on hold," a White House aide said in response to speculation that the trip, which had been planned for mid-November, is virtually certain to be put off. 
 A State Department official, responding to questions on condition that he not be identified, said he, too, understood the visits had been indefinitely postponed.
In May, India exploded five nuclear devices, and the United States imposed sanctions against the country, warning Pakistan not to respond with tests of its own. But at the end of the month the Pakistanis conducted nuclear tests, and the United States imposed sanctions on Pakistan, too.
India and Pakistan have been antagonists since 1947 when they became separate, independent nations carved out of British colonial India.
Mr. Clinton had hoped to go to India, Pakistan and possibly Bangladesh in November. Promoting trade would have been high on the agenda, as well as encouraging an end to nuclear arms competition.
The White House is not expected to announce a final decision until after the President meets with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan next week at the United Nations, but there is a growing consensus among Mr. Clinton's advisers that not enough can be accomplished then to make the trip to South Asia worthwhile.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright; the national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, and Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen are among those who are believed to have told the President that such a trip would be unwise.
Late last year, in a wide-ranging interview on his foreign policy plans, President Clinton said he hoped to visit India and Pakistan in 1998 "if all goes well."
The most severe economic sanctions imposed against both nations after the tests were soon lifted. American diplomats met with Indian and Pakistani leaders to discuss the arms race, but made little tangible progress.

HEADLINE: Xiaogang Journal;
Village of Small Farmers Marks Own Great Leap

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: XIAOGANG, China

 BODY:
Shooing away clouds of giant dragonflies, surrounded by lush fields of rice and platoons of clacking ducks, it is hard to imagine the parched and decrepit conditions of this little village 20 years ago that forced many of its residents to become itinerant beggars.
As a few middle-aged villagers tell their practiced story, it is even harder to imagine that these same people once fearfully defied Communist Party policy, secretly dividing up the communal farm that Mao had imposed with disastrous results. 
 In late 1978, starving and desperate, the 20 families in this village of Anhui Province in eastern China took matters into their own hands, risking the wrath of the party.
Within a few years, as the country learned of the remarkable gains in Xiaogang and a few other pioneering places, the hated communal farms would break apart all over China -- the single greatest step toward the country's vibrant, market-oriented economy of the 1990's. This village in the middle of nowhere earned an important footnote in the history of the new, post-Mao China.
Historians often focus on leadership struggles in Beijing to explain such momentous shifts in policy. But the insistent demand for change from the bottom also played what scholars say is an often overlooked role in smashing the communes. And similar grass-roots pressures could, some think, be a driving force of future convulsions in Chinese politics or economics.
Restoring the family farm, and wider decontrol of rural business that followed, "radically changed the face of China, altering the relationship between central and local authorities and perhaps providing China's best single hope of making the transition to a post-Communist world," said Joseph Fewsmith, a China scholar at Boston University.
Situated on a fertile plain between the Yangtze and Huai Rivers, Xiaogang should never have reached the nadir it did.
The disasters began soon after the forced collectivization of farming here and then the introduction of communes during the Great Leap Forward of 1958-60. Many Xiaogang residents starved to death in the catastrophic national famine that resulted from the disruption of agriculture under the Great Leap.
The bitterness among the area's farmers never dissipated, and productivity declined. In the decade up to 1978, the village required large subsidies of grain from the Government, recalled Yan Junchang, 57, who was leader of the communal village "production team" in 1978. Travelers described homes with no doors, with chairs and tables made only of mud.
"The enthusiasm of the farmers was frustrated," was how Mr. Yan described the corrosive effects of communal work in a recent interview.
Local party officials selected Mr. Yan along with Yan Hongchang, 48, who was deputy production leader in 1978, and Yan Jinchang, 55, another one of the original rebels, to meet a foreign reporter in Xiaogang, with Yan Junchang, the former team leader, apparently designated to do the talking. As in many Chinese villages, many residents are from the same clan and share the same family name.
"As team leader, no matter how hard I rang the bell or blew the whistle, I couldn't get anyone to go into the fields," Yan Junchang said. Much of the available land was not even tilled.
More and more, family members would spend months away in towns, begging for food and coins. Then in 1978 a severe drought made conditions unbearable.
At an emotional meeting at the end of that year, the family heads drew up an oath, signed with thumbprints. The parceling of land to individual households would be kept secret, they agreed. If any among them were imprisoned, the rest would raise their children to the age of 18.
The change was immediate.
"Some people even got up before dawn to go work in the fields," Mr. Yan said. The amount of land planted to grain nearly doubled in one year, and the village began producing a surplus.
Neighboring villages learned of Xiaogang's move and sought to emulate it, but angry commune officials tried to squelch the rebellion, at one point in late 1979 cutting Xiaogang off from its subsidies of seeds, fertilizers and pesticides, Mr. Yan said.
But soon after, the county party secretary visited and called this a worthy experiment. Then the Communist Party leader of Anhui Province, Wan Li, visited Xiaogang and gave his blessing -- a bold decision at a time when the top farm officials in Beijing were still promoting communal farming, true to the memory of Mao, who died in 1976.
In that first year, the village produced a large grain surplus, according to the official history, and output continued to rise. In 1980, as similar wildcat breakups of communes occurred around the country, Deng Xiaoping -- who was consolidating power as the national leader -- openly endorsed the change for the first time.
By the end of 1984 the communes had disappeared nationwide, Zhang Guangyou, a former aide to Wan Li, said in an interview. Mr. Wan himself, a largely unsung hero of China's economic reforms, quickly moved on to high office in Beijing and is now a retired party elder.
Scholars like Mr. Fewsmith warn against romanticizing the role of Xiaogang and other villages that defied national policy. Such broad national changes, he said, resulted from an interaction among grass-roots pressures, the work of sympathetic local officials and, at the top in Beijing, the drive of Deng and other reformers to oust hard-line Maoists.
Still, "Xiaogang is a legitimate symbol of independent farmer action," said Dali Yang, a Chinese-born political scientist at the University of Chicago and author of "Calamity and Reform in China" (Stanford University Press, 1996).
Even today, 70 percent of Chinese live in the countryside: the breakup of the communes altered more lives than any subsequent event. It also, scholars say, was the inspiration for Deng's much-vaunted urban economic reform in 1985, which allowed the spread of private enterprise and, in recent years, spectacular growth.
Injecting market forces into the factories and cities was easier, Mr. Yang observed, because three-fourths of the population already lived in a virtual market economy, producing not only ample food but also sought-after consumer goods.
With "market socialism" China's new dogma, Xiaogang's onetime rebels are now heroes of the post-Mao revolution. Today, Xiaogang has a colorful archway at its entrance and a paved strip of road down the middle, the better to greet the occasional official visitor. Many are expected this fall and winter to celebrate the 20th anniversary of that legendary secret oath.
Its borders expanded, the village now is home to 312 people in 75 families. If they are not nearly as prosperous as those in more advantageous locales, many farmers here have small tractors and have branched out into production of ducks and pigs and watermelons, and many homes sport refrigerators and washing machines.
These days Mr. Yan, the onetime production team leader, is careful with his words. "What we did was still under the socialist system, but the pattern was just changed," he repeats.
Both Mr. Yan and Yan Hongchang, the younger, former deputy team leader, are now officials in a nearby larger town. The older Mr. Yan said he became a party member in 1988.
"The superiority of the Communist Party led me to join," he said, looking over the green fields.
His 27-year-old son is the party secretary of Xiaogang.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Twenty years ago the farmers of Xiaogang disbanded the village's commune and helped start China's movement toward family farms. Three leaders, from left: Yan Junchang, Yan Hongchang and Yan Jingchang. (Erik Eckholm/The New York Times)
 
Map of China showing location of Xiaogang: Xiaogang earned an important footnote in post-Mao history.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1716 words

HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE SUPPORTERS;
Blacks Stand by a President Who 'Has Been There for Us'

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Sept. 18

 BODY:
While moving about his Congressional district here last weekend, just after the release of Kenneth W. Starr's report, Representative John Lewis was struck by the universality of support for President Clinton that he found among black Atlantans.
He heard it at Bobby's Barber Shop. He heard it at a candidates' forum at the Ben Hill Recreation Center. He heard it at a community festival in Candler Park. 
 "People would say, 'Take care of the President, take care of my man,' " said Mr. Lewis, a Democrat who is black. "They don't want to see him resign. They don't want to see him impeached. They just want us to leave him alone because there's this deep feeling in the black community that this President has been there for us."
After a week devoted to assessing public opinion about Mr. Clinton's involvement with Monica S. Lewinsky, perhaps the most striking findings have been the circle-the-wagons defense of Mr. Clinton by black Americans and the undeniable racial gap between the views of whites and blacks.
Polls conducted after the release of the Whitewater independent counsel's report show that blacks are far more likely than whites to approve of Mr. Clinton's job performance, to regard him favorably, to trust him to keep his word, to blame his enemies for his problems and to oppose his resignation or impeachment. Even within the President's own party, black Democrats are significantly more supportive than their white counterparts.
In dozens of interviews this week, black Americans ranging from Julian Bond, the chairman of the N.A.A.C.P., to the comedian Chris Rock cited everything from Mr. Clinton's choice of friends to his choice of musical instruments in explaining that he has connected with minorities, both politically and viscerally, in a manner never achieved by previous Presidents.
And while blacks, like most Americans, are deeply disturbed by his infidelity and recklessness, they are not willing to jettison what they see as a unique relationship in exchange for an uncertain and potentially threatening future.
Many of those interviewed remarked on the ease with which Mr. Clinton moves in black circles, noting that he golfs with Vernon E. Jordan Jr., that he and his family seek spiritual counsel from the Rev. Jesse Jackson and that he sings in black churches without the aid of a hymnal. Many said there seemed to be a guiltless and unpatronizing egalitarianism in Mr. Clinton's relationships with blacks that reflected his standing as the first President to come of age after the demise of legalized segregation.
"What he has been able to project, unlike any other President in recent memory, is that he is completely and totally comfortable with black Americans," said George C. Wolfe, producer of the Joseph Papp Public Theater-New York Shakespeare Festival. "It is not something that had to be negotiated or learned."
The Rev. Joseph E. Lowery, the recently retired president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, said he knew perfectly well why black Americans were more forgiving of Mr. Clinton's transgressions than white Americans.
"It's the saxophone," Mr. Lowery said, with an impish sound in his voice. "The man has soul."
Most minorities clearly admire the President's defense of affirmative action, his appointments of black officials and judges and his eagerness to confront racism. But their support for him is not simply a reflection of loyalty and political self-interest. It is also the product of distinct cultural traits born of the black experience in the United States, including a broad distrust of prosecutors, an instinctive empathy for the persecuted and a spiritual emphasis on forgiveness and redemption, many African-Americans said.
Mr. Rock, the hot young comedian, goes so far as to describe Mr. Clinton as "the first black President" because, he said, his every move is scrutinized. "He got his hair cut for $200 and people lost their minds," Mr. Rock said in his trademark screech. "It's very simple. Black people are used to being persecuted. Hence, they relate to Clinton."
Alvin F. Poussaint, a black professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School, said some minorities were so aware of Mr. Clinton's seeming affinity with black people that "they circulate rumors that he must have had black ancestry." And in a poll last year, the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies found that Mr. Clinton was more popular among blacks than either Mr. Jackson or Gen. Colin L. Powell, the former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
What's more, many of those interviewed said they not only subscribed to Hillary Rodham Clinton's statement that a "vast right-wing conspiracy" had been directed against her husband but also that they believed the conspirators were motivated by a desire to reverse the gains made by blacks during the Clinton Administration.
"You just can't help but think that some of this is race-based," said Mr. Bond. "In civil rights terms, this guy's a liberal, and there's a part of the body politic that just can't stand this. They have been determined to bring him down from the very first."
Whether that is true, such attitudes provide yet another prism through which to view the enduring racial divide in this country, not unlike the polarized reactions to the not-guilty verdicts in the murder trial of O. J. Simpson in 1995.
From the beginning of Mr. Clinton's national political career, blacks have been among his most ardent supporters. He received an estimated 83 percent of the black vote in the 1992 Presidential election (compared with 39 percent of white votes) and 84 percent in 1996 (compared with 43 percent among whites).
As with white Americans, the percentage of blacks who view Mr. Clinton favorably has declined since the Lewinsky scandal emerged, according to polls. Yet, affection for the President among blacks remains remarkably high.
In a New York Times/CBS News poll taken from Sept. 12 to Sept. 14, 86 percent of black respondents said they approved of the way Mr. Clinton was handling his job and 69 percent said they viewed him favorably, compared with 58 percent and 34 percent, respectively, among whites. Only 10 percent of blacks said he should resign or be impeached, compared with 44 percent of whites.
Fifty-five percent of blacks said Mr. Clinton's enemies, as opposed to the President himself, were most responsible for creating his problems, compared with 32 percent of whites. And while Mr. Starr, the independent counsel, has charged that Mr. Clinton perjured himself repeatedly, 86 percent of blacks said Mr. Clinton could still be trusted to keep his word as President, compared with 44 percent of whites.
"Black people," said the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, the pastor of Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, "simply are more willing to judge him by his stride than his stumble."
Clearly, a significant factor behind the President's support among blacks has been his record, particularly in the last four years, when blacks have relied on him to fend off a Republican-controlled Congress that they view as hostile to their interests.
Those interviewed this week spoke of the economy's boost for black employment and homeownership. They cited the President's numerous appointments of blacks to significant jobs, a record 13 percent of political appointments, according to the White House.
They also mentioned Mr. Clinton's approach to racial issues, including his "mend it, don't end it" prescription for affirmative action, his creation of an advisory board on race and his trip this year to Africa, where he expressed regret for America's role in slavery.
A number of blacks also said they had rallied around Mr. Clinton because they believed that Mr. Starr's investigation followed the pattern established by the Federal Bureau of Investigation's inquiry into the activities of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in the 1960's, including the surveillance of his sex life, and by the prosecution of black leaders like Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington.
"Instead of starting with the crime and looking for the man, Kenneth Starr started with the man and looked for the crime," said Mr. Bond. "And we've just experienced this time and again with black leaders."
Black Americans, Mr. Lowery said, know persecution when they see it. "We've drunk from the bitter cup of persecution and repression, and if ever a President has been persecuted William Jefferson Clinton has been persecuted," he added. "Now I'll agree with you that he has cooperated with his persecution by providing bullets for Ken Starr's gun, but he's been persecuted."
As suggested by Mr. Lowery's comments, none of the black Americans interviewed this week found Mr. Clinton faultless. Many were incensed that the President had so foolishly placed his agenda, and theirs, at risk.
"As a matter of logic, blacks might be among those with the most cause for anger about a squandered opportunity," said Christopher F. Edley Jr., a black professor at Harvard Law School and a consultant to Mr. Clinton on race. "But I think the faith in redemption cuts the other way. When you have a whole history of turning to the church for succor in the face of painful circumstances, you have to believe that faith will not only heal your wounds, but also reform the master."
The teachings of black churches about forgiveness and redemption, nourished by the scriptural examples of Jesus and David, came through in interview after interview. Many pointed to this month's decision by the board of the National Baptist Convention U.S.A. to forgive its president, the Rev. Henry J. Lyons, who admitted having an "improper relationship" with a church worker. They also spoke of the willingness of black voters in Washington to re-elect Mayor Barry after he was convicted on drug charges, and of black Alabamians to forgive former Gov. George C. Wallace, after his apologizing for staunchly supporting segregation.
"African-Americans are largely a very religious people, and forgiveness is part of the culture," said Gregory Jackson, a black Detroit businessman who owns three automobile dealerships. "It has been a survival technique. We couldn't survive with all that pent-up hatred, hostility and fear, so we've had to forgive and move on."

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
BLIZZARD OF ONE: Poems, by Mark Strand. (Knopf, $21.) A distinguished contemporary sets the purity of his language against an essentially godless, Wallace Stevensish universe that returns our examination with a blank stare.
 
COLLECTED FICTIONS, by Jorge Luis Borges. (Viking, $40.) The first complete English version of all the fictions of the father of magic realism in a single voice, that of Andrew Hurley, a professor of English at the University of Puerto Rico.
 
DEATH IN SUMMER, by William Trevor. (Viking, $23.95.) The child of a man who has never known love is abducted by a woman who longs for love with something like madness in this novel by an author expert in malformations of the heart.
 
EAST AND WEST: China, Power, and the Future of Asia, by Christopher Patten. (Times Books/ Random House, $25.) In a mixture of memoir and maxim, the last British Governor of Hong Kong defends the connections between democracy and prosperity and condemns the proposition that Asians need authoritarianism.
 
AN EMPIRE WILDERNESS: Travels Into America's Future, by Robert D. Kaplan. (Random House, $27.50.) A journalist traverses the West and foresees an America of corporate fortresses, guarded housing developments, increased auto dependence; he finds it "not so bleak." Thanks.
 
LASSO THE WIND: Away to the New West, by Timothy Egan. (Knopf, $25.) Less an inquiry than a didactic tour, this heartfelt jeremiad by a national correspondent for The Times rages against dam builders, big ranchers, real estaters and the dead-hand legend of the Old West, with its chronicle of macho grabbing by the first comers.
 
THE LONG FALLING, by Keith Ridgway. (Houghton Mifflin, $22.) An Irish writer's first novel, which turns the quite understandable murder of a truly horrible husband into a meditation over whether taking another's life is ever justifiable.
 
THE NURTURE ASSUMPTION: Why Children Turn Out the Way They Do, by Judith Rich Harris. (Free Press, $26.) Current theories of child rearing are given an interesting new perspective with the author's argument that peers -- other children -- are exceedingly powerful agents in determining a child's personality development.
 
RESERVATION ROAD, by John Burnham Schwartz. (Knopf, $24.) A painful, spare novel that explores lives altered and grief transmuted to revenge by the hit-and-run death of a 10-year-old.
 
THE VOYAGE OF THE NARWHAL, by Andrea Barrett. (Norton, $24.95.) A British naturalist turns a search for Franklin's disappeared Arctic expedition of 1845-47 into a voyage of self-discovery in an adventure novel that also serves to show the power of narration to make history.

HEADLINE: Russia's Cultural Revolution

BYLINE: By By James Cracraft; James Cracraft, a professor of history and university scholar at the University of Illinois, Chicago, is the author of "The Petrine Revolution in Russian Imagery" and editor of "Peter the Great Transforms Russia."

 BODY:

RUSSIA IN THE AGE OF PETER THE GREAT
By Lindsey Hughes.
Illustrated. 602 pp. New Haven:
Yale University Press. $35. 
 As Russians rise from the rubble of the Soviet Union to face an uncertain future, the ghost of Peter the Great, Czar and first Emperor (reigned 1682-1725), rises with them. Though he was never really forgotten during the Soviet era, his memory was carefully controlled in keeping with Marxist doctrine and whatever was the current Communist Party line. But now he seems to be everywhere, his image harnessed to the sale of beer, vodka and cigarettes or to the promotion of banks and real estate. Ships are named after him, along with schools, streets and museums. His tricolor mercantile flag, patterned on contemporary Dutch and British naval flags, is now the Russian national flag; his city, created in the marshy Neva estuary, is again called St. Petersburg; his towering figure, embodied in a colossal new statue 15 stories high, today graces Moscow, the city of his birth, which he later abandoned in favor of his "paradise" by the Baltic. When asked in a recent interview to select a hero from Russian history, Boris Yeltsin named Peter. His choice, by all accounts, enjoys broad popular support.
 In the conclusion to "Russia in the Age of Peter the Great," an admirably comprehensive volume, Lindsey Hughes, a professor of Russian history at the University of London, suggests that Peter's revival in Russian esteem is the flip side of contempt for Mikhail Gorbachev, a "reformer" who, like Peter, "challenged old orthodoxies, broke down walls, changed his titles, acknowledged the need to learn from the West, and traveled there himself, creating a new image for Soviet leaders. But whereas Peter presided over the consolidation and expansion of empire, Gorbachev precipitated its collapse." Today, she adds, "frustrated, disappointed Russians quote Peter's example to criticize the incompetence and feebleness of post-Soviet rulers," Yeltsin certainly included.
There is more to the problem of Peter than that, of course, as Hughes well knows. His grand project -- constructing a modern European empire on the shoulders of the medieval kingdom of Muscovy -- has always excited both admiration and disgust, whether in Russia or abroad. Cosmopolitans, modernizers and power groupies have acclaimed him as a model of enlightened absolutism while others -- call them populists -- have variously deplored his reign and legacy. Russian nationalists have viewed him as the chief enactor of Russia's imperial destiny -- or as a tyrant worse than Ivan the Terrible and the forerunner of Stalin.
The historian Nicholas Riasanovsky of the University of California, Berkeley, has published a large volume titled "The Image of Peter the Great in Russian History and Thought," leaving his former student Xenia Gasiorowska to focus on "The Image of Peter the Great in Russian Fiction." Both books attest to the magnetism the myth of Peter has exerted on Russian writers of all stripes, and to the deep controversy it has aroused.
Among American historians, or historical writers, two may be singled out: Eugene Schuyler, the scholar-diplomat, whose two-volume biography of Peter (1884) was the first extended study in English based on Russian sources, and Robert K. Massie, whose vast "Peter the Great, His Life and World" (1980), heavily indebted to Schuyler, won a Pulitzer Prize. Like all ambitious histories intended for a wide audience, each also tells us about the times in which it was written: in Schuyler's case, the United States of President William McKinley, Theodore Roosevelt and Adm. Alfred Thayer Mahan, aspiring to be a world power; in Massie's, the America of Hollywood and the cold war. Yet however different their perspectives and styles (the one prosaic, diplomatic; the other romantic, even melodramatic), both writers evince great admiration for their subject and his achievements along with a certain reluctance, perhaps as outsiders, to criticize or condemn.
Not so Hughes -- and that is not the least of her big book's strengths. Every last wart on her subject's royal visage is displayed, every known chink in his imperious armor. The man's myth, periodically evoked in its various formulations, is briskly, as well as lengthily, torn to shreds. We are left with a Russia, at Peter's death, that is exhausted, confused and fearful -- the lachrymose praises of an opportunistic new elite notwithstanding.
WE are left with a Peter, for all the incredible color and drama implicit in his history (see Massie), who is complex but crude, neurotic, bad-tempered to the point of cruelty and faintly ridiculous; a figure heroic at times, it may be, generous and kindly on occasion, remarkably bright despite his lack of formal education, but ultimately a lonely man, this in part because he was a reformer steadfastly pursuing his Westernizing agenda within a tradition-bound Muscovite society, in part because of the "uncomfortable traits of his personality." This is a Peter, indeed, for today's rather chastened political tastes. Nor will Russians seeking guidance find much comfort here: "The day when Peter the Great and his reforms cease to be a live issue in Russia,"
Hughes advises, "will be the day when Russia finally resolves the 'cursed question' of its true identity and its relationship with the outside world."
I might, as a fellow petroved (Peter freak), beg to differ with Hughes here and there, but I won't. Too much of what she says seems to me right on target. Her exhaustive research in Russian sources, including archives in Russia in company with leading Russian specialists, is virtually faultless. The attention she pays to Peter's opponents in Russia, to his court, both mock and real, to family and friends, to women -- to people --can only be welcomed, and should be weighed against her somewhat perfunctory if lengthy treatment of war and diplomacy, economics and government. Her detailed depiction of developments in education, the fine arts, book culture and language is also most welcome, and similarly distinguishes her book from its rivals. Sex, music, medicine, dress, manners, hair codes -- seemingly nothing of any consequence is ignored.
On larger matters, Hughes demonstrates that Russia's "international status had grown immeasurably" under Peter, but then asks, in effect, "so what?" Acknowledging that "in a number of respects Russia was a very different place . . . when Peter died from what it had been . . . when he came to the throne," she demands to know: "But did change mean 'progress,' and did progress mean improvement? Was Russia better or worse off as a result of Peter's reforms?" Like a good teacher, she doesn't really tell us what she thinks, but we emerge from her course invigorated, our noses well rubbed in the data, ready to argue with the historians, politicians and ideologues she quotes and eager to advance our own views.
My own construction of much of the evidence adduced by Hughes and others is that what happened of greatest historical consequence in Russia under Peter was a kind of cultural revolution -- a term that Hughes hazards a time or two but then, oddly, drops. From a position on the fringes, at best, of Europe, Russia by Peter's death had become a full member of the European state system and had begun the process of economic integration.
But these political and economic developments, sudden yet long lasting, major not minor, inevitably bore innumerable cultural connotations, as did Peter's vast expansion of Russia's armed forces and his creation of a Russian Navy; and all was done in close accord with prevailing European norms (techniques, practices, values), hitherto largely or wholly unknown in Russia. Add to this the deliberate importation of European learning and dress codes (elite Russians had previously dressed in what Europeans regarded as "Oriental," Turkish-style attire), the creation of St. Petersburg, the foundation of a Russian Academy of Sciences and so forth, and we have on our hands nothing less than a full-scale cultural revolution. How to evaluate it is another question entirely, and one that has produced, in fact, most of the controversy.
We need consider only the verbal dimension of Peter's revolution to see the point clearly. Hughes cites the figures: some 3,500 new words -- German, French, Dutch, English, Italian, Swedish in origin -- entered Russian in Peter's period, roughly one-fourth of them shipping and naval terms, one-fourth administrative, one-fourth military and one-fourth other (commercial, medical, mathematical, architectural, you name it). Many of these borrowings, Hughes concedes (I would guess most, but much work remains to be done in this area), "remain in the vocabulary today." This was a lexical invasion, deliberately promoted, of entirely unprecedented scope in Russia (perhaps anywhere) and is as sure an indicator of a cultural revolution as one could ask for.
THE revolution had its visual component, too, a point that Hughes also documents. One chapter begins: "There are few better places to experience the palpable differences between late Muscovite and Petrine culture than in Russia's national art collections," where, as she leads us through the rooms, the iconic representations of dead saints typical for centuries of Russian visual culture suddenly give way to naturalistic portraiture, "a gallery of royal personages, ladies and gentlemen indistiguishable in dress and hairstyle, if not always in the quality of the painting, from their European counterparts." But she immediately asks "to what extent do the selected images in the Petrine portrait gallery reflect Russian reality?" (what's "real"?), and we are treated to pages of often fascinating information derived from visual sources -- buildings, coins, sculpture and prints as well as paintings (flags, seals, maps, coats of arms and medals might have been added) -- accompanied by commentary suggesting that our guide is either not sure what it all means or is too reticent to tell us.
Hughes's approach to the history of Peter's era is scarcely touched by the turn to social science in recent British-American history writing, still less by the advent of culture studies (the term "discourse" does not appear even once in her hundreds of pages of text and notes). Nor does she provide more than a cursory review of the historical scholarship on Peter, or any systematic source criticism. Still, this is not a book for the casual reader, nor even your average history buff, who might well find its detail overwhelming. This is rather a scholar's compilation, so organized -- with its full index and bibliography, lengthy chronology of events and topical arrangement of chapters and sections -- as to facilitate ready reference, the whole attractively printed with an absolute minimum of gaffes, all as befits the leading British authority on the subject and her distinguished publisher.

HEADLINE: Story of a Hole in the Ground

BYLINE: By Timothy Egan; Timothy Egan, a national correspondent for The Times, is the author, most recently, of "Lasso the Wind: Away to the New West."

 BODY:

HOW THE CANYON
BECAME GRAND
A Short History.
By Stephen J. Pyne.
Illustrated. 199 pp. New York:
Viking. $24.95. 
 The person who does not love Paris, goes the old line, does not love life. America has no City of Light, no cathedrals for the ages. What we have is an awfully big ditch that slices through the Colorado Plateau, a curiosity that only in the last hundred years or so has been tied to the national identity.
As Stephen J. Pyne details in his latest meditation on forces that shape and animate the earth, "How the Canyon Became Grand," it took a long time for American and European intellectual thought to come to terms with that big ditch. Who needs Paris, London or Rome, it was ultimately said, when wind, water and time have conspired to create something that human hands will never duplicate. "I have heard rumors of visitors who were disappointed," J. B. Priestly said of the Grand Canyon. "The same people will be disappointed at the Day of Judgment." Take that, Paris.
Reading about place is not unlike reading about food: at some point you want to get on with the descriptions and try out the recipes. Pyne holds off on practical information. His task in this energetic paean is to show how human interpretations of the canyon have changed over the years. The book is the third volume in Pyne's Grand Canyon Suite, as he calls it. He is a history professor at Arizona State University who to his lasting credit spent 15 seasons working as a firefighter on the canyon's wild North Rim. The writing in this book, which started nearly 25 years ago as a graduate paper, strays on occasion into the desert of academia. But it quickly returns to the canyon's glories and the people who have tried to understand it. In that regard, Pyne's years as a firefighter on the North Rim have served him well.
Europeans now flock to the Grand Canyon and its neighboring national parks in the Southwest. But for centuries, when explorers from the Old World were among the first to gaze into the breach of wonder, they had no use for it. The Spanish, of course, were in search of gold, and not unlike American mining companies tearing up parts of the West today, they seem to have been blinded to the other treasures around them. Members of Francisco Vasquez de Coronado's plunder quest in 1540 spent time on the canyon's rim, and tried to hike to its bottom, but if they were impressed, they said little about it. They did not have a metaphor to apply to what they had seen -- they mentioned only that some of the rock towers were like features in Seville -- and thus the canyon had no meaning. "Great arroyos held no value, not political, not economic, not intellectual, not esthetic," Pyne writes. "That Spanish adventurers and missionaries made it to the canyon rim is one of the marvels of Western history; that they failed to appreciate what they saw, one of its lesser mysteries."
More than 200 years later came another round of Spanish reconnaissance, from two expeditions led by Jesuits who again seemed more like accidental adventurers for the lack of enthusiasm they showed. Pyne notes that at a time when Jefferson "was waxing wondrous about so prosaic a phenomenon as Virginia's Natural Bridge" and the English were swooning over ruins in Italy, the Spanish could not get worked up over a canyon nearly a mile wide and a mile deep with colors yet to be fully reproduced on canvas. By the mid-19th century, Mormon scouts looking to expand Brigham Young's secular empire were skirting the edges of the canyon, but they too had other things on their minds. To the Mormons, the Grand Canyon was a wasteland, Pyne writes.
It took an American age of discovery, a surge of nationalism tied to natural wonders and a pioneering passion for conservation, led in part by landscape artists, for the canyon to become grand, in Pyne's view. The first of the American expeditions, in 1857, was led by Joseph Christmas Ives. He steamed up the Colorado to the western edge of the canyon, then left one of those statements for posterity that should remind anyone on a government exploration payroll to be careful what he says: "It seems intended by nature that the Colorado River, along the greater portion of its lonely and majestic way, shall be forever unvisited and undisturbed." Visitors, and some disturbers, would soon follow. The most famous one-armed Civil War veteran in the history of the West, John Wesley Powell, made his descent of the forbidding rapids of the canyon in 1869. His report captured the country's imagination and led to a still unresolved debate over how the arid lands should be managed.
FOR scientists, the canyon was the centerpiece of studies that greatly advanced natural history. As Pyne points out, the age of the earth increased a millionfold, from 6,000 years to more than 4.6 billion, from the late 18th century to the mid-20th: "The Canyon became to geology what the Louvre was to art, or St. Peter's Square to architecture." The artist Thomas Moran, invited by Powell to accompany him on his second tour of the canyon in 1873, painted "The Chasm of the Colorado," which started an esthetic stampede to the Southwest. And Theodore Roosevelt provided political muscle, setting the canyon aside in 1908 as a national monument under a new law designed to protect American antiquities. Eleven years later it was made a national park. Since then, the Colorado River has been pinched by massive dams on either side of the canyon; the river that flows through the breach is a cold, contained flow from a reservoir that buried many of the sights that entranced Powell -- now named, in one of those uncomfortable twists, Lake Powell -- and it powers an electrical grid that runs a million air conditioners in Las Vegas and Phoenix.
Pyne makes a strong case that the Grand Canyon is as much an American invention as baseball. His essay is a bit wordy in places, perhaps reflecting the fact that it was started by a less confident writer toiling in graduate school long ago. He overlooks -- significantly -- how the canyon was viewed in many American Indian and Anasazi creation myths. But overall, he leaves the impression that much of the rubbernecking people experience while floating the canyon could be done, with equal excitement, in a gallery or library devoted to this singular piece of scenery.

HEADLINE: Unchained

BYLINE: By Jeffrey E. Garten; Jeffrey E. Garten is the dean of the Yale School of Management.

 BODY:

RESCUING PROMETHEUS
By Thomas P. Hughes.
Illustrated. 372 pp. New York:
Pantheon Books. $28.50. 
 Pathbreaking mega-engineering and technology projects have been hallmarks of our history. The Erie Canal, the transcontinental railroad, the Tennessee Valley Authority complex, the Manhattan Project -- these are just a few of the achievements reflecting America's genius for inventing and building. In "Rescuing Prometheus," Thomas P. Hughes, a professor of the history and sociology of science at the University of Pennsylvania, focuses on the cold war years, a particularly exciting era when rivalry with Moscow caused Washington to finance vast technological innovation, when collaboration between the Pentagon and companies like IBM and universities like the Massachusetts Institute of Technology reached its zenith and when the country's finest talent opted for careers in science and engineering rather than banking and marketing. Writing simply and directly, if a bit dryly, Hughes makes an important contribution to an understanding of the history, politics and culture of big science-based projects in that era.
Hughes begins by discussing the early development of air defense systems, which led to the first computers that could assimilate and analyze astronomical amounts of information in order to monitor and control complex military operations. He then turns to the building of the Atlas intercontinental missile, involving over 18,000 technical experts and 200,000 suppliers. From here he moves to the construction of Boston's Central Artery and Tunnel Project, America's largest urban transportation project. And finally he discusses the project called Arpanet (because it was financed by the Pentagon's Advanced Research Projects Agency), which connected networks of computers across the country and became the forerunner of the Internet.
His concern is the challenge of managing highly complex projects rather than the importance of the technological breakthroughs themselves. He assumes that scientific knowledge exists or can be discovered, but maintains that it was the application of far-reaching managerial innovations that constituted America's most impressive technological achievement. In the search for an antimissile defense system, for example, he dwells on the struggle for effective cooperation between the Pentagon and research universities, and the difficult task of integrating frontier thinking from experts in engineering, physics and economics. In the Atlas project he underlines two managerial advances: eliminating the old system of prime contractor in favor of a neutral "project czar," and applying new statistical techniques to quantify and monitor every component of a complex process. And in the story of the Arpanet he points to the evolution of a new organizational ethos that anticipated the nonhierarchical, flexible management teams of Intel and Microsoft.
Hughes is enamored of leaders who can orchestrate complex systems. He emphasizes techniques of "systems engineering" and "operations research" that allow managers to link the many moving parts of a megaproject and to understand so deeply the many interfaces of a project that they can anticipate adjustments throughout the system required by any change in any part. A particularly intriguing chapter deals with the effort, during the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, to adapt management processes developed in the military arena to solve great domestic problems. "The techniques that are going to put a man on the moon," Vice President Hubert Humphrey said, "are going to be exactly the techniques that we are going to need to clean up our cities." Hughes shows how Pentagon-supported research organizations like the Rand Corporation or defense contractors like TRW were enlisted in civil projects, and analyzes why such attempts ultimately failed.
The four case studies move quickly, and Hughes skillfully explains how lessons learned in one were applied to the next. He is at his best in providing texture by describing the backgrounds and personalities of some of the key figures -- like Jay W. Forrester, who led M.I.T.'s team to create a modern computer for missile defense; Gen. Bernard Schriever, the Air Force combat pilot and engineer who was a power behind the Atlas project; and Frederick Salvucci, an engineer and savvy mediator among special political interest groups in Boston. In all four projects he deftly describes both the political setting and the internal politics of the projects. His enthusiasm for the era is contagious.
The book has some shortcomings. There are almost no memorable anecdotes, and the few quotes cited stem from secondary sources. At times Hughes is a bit too breathless in his claims for unprecedented progress. No doubt the development of computers, missiles, the Internet and major transportation systems required new forms of management. But so did the building of the Panama Canal and the construction of the New York subway system -- both in the early part of this century -- and the interstate highway project begun in the Eisenhower era. Hughes hangs a lot of his enthusiasm on dramatic breakthroughs that "systems engineering" brought, but he could have been more convincing if he explained more lucidly what such techniques really entailed, how they worked and especially why they differed so much from the past.
Nevertheless, "Rescuing Prometheus" implicitly contains a powerful message. Throughout our history, great technological advances -- including the radio, the telegraph and the airplane -- have had a strong push from the military. For the last half-century, in particular, it is difficult to think of any major scientific breakthrough in America that cannot be linked to Federal subsidies to universities or to guaranteed Pentagon purchases of technology from private companies. But in recent years Government support for key areas like advanced electronics has been declining. The portion of American students going into hard sciences or engineering is also shrinking, and because of outsized compensation opportunities a growing percentage of graduates are going into private industry and not research universities. Absent a national threat, or a powerful new vision backed by substantial financing from Washington, America's technological base will rest increasingly on the activities of companies whose prime interest is the price of their stock. Anyone reading this book -- with its uplifting description of what this country has achieved over the last few decades -- cannot help worrying about this trend.
