HEADLINE: Tornado Alert

BYLINE: By Gary Krist; Gary Krist's most recent book is "Bad Chemistry," a novel.

 BODY:

ALMOST HEAVEN
By Marianne Wiggins.
213 pp. New York:
Crown Publishers. $22. 
 HUMAN relationships, like other complex systems (weather, traffic, the stock market), are notoriously difficult to forecast. All of them involve too many tangled variables to allow anything but rough predictions. A sudden high-pressure zone on the outskirts of a friendship, a surprise pothole on an otherwise smooth road through marriage, a slight dip in a lover's interest rate -- any of these can overturn the entire system, altering its character in unforeseen ways. As a result, a process that is theoretically understandable -- like the course of love -- often appears to us an utter mystery. As with lightning or a market crash, passion develops through hidden chains of causality, so we never know exactly where or when it's going to strike.
Marianne Wiggins has obviously done a lot of thinking about complex systems, in particular about the esoteric workings of desire and their similarity to those of the weather. Her new novel, "Almost Heaven," bristles with meteorological imagery -- from heat waves to hailstorms to torrential rain -- all of it related to the emotional lives of her characters. In fact, it's one of the book's many excesses that her main characters need only feel the first stirrings of distress or yearning for some equivalent atmospheric disturbance to loom suddenly on the horizon. And given the turbulent circumstances in which she's put her characters, the weather they generate is almost always heavy. Readers may want hip boots and a sturdy umbrella.
The novel opens with Holden Garfield, a foreign correspondent for Newsweek magazine, returning to Washington after an eight-year stint in Europe. Though still in his 20's, he suffers from an older man's disease: he's burned out, emotionally exhausted, at the "end of the ride." Having witnessed the horrors of the Balkan war, including the crucifixion of a Muslim baby, he's desperate to purge tragedies from his mind and start over. But he's barely out of customs when he runs into a different kind of tragedy, involving the sister of his closest friend and mentor. Melanie Page, a middle-aged beauty described as "the original soccer mom," has just seen her husband and four children die (killed by a tornado). Now she's hospitalized in Richmond, suffering from an "involuntary differentiating forgetfulness." She can't remember ever having a husband and children, let alone losing them.
In short: She can't remember; he can't forget. Cold front meets warm front. Sounds like a storm brewing.
Sure enough, when Holden turns up at the hospital in Richmond, passion strikes out of nowhere (her beauty "hits him like lightning"). Though the two have never met, they find themselves instantly and mysteriously drawn to each other. Quicker than you can say "occluded air mass," Holden has Melanie checked out of the hospital. With her psychiatrist's tacit (and outrageously unprofessional) approval, the two are heading cross-country in a sleeper van, searching for Melanie's brother. And although Holden recognizes that what this disturbed woman needs is "friendship, help, compassion and support, not a quick feel" or quick sex "in a Kmart parking lot," the two are clawing at each other before they even get west of the Appalachians.
Wiggins, the author of the highly praised novel "John Dollar," is obviously a writer of substantial gifts, but with "Almost Heaven" she's produced a work crippled by ponderousness and melodrama. Such an overwrought story, with its unfortunate echoes of soap opera (the amnesia element doesn't help), would be difficult to make credible and appealing under any circumstances. But Wiggins seems intentionally to make her task harder. For a start, Holden, the central consciousness of the book, is a distinctly unpleasant character -- cynical, nasty to strangers, displaying no real sense of how monstrously irresponsible his actions would be in anything like real life. Far too much of the book consists of his obnoxious internal monologue, which often begins in gratuitous sarcasm before degenerating into self-pity: "What's this statue of George Washington trying to tell him? Think of me when you put on a wig?
"Think of my wooden teeth and remember to floss?
"Think of me before catching pneumonia? . . .
"Think of the memory of me outlasting my lifetime while you're going to die unmissed unremembered and unloved you stupid schmuck."
But Holden is only part of the problem. One may justifiably ask (while we're in rhetorical-question mode) why Wiggins burdens her story line with so many bizarre anomalies. Why include an obtrusively implausible scene in which a man is struck by lightning in an airplane? Why make repeated reference to a minor character's botched breast-enhancement surgery? Why fill the narrative with so many funny names -- Kanga and Pooh, Small Gray, Dr. Alexander Graham (ring a bell)? For that matter, why give the protagonist a moniker so similar to that of J. D. Salinger's Holden Caulfield?
Just as perplexing is the book's over-the-top prose. One would think that a light hand might be advisable for dishing out such superheated material. But Wiggins exercises little restraint. While there are flashes of fine writing (at one moment, contemplating Melanie's blankness, Holden "feels its presence like the chill reach of darkness at the entrance of a vast uncharted cave"), the novel more often succumbs to a kind of aggressive grandiosity. It is full of wild, abstract arias on everything from memory to mourning, often ending with empty sentence fragments like: "From sorrow to love. From forgetfulness into eternity." And the writing about sex frequently crosses the line between poetry and porridge: "In her eyes while they are making love he sees a thing he's never seen before, something fundamentally thrilling, the Look of something that exists beyond Time -- the Look of innocence. Of the eternal. Emptiness. Of everything and nothing." (And, yes, the earth does move at least once.)
It's a pity that in warming to her subject of love's ability to erase the past, Wiggins herself seems to have forgotten some of the laws of good writing. But her novel displays enough intelligence and sophistication to suggest that this heavy-handedness may be a temporary aberration. Granted, writers are as unpredictable as any other complex system, but I'm hoping for clearer skies in her next book.

HEADLINE: The Unbearable Lightness of Being

BYLINE: By James McManus; James McManus's most recent novel is "Going to the Sun." His fifth, "The Winter Casino," will be published next year.

 BODY:

BIRDS OF AMERICA
Stories.
By Lorrie Moore.
291 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $23. 
 The Lorrie Moore sentence, choosing almost at random from her latest collection of stories:
"He was thinking, but she could tell he wasn't good at it."
"We are lucky simply to be alive together; why get differentiating and judgmental about who is here among us?"
"Claudia Osk must die."
"A little light chemo: vincristine and ----"
"I'm going to marry you, whether you like it or not."
"She was in bed, a book propped in her lap -- a biography of a French feminist, which she was reading for the hairdo information."
" 'You know, the chef has AIDS,' said the woman."
Fluid, cracked, mordant, colloquial, Moore's sentences hold, even startle, us as they glide beneath the radar of ideological theories of behavior to evoke the messy, god-awful behavior itself. She is also a master of the tenderly mindbending analogy, a writer in whose hands a blood clot in a child's diaper can become "a tiny mouse heart packed in snow" as convincingly as a woman's emotions can go "well beyond rage into sarcasm and carcinoma."
Like Stuart Dybek and Alice Munro (and, before them, Raymond Carver and Eudora Welty and Hemingway), Moore's natural scale is that of the short story. Rather than setting elaborate plots into motion toward a clear or even a provisional resolution, Moore sketches predicaments that her articulate, erotically frustrated protagonists (usually women caught up in the politics and biology of reproduction) worry about, reflect on, fail to resolve. Enriched by contrapuntal motifs against which the narrators caustically riff, the stories, like Dybek's, have long, plaited movements that unfold through a fugal procedure. Unlike Munro's work, Moore's stories tend not to encompass lifetimes; rather, they achieve a density of weave that allows us to infer a full life from a cross-section, a moment of crisis. In her less effective passages, the characters often feel like mere excuses for their author to crack wise. Her raconteuse's panache and way with a double-entendre give her such a strong scene-writing hand that she sometimes submits to the temptation to overplay it. In one story, a Great Books instructor thinks her monthly departmental meeting is aptly named, "since she did indeed depart mental." Another woman defends her brand of Scotch by saying: "I suppose you're out of sympathy with Dewar's. I suppose you're more of a Do-ee." Her husband responds: "I'm being earnest here. And not in the Hemingway sense, either." Harmless enough in themselves, such puns can quickly accumulate beyond the point of diminishing returns.
When Moore has her timing, however, her wit is a swift, racy vehicle for the warmly comic sensibility that steers her narratives. She can also produce searing poetry. In "Willing," an actress past her prime discovers that her lover has been unfaithful. "Something light and breathing fled through her head, the house of her plastic-wrapped and burned down to tar." In "Beautiful Grade," a fiftyish professor of law is dating a 24-year-old student, much to the chagrin of his friends. He finds himself falling for a married woman closer to his age, only to learn she is having an affair with his best friend. Near suicide, he begins work on an essay: "The young were sent to earth to amuse the old. Why not be amused?" Whether he will be persuaded by his own rhetoric in time to save his life is a question Moore refuses to answer.
"Real Estate," one of the powerhouse trio that concludes the collection, has the heft and ranginess, even the headlong story line, of a compressed novel. Ruth, who is dying of cancer, is no longer able to tolerate her husband's affairs. As part of her program of "nuptial forensics," she fixes up a house, learns to fire a pistol and considers taking a lover, musing all the while on her illness: "The healthy, the feeling well, when they felt that way, couldn't remember feeling any other, couldn't imagine it. They were niftily in their bodies. . . . Whereas the sick could only think of being otherwise. Their hearts, their every other thought, went out to that well person they hated a little but wanted to be. . . . The feeling well were running the show; which was why the world was such a savage place." Ruth doubts she has the audacity to act on these insights, yet when this gentle woman does commit an act of spectacular violence, she achieves no catharsis (though the reader feels great satisfaction). Ruth, in fact, may only have made herself sicker.
In "Terrific Mother," another woman dying of cancer retains her prized sense of humor: " 'The silent killer,' she would say, with a wink." As her disease progresses to the point where she loses even that, the effect is all the more chilling. When she wonders why no one is visiting her, her daughter Adrienne delicately explains that "no one lived that close" -- just before Moore's narrator comments, "No one lived that close to anyone."
Adrienne herself has entered "a puritanical decade, a demographic moment . . . when the best compliment you could get was, 'You would make a terrific mother.' The wolf whistle of the 90's." After accidentally causing the death of her friend's infant, she sinks into near-catatonia, although everyone else, including the dead child's mother, has forgiven her. She is no longer able to want the "normal" things -- marriage to Martin, for example, an affectionate economist who brings her on a monthlong retreat to the Villa Hirschborn (a wickedly accurate send-up of the Rockefeller Foundation's Villa Serbelloni) in the Italian Alps. Haunted by the dead infant, Adrienne and Martin grope toward a decision about conceiving their own child, assisted by a masseuse who explores with them the ecstatic possibilities of the body as well as its capacity for anguish.
"Birds of America," while often lighthearted and steadily hilarious, is a sublimely dark book. Its ironic title may call to mind pretty girls in their summer dresses sashaying up Main Street or Broadway, but, like most bodies of work having to do with mortality, its tendency must be one or the other -- a coronary book ("Lolita," for example, or Beckett's trilogy, "Molloy," "Malone Dies" and "The Unnameable") or a cancer book. Moore's fifth book of fiction, and her most potent work so far, is emphatically the latter.
Its piece de resistance is "People Like That Are the Only People Here," a story that is already famous and likely to become even more so. The "here" of the title is a pediatric oncology ward, which a 1-year-old boy and his parents are forced to inhabit for several weeks. The surreal conversation in which a surgeon informs the mother about her son's malignant tumor is fiction with the impact and persuasiveness of documentary. "I've never heard of a baby having chemo," the mother says, as her son switches the lights off and on. "Baby and Chemo, she thinks: they should never even appear in the same sentence together, let alone the same life."
What follows can be viscerally difficult to read, yet the prose still makes us laugh in dozens of precisely observed moments of raw parental horror. By withholding names -- calling her characters the Baby, the Father, the Radiologist -- and employing a hybrid of first- and third-person narration, Moore mitigates the horror's effect, but not much. Like Beckett, she accepts that nothing is funnier than unhappiness; that the more horrible a scenario, the more humor a few literary artists are able to wring from it. In so doing, she also manages to make "People Like That" the story of a sophisticated New York artist "reduced" to Midwestern ordinariness, of a post-modern writer jolted past her emotional limit. Asked to take notes by her husband because the family will need whatever money a written account will bring, the mother's instinct is to doubt her own writerly gifts (while satirizing Moore's): "I can do -- what can I do? I can do quasi-amusing phone dialogue. I can do succinct descriptions of weather. . . . I do the careful ironies of daydream. I do the marshy ideas upon which intimate life is built. But this? Our baby with cancer? I'm sorry. My stop was two stations back." Moore herself sees the trip through, and us with her, to its blasted, overpowering nonconclusion.
Aug. 2 marked the 10th anniversary of Raymond Carver's death, at the age of 50, from cancer. While there is no evidence to suggest Moore intended this, "People Like That Are the Only People Here" extends the legacy of "A Small, Good Thing," Carver's masterpiece of parental empathy and grief. And "Birds of America," especially its three final stories, will stand by itself as one of our funniest, most telling anatomies of human love and vulnerability.

HEADLINE: Conduct Unbecoming

BYLINE: By Richard L. Berke; Richard L. Berke is the national political correspondent of The New York Times.

 BODY:

The Death of Outrage
Bill Clinton and the Assault on American Ideals.
By William J. Bennett.
154 pp. New York:
The Free Press. $20. 
 In the closing days of the 1996 Presidential campaign, Bob Dole would bellow to anyone who would listen, "Where's the outrage?" To Dole's distress that November, few voters were listening -- or even seemed to care -- about his catalogue of Bill Clinton's ethical transgressions. Now, William J. Bennett, the self-appointed values monitor whom Dole considered as his running mate, sets out to answer the rhetorical question of his party's nominee. Thanks to the debacle over Monica S. Lewinsky and to President Clinton's handling of it, Bennett has no shortage of fresh material.
Yet for all his indignation over Clinton's behavior, "The Death of Outrage" offers few fresh insights into what for Republicans (and growing numbers of Democrats) is the most confounding political mystery in years: Why, besides low inflation and low unemployment, have voters seemed unwilling to punish Clinton for his ethical lapses? While he presents himself as more interested in morality than politics, Bennett is a longtime critic of Clinton, and he could not escape writing a political document. Bennett, the editor of the best-selling "Book of Virtues," is, after all, a favorite of religious conservatives who held top appointments in the last two Republican Administrations and is occasionally talked of as having Presidential ambitions of his own. He devotes a chapter to a staunch defense of Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel who is reviled by many Clinton loyalists. His partisanship notwithstanding, Bennett's slim volume is useful in recounting -- and then ridiculing -- the sometimes ludicrous rationales and excuses advanced by Democrats he repeatedly describes as Clinton "apologists." (One vociferous Clinton defender he neglects to chastise is his older brother, Robert, one of the President's lawyers.)
Bennett presents his argument well, especially in making Clinton defenders sound like stooges by hanging them on their own words. Consider these doozies: He quotes Wendy Kaminer, the feminist author, as saying there is something "childlike and potentially dangerous" in expecting a President to have high moral standards. He understandably scolds the Rev. Billy Graham for practically excusing Clinton's infidelity by saying that he is a man for whom "the ladies just go wild."
And Bennett is persuasive in highlighting the "breathtaking hypocrisy" of the leaders of women's groups who came close to undermining Clarence Thomas's nomination to the Supreme Court because of allegations about sexual harassment but have fallen silent about Clinton, presumably because he shares their positions on many issues.
The central point of Bennett -- whose book was finished just before Clinton testified to a grand jury and confessed to the nation that he had lied about his relationship with Lewinsky -- is that the public's willingness to shrug off "among the most corrupt" Administrations "in the history of the republic" has dangerous consequences for the future. This point was also made by Bennett's friend Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, a Connecticut Democrat, in a stern Senate speech earlier this month, one that set off a wave of repositioning in the President's own party.
"In the end," Bennett writes, "the President's apologists are attempting to redefine the standard of acceptable behavior for a President. Instead of upholding a high view of the office and the men who occupy it, they radically lower our expectation."
Yet for all his bewilderment, even alarm, that the public had thus far given Clinton a pass, Bennett may have overestimated the tolerance threshold of Americans. True, public opinion polls consistently showed through the spring and summer that most people did not think Clinton should be impeached. True, the Chief Executive's sexual proclivities have become standard fare on the late-night television monologues. True, this President has compromised the dignity of the Oval Office. But that does not mean the public actually condones Clinton's behavior -- or is not embarrassed by it. And it does not mean that voters will be eager to elect another President who is known for his marital infidelity.
It may be premature to pronounce outrage dead. It could be that Americans are no less disgusted with Bill Clinton than Bill Bennett is. That may be why most polls suggested that voters are so furious at Clinton that they want to put the whole scandal behind them -- the quicker the better.

HEADLINE: The Lost Tribe of Natchez

BYLINE: By JENNIFER MOSES; JENNIFER MOSES is author of "Food and Whine," to be published next spring by Simon & Schuster.

 BODY:
MY 8-year-old son, Sam, and I are sitting on either side of Marty Nathanson, in the last row of Temple B'nai Israel, in Natchez, Miss. Since the mid-1970's, the 86-year-old Mr. Nathanson, the unofficial historian of Jewish Natchez, has conducted Friday night services here -- sometimes to a congregation of no more than two or three souls.
It's been years since there was a big enough Jewish community in Natchez to support a rabbi full time -- today, according to the few Jews left, there isn't a single Jewish child living in this jewel-like city on a bluff above the Mississippi River. The Jews once helped oil the machine that was rich, heady and proud Natchez, a world port for the cotton trade. They are all but gone: the living to larger, more dynamic cities, the dead to Jewish Hill on Cemetery Road. 
 But for now, Mr. Nathanson isn't interested in the dead, but in the beautiful neo-classic temple itself, with its soaring ceilings under an exterior dome, stained-glass windows, ark of Italian marble -- within which are century-old Torah scrolls -- and historic pipe organ (built by Henry Pilcher's Sons of Louisville over a century ago). He explains that its roots go back to the establishment of a Jewish burial society, or Hevrah Kedusha, in 1843 -- making B'nai Israel the oldest functioning Jewish congregation in Mississippi, and one of five original charter members of the American Reform movement. Indeed, the cornerstone of the original building was dedicated, in 1870, by Rabbi Isaac Mayer Wise, the founder of American Reform Judaism. Finally, he points to the balcony above our heads.
"That's where the black drivers sat," he says. "That way they could come inside, get out of the heat."
"You mean the Jews had slaves?" Sam asks, incredulous.
"This was after the war between the states," he says, adding that the drivers were paid employees. "But after all, the Jews here were Southerners. What side do you think they fought on?"
Not only did the Jews of Natchez fight on the Confederate side, but a 7-year-old Jewish child, Rosalie Beekman, was the sole Civil War casualty in Natchez proper. She was hit by a Yankee shell fragment in front of her father's store, on the street of gamblers, riverboaters, prostitutes and shop owners known as Natchez-Under-the-Hill. (Today, Natchez-Under-the-Hill houses restaurants and a docked casino boat.)
Like Rosalie's parents, Aaron and Fanny Beekman, who emigrated in 1843 from Forets, Germany, the Jews who came to Natchez in the early 19th century were primarily French and German speakers, from Alsace-Lorraine and Bavaria. They fled mandatory conscription, anti-Jewish laws and economic constrictions to take their chances in a new, hot, fertile and wide-open land. Their story can be heard and seen year-round on bus tours run by the Museum of the Southern Jewish Experience and tour operators.
In Natchez, as elsewhere in the South, Jewish settlers, many of whom got their start as peddlers, thrived primarily as businessmen. Among them were shop owners who extended credit to cash-strapped farmers, middlemen who financed the cotton trade, and traders who took advantage of the river traffic. Within decades, too, they had cast off the strictly Orthodox Judaism of their ancestors, and had become Southern Reform Jews, a people who rejoiced in the new, streamlined Americanized version of the ancient Hebrew prayer ritual.
They allowed family members of both sexes to sit together to worship, and looked the other way when Jewish shopkeepers worked on Saturday. In fact, by the turn of the century, Jews had moved from Natchez-Under-the-Hill to above the cliff, the site of present-day Natchez, where they had 45 businesses -- about a third of all in town -- and continued to flourish until 1908, when the boll weevil devastated the cotton crop.
"They were wholesalers, traders, retailers, suppliers, you name it," Mr. Nathanson tells Sam. "Main Street and Franklin Street were lined with Jewish businesses, and they stayed open on Saturdays until 1 or 2 in the morning, because the black workers didn't come in until 8 or 9 at night. There were black bands, and hot tamale sellers. I tell you, it was a swinging place. And the Jews were at the center of everything."
Though the city is host to two annual pilgrimages, most tourists are largely unaware of the city's Jewish past, seeking instead a whiff of the glories of its planter society: visiting the antebellum mansions and plantations that ring the city, seeing the Confederate pageant, and in spring, strolling through gardens ablaze with azaleas, crepe myrtle, camellias, phlox and iris. But if you scratch the surface -- or visit Temple B'nai Israel's basement, which doubles as a branch of the Museum of the Southern Jewish Experience, and has exhibits and videos about the history of Jewish Natchez -- you can't go a block without hearing the echoes and seeing the shadows of the city's Jews. They're all but gone, but the buildings they built and inhabited remain.
Which is one reason why the first stop Sam and I make after saying goodbye to Mr. Nathanson is the former home of the Simon Moses family, Glen Auburn, only a few steps from the temple on South Commerce Street. The Moses family owned, at various times, D. Moses & Sons ("Cheap Cash Store"), several cotton-buying houses and the streetcar line.
Built in 1875, Glen Auburn is the home of Ann and Randy Tillman and their six children, descendants of Joseph and Ricka Tillman (and their son, Casius Tillman, once president of the Cotton and Merchants Exchange). Though this branch of the Tillman family is Catholic, their Jewish antecedents seem very much part and parcel of the air they breathe. (You can arrange a visit through Temple B'nai Israel or the Historic Natchez Foundation; the family asks that a donation be made to the temple.)
The exterior of the three-story house is French Second Empire, but the large, airy, romantic interior is what Mrs. Tillman calls Old Natchez. The original 14-foot hand-painted ceilings are being restored, and the two-foot-thick brick walls still keep the house cool -- as does the latticework that connects the main house to the servants' wing, which now houses children's bedrooms.
As we leave Glen Auburn, I try to imagine what life must have been like for the descendants of those first French- and German-speaking Jews. What was it like to wake up every morning to a view of the Mississippi River, to walk on a Main Street filled with familiar faces, to alight at temple from a horse-drawn carriage, and to try sleeping through a blazingly hot and muggy August night? As if in answer to my thoughts, a horse-drawn carriage appears around the bend with a clip-clop, clip-clop sound.
Because Natchez was largely untouched by Union shelling, and later ignored by urban development, the visible city is a kind of living time warp -- a time warp, however, that caters to late-20th-century visitors. And among Natchez's many small inns are those that were once the homes of prosperous Jews.
A block from Glen Auburn, in fact, is the Bailey House Bed and Breakfast, originally the private home of the Jacobs family, whose businesses included dry goods, liquors, cotton and the A. Jacobs & Sons Banking Company. Built at the turn of the century, the Bailey House (named after a more recent owner) has recently been restored to its Colonial Revival style. The columned house has broad verandas, a corner tower, and five bedrooms for paying guests.
Or you might prefer to walk the seven or eight blocks to the antique-studded Burn Mansion (circa 1836), another small inn, once the home of Saul Laub, a Jewish businessman who was Mayor of Natchez in the early 1930's. There, you can sit outside on wrought-iron chairs and admire the wildly blooming back garden while you sip on the best mint julep I've ever tasted. And there are numerous other B & B's (like Highpoint, once the home of the Friedler family, and Clifton Heights, which belonged to the Lehmann family) where mezuzas once hung, and candles were lighted on Friday nights in the spacious dining rooms.
At noon, Sam and I find ourselves strolling along the remains of Clifton Avenue, a once-magnificent street sitting at the very top of a cliff above the river. Most of Clifton Avenue, which over the years had begun to erode off the cliff, has been shored up and turned into a walking path. Sam is staring at the silvery-brown expanse of river and the miles and miles of green on the distant shore, thinking (he tells me) about Huck Finn; I'm gazing at the dilapidated Queen Anne and Colonial Revival mansions that look out over the river, wondering whether or not it would be possible to buy one of them, perhaps as a weekend place. There are turrets and towers, wide verandas and wild rosebushes, and the lonely sounds of birds and wind.
It's spooky here -- too quiet. But at the turn of the century, this was the Jewish neighborhood, the land acquired in 1888 Isaac Lownburg and Henry Frank, partners and merchants. Indeed, the three decades preceding the purchase had seen a Jewish mercantile explosion -- in 1858, there were 12 Jewish businesses in town; by 1877, there were 28, making up more than half the dry goods and cotton-buying operations in this town, where cotton was still king and Jews and gentiles alike shared the pleasures of belonging to the exclusive, all-male Prentiss Club on the corner of Pearl and Jefferson Streets (now home to the Pearl Street Cellar, a night spot).
"But Mom," says Sam, still mystified by the paradoxes of history, "How could they fight on the Southern side? Didn't they know that slavery is wrong? I mean, hadn't they read the Book of Exodus?"
The Jews who came to Natchez broke bread from the get-go with the planter class, I explained. Their fortunes rose and fell together, their children and children's children intermarried, they celebrated the same victories and died from the same diseases.
And they lie up on Jewish Hill, surrounded by hundreds of Christian graves. The entire cemetery is beautifully maintained by the city. There are whole families -- wiped out by yellow fever, in some cases -- under distinctively Jewish headstones: the clasped hands that signify marriage, the outstretched hands of the kohanim (Jews of priestly descent).
They are buried beneath Hebrew lettering under a blue dome of Southern sky on this peaceful, lovely hill above Big Muddy. Here are names and more names: Frank, Friedler, Goldberg, Hart, Dreyfus, Lemle, Geisenberger, Weiss, Samuels, Wise. Husbands and wives, brothers and sisters, the generations lying side by side.
And here, too, is Mena, wife of Aaron Roos. Her headstone speaks eloquently of her journey: For though she was born in Klingen, Bavaria, in the Hebrew month of Kislev in the Jewish year 5586 (or 1826), she died in Natchez on Nov. 3, 1903.
 
If you go
To arrange a tour of Jewish Natchez, contact The Museum of the Southern Jewish Experience, Post Office Box 16528, Jackson, Miss. 39236; (601) 362-6357. The museum itself is in Utica, Miss., about 65 miles northeast of Natchez.
The museum can arrange appointments to see the exhibits in its satellite in the basement of Temple B'nai Israel (suggested donation $4), or call the temple at (601) 445-5407.
Information is also available from Historic Natchez Foundation, 108 South Commerce Street, Natchez, Miss. 39120; (601) 442-2500.

HEADLINE: ART;
Charting the Essence of Omnipresent Fear

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ZIMMER

 BODY:
THERE'S nothing subtle about the current show at Erector Square Gallery in New Haven, and that's the way it has to be. The subject is fear, and it turns out to be rather creepy fun, high in imagination. That's why it's properly a show rather than an exhibition, which sounds more staid; it even contains works that might pass for theater sets.
The organizer, or impresario, behind "Inspired Fear" is Eileen Doktorski, who is in the show herself in a rather commanding way. The more expansive of her two contributions might be called either an installation or a relief sculpture. It stays close to a gallery wall and takes up most of it. "Overpowered" is a multitude of projecting hands made of hydrocal, a lightweight plaster. 
 Most of them are clenched fists, but some hold an object like a gun or a plate. The show comes with a fully illustrated catalogue, and the artists divulge what inspired them to make a work about fear or its ramifications. Ms. Doktorski says she was spurred to make the piece when a bullet was shot through a window of her home while she was there.
Another work on a grand scale is "The Nutcracker Suite," an installation by Annee Spileos-Scott. Occupying a large portion of the gallery's interior, it's an impenetrable square with edges that are defined by straight-backed wooden chairs with lamps clamped on their backs that emit harsh light. The work is beyond evoking benign group therapy, and can't help but refer to humankind's alarming history of rough interrogations. There is a surfeit of printed words: the seat of each chair is filled with the details of varied case histories contributed by six women who then diagnosed themselves. The results are prominently displayed on clipboards in quick phrases, more or less understandable, such as "drug addict," "oral hysteric" or "p.i.m.: paternalistic induced madness."
Guns rear their heads often and, for once, creatively. Dorothy Powers's pair of drawings, one a white weapon on a black ground, and the other the reverse. The drawings are silhouettes that outline the fearsome details of guns, especially the triggers. They are prime examples of how abstract painting at the present time relies on content to be powerful.
Richard Klein's sculptures also make an impact by their terseness. "Drunken Father," an actual rifle butt juxtaposed with a gallon jug turned upside down, was based on a wire-service account of a despondent, recently unemployed man who killed himself after holding his wife and two children hostage.
It's possible to treat guns lightly, but with serious intent. Peggy Diggs creates an audaciously absurd wall tableau displaying an arsenal of varied weapons, each covered with a custom-made quilted cozy. Ms. Diggs writes that she is referring to domestic violence, but in addition to symbolizing nurturing, the cozies may be muzzles or might serve to keep the weapons warm.
Another quick take is "Trap," by David C. Terry, who has placed a hand gun, painted and carved with depressions to resemble Swiss cheese, next to an outsize spring of a mousetrap. This is one of the blander statements in the show. It may be frightening that owning a gun can get one into an inextricable mess, but it's also a pretty toothless truism.
The show isn't without its murky or unclear moments, which viewers may not know how to connect with fear, because they don't have an immediate reaction to them. This is the case with Lisa Hess's paintings featuring children at play. In one, a girl looks as if she's tied to a chair while a boy stands behind her.
There may be ambiguity between what's fearsome and what's innocent play, but these sentiments can't be imported into a painting. They have to reside there and it takes an especially deft painter to render this equivocation convincingly. Sharon Kurland illustrates the universal pressures and downright fears associated with being a child in a small book that can get lost among the more clamorous art.
There's some fear of the good old horror movie kind. Noe Hernandez was born in Mexico, and though he now lives in New Brunswick, N.J., he retains some darker Aztec roots. His paintings refer to the pre-Columbian era: his characters wear masks that resemble the faces of ancient sculpture. The works are mixed-media, not only paintings; in "Agony Held Up With Threads," real rope binds the wrists of the man who personifies agony to the painting's frame. Ropes also stretch to the frame from a gaping wound where the man's heart should be.
Jenny Krasner calls her assemblage sculpture "The Pieta," but it could be a body snatcher. It's a white plaster form with a small animal-like form dandling from its wrist. Its skinny legs form the hands of a clock that is delineated by a circle of 12 stones, so it seems to be some alternative to the grim reaper.
Few local artists have charted death more than Robert Zott. Mr. Zott photographs tombstones, and it must make his day when a name carved on one is either patently absurd, or if he can pair it drolly with another name. One photograph has "cocaine" on the grave marker, but Mr. Zott includes a fetching twosome, "Holmes" and Watson," who could strike fear in the hearts of London miscreants.
"Inspired Fear" remains at the Erector Square Gallery in New Haven through September.

GRAPHIC: Photos: From "Inspired Fear" at the Erector Square Gallery in New Haven through September. Clockwise, from above: "The Nutcracker Suite"by Annee Spileos-Scott, detail from "Overpowered" by Eileen Doktorski and "Drunken Father" by Richard Klein.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
Armonk Shopping Center's Developer Avoids Chains

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD

DATELINE: ARMONK

 BODY:
A THIRD-GENERATION Westchester development company now building a 20,050-square-foot shopping center near the downtown of this affluent hamlet has resisted the overtures of national chain stores interested in leasing space in favor of an exclusively local approach.
According to Jeffrey Garson, a principal with Garson Brothers Development L.L.C., based in Yonkers, Rite Aid and CVS pharmacies expressed interest in leasing 12,000 and 10,000 square feet, respectively. "We turned them down," Mr. Garson said. Referring to one of the large White Plains malls, he added, "We wanted a more boutique-type store, one you can't find in a Galleria." 
 There will be a pharmacy at the new Armonk Town Center on Route 128, Armonk's main street, but it will be a regional one. "The Kadish Pharmacy already has a store in North White Plains, but wanted a bigger one in Armonk," Mr. Garson said. "We wanted a store that wouldn't be changing pharmacists every few months, with a pharmacist who will know his customers by name."
The center, which is scheduled to open around Thanksgiving Day, is now about 80 percent leased by stores that are either new and locally owned or part of a regional chain. In addition to the pharmacy, there will be a European gift shop, a kosher deli, a pizza/pasta restaurant, an exercise salon, a tailor/cobbler/dry cleaner, a toy store and a beauty salon/spa.
"If we had said yes to one chain, they're like a posse -- they all travel together," Mr. Garson said. "It would be like getting in a plane and going to a shopping center anywhere in the country. You wouldn't know where you were."
When Garson Brothers purchased the two-acre parcel, only a few hundred feet from the center of Armonk's downtown, "it was the last commercially zoned property left in Armonk," Mr. Garson said. His company prevailed in a bidding war, paying $1.1 million for the property, which was previously owned by a soil-mixing operation.
"Quite frankly, leasing to chains is easier," Mr. Garson said. "There's less financial risk. By leasing to locals, we take on the risk, but I'd rather do that and have the kind of center we want."
Leasing exclusively to local businesses represents "the back side of the curve in downtown development," according to Doyle Hyett, a principal with HyettPalma, a national downtown consulting firm based in Alexandria, Va.
"It's not usually the developer's desire, as it appears to be in this case," Mr. Hyett said. "More frequently, it's the local officials who are taking a more active role in guiding the destiny of their downtowns."
ARMONK is an unusual Westchester downtown, in that it's patronized by the employees of several large corporations that surround it, including I.B.M and Swiss Re, the Swiss reinsurance firm. Yet it has been able to retain its countrified look and a predominance of local stores.
"It has mostly local and regional stores," said Jack Lombardi, Supervisor of the Town of North Castle, which governs Armonk. "They're the kind of stores you use for one-day needs. The downtown's appearance has been preserved by regulations about signage, building heights, etc. And fast-food and take-out establishments are prohibited."
As it is now, Mr. Lombardi thinks the downtown has done a good job of providing enough conveniences to meet the needs of its residents. If they have more extensive needs, they can drive 10 minutes to the Village of Mount Kisco, Mr. Lombardi said, which has a much larger commercial area, with a combination of local shops and chain stores.
That's the more dominant trend in downtowns across the country, according to Mr. Hyett. "It's only in recent years that the chain stores have been interested in downtowns," he explained. "And that's because they're doing well. The ones that work best manage to retain their village atmosphere and let some chain stores in to cater to specific needs."
One successful example of that strategy is the Village of Bronxville, one of Westchester's liveliest downtowns. It has two national drug chains, CVS and Value Drugs; a Starbucks and the Gap, which is scheduled soon, according to Mayor Nancy Hand. "Value Drugs moved into a space formerly occupied by Woolworth's, which had been in the village for 50 years," the Mayor explained. "So we've always been anchored by a chain.
But the majority of Bronxville's businesses are locally operated "and offer unique merchandise you won't find in a mall," Mayor Hand added. "I think the mix of the chains and small shops is the secret to our success."
From a local retailer's standpoint, the inclusion of chains can be desirable because they draw traffic. "It's an advantage, I won't lie to you," said Mark Mazzotta, owner of Amore Pizza & Pasta, which will move into the Armonk Town Center. But he also sees an advantage in having all local stores. "I think it's a good retail mix and I like the fact that they're all individual and unique stores," Mr. Mazzotta said. "Because we think we're unique."
Mr. Mazzotta will also maintain his current restaurant in Scarsdale, which has a more diverse downtown. "We will serve a different niche in Armonk," Mr. Mazzotta said. "But the same upscale market."
The hamlet of Armonk has some of the highest income demographics in Westchester, with a $59,000 per capita income, according to Mr. Lombardi. "They're very well-heeled people there in million-dollar homes," he said. "Many of them are stockbrokers, lawyers and investment bankers."
Chuck Anderson, owner of La Denelliere, a gift and interior design store in Scarsdale, plans to open another at the new center in Armonk. "We sell chandeliers, hand-painted furniture and humidors that sell from $1,200 to $4,000."
He said he was optimistic that "with two food establishments, the center will attract a good crowd at lunchtime and we'll benefit from that."
"We also expect the gym and spa will attract a good number of female customers to our store," Mr. Anderson added.
THE exercise gym, called Spin, will offer an intense bicycle workout. "It will be the first in the county," said its owner, Michelle Racine. "The only other one nearby is in Greenwich, and to use that gym you need a two month reservation. So I think we'll be getting the overflow from there as well as Westchester residents."
For the center's appearance, Mr. Garson was looking for a countrified look with a peaked roof, fish-scale shingles and two cupolas, topped by weathervanes handmade in Cape Cod.
"We didn't want it to look brand new" said John Currie, of Currie Associates Architects, of Greenwich, Conn., which is designing the project. "It also needs to link to the downtown, which it is separated from by a few pieces of property."
In addition, there will be dense landscaping, especially at the rear of the center, which abuts a residential area. "The residents wanted to see as little of us as possible," Mr. Currie said. "We'll be using evergreens and other indigenous trees, designed to keep the deer away."
Garson Brothers started out building housing, primarily in Manhattan. Its first commercial development was a 12,200-square-foot medical office building on Central Park Avenue in Yonkers. It then built the Garson Plaza shopping center, with all local or regional stores, near Yonkers Raceway.
"The kosher deli from that center is now opening a second store with us in Armonk," Mr. Garson said. "It's gratifying to start out with small businesses and watch them grow and expand. For now, it's the way we want to continue to do business."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jeff, left, and Stafford Garson, partners in Garson Brothers, at nearly completed Armonk shopping center. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Spec Construction Ending Route 1 Corridor Lull

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
AN eight-year lull in speculative office construction is ending on the Princeton Route 1 corridor, where three projects are about to get under way without leases from a single tenant in place.
A fourth project, with a commitment from a tenant for a sizable amount of space, is also moving forward. 
 If realized, the projects will within a year bring a total of 723,000 square feet of space onto the corridor, a 20-mile stretch between New Brunswick and Trenton. With vacancy rates low and rents high enough to justify new construction, developers say it is a good time to build, despite the stock market's volatility in recent weeks. Three of the projects are in West Windsor and one is in Plainsboro.
"New construction will and should occur to meet the market demand," said Aubrey W. Haines, a vice president at GMH Realty, a commercial brokerage firm in Lawrenceville. "Otherwise business expansion in the Princeton area could be choked off because of excessive rental rates or insufficient space, forcing an exodus to other markets in the region."
The demand is coming mostly from local companies -- including insurance, pharmaceutical and technology concerns -- seeking to expand, as well as companies wanting to relocate to the area.
Speculative construction started to sprout in the 11-county northern New Jersey office market in 1996 and is now gaining momentum. In the last two years 667,590 square feet of speculative space in five buildings have been completed and most of that space has since been leased. In addition to the Route 1 corridor speculative projects, 3.4 million more square feet of such space are under development throughout the state, according to Grubb & Ellis, the national commercial brokerage.
The activity took a long time to reach the Route 1 corridor, where overbuilding in the mid-80's forced companies to shed space and drove the vacancy rate to 26.7 percent in 1988. And recession retrenchment kept the rate high.
Though the last new construction there was completed in 1990, it still took until 1996 to absorb the excess space.
The corridor's office market comprises 8 million square feet, of which 514,914 was available as of the second quarter of this year, according to Grubb & Ellis. The number doubles to 16 million square feet when owner-occupied space, such as that housing area corporate stalwarts such as Bristol-Meyers Squibb and Merrill Lynch & Company, is counted.
The vacancy rate in the corridor for space occupied by tenants rather than owners was 6.4 percent as of the second quarter, down from 8 percent a year earlier; the rate for Class A space was 3.9 percent. At the same time overall asking rents have risen to $21.44 from $20.28 a square foot and asking rents for prime space increased to $25.16 from $23.38, Grubb & Ellis reported.
J. Douglas Petrozzini, a senior vice president at the brokerage's Edison office, said tenants looking for 20,000 square feet of space or more were having a difficult time finding it along the corridor, which continues to be bolstered by its central location, proximity to Princeton University and access to labor. Over the last year, he added, some 700,000 square feet of space was absorbed, "So putting another half million square feet or so on the market should not affect that momentum," Mr. Petrozzini said.
And David H. Knights, director of marketing and leasing for the 2,200-acre Princeton Forrestal Center straddling South Brunswick and Plainsboro, noted that "at least three tenants known to be shopping for space have requirements equaling a total of 160,000 square feet." The center is owned by Princeton University.
The only large block of Class A space available is the 332,767-square-foot building nearing completion by Dow Jones on its 207-acre campus at Route 1 and Ridge Road in South Brunswick. Originally intended for one of its divisions -- Dow Jones Markets, which has been sold, it is being marketed to tenants, said James P. Quinn, a senior director at the Manhattan office of Cushman & Wakefield, the national brokerage, which is handling the leasing.
Brokers agree that, given the tight market, that space as well as the four announced projects will be leased before the new buildings are completed. And if the amount of new construction does not increase significantly beyond the four buildings about to rise, they say, the market will easily absorb the space.
"The first two or three projects should hit home runs," said Mr. Petrozzini of Grubb & Ellis.
THE 3 percent vacancy rate at Princeton Forrestal Center, where 5.7 million square feet out of a projected 8.5 million square feet have been built, has encouraged the start of a 168,000-square-foot building there, which has a tenant for 60,000 square feet.
The nearly $30 million project, for which ground is to be broken Sept. 29, is to rise over the next year on 12.8 acres along College Road in Plainsboro. It is being developed by Aegis Property Group of Philadelphia with Berwind Property Group, a subsidiary of the Berwind Corporation, a real estate investment trust, also of Philadelphia, as its financial partner.
Given the low vacancy rate in the center and the corridor "it made great sense to move forward," said James Kinzig, a partner at Aegis. He added, however, that the partners would not have done so without a tenant "because speculative development is tougher to finance and presents more risk."
Still, that is a risk the other developers are willing to take. Ground was broken on Sept. 3 for the Commons at Princeton, a two-building complex with 300,000 square feet of space on 25 acres off Route 1 North and Alexander Road in West Windsor.
The more than $50 million project is being developed by SJP Properties of Parsippany in partnership with Prudential Insurance Company of America in Newark. Fleet Bank is providing a $43 million construction loan; the rest of the financing is coming from the partners' own equity.
The project marks the initial foray into the Princeton market for SJP Properties, which is no stranger to speculative construction. In the last two years the company has built or is building some 1.5 million square feet of speculative space, primarily in Morris and Somerset counties.
"We react to timing," said Steven J. Pozycki, SJP's president. "And in a market like Princeton that does not have a huge absorption rate you don't want to be last when the activity is good."
Mr. Pozycki said his company was also drawn to the site by its accessibility to the four-way interchange at Alexander Road as well as to the Princeton Junction train station with service to New York and Philadelphia. And it is adjacent to the 348-room Hyatt Regency Hotel, to which the new office complex will be connected by a footbridge.
The complex will comprise a 185,000-square-foot five-story building and a second structure with 115,000 square feet on three levels. There will be an enclosed elliptical courtyard between the two buildings and parking for 950 cars.
Completion is set for next July. Rents have not been set, but they will be competitive, said Mr. Pozycki.
At Alexander Road, a half mile east of the SJP project, Trammell Crow, based in Dallas with offices in Chatham and Cherry Hill, is to start construction within a month on a $33-million, 140,000-square-foot building. It is being financed by the Multi-Employer Property Trust, a construction union pension fund, said Mr. Haines of GHM Realty, the leasing agent for the project. Completion is expected by next July, he said, noting that asking rents are to be $27.50 a square foot.
At Carnegie Center, ground was broken on Sept. 9 for a 115,000-square-foot three-story building by Boston Properties, a real estate investment trust, which in June acquired the 560-acre business park that sits on both sides of Route 1 in West Windsor.
"There was no absorption in the park in the first half of 1998 because there was no available space," said Roger M. Steinhardt, director of marketing and leasing for Boston Properties Carnegie Center. "So we are building to add to our inventory to accommodate tenants in the park that want to expand and those outside the park that are unable to find space." At present, there are 1.9 million square feet of offices at the mixed-use park, where an additional 2.2 million square feet could ultimately be built.
The new building is a conservative response to the market demand, Mr. Steinhardt said. The $18-million project is to be completed by next August, he added, noting that rents would be in the upper $20-a-square-foot range.

HEADLINE: Reserved Celebration of a Century of Golf

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH

 BODY:
SITTING in a rocking chair on what used to be the men's porch at the New Haven Country Club, Joe Goldshinsky recalled the Rolls-Royces, Packards and LaSalles that once took up much of the space in the club's parking lot while their well-to-do owners played golf and cards and had lunch in the men's grill.
"Things have changed a lot here," said Mr. Goldshinsky, who has observed happenings at the New Haven Country Club (actually in Hamden) since 1926 when he started as a caddie; eventually he rose to become the head golf professional. "For one thing, there were very few women members, and hardly any of them played golf. And this porch was a sacred area, strictly for the men." 
 Sacrosanct, too, was the men's grill -- until 1991.
The 100-year-old New Haven Country Club, like many other clubs in the country, has become more inclusive and less formal over the last decade or so while. The current membership is more egalitarian than it was during, say, its first 50 years, when members included William Howard Taft, who after serving as the country's 27th president, taught law at Yale, his alma mater. Another member and Yale alumnus was Walter Camp, the father of American football.
In his book about the club's history, Rick Odermatt, formerly a columnist with The New Haven Register, recounts how Ray Brock, later a president of the club, sometimes caddied for Mr. Taft and would place the golf ball on the tee so that the former President (who weighed more than 300 pounds) would not have to bend down. Mr. Camp became renowned at the club for his fast play.
Mr. Goldshinksy recollected that quite a few members were from Yale, including A. Whitney Griswold, president of the university from 1950 to 1983. "But," he said, "a lot more were big executives from companies like Sargent, Winchester, Southern New England Telephone and American Steel and Wire, along with a lot of professional men."
None, perhaps, was more dedicated to the game of golf than a New Haven lawyer named F.L. Perry. "Mr. Perry had a hard time walking, and had to use two canes to get around," Mr. Goldshinsky recalled. "This was in the 1930's, before golf carts. But he still was determined to play so he got a rickshaw -- I have no idea where, but he got one -- and, after hitting the ball, would sit in the rickshaw and be pulled around by his caddie, Red Lawson. When Mr. Perry finished, he would give Red the 75-cent caddie fee and another $3 for pulling the rickshaw."
It was as caddies that many club members learned the fundamentals of golf. "I caddied at the club from the time I was 13 through the age of 17," said the current club president, Walter Nester. "It was a great way to learn about the game and about the golf course."
The course, ranked as one of the most challenging in the state, is a source of pride for the club's 500 or so members. Redesigned in 1921 by Willie Park Jr., a two-time winner of the British Open, the course is built on 110 acres off Whitney Avenue in Hamden and is best known for its large, undulating greens, which put a premium on accurate putting.
Laid out over what had been virtually treeless farmland, the course now includes hundreds of trees, most of which were planted in the mid-1920's, that separate the smooth fairways.
"The membership was older when I joined in 1952," said Ericsson (Pete) Broadbent, a former club president. "And there were a lot of rich guys. But now we have a lot more young people and many more women playing."
One of them is Anita Sullivan Fivek, who has won the women's championship 11 times since 1973 and whose father, Veggo Larsen, captured five men's titles. "Not only do we have more women playing now," Mrs. Fivek said, "but a lot of them are working women." Another former club champion, Leslie Shannon, played on United States Curtis Cup teams (the equivalent of the Ryder Cup) in the 1980's and early 1990's and was the team's captain in 1990.
Though the club no longer has a heavy Yale presence -- mainly because of the Yale Golf Course, which was built in the 1920's -- it owes its origin in large part to a former Yale professor, Theodore S. Woolsey.
Professor Woolsey had been one of the organizers of the nine-hole New Haven Golf Club, built in 1895 between Prospect Street and Winchester Avenue, where Albertus Magnus College is now situated.
But, along with many other members of New Haven's first golf club, he grew disenchanted when the golf course became overrun with Yale students who had taken a liking to the newly imported game.
So it was that Professor Woolsey organized the New Haven Country Club in 1898 and leased farmland along Lake Whitney in Hamden for the construction of a golf course. A major proviso, set down by the organizers, was that the course would be off limits to Yale students, except as occasional guests.
Club members, who numbered 150 at the start, eventually voted to buy the property -- the course had been expanded to 18 holes in 1900 -- for $80,000 in 1915. Two years earlier, a Spanish-style red tile roof had been built in sections atop the stone clubhouse, giving it a striking distinction that has persisted over the years.
"One of the biggest changes at the club has been the geographic expansion of the membership," said John Walsh, another former caddie who ascended to the club's presidency. "Thirty or 40 years ago, almost all of the members lived within a five-mile radius of the club. But now we have members from as far away as Greenwich."
Bruce Guthrie, the club's vice president, said he thought the club was attracting more members from Fairfield County because of long waiting lists at most country clubs in the county, along with initiation fees that sometimes exceed $50,000, far more than those assessed at the New Haven Country Club. "We're not a big social club, and golf is our only basic," said Mr. Guthrie, also a former caddie.
By contrast with some country clubs in Fairfield County, there was a time when there was no waiting list to join the New Haven Country Club, Mr. Walsh said. "It was because of the recession in the 1980's," he said. But that that hardly meant anyone could join, and the waiting list has returned. But, he noted, "there have never been tee times, and there aren't now."
Another reason for the temporary decline in golfing members, and, indeed, the more diverse membership has been a change in Federal tax laws that prevents corporations from writing off country club memberships as business expenses.
Apart from a fireworks display in August and a centennial ball last evening, the club's centennial is being observed rather quietly, as are similar 100th anniversaries at the Wallingford Country Club, which is private, and the Shennecossett Golf Club in Groton, which is publicly owned.
Change, ranging from a recent $1 million restoration project to the opening of the men's grill and the men's porch to women, seems to have come smoothly to the club. But devotion to tradition is hardly lost.
"Most of the changes have been good," Mrs. Fivek. "But I would have preferred if the men's porch remained the same. After all, it does lead to the men's locker room. Yet I know that some women go out of their way to go up the steps to walk on the porch on the way to the women's locker room. I, myself, would never set foot on it."

HEADLINE: Magnet School, in Suburbia And Aiming for a Profit

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT has its first Edison Project school -- a public/ private for-profit partnership run by Edison, aNew York-based company now having almost 50 schools in 25 cities under its direction.
It is the Wintergreen Interdistrict Magnet School, which takes its name from the Hamden street on which it is situated, replete with Edison and statewide firsts. 
 For Edison, specializing in partnership and charter school management, Wintergreen is its first multidistrict venture and the first magnet school. Four disparate communities have come together to participate: Hamden, Wallingford, New Haven and Woodbridge.
For Connecticut, Wintergreen is the first suburban/urban magnet school, and the first public school designed to earn a profit. For Edison, Wintergreen is a first experience with a complete renovation of an existing school, a formidable task. And for the first time, Edison will not answer to a single school system but to a regional educational service center, the Area Cooperative Education Services center, which includes school board representatives from the four school districts. The center manages the Educational Center for the Arts, a New Haven-based arts magnet for high school students.
Wintergreen is doing some things the same and some things differently from the partner districts. Each day, there is a 90-minute reading pause for all children with every teacher in art, music, physical education, as part of the Success for All Reading Program from Johns Hopkins University. A University of Chicago mathematics program and a richly well-stocked science room are standard components of all Edison schools. Spanish is offered beginning in kindergarten.
 Edison is known for its reliance on technology. In the second year each family of third graders and up will receive a desk-top computer to stay in touch with teachers and other Edison parents across the country. Computer training is required of parents, and each classroom has three computers.
Parents will be able to reach teachers at their homes to discuss their children's progress, unusual in public schools. Teachers will work on year-long contracts, with salaries on a par with the top two-thirds of state teachers. About 400 educators competed for the 27 positions at Wintergreen.
The standard school year for Connecticut schools is 180 days. By the second year Wintergreen plans to be open 205 days, and the school day is about a half-hour longer than at most public schools. And every spring Edison will query parents, students and staff with a customer satisfaction survey. Like any business, it will consider their future strategies on the basis of the survey results.
 How will Edison make money? Nancy Bailey, a start-up manager for Edison, says the company relies on economies of scale -- purchasing computers for many schools at once, for example. It seeks out bargains rather than filling out a purchase order and waiting for an office to process the request. One staff custodian is always in the school, but maintenance is handled by an outside cleaning company. "We expect to make a small profit from many schools," Ms. Bailey explained, with Wintergreen expected to be in the black in five years.
 The profit aspect of Edison ventures has been controversial elsewhere but in Connecticut, parents in Hamden, New Haven and Wallingford responded so enthusiastically that a lottery was needed for admission.
Woodbridge parents, however, have not sent any students to fill their 20-seat allotment. The superintendent of Woodbridge's single elementary school, Dr. Peter Madonia, said, "Our parents needed to have a product to see because many of them came to town for Beecher Road School." He added, "One of the other problems was the misunderstanding about length of travel time."
He was personally disappointed no Woodbridge children are participating this fall, he said, because he admires the Edison Project educational philosophy. "They're trying to raise the bar in terms of standards and achievement of students," he said.
In Hamden, the school superintendent, Alida Begina, said, "We had 700 applicants for 249 slots." She cited the longer day and year, all-day kindergarten, Spanish instruction and the hefty infusion of technology as some of the differences from her regular programs. "I wanted a parental choice that was different and this is it," she said.
In New Haven, the superintendent, Reginald Mayo, said he joined the consortium because, "It's very consistent with our pioneering efforts with interdistrict schools. We have 450 students coming into New Haven from the surrounding towns. It would be hypocritical not to share in a reciprocal way."
Dr. Mayo is curious about the Edison Project. "This is a chance to take a look at Edison," he said. "I have played with it and toyed with it. We may involve some of our own schools."
The profit element does not trouble Dr. Mayo. He said he is concerned with results. He cited outside food services as an example of using non-school personnel. "I have no problem with an outside organization doing the instructional piece. We're not doing so well with the instructional piece."
Dr. Joseph Cirasuolo, superintendent of Wallingford Schools, said his district was sending 32 children although originally they only had a 20-student allotment. Travel time could be up to an hour each way, he said, but the greater diversity of the Wintergreen student population was one attraction of the new school, as were the foreign language and the longer school day, which he hopes may eventually be adopted statewide.
The Wintergreen student body is 61.4 percent white, 25.6 percent black, 5.7 percent Hispanic, 4.4 percent Asian and 2.8 percent other. This year it has 336 students from kindergarten through grade three. The following year grades four through eight will be added for a total enrollment of 600.
The school plans to offer older children the chance to be mentors to the younger ones. "They will teach what they know, which reinforces what they have learned," explained Dale Bernardoni, the principal of Wintergreen. Ms. Bernardoni, a popular principal from East Hampton, said, "I think the most serious problem we will ultimately have to face will be excess applicants."
For Peter Young, director of the Area Cooperative Education Services center, the Wintergreen Interdistrict Magnet School is the fulfillment of a long-term commitment: 'Magnets in the south-central region have essentially been centered in New Haven," he said. "We felt that it was important to have magnets not only in New Haven but to have New Haven kids moving out to the suburbs."

HEADLINE: Two Towns, Sad Legacy From the Old Ivory Trade

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN

 BODY:
IN the last half of the 19th century and the first half of this century, two towns near the mouth of the Connecticut River were famed for an industry that brought them great prosperity. Today that industry would provoke screams of rage from human rights and animal rights activists for the dead bodies, thousands upon thousands of them, human and animal, that the industry left in its wake.
The towns are Deep River and Essex and the industry was ivory, the importing of elephant tusks from Africa and the cutting of them into combs and knife handles and ornaments but particularly into piano keys at a time in America when every family had a piano, or wanted one. 
 In both communities, the sight of elephant tusks being hauled off the decks of steamships at river landings, or being transported to factories in horse-drawn wagons, was once so commonplace that no one turned a head.
The two companies that shaped the towns for generation after generation were Pratt, Read & Company in Deep River and Comstock, Cheney & Company in Essex. Now they are memories, but their buildings remain -- Pratt, Read's now a condominium complex known, appropriately, as The Piano Works and Comstock, Cheney's now mostly occupied by other businesses. Starting on next Sunday, half a century after the ivory business finally collapsed with the advent of plastics, the two river towns will jointly offer a series of free programs and exhibits on the ivory trade. Entitled "The Towns That Elephants Built," the series is the brainchild of Robbi Storms, librarian in the Ivoryton section of Essex. A couple of years ago, Mrs. Storms says, she opened a letter from the Connecticut Humanities Council advising that grant money was available. A former high school English teacher, she had never written a grant proposal but did have an idea, and the grant was won.
Her idea was to explain the economic and social impact of ivory on Essex and Deep River as Pratt, Read and Comstock, Cheney became so economically powerful that at the turn of this century they dominated the ivory trade between Africa and America. And, of course, they also dominated their towns simply by being the major employers. People in Deep River worked for Pratt, Read. People in Essex, particularly those in Ivoryton, worked for Comstock, Cheney.
Ivoryton was, and because so much of it remains intact, still is, a model of a company town. Virtually everything of importance was connected to Comstock, Cheney.
The Ivoryton Library was put up by Comstock, Cheney for its workers. The company also built the Ivoryton Playhouse, diagonally across Main Street from the library, as a place where the workers could go for meetings and entertainment. It provided a company store and an Episcopal church, All Saints. It constructed a dormitory for unmarried male workers, houses for married workers and bigger homes for its executives, all within walking distance of work. The old dormitory, which eventually became the Ivoryton Inn, is now shuttered but still standing, as are the homes built for the factory workers and now owned privately. The playhouse is enjoying an extended life as a summer theater.
The library, now supported by the town, is a structure of wooden walls and high ceilings, so ornately Victorian that a visitor almost expects the librarian to wear a hoop skirt. The only major alteration to the building from the 1890's, when it was new, is a central heating system, a modern-day substitution for the building's seven fireplaces.
But despite all the reminders of the earlier, and fascinating, age all about them, Mrs. Storms says, many people in Ivoryton today, even some who live in former factory-built homes, know little about the history of the area and the ivory trade.
"I want people to know the history of this library and the town, and ivory," she says. "Ivoryton has a new population of people who live in big houses on big lots going up all around us and they know nothing about the history here."
She realizes that the history includes a somber downside in Africa, where the number of animals slaughtered and the number of enslaved Africans who died in the hunt for ivory is a horror story. But it is part of the overall story that should also be told, she feels. And that is where Richard Conniff comes in.
Mr. Conniff, recruited by Mrs. Storms for her project, is a writer whose work appears in National Geographic Magazine and other publications and who lives in Old Lyme. He is also, sort of by happenstance, very well versed in the ivory trade.
In the mid 1980's, Mr. Conniff was living in an old ship captain's house in Deep River and stumbled upon a facet of the town that particularly interested him. It was the link to the African ivory trade and he started to investigate it.
The result was a long article in Audubon Magazine in 1987, entitled "When the Music in Our Parlors Brought Death to Darkest Africa."
The article detailed the start of the ivory industry along the Connecticut River in 1798 when a Yankee artisan named Phineas Pratt invented a saw, using wind or water power, to cut ivory.
Ivory is simply the elongated and pointed teeth that extend outside the mouths of certain animals. Elephants have the hardest and smoothest, and therefore most desirable. Mr. Pratt's device was to transform ivory cutting from a tedious craft into an industry.
The Pratt business originally concentrated on ivory combs but in the latter part of the 19th century the piano business was booming, ivory for the piano keys was in great demand, and Pratt, Read and Comstock, Cheney, were prospering.
"For a time they had so dominated the ivory trade that their business determined not just demand in Zanzibar, the major trading center, but even the price paid for tusks in the East African bush, where the elephants were being killed," Mr. Conniff wrote.
"They were major buyers during the period of wholesale slaughtering of Africa's elephants, from about 1860 to 1930. According to various estimates, 25,000 to 100,000 elephants died each year then, the vast majority of them to supply the raw material for the piano keys that brightened every Victorian parlor."
One of the early enigmas of the connection between Connecticut and Africa was that some of the businessmen involved here were ardent abolitionists who either did not know of the horrors of getting the ivory there -- or chose to ignore it.
The toll in human life was beyond calculation. In the last century, most of the ivory trade in Africa was conducted by Muscat Arabs of Zanzibar. They directed caravans of men, women and children farther and farther into the interior of what was still a mostly unknown continent, in the search for elephants to kill and to transport the tusks back.
Many of the slaves never made it. Henry Morton Stanley, the newspaper correspondent who attained fame for finding the missionary and explorer David Livingtone in Africa, wrote about long lines of half-starved slaves, bound with chains that would have restrained an elephant, on marches that would last for months.
Those who lagged behind were killed, he said, and estimated that every pound of ivory cost the life of a man, woman or child in Africa.
David Livingstone estimated that not more than one in five slaves who started back to the coast reached their destination, not more than one in nine on some routes. It was a business of horrific dimensions on a continent thousands of miles away from the white populations of Deep River and Ivoryton.
 
A Timetable
"The Towns That Elephants Built" series of programs will start with a reception for members and sponsors next Sunday from 3 to 5 P.M. at Ivoryton Library and will feature an exhibition of 30 large photographs of the ivory trade.
Other key dates are:
 Oct. 18 at 3 P.M. at the Ivoryton Playhouse, lecture on development of the factory town and creation of the ivory industry, by Donald Malcarne.
Nov. 15 at 3 P.M. at the Ivoryton Library, lecture and colloquium on the uses of ivory, presented by Brenda Milkofsky. Evaluation will also be made of buttons, combs and other ivory artifacts.
Jan. 17, 1999, at the Ivoryton Playhouse, "An Evening of Scott Joplin and Friends," a musical presentation by Todd Ellison.
Feb. 7, 1999, at the Deep River Historical Society, lecture by Richard Conniff on the connection between the ivory trade and the abolition of slavery.
