HEADLINE: In Church, Changing of the Guard

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
BESET by rising costs and shrinking congregations, traditional Protestant churches that were once community mainstays in dozens of Long Island towns and villages are struggling to stay afloat.
Although some of the Island's nearly 800 Protestant congregations are expanding or holding their own, many are selling property or renting church buildings to other congregations and private groups to make ends meet. 
 Increasingly, smaller congregations unable to pay the salary of a full-time minister are economizing with part-time or retired clergy. Some churches open only for Sunday services.
For other congregations meeting in now-outsized church buildings that are filled, on Sundays, not with parishioners but with empty pews, the cost of maintaining aging church buildings is growing ever more onerous.
At the Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City, a floriated Gothic church consecrated in 1885 and the seat of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, declining attendance had left the cathedral, which can comfortably seat about 650 people, less than half full on most Sundays in recent years.
The diocese, which includes Nassau, Suffolk, Queens and Brooklyn, is facing financial problems and in recent years has sold a number of properties, including the former St. Paul's-St. Mary's School in Garden City. The cathedral is currently in bankruptcy because of debts incurred by the schools.
The Rev. Canon F. Anthony Cayless, the cathedral provost, said the picture had brightened within the last two or three years. "Suddenly we've got lots of children and young families," he said. "So I think the tide is turning."
But conditions were not so hopeful at small Protestant congregations where membership has hovered near historic lows.
While dissolution of congregations remains rare, pressures that have been building for years are approaching a crisis point in some parishes, clergy members from several denominations said.
"Let's just say that survival is most on their minds," said the Rev. Tom M. Castlen, executive presbyter of the Presbytery of Long Island, which includes 57 Presbyterian churches in Nassau and Suffolk.
Mr. Castlen said that the two largest Presbyterian churches on Long Island were now a predominantly African-American congregation, Memorial Presbyterian Church in Roosevelt, and a Korean congregation, the United Korean Presbyterian Church of Long Island, which has opened a new church in Bethpage in a former Grumman Corporation building.
Indeed, Protestant clergy agreed that growth and stability appeared greatest in African-American and Asian congregations, while predominantly white, traditional congregations seemed most battered by change.
They also agreed that charismatic and more scripturally conservative congregations, some relatively new, seemed to be faring better than traditional Protestant churches, which generally hold more liberal positions on issues such as abortion and homosexuality.
In sum, they suggested that after 50 years of steady decline, the long reign of the WASP seems to have been eclipsed, at century's end, in a region where Protestants held sway for more than 300 years.
Long Island, whose European settlers were English Protestants on the East End and Dutch and English Protestants in Brooklyn, Queens and what is now Nassau County, remained predominantly Protestant through the first half of the 20th century.
In some areas on the North Shore of Nassau County, incorporated villages were almost exclusively Protestant enclaves where Catholic and Jewish families were present in very small numbers, if at all.
But after World War II, rapid change began as more Catholics, many of Irish and Italian origin, moved to the Island. The Island's Jewish population also grew dramatically, especially in Nassau County.
Currently, most demographers estimate Long Island is about half Catholic and about one-fifth Jewish. Protestants and others make up the remainder.
Estimates vary, however. A 1993 survey by the Long Island Council of Churches said Protestants made up 53 percent of the Long Island population. Demographers and others generally regard that estimate as too high.
The Federal Census does not include statistics on religious adherence because of the Constitutional requirement for separation of church and state. But according to the Compton's Encyclopedia, 64 percent of Americans are Protestants, 25 percent Catholic and 2 percent are Jewish. The remainder belonged to other major faiths or had no religious ties.
Long Island's population of about 2.7 million is up only about 50,000 from 1980. But many Protestant clergy members said that as Protestant families left during the past two decades they were most often replaced by families of other faiths.
"Anecdotally, real estate agents tell us that only about one in six houses are sold to Protestant families," said the Rev. Maurice A. Fetty, senior minister of the Congregational Church of Manhasset, an area with a high Protestant population.
Mr. Fetty said that an influx of young families into the Manhasset area was bringing new members to the church to replace older ones who had left. Sunday school attendance was up, he said, reversing a trend, and adult membership was holding steady at about 700 still far below the 3,700 adult membership in 1970. The church now rents space to an independent Chinese congregation.
"We are holding our own now, but the difference is that younger people do not attend church as regularly as former generations," Mr. Fetty said. "Many have weekend condominiums, boats, places in the Hamptons, ski lodges, and there are so many weekend sports activities. But they do support the church financially."
At Christ Church of Manhasset, an Episcopal church, the Rev. Leslie C. Hughs said membership had remained stable at about 300 for the past decade. But changes in the congregation have brought financial challenges.
"When we lose established members through death, retirement and leaving Long Island, they tend to have been giving at a higher level than the younger families coming in," Mr. Hughs said. "The numbers remain consistent, but the level of income from contributions goes down."
Episcopalians, theologically the closest to Roman Catholics of all Protestants, make up about 4 percent of the country's total Protestant population, according to Compton's. But on Long Island, as elsewhere, church members historically included some of the region's wealthiest families.
"The wealth and the power of the Episcopalians made them appear bigger than they were," Mr. Hughs said. He said the reputation also added to current problems for his church.
"One of the misconceptions is that churches on the North Shore of Long Island have huge endowments from the families that used to live here, and generally that's not true," he said. "It's a real problem because people say they don't need money."
For several years Christ Church has been trying to sell or lease property adjacent to the church where the parish house is located. "It just became too expensive to maintain such a facility that had really outgrown the congregation's use," Mr. Hughs said. He said the house and the church were used by a Korean Presbyterian congregation.
While some churches in Manhasset struggle to hold their ground, at least one -- the Manhasset Baptist Church -- is thriving. The church, which expanded four years ago to accommodate about 400 worshipers on most Sundays, is "theologically more conservative" on issues such as abortion and homosexuality, said the Rev. Bryan Wilkerson, its pastor. He said about half the worshipers were former Catholics.
"People are looking for a strong message from the Bible that speaks to their everyday needs," Mr. Wilkerson said. "Our services are vibrant and upbeat, and they don't feel they have stepped out of normal life into some bygone era or cloister."
Traditional sacred music is still used at the church. But in addition, what Mr. Wilkinson called contemporary Christian music is provided by a "praise band" whose instruments include electric guitars and drums.
Some congregations have resisted renting or sharing church space with other denominations or groups. But many others now depend on rents to meet budgets, pay pastors and keep up buildings.
"Some of our churches probably could not hold on to their buildings unless they rented to other groups," said the Rev. Dr. John A. Blackwell, the associate conference minister for the southern region of New York for the United Church of Christ.
"A number of churches have been forced to sell property, and there are others who should sell or rent property to another church, but you have people who just won't do that."
Dr. Blackwell said the cost of maintenance augmented the difficulty some churches had meeting United Church of Christ salary guidelines for pastors. The lowest recommended base salary is $20,944, which does not include benefits such as health insurance, pension and residency in a church-owned parsonage.
"With some of the smaller churches this is just out of the question," Dr. Blackwell said. In such cases, congregations hire part-time or retired pastors and pay what they can.
Some churches have drawn on their prestige and status as local architectural landmarks to meet unexpected expenses.
The Venerable Jerome J. Nedelka, the rector of St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Islip and the Archdeacon of Suffolk County for the Long Island diocese, said St. Mark's faced crisis when it was extensively damaged in an arson fire in 1989.
Some of the damage was covered by insurance, but the church also incurred substantial costs. Church and community members helped meet the expense.
"We rebuilt it exactly the way it was, with some modern necessities, and that cost us an extra $1 million," Mr. Nedelka said. "Fortunately because of the church history and prestige in the community we were able to raise most of it. But the upkeep and maintenance of older buildings is significant and you need the kind of congregation that is interested in doing what is needed."
Mr. Nedelka said the church recently spent $45,000 to replace windows "despite doing all the work ourselves."
The church was built in 1880 with a donation from William K. Vanderbilt, whose summer mansion, Idle Hour in Oakdale, is now part of Dowling College.
But with super-wealthy patrons gone and large churches and properties difficult to maintain, the Episcopal diocese is feeling the strain.
"It is simple a reality that many things that were needed and viable in the 19th century become unnecessary and cannot be sustained as you enter the 21st century," said the Venerable John A. Greco, Archdeacon of Nassau County for the Episcopal diocese.
"In my own experience, any number of my former parishioners and their children have moved away from Long Island for job opportunities, because of the cost of living, or just because they wanted a different environment," said Mr. Greco, the former rector of St. Jude's Episcopal Church in Wantagh. "Now we have an awful lot of churches in the diocese of Long Island reflecting the post-World War II boom, and a lot of them have proven to be redundant."
There are 44 Episcopal churches in Nassau and 43 in Suffolk.
An air of mystery persists over what happened to all the Protestants, and how this once-dominant segment of the Long Island population came to be a minority.
In Manhasset, Father Hughs of Christ Church said, there was among some members of the clergy a half-serious explanation. "At one point the presidents and vice presidents of companies lived in Manhasset, but then they moved on to Lattingtown and Locust Valley and were replaced by the next level down."
And, the theory goes, the presidents and vice presidents were mostly Protestants, while those in the the next level down were less likely to be Protestant.
In Locust Valley, the Locust Valley Reformed Church was "thriving with a good strong membership and financial base, and a growing Sunday school," said the Rev. Dr. Randall Bosch, who retired two years ago as the church pastor.
But. Mr. Bosch said he too was puzzled by changes in Long Island demography that have made Protestants a minority.
"What happened? That's the $64,000 question," he said. "You could give any number of explanations. No one of them explains the situation."

HEADLINE: CHATTER;
A Casino in Wildwood?

 BODY:
Should an Indian-run casino be allowed in Wildwood on a municipal parking lot that would be transferred to the Delaware tribe?
 
Why Not?
Why not have a casino in Wildwood? If they have them in Atlantic City, I don't see any harm in having one in Wildwood.
 
CINDY CIOFFI
West Long Branch
 
Nothing to Gain
I'm absolutely against it because of the environmental impact. It will mean an influx of more people in an already overcrowded area. If they think it is going to give the area an economic boost, they should look at what casinos have done in Atlantic City. It just put more people in poverty and hasn't helped the residents at all.
 
LESLIE EDEN CLARE
Atlantic Highlands
Indians Deserve It
The Indians have their basic rights. Give them what they deserved. They have been abused for so long. God bless the Indians.
 
NAPOLEON A. BARTOLAZO
Seminole, Fla.
 
Yes and No
Talk about an interesting quandary. On one hand, I'm very supportive of Indians and trying to "give back" what we've taken, if that is possible. But on the other hand, I'd hate to see a casino come into the Cape May area, where I used to spend time.
Casinos have shown that they can revitalize an area. They provide jobs for native people who are typically unemployed and they provide much needed income for people who are usually living well below the poverty line. Casino work provides a measure of self-respect and pride for reservation people. But there is no reservation at this site. So, who would be employed there but non-Indians?
Additionally, a casino brings in more people, more traffic, more drinking, and a lot of problems.
Does the land need to go to the Indians? Maybe, but I'd vote against it if it were up to me.
 
ELISANNE MacHARDY MEAD
Salt Lake City
 
Share the Wealth
I am not necessarily against an Indian-run casino whose money would ultimately be transferred to the Delaware tribe, but the Wildwood proposal does not seem fair for the other groups who live there. The money raised on municipal land should be directed to social agencies that would benefit the whole community, such as hospitals, libraries or schools.
 
LAURA COBRINIK
Queens, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Space Is Tight, Office Markets Robust

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
WITH vacancy rates declining, rents rising and some tenants opting to move either to the suburbs or to parts of Manhattan that were once avoided, the fundamentals of the commercial real estate market in the New York area have been robust in the first nine months of the year.
According to preliminary third quarter figures compiled by the Julien J. Studley company, the overall vacancy rate for office space in Manhattan fell to 5.8 percent, from 6.8 percent in the second quarter, while average rents rose to $31.29 a square foot annually, from $28.97 a foot. 
 Lost in these averages is the fact that in some parts of midtown, such as the area near Grand Central Terminal, space in the newest and best buildings is all but unavailable, and asking rents of $70 a square foot have been reported.
The vitality of the office market has also been reflected in the retail sector, with some stretches of Madison and Fifth Avenues commanding annual rents of $300 to $500 a square foot. Hotels are filled nearly to practical capacity, with room-rate increases fattening owners' profits.
But the gyrations of the stock market are having an impact on sales of property, with the decline in the price of real estate investment trust stocks removing them, at least temporarily, from the acquisition scene and forcing other financing sources to reevaluate their plans.
"The sentiment is different," said Peter Hauspurg, the chairman of Eastern Consolidated Properties, which specializes in building sales, "and we're trying to sort out what it means." He said financing sources were now requiring developers to supply a higher proportion of funding for deals. "Wall Street and the hedge funds pulled back from financing in the 80 to 90 percent range," Mr. Hauspurg said.
Mr. Hauspurg said the new reluctance of investment firms to aggressively finance purchases was likely to slow the pace of transactions as buyers and sellers are forced to negotiate new terms. "This is not great for the sales business," he said. "When the price changes, the volume drops 80 percent."
"There were a number of players," said Sean F. Hennessey, director of the New York hospitality practice for PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting and consulting firm, "who were going to put properties on the market who have pulled back due to the impact of the stock market. The buyers have gotten fewer and pickier. They are looking for better deals than two months ago."
The real estate investment trusts, the tax-sheltered acquisition and ownership vehicles that made such a splash in the metropolitan area over the last few years, have grown quiet, the victim of their falling share prices and their own structure.
To avoid paying taxes on income, the REIT's must pay out 95 percent of their income to shareholders as dividends. This means they do not have much in the way of retained earnings. And with a depressed price, they are not inclined either to return to public markets for additional financing or to use their stock to acquire properties, in order to avoid diluting the value of existing shares.
For instance, Vornado Realty Trust, which acquired Bernard Mendik's portfolio of midtown buildings in 1997 and went on to buy most of the property along Seventh Avenue between 34th and 31st Streets, has not announced any new acquisitions recently. That is probably because its shares, which reached $50 early in the year, have recently been trading below $30 a share.
"At this point, it is difficult for REIT's to raise capital and they don't want to use their own stock as scrip to make acquisitions," said Michael T. Cohen, the president of Williams Real Estate. "REIT stock is not cash anymore."
Some market watchers say the decline of the REIT's represents a return to reality. "The market got frothy," said Dennis Yeskey, the regional manager for real estate services at Deloitte & Touche, an accounting and consulting firm. "REIT's were out of whack in 1996 and 1997, trading at 20 times earnings, when they should be at 8 times."
REIT's will find a way to stay active players in the real estate market, but will be forced to change their tactics, others argue. "REIT's were the number one bidder for every property coming on the market seven or eight months ago," said Kevin Haggarty, executive managing director of the Insignia/ESG Capital Advisers group. "Now they are number two or number three, but they will continue to make acquisitions in categories where they are dominant."
Rather than trying to sell stock or debt securities based on the overall corporation, REIT's seeking capital in the current climate are likely to place mortgages on individual properties, Mr. Haggarty said, although there is little evidence they have done so yet.
But if the investment market is being roiled by the stock market, the leasing market remains strong, so strong that some tenants' brokers are recommending that their clients not make any long-term commitments at this time.
"I'd advise people to extend their lease short-term and stay where they are," said James Meiskin, president of Plymouth Partners, a tenants' broker. "This is no time to make long-term decisions. The market may well be at its apex."
Ruth Colp-Haber, a partner in Wharton Property Advisors, which also represents tenants, said that because of the tight market "landlords are making demands at the last minute, upping rents and taking away space." High rentals and the shortage of space "represent a significant impediment to small business growth in New York City," Ms. Colp-Haber added. "This is the downside of an otherwise vibrant economy and booming real estate market. In sum: things are so good, they're bad."
According to market analysts, the demand for space is being driven by rising employment and the fact that virtually no new office buildings have been added to the city's inventory for almost 10 years. "There have been 180,000 jobs added in New York and those people need space to work," said Raymond T. O'Keefe, the president of Grubb & Ellis New York.
"Look out the window, there are no building cranes," said Thomas P. Falus, the president of Cushman & Wakefield of New York, speaking of most of the city. "The only building that's going on is where there are already leases. The supply/demand equation looks pretty good."
Without the glut of empty space coming on to a declining market that characterized the late 1980's, many real estate executives expect rent levels to hold, with companies priced out of the Manhattan market heading for the other boroughs or suburbs. "I don't think we are going to see a big increase in rents, which is good," Mr. O'Keefe said. "They will probably stay on this plateau for awhile." He said the reason for this moderation is that demand for space and the available supply are in rough equilibrium.
 
Midtown
Low Vacancy Rates And New Patterns
Class A space, which is in the newest and most technically advanced buildings, is all but unavailable in midtown, with CB Richard Ellis calculating the vacancy rate at 2.2 percent. This has produced some movement of tenants to downtown, but for many companies a midtown location is essential to running their business and they are paying to stay put.
"There are lots of alternative markets, including North Dakota," observed David W. Levinson, an executive managing director of Insignia/ESG, a real estate services company. "The critical questions are where are a company's clients and can they get the employee skills they need. It's these operational issues that are critical, not saving a couple of dollars a square foot on real estate. Real estate only controls the relocation decision if everything else is neutral."
To avoid an unending upward spiral some companies are seeking to break out of the traditional tenant-landlord model. For instance, the news and financial information company Reuters has formed a joint venture with the Rudin family to build an 855,000-square-foot building on Seventh Avenue from 42d to 43d Streets that will serve as Reuters headquarters.
Reuters officials have said they see the joint venture as a means of controlling costs in a rising market and being able to tailor the building so it projects the image of a high-technology company.
Similarly, Bear Stearns will control its own 1.1 million-square-foot building at 383 Madison Avenue between 46th and 47th Streets, where demolition of the old structure on the site is currently under way. The financial services company has a 99-year lease on the underlying land.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has a 49-year lease on all 1,595,000 square feet of space at 2 Broadway under which it controls the building and pays all the bills.
"Major tenants don't want the traditional tenant-landlord relationship," said Peter Riguardi, an executive vice president of Colliers ABR, who helped negotiate the M.T.A. deal this summer. "They want to control their environment and have their own security. They don't want to have to look at the lease every time they want to do something different."
With the Reuters and Bear Stearns projects under way, the 1.6 million-square-foot building under construction by the Durst Organization on Broadway between 42d and 43d Streets loses it distinction as the only major new office project in the city.
Real estate executives said they expect other available building sites to be utilized quickly. These include the two remaining Times Square sites south of 42d Street, which are controlled by Mortimer B. Zuckerman and George Klein, and the half block on Seventh Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets that is usually referred to as "Rock West" because it is owned by The Rockefeller Group. At Rock West, the financial services company Morgan Stanley Dean Witter has reached an agreement with the Rockefeller Group to build a million-square-foot building on what is now a parking lot.
Since sites where new construction can proceed are very few in Manhattan, older buildings will have to be upgraded if they are to be competitive. A market report prepared by CB Richard Ellis noted that while the vacancy rate in midtown buildings built since 1980 is 2.3 percent, it is 6.3 percent for those built before that. "Building renovations will accelerate as the office market tightens and tenants demand Internet-ready infrastructure," the report predicts. "As Grand Central station finishes its renovation, look for the entire submarket to respond with building upgrades."
 
Downtown
Companies Move In To Get Lower Rents
A few years ago the prospects for real estate in the downtown market were so bleak that the city mounted a special incentive program that gave tax breaks to commercial tenants who would locate there and incentives to owners who would convert old office buildings to apartments and condominiums. Now downtown is becoming an outlet for tenants being squeezed by midtown's rising rates.
The M.T.A.'s decision to lease the entire 1,595,000 square feet at 2 Broadway, between Stone and Beaver Streets on the southern tip of the island, was one of the biggest leasing transactions of recent years, but not the only one.
Guardian Life Insurance Company is leaving its midtown south location near Union Square to occupy 450,000 square feet of space at 7 Hanover Square at the intersection of William and Water Streets. The company also has options to expand to 880,000 square feet over the next 10 years.
According to a survey by Cushman & Wakefield the overall vacancy rate downtown has dipped below 10 percent, with Class A vacancies down to 5.9 percent at the end of the second quarter, compared to 12.2 percent a year earlier.
Meanwhile, the average asking rent in the district reached $28 a square foot annually, a 13 percent increase from $24.85 in the same 1997 quarter, with Class A space up to $36.48 from $30.11 a year earlier.
"Back in the 1980's Park Avenue South was developed as an alternate to midtown," said Mr. Levinson of Insignia/ESG. "Now it is downtown that is the alternative. The office market is getting so tight that some buildings that were scheduled for conversion to residential may stay office." For example, the building at 10 Hanover Square was scheduled for conversion before the Goldman Sachs financial services company leased 522,000 square feet.
"Downtown is much healthier than it was, due to the conversion program," said Mr. O'Keefe of Grubb & Ellis. "You have the residential units, and the state has signed to develop the Hudson River park. The area will have a life of its own."
 
The Suburbs
On Hudson Shore, Construction Is Back

 "The squeeze in on in midtown, and for that reason the Jersey shoreline will blossom," said Michael T. Cohen of Williams Real Estate.
With the waterfronts of Jersey City, Hoboken and Weehawken just a few PATH tube stops from Manhattan, building has resumed in Jersey City for the first time in almost a decade.
The Lefrak Organization is building a 561,000-square-foot office building at its Newport complex, while Hartz Mountain Industries is at work on a 419,000-square-foot tower at its Colgate site. Last week, the fund-management company Lord, Abbett & Company announced that it would move next year from the General Motors Building on Fifth Avenue to 150,000 square feet in Hartz Mountain's Colgate Center.
Other projects are being planned, including a 1,150,000-square-foot office and retail complex in Hoboken.
"There is a lot of activity in New Jersey," said Donald P. Eisen, an executive managing director of Cushman & Wakefield who specializes in suburban properties. "Now we are seeing companies compete for the same space. There is great interest in Newark from telecommunications companies who want to be close to the main telephone switches."
Rental rates for office space in the northern part of the state increased $2.15 a square foot to an average of $27.35 a square foot, Cushman & Wakefield reported, and several speculative office buildings are under construction.
The activity in New Jersey is not limited to office properties. The number of movie screens in the state has increased to 828 from 550 over the last decade as shopping center developers increasingly incorporate them in their designs to add entertainment to consumption and try to increase the latter by keeping shoppers around longer.
Real estate executives say the office markets in Westchester and Fairfield Counties have not revived to the extent New Jersey's has. "There is still space available in Westchester, although there is renewed interest in White Plains," Mr. Eisen said. He noted that Zurich Insurance was continuing to build in Stamford, Conn., but had decided to keep its headquarters in Manhattan.
On Long Island, the office market continues to recover, with the overall vacancy rate dropping 2.4 percentage points to 10.8 percent. At mid-year 1990 the rate was 17.6 percent, according to Cushman & Wakefield. Despite the low vacancy rate, rents, averaging $24.43 a square foot, have not risen enough to justify speculative construction, many real estate executives say.
 
Retail
For Shopping, Hot Area Is SoHo
SoHo is the hot shopping area, retail leasing specialists say, with both domestic and foreign-based retailers taking the place of the art galleries, whose inability to pay rising rents has driven them to west Chelsea. "It is as if a whole new shopping area is being built there," said Alan Victor, an executive vice president of Lansco Corporation, retail leasing specialists. He said many of the stores opening in the area are selling merchandise priced below that in stores along Fifth and Madison Avenues.
"If it is a jewelry store, it will sell fashion jewelry as opposed to custom works of art on Fifth Avenue," he said.
The robust economy, which has filled office buildings with well-paid workers, and the additional housing that has been built or converted is fueling demand for retail services, analysts say. This has strengthened the hand of landlords, particularly in areas of the city where certain retailers feel they must have a presence.
"Carriage trade retailers from all over the world need a Madison or Fifth Avenue address to show they are contenders in the world of platinum-card purchasers," a study by CB Richard Ellis concluded. "Entertainment and sports retailers are interested in Times Square and Fifth Avenue locations in order to burnish their images as players on a global stage."
According to the study, the higher retail rents, from $300 to $500 a square foot a year, are charged on Madison Avenue between 58th and 72d Streets and on Fifth Avenue between 51st and 59th Streets.

Hotels
Occupancy Is Up, And Prices Rise
New York's hotels remain filled to a high level of occupancy, as tourism and business bring more visitors to a city that is seen as safe and exciting. According to a survey of 70 hotels by PricewaterhouseCoopers, occupancy rates were 83.2 percent in the second quarter of this year, compared to 81.5 percent in the same period in 1997.
Strong demand is allowing hotel operators to improve their profit margins by boosting room rates. According to the same survey, the average daily cost of a hotel room in Manhattan rose to $198.70, a 16 percent increase over last year's second-quarter average of $171.39.
"It's no longer an occupancy story, because it can't get much higher," Mr. Hennessey said. "But it is giving hotel owners the opportunity to push up room rates."
And that translates directly into profits, because most hotel costs are fixed. Once the break-even point has been reached, much of the additional revenue falls to the bottom line, Mr. Hennessey said.

SECTION: Section 14; Page 4; Column 2; The City Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Language Schools Count More On Bonjour

BYLINE: By MARCIA BIEDERMAN

 BODY:
USING pictures, pointing and pantomime, Margarita Gutierrez, an instructor at Berlitz International's language center on Rector Street, recently taught a visitor the Spanish words for "ballpoint pen," "briefcase" and "part-time job." But when the subject was computers, she had to violate Berlitz's policy of speaking only Spanish in a Spanish lesson. She used the English word "Internet" because it is used everywhere, she said.
The same phenomenon that confronted Ms. Gutierrez has long stoked Berlitz and other businesses like it. The global spread of English has provided the city's commercial language schools with a steady stream of foreign students eager to master it. Americans associate Berlitz with the "total immersion" courses in French and German popular in the 1960's, but the company's growth in recent years has owed more to the hunger for English, said John F. Bennett, Northeastern regional director. His statement was echoed by officials at other language schools. 
 Now, however, economic turmoil in Asia has slowed the enrollment of foreign students from Korea and Japan. "Some schools have been wiped out in the past year or so because they depended purely on teaching students from Korea," said Michael Riley, director of marketing for Rennert Bilingual on East 45th Street.
As a consequence, some schools have been shifting their focus to languages other than English, which for many had been a less important part of their business. While this retrenchment is hardly good news for the country's language schools, the ones in New York can at least see a silver lining.
In New York, the strong local economy and enthusiasm for multiculturalism -- among people who can afford to pay for language lessons -- have helped companies pick up the slack.
"People here are open to other cultures," Mr. Bennett said. "They like opera, they like foreign restaurants, they travel more than people in Cleveland." The city also has a supply of French and Chinese buffs, said Bernard Madon, director of the Language Learning Center on East 40th Street. "They want to learn it with no intention of using it."
New York's abundance of headquarters for multinational companies also gives city language schools a leg up. For-profit schools, which generally focus on the high end of the employee market, can sell individual instruction for upward of $35 an hour and fill up classes that are much smaller and more expensive than those given by colleges or nonprofit institutions.
At Berlitz, a worldwide company which is by far the leader among New York language schools, with one-third of the market, about 40 percent of the tuition is paid by employers. The proportion is growing, said Erin Giordano, a Berlitz marketing associate. At Accent on Language, which has corporate accounts with banks that do business in Brazil, the rolls for Portuguese lessons have grown 25 percent since 1996, while the number of English students has declined 50 percent, said Elio Boccitto, the company's owner.
Studying foreign languages is often a more lighthearted endeavor than studying English. Many foreign students of English are very serious, some being required by immigration laws to study 20 hours a week. English speakers studying other languages are more dilettantish, pleased to attain the high-beginner level at which they can get around in their second language, but not "like Henry Kissinger," Mr. Bennett said.
That level of skill is enough to please many employers. Selena Morris, a spokeswoman for Merrill Lynch, said her company offered optional language lessons, usually through Berlitz, to overseas-bound employees as part of an "expat package." But a rudimentary knowledge is all that is needed, she said, because Merrill Lynch business worldwide is conducted in English.
So the schools gear various programs for "lite" language learning. At Rennert Bilingual, there are wine-and-cheese parties where students are required to socialize in the languages they are studying.
This technique may be particularly apt because many students, business executives or not, are learning the foreign language for social reasons, Mr. Riley said. "Suzy Q might have an Italian boyfriend and she wants to get better acquainted with his family," he said.
An important growth area for Berlitz is its Cross-Cultural Training program for employees who are relocating and, equally important, for their families. ("Companies have found that unhappy families are the leading cause of unsuccessful assignments abroad," Berlitz says in its advertising materials.)
The program does not teach language, but rather manners and other useful knowledge for those going overseas. Berlitz students will learn that red roses are far too romantic to bring to a Swiss dinner party, and that asking an Arab man even routine questions about his wife may be frowned upon.
And the Language Learning Center, which is strong in French, Russian and Mandarin Chinese, matches students who are studying one another's primary language. These language pairs meet outside class time and some have even married each other, Mr. Madon said. Occasionally, he added, one person so dominates the conversation that the partner asks to be switched to someone else.
Richard Huarte, director of studies at the Inlingua Language Centers on Fifth Avenue and on Pine Street, said his school, which is second to Berlitz in its share of the New York market, has also used some of these techniques. Many other schools have, too.
Besides these special features, some schools peddle foreign language instruction as necessary for business even though English is now global. While an overseas business meeting may start out in English, a Berlitz brochure warns, "as the discussion becomes intense, people revert to their native language to express their true feelings and opinions."
Even though foreign language instruction is now helping these businesses through hard times, Mr. Boccitto said, it is a mature industry in the United States. That is why, he said, Berlitz paid $95 million last September for ELS Education Services, which specializes in English instruction. It may also be why Berlitz's first expansion in decades in the city, to a center in Flushing that opened in January, is intended primarily for the teaching of English.
Future growth in the industry will come from people yearning to speak English, said Mr. Boccitto, who served as president of Berlitz International until 1993. That is, if "we can survive these little hiccups," he added, referring to the Asian crisis.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rennert Bilingual, above, gives parties at which students must socialize in the languages they study. Below: A Berlitz Spanish class. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)
 
Charta: "TECHNIQUES: Speak Easy"
Some teaching strategies used by the city's language schools.
 
Language Learning Center
Practice partners. A French speaker, say, who is studying English is paired with an English speaker who is studying French. Partners meet in unused classrooms or at coffee shops for conversation.
 
Berlitz
Cross-cultural training for relocating employees and their families. Lasts several days and goes beyond "handshaking versus bowing," the school says.
 
Rennert Bilingual
Wine-and-cheese parties. Students must converse in the language studied.
 
Inlingua Language Centers
Practice partners paired by profession. Like Language Learning Center's program, but bankers are matched with bankers, doctors with doctors.

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
New Issues Don't Mean Easy Pickings

BYLINE: By MARK HULBERT 

 BODY:
INITIAL public offerings are viewed by many investors as the ultimate no-brainer. Virtually no homework is required in order to win. All you have to do is buy a company's stock on the day it goes public and realize huge one-day profits.
The coming I.P.O. of Goldman, Sachs & Company is feeding into this perception. Like schoolboys flipping through an issue of Playboy, investors reading the preliminary prospectus are titillated by the huge sums that the firm's partners stand to gain if, as expected, the firm goes public this November. Investors want part of the action. 
 All but lost is a more important question: Should investors be drawn to Goldman's I.P.O. simply because it is a new issue?
It is easy to understand why investors think they should. Imprinted on their memories are I.P.O. success stories like the saga of Netscape Communications, which soared to more than $75 from $28 on its initial offering day in 1995. I.P.O.'s are just so much money in the bank, they figure.
A funny thing has happened, however, on the way to the bank. Consider the performance of two newsletters that focus on I.P.O.'s: New Issues, published by the Institute for Econometric Research in Deerfield Beach, Fla., and Emerging and Special Situations, from Standard & Poor's. If returns like Netscape's were readily achievable, these newsletters should have easily beaten the market. But I calculate that they lagged behind the return of the Wilshire 5000 by 5.2 and 7.3 percentage points a year, respectively, from 1983 through July 1998. The Wilshire, made up of about 7,600 companies, is used as a proxy for the entire stock market.
Nor is the experience of these newsletters unique. Academic studies have consistently found that the average I.P.O. lags significantly behind the market in the five years after going public.
How could the public's perception become so distorted? Memories, it seems, are selective: Investors far more readily recall the Netscapes than the laggards.
If this were the end of the story, my advice would be to avoid the Goldman offering. But it's not, thanks to a recently published study by two professors, Alon Brav of the University of Chicago and Paul Gompers of Harvard. They discovered a peculiarity of previous studies that made the performance of I.P.O.'s appear to be worse than it was.
Here is why: Most companies that go public are of the "small cap growth" variety; they have small market capitalizations and relatively high price-to-book ratios. Historically, such companies have underperformed the broad market. When previous studies found that I.P.O.'s underperformed, all they were really reporting was the pattern of small-cap growth stocks.
As a result, such studies are not particularly relevant to the I.P.O. of a business like Goldman, which is certainly not a small-cap company and may or may not qualify as a growth stock depending on the price it brings. To correct for this, the professors studied I.P.O.'s after adjusting for market capitalization and price-to-book ratios. They found that the average I.P.O. matched the market's performance.
The implication is that the investment value of a company going public has nothing to do with the fact that it is a new issue. While you shouldn't automatically avoid I.P.O.'s, neither should you reflexively buy them.
But there is one more cautionary note to the findings: More companies go public near market tops than near bottoms. A company typically doesn't go public when it thinks the market will undervalue it.
Where are we now? The Institute for Econometric Research compares weekly I.P.O. dollar volume with gross domestic product on an annualized basis. Lower readings are more bullish. This ratio, which normally fluctuates between zero and five-tenths of a percent, soared to 2.53 percent in mid-July, when volume was extremely high. Even though volume has fallen, the current reading is a still-bearish 1.68 percent.
The bottom line is that there is no reason to expect that the Goldman offering will fare better or worse than the market over all. But the recent pace of I.P.O.'s casts doubt on the health of the market itself.

HEADLINE: PRELUDES;
Breathe Deeply, and Start Saving

BYLINE: By ABBY ELLIN; Abby Ellin is a Manhattan writer. Her column on starting out in the world of money will appear the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: preludes@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IN "Down and Out in Paris and London," George Orwell wrote that "poverty annihilates the future." In a way, he was right. There is something liberating in being down to your last centimes and surviving, especially if you're George Orwell.
But this isn't Paris in the 1920's. This is New York on the cusp of the 21st century, with $9 movie tickets, $75 theater tickets, $300 for dinner for two at a four-star restaurant and $2,000 monthly rent for a one-bedroom apartment. At times, it's enough to make you long for a small town -- say, Ithaca, N.Y., where the winters can be dreadful but where Stephanie Winston, 32, and formerly of Manhattan, pays only $450 a month for a one-bedroom apartment with free off-street parking. 
 "I've got my car, I've got my job, and I don't stress trying to make ends meet," she said.
In the city, most people I know -- actors, writers, musicians, doctors, lawyers, chefs, professors, even an M.B.A. candidate -- do stress. And that anxiety has forced them to get serious about their fiscal prospects.
They now engage in all sorts of new behavior: scanning stock reports, lamenting the potential demise of Social Security, investing in condos. Partly, this stems from the fact that many are single women who have had to learn to take care of themselves. But some have reached genuine turning points, minor existential crises that propelled them into financial maturity.
"When I was 31, I was robbed at gunpoint, and it made me start thinking about my future," said Jill Diamond, now 33. "I realized I wanted security and stability, that I wanted to buy an apartment in New York, have a house in the country, afford clothing, travel and dining to my liking, and give my kids a similar upbringing as I had -- safe, and full of opportunities that money lends itself to."
So she educated herself, sitting down with accountants, lawyers and family members and questioning them about her finances.
She remembered the process: "I asked my family about the investments they already had in my name: What were they? How much was invested? What kind of access did I have to them? I never knew or really cared about any of that before."
She read books on money and self-esteem. And she abandoned her early career aspirations, of becoming a singer, instead opening a language school in Manhattan, which gave her a steady income and a greater sense of self.
Previously, she said, she found herself "dishing out thousands of dollars to musicians and making zilch on every gig, and teaching at a university as an adjunct with no prospects of a full-time job with benefits."
"This wasn't conducive to saving money," she noted. Almost two years later, the school is successful and her bank account solid.
Others took inventory after economic realities smacked them in the face.
Like many new college graduates, Amy Trapp moved into an apartment in New York long before she could support herself. "I ended up charging way too much and got myself in deep credit-card debt," recalled Ms. Trapp, now 38, of those days in the early 1980's. "One day when I realized that I couldn't take a cash advance on my Lord & Taylor card -- the only one that wasn't charged to the max -- I decided to consolidate my debt and begin paying off the balance each month. It took 18 months, but it worked."
It worked so well that after she paid off her debts, she kept making the same monthly payment to herself, putting the money into a savings account. Once she acquired a critical mass of cash, she moved up to a higher-interest, money-market account.
And after she received her first raise in her job as a credit analyst, she began setting aside half the after-tax amount. With enough money for the minimum investment, she tried a mutual fund.
"There were times when I spent the money I'd saved and times when my expenses got ahead of me, but I'd just go back and start again," she said. "Saving can be done in baby steps, and if it's done in smaller and more frequent increments it hurts less."
YES, it does -- much less than watching your A.T.M. spit out a notice of insufficient funds. And this is true even if you believe, as Orwell did, that there is "a great consolation in poverty," which he later described as "a feeling of relief, almost of pleasure, at knowing yourself at last genuinely down and out."
He added: "You have talked so often of going to the dogs -- and well, here are the dogs, and you have reached them, and you can stand it. It takes off a lot of anxiety."
Orwell may have been on to something, and all the poets, actors and artists of the world can take solace in it. But the rest of us find solace in knowing ourselves genuinely secure. That takes off the anxiety.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
In Silicon Valley, Talent in Reserve

BYLINE: By VIVIENNE WALT 

 BODY:
IN 1994, Michael Bowles was skulking outside his office at Hughes Electronics in El Segundo, Calif., whispering on public telephones to potential investors and pleading for financing to start his own cable modem company.
"It was pretty discouraging," he said. "None of them knew me, and they had a lot of trepidation about handing over a company to me." 
 Mr. Bowles, 49, finally pieced together the money to move to California's Silicon Valley and start Com21 in Milpitas. In classic Valley style, though, the thrill ended for him the moment the company went public last January. But rather than return to the phone booth, he became one of the high-technology industry's most desired modern commodities: an entrepreneur in residence.
That meant that for six months, Crosspoint Venture Partners in Woodside, Calif., paid Mr. Bowles to scrutinize potential business plans and pick which company he might want to run next -- "quite a contrast" to his situation five years earlier, he said.
"We just sat around and talked about, 'Gee, wouldn't this be a cool business?' " Mr. Bowles said. Three months ago, he founded iBeam Broadcasting, an Internet satellite broadcasting company, with financing from Crossport.
Silicon Valley's frantic hunt for the new, cool and profitable has come to rely increasingly on executives like Mr. Bowles, who, between jobs, set up shop in venture capital firms and plan their next moves. Several venture capitalists say they regard the arrangement not only as a successful strategy but also as a crucial edge in the scramble for good investments.
The concept isn't new. Since the early 1980's, larger venture capital firms have brought in -- sometimes for as long as two years -- managers they regard as candidates to run a company. The firms introduce these entrepreneurs to potential investors, have them evaluate business plans and draw up their own.
Until two years ago, though, competition for such posts was so fierce that they were unpaid. The opportunity alone, said John Mumford, the managing director at Crosspoint, was something entrepreneurs "would just die to come do."
"They received no pay," he added, "and, in fact, they would have paid the v.c.'s to sit there and find the next golden nugget."
But Silicon Valley's arithmetic has shifted the balance of power. Awash in capital, many venture capital firms have more money to invest than can readily be soaked up by new, sure-fire companies. In one measure, Venture Economics, a research firm in Manhattan, said venture capital firms raised $10 billion in 1997; through just the first half of 1998, the firms raised $7 billion.
And in the second quarter, venture capital investments in the Valley alone were $1.24 billion, one-third of all venture funds spent nationally, according to a survey of 721 companies by PricewaterhouseCoopers.
AS capital has flooded in, the number of start-up deals has so accelerated that venture capital firms have been left begging for people to run the new companies.
Consequently, entrepreneurs in residence have become high-priced chief executives in waiting. According to those interviewed, they earn about $10,000 a month from the venture capital firms, a princely rate that Mr. Mumford calls "stupid" but which is paid partly to keep the entrepreneurs from going elsewhere.
The entrepreneurs face few rules or expectations. When they find a business plan they like, they don't even have an obligation to choose their sponsoring firm as an investment partner -- though almost all do.
Ultimately, the goal is to breed a group of loyal entrepreneurs who will return again and again to the venture capital firm to build their next companies and thus undercut the executive shortage.
"The talent pool has been very, very heavily diluted because of the amount of new companies being formed," said Steven Baloff, general partner of Advance Technology Ventures in Palo Alto, Calif. "Fifteen years ago, if your company failed, it was a black mark on your resume. Now venture capital firms almost prefer it. You've got your scars, and you've learned some hard lessons."
From the moment Chris Risley announced last year that he was resigning as chief executive of On Technology, a network management software company in Cambridge, Mass., venture capitalists on both coasts began calling him. He declined all offers, moved to Silicon Valley and spent three months vacationing throughout California with his wife, Susan, and son, Luke.
Finally, he became an entrepreneur in residence at Bessemer Venture Partners in Menlo Park, where he spent six months reading "several deal pitches a week." Two weeks ago, Mr. Risley joined Insite Innovations, a software start-up in Menlo Park, as its chief executive.
His transition, he said, might have been trickier without the entrepreneur-in-residence program. He said the most common mistake entrepreneurs make "is to send in a business plan in the hopes that someone will get excited and call them."
"In my experience, that never turns into a deal," he said. "You need a meeting to do a presentation, and for that, you need someone to refer you to a venture capitalist."
That need gives the entrepreneurs in residence a huge advantage. In turn, it also risks creating a fairly narrow circle of start-up executives.
As for Mr. Bowles, he could be set to become another of the Valley's most highly prized commodities: a start-up addict. Mr. Mumford of Crosspoint, who has backed both of Mr. Bowles's ventures, expects to see him again. "Mike will be back in our office starting a new company a year from now," he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Is the Other Brick About to Drop on Construction?

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
DO construction executives know something the rest of us don't?
Reasons for thinking that the present boom in construction has run its course are plentiful: 
 * So many professionals left the building trades during the last recession -- and so few young people are opting for careers in building now -- that builders find it hard to hire construction engineers, let alone welders or bricklayers.
* Cement and other building materials are in short supply, and prices are rising.
* Economic turmoil in Asia and Russia is stifling overseas demand, as project after project is halted or postponed, while the resulting financial-market gyrations provoke caution among American corporate customers.
And yet, across the country, construction executives are clicking their heels.
"Sure, some people are in trouble overseas, and some are facing shortages, but by and large, this industry is in really good shape," said Gary Tulacz, a senior editor at Engineering News Record, a construction trades journal.
For the moment, Mr. Tulacz may be right, but analysts are sounding alarm bells about the not-too-distant future. "Everyone is busy, but materials and people are really being stretched thin," warned Louis Taylor, senior real estate analyst at Prudential Securities.
Robert A. Murray, vice president of economic affairs for the F. W. Dodge unit of the McGraw-Hill Construction Information Group, predicted that total building activity would rise just 3 percent in 1998, compared with a 7 percent leap in 1997. "The industry is at cruising speed, but the strongest growth years are behind it," he said.
Asia's woes, meanwhile, may prove to be a double whammy for the American construction industry. The Fluor Daniel Inc. unit of the Fluor Corporation, whose revenue from telecommunications work has stalled at about $160 million a year because so many overseas projects are on hold, worries that hungry Asian contractors will start competing in the United States. "They're already bidding for work in Latin America," said Ron W. Oakley, president of Fluor Daniel's Infrastructure Operating Company.
Prices for cement, insulation and materials are inching up even though manufacturers have stepped up production. "There'll be a significant gap between supply and demand for the foreseeable future," said Edward Pile, a spokesman for the Lafarge Corporation, a large cement company.
The labor shortage is also likely to persist, warned Louis J. Coletti, chairman of the Building Trades Employers Association in New York, which recently joined forces with the local construction workers union to funnel high school graduates into apprentice programs. "The lack of a skilled work force has leaped out as the single biggest issue facing the construction industry in this country," he said.
With so many alarm bells clanging so loudly, why are construction executives feeling so good? For one thing, many say their exposure to trouble overseas is much smaller than a casual observer might think. Many projects scuttled by economic meltdowns in Asia and Russia were being handled by local contractors, while multinational companies like Merck, Exxon and Hoechst continue to hire American companies to design and build oil refineries, power stations and pharmaceutical plants -- and pay in dollars. "Our bookings are at an all-time high," said Richard J. Swift, chairman of Foster Wheeler, which gets two-thirds of its revenue overseas.
In the United States, Congress has authorized $217 billion for highway construction, and localities are floating many bonds that will pay for projects like new schools. "The government is going to be a huge source of growth for us," said Bradley S. Jacobs, chairman of United Rentals, which rents building equipment.
It will be a while before that money is disbursed, giving builders time to prepare. "Companies are already pulling kids out of Burger Kings and training them in construction," said Tobias M. Levkovich, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney.
Industry consolidation and modern communications have made it easier to shift people, equipment and even work where they are needed. United Rental has gobbled up local rental companies, adding to its fleets of cranes, compactors and other equipment. Fluor Daniel uses new engineering centers in New Delhi and Manila for work on American projects. "If you don't have people where the work is, you move the work to where the people are," said Ron Peterson, a Fluor Daniel group president.
Some makers of building materials, like Owens-Corning, are supplying United States projects from plants in China and Europe, while others, like Lafarge and Certainteed, are building or opening new plants.
The last time the industry roared like this was in the late 1980's, just before a recession brought new construction to a crawl. No one expects another such crash, but cautious notes are being sounded. "The telecommunications companies, the banks -- all are reassessing their needs," said Daniel R. Tishman, executive vice president of the Tishman Realty and Construction Company. Others say that such rethinking is occurring in just about every industry.
"Tremendous caution has welled up in executives who were positively ebullient a few months ago," said Thomas P. Falus, president of Cushman & Wakefield New York, a real estate firm owned by the Mitsubishi Estate Company. "They are not going to commit to a lot more space. And that has got to mean a damper on construction."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
The Have-Nots, at Least, Have Shelter in a Storm

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
INCOME inequality is taking on a new dimension these days. Not only have people's weekly earnings grown more disparate than in the past; what they possess -- their accumulated wealth -- has also grown more unequal lately. The haves and the have-nots, or more precisely those who have prospered and those who have stood still, are becoming easier to tell apart. Now the have-nots might get a break.
The haves in this race -- the hares, so to speak -- are the 25 to 30 percent of all American households that in the 1990's have become much wealthier than many ever anticipated. They are the families earning north of $75,000 a year, often far north. And while they own homes, they have invested most of their savings in the stock market, which boomed fabulously until midsummer. Their net worth, adjusted for inflation, has grown by nearly 20 percent since 1989. The least wealthy among them are worth more than $100,000, and the nest eggs go straight up from there. 
 The have-nots -- the tortoises -- are the mass of families earning less than $75,000 a year but more than $25,000, just enough to afford at least a semblance of middle-class life in much of the country. Their incomes, adjusted for inflation, have remained largely unchanged, despite a brief rise in 1989 and another one now.
These families' biggest investments are their homes, which rose smartly in value in the 1970's and 1980's, often outpacing the stock market, and net worth grew in tandem. The 1990's have been an entirely different experience for these families: For the first time, their net worth shrank; it has made only a partial recovery since 1995.
"The story is that the assets of these families, mainly housing, were not the big winners of the 1990's," said Edward N. Wolff, an economist at New York University.
In the children's story of the tortoise and the hare, the steady tortoise wins the footrace. But the odds of a tortoise victory in the net-worth race are remote, although the tortoise has closed the gap slightly. A victory would require that housing prices, employment and earnings all hold up as the national economy slows or falls into a recession brought on by the spreading Asian crisis. Stock prices would have to fall simultaneously, far more than they already have. By some estimates, the Dow Jones industrial average would have to drop to 5,500 or below for the tortoise to edge out the hare.
"For a long time, housing wealth has been more equally distributed than stocks and most kinds of other financial wealth," said James M. Poterba, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "If house prices rise and stock prices fall, that translates into more equalization."
Most of the new information on household wealth comes from Mr. Wolff, who has analyzed data collected by the Federal Reserve through 1995 and has calculated projections for 1996 and 1997. The Economic Policy Institute has provided additional information.
Most economists agree with Mr. Wolff's findings, although some question his definition of wealth. Mr. Wolff, for example, includes 401(k) plans and similar retirement accounts, but he excludes Social Security, most company-paid pension plans, and "things" -- the appliances, furniture and cars, for example, that families own. Counting these would raise estimates of the wealth of the less affluent.
BY Mr. Wolff's calculation, the median wealth in America (the level at which half of all households have more, and half less) rose to $54,600 in 1989, from $51,000 in 1983 and $36,200 in 1962. But it fell from the 1989 peak to $45,600 in 1995, and then rebounded part way, to $49,900, last year. (All these figures are adjusted to 1995 price levels.)
The reasons for the decline are clear enough: Home prices have risen, particularly since 1996, but mortgage debt and home equity loans have risen faster, diluting net worth.
Consumer spending has risen faster than earnings, forcing middle-level families to borrow or cut into liquid savings, which they hold mostly in bank accounts. Many more Americans own stock today than in the past, and this is billed as evidence that the benefits of a rising stock market are spreading across the population. But in fact, the vast majority of shareholders have less than $10,000 apiece in stock and mutual funds.
So the tortoises have actually lost wealth during the economic expansion of the 1990's, now perhaps ending. If wealth is a buffer against job loss, the tortoises are less secure than they were in 1989. And if political clout and campaign contributions are linked, then the growing wealth of the upper 25 percent of households has made them even more politically powerful.
But there is a silver lining, or a gray one. "If the market continues to take a hit, that will demoralize wealthy Americans more than the less affluent," said Daniel Yankelovich, chairman of DYG, a polling firm. The latter "are used to seeing their wealth decrease, and won't feel as bad."

LENGTH: 1145 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/James H. Gipson;
Clipper Fund

BYLINE: By WILLIAM R. LONG 

 BODY:
AS stock indexes climbed to record highs during the first half of the year, many managers of stock mutual funds were throwing most every dollar they had into the market. Not James H. Gipson, founder and lead manager of the Clipper Fund. By mid-July, he had a fat 44 percent of his portfolio in cash and Treasury bonds, with the balance in just 17 stocks.
Investors were not happy, said Mr. Gipson, recalling snippy letters from shareholders. One, he remembered, said something like this: "If I wanted my money in cash, I would have put it in the bank." 
 With the summer selloff in stocks, cash suddenly looked great, and so did Clipper, which lost far less than the market over all. And the fund now has a bundle of cash on hand for bargain-hunting.
"I think you will find that we did an exceptionally good job of capital preservation during a difficult period," he said.
He's right. From July 17, when the market peaked, through Sept. 11, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slumped by 17.2 percent. The average large-capitalization value fund lost 17.4 percent over that period, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago financial publisher. Mr. Gipson's fund, with $960.1 million in assets, lost just 7.2 percent.
Since its inception in early 1984, Clipper has returned 17 percent annually, on average, just ahead of the S.& P. and substantially better than the 13.5 percent of the average large-cap value fund.
MR. GIPSON founded Clipper's adviser, Pacific Financial Research of Beverly Hills, Calif., in 1980, to manage institutional portfolios. Last year, he and four minority partners sold Pacific Financial to United Asset Management, "in part for personal reasons but also for the same reason that we've been selling stocks in the portfolio," he said. "We found the market was generously valued and we decided to take some money off the table."
He has a contract to continue running the firm for seven years, as do his co-managers, Michael C. Sandler and Bruce Veaco.
Mr. Gipson buys a company's stock only when it is priced at least 30 percent below its so-called intrinsic value, the amount a company is estimated to be worth to a private buyer, and typically sells when it hits that value. For the last two years or so, the fund found few stocks that met its standards, and its cash position grew.
Since the market correction began in July, however, the number of stocks in Clipper has risen to 23, while cash has fallen to less than 40 percent. "We have shifted from being holders of sizable cash to being patient buyers" of stocks, Mr. Gipson said.
Not that the fund's concentration bothers him. Last week, Mr. Gipson rolled out a more concentrated and equity-heavy version of the fund, UAM Clipper Focus, which invests in the same stocks but holds no more than 5 percent in cash.
Clipper uses a variety of models in putting a price tag on companies, a process that helps set Mr. Gipson apart from other value investors. "There's a large segment of value investors who use a simple mechanical approach to determining value," he said, citing price-to-earnings ratios, price-to-book ratios and high dividend yield as examples. He said an advocate of such a strategy could be considered "a first-generation value investor, who uses the same valuation approach for each kind of company."
He calls his team of seven analyst-managers "second-generation value investors," because they try to value each company in the way a private buyer would in bidding for the company, tailoring the analysis to the nature of the business.
In valuing a media company, for example, relevant benchmarks may be price to cash flow or price per subscriber, but not book value, he said. "On the other hand, book value does have a sizable element of relevance if you're looking at a bank or an insurance company or a security broker."
For giant companies like Coca-Cola or Philip Morris, it may be more difficult to establish intrinsic value, so he relies heavily on a model of discounted free cash flow. He takes his 10-year estimate of a company's free cash flow -- cash after capital and other expenditures -- and discounts it by the return of a 30-year Treasury bond (now 5.14 percent) and then by a "risk premium" that varies with each company (say, 2 percent for Coca-Cola, a company seen as having little risk, and 4 percent for Philip Morris).
Mr. Gipson then compares the company's intrinsic value with the price of its stock. "If we can buy the company at 70 percent or less of its intrinsic value, then that company would become a good candidate," he said.
"You have to make sure that you buy stocks with a margin of safety," he added.
Mr. Gipson looks for opportunities company by company, with no preference for any economic sector or industry. Currently, he said, "we are finding some reasonable opportunities in specialty chemical companies." But he declined to identify the stocks because he was still buying them.
In recent months, the fund has been heavily weighted in the financial area because of large positions in the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac, the Government-sponsored mortgage enterprises; each is about 9 percent of the portfolio.
"They are two very good companies who share a market niche that is highly profitable and well protected from competition," Mr. Gipson said. Fannie Mae closed at $63.375 on Friday; he estimates its intrinsic value at $82. Freddie Mac trades at $47.125; he puts its intrinsic value at $60.
The biggest position in Clipper, nearly 12 percent of assets, is Philip Morris. "We had a smaller position going into the spring of this year, when the concern about both litigation and legislation reached a crescendo," he said. He bought more Philip Morris, in the $36-to-$39 range, in mid-May. "That was an example of being a contrarian value investor, buying on bad news," he said. The stock has climbed to $46.25, even as the market has fallen.
"The prime reason it's cheap is concern over litigation and legislation" on domestic tobacco, he said. "But there's more to Philip Morris than domestic tobacco. They have a very good food business and a great international tobacco business."
Mr. Gipson estimates the company's intrinsic value at $70 a share, but he is in no hurry to see it reach that point. "We're quite happy to sit and wait, with the 4 percent dividend yield," he said.
And he is not afraid to venture abroad. In recent months, Clipper added to a small position in De Beers Consolidated Mines, the South African diamond giant. He recently paid between $12 and $15 for its American depository receipts, which have fallen by nearly half from their April high on concern about plummeting diamond sales in Asia. The A.D.R.'s trade at $14.3125; Mr. Gipson puts the intrinsic value at $30.
