SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 2453 words

HEADLINE: Talking the Tawk;
New Yorkers Are Sounding More Like Everybody Else. Is It Curtains for the Accent People Love to Hate?

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER

 BODY:
IT'S loud, it's fast and when some of its more famous speakers -- like Fran Drescher ("The Nanny") and Joe Pesci ("My Cousin Vinny") use it, you know exactly where they're coming from. It's New York ese, the mother tongue of millions of city dwellers and of expatriates who have taken it to Long Island, New Jersey and beyond.
But though plenty of people in and around the city sound more Co-op City or Greenpoint than, say, Kansas City or Greenwich, some experts on language believe that well-known elements of the distinctive New York accent are fading away. Shamed by the scorn of outsiders and tamed by the colorless, dulcet tones of national television and radio announcers, New Yorkers just don't talk the way they used to. In fact, some experts say, they're sounding more like everybody else. 
 "New York accents aren't so extreme anymore," said Robert Hendrickson, an author of numerous books on regional speech including the forthcoming "New Yawk Tawk: A Dictionary of New York City Expressions" (Facts on File). "Strong accents still exist, but they are more common among older people."
William Stewart, a professor of linguistics at the City University Graduate Center, agreed. New York ways of speaking are "either being dropped or incorporated into the language as a whole," he said. But regional variations in speech are becoming less noticeable all over the country, he and other linguists said, because of mass communication, increased mobility, different immigration patterns and more people moving up the social ladder and dropping their accents along the way.
In the future, said George Jochnowitz, a professor of linguistics at the College of Staten Island, "the big differences will not be regional, but ethnic and educational."
But while New Yorkese is changing along with other regional modes of speech, many of its distinct characteristics remain, he said. "Stigmatized features are less than they were, but a lot of the more subtle things are as strong as ever," like the pronunciation of bad as "bay-ed," Professor Jochnowitz said.
And enclaves of traditional New Yorkese still exist in the metropolitan region, mostly in Brooklyn and Staten Island and on Long Island, where many sons and daughters of the city moved after World War II, Professor Stewart said. "Staten Island," Professor Jochnowitz noted, "is the last and best holdout in the city of the New York accent."
Born of the confluence of many linguistic streams -- the languages of the Dutch, the English, the Irish, the Italians and European Jews are but a few of them -- New Yorkese has always had a decidedly down-market image. Sure, those who live beyond the Hudson love to laugh with Woody Allen when he jokes in his Noo Yawk voice, but would they want their children to talk that way? New Yorkese is the language Americans love to hate, widely seen as an exemplar of ignorance, a "dese and dem" dialect for dummies. And so it has been for years, especially after talking pictures became popular and during World War II, when the Bowery Boys and Brooklyn's G.I. Joes put the corner of "Toity-toid and Toid" on the national map, according to John Singler, chairman of the linguistics department at New York University.
New Yorkers, of course, do not as a general rule care about what others believe. "I think that it's the rest of the country that has an accent," said comedian Jackie Mason, who was raised on the Lower East Side. "In New York, anyone who talks like an American sounds like a foreigner."
The writer Jimmy Breslin, a native of Queens, defends New York speech as an essential part of the city's character. "Anything that made the place different is what made it what it is," he said. "If you're going to homogenize it, you make it no good."
But these champions of New York-speak appear to be in the minority. "New York is the most extreme case of local speech having low local esteem that I know," said William Labov, a linguistics professor at the University of Pennsylvania who has done extensive research on New York speech. "Every time you put a microphone in front of New Yorkers, they try to change the way they talk."
It's no wonder that there are 28 listings for voice and diction coaches in the Manhattan Yellow Pages. Their clients -- and the countless others who try to shed the New Yorkiness of their speech on their own -- embrace what Sam Chwat (pronounced shwa), a Manhattan speech therapist who has coached Robert De Niro, Kathleen Turner, Julia Roberts and other actors, calls "standard American English," an "educated-sounding" form of speech that, as Mr. Chwat put it, "makes you sound like you're from nowhere."
That's what Patricia Allaire, a Brooklyn native who lives in Flushing, Queens, wanted when she went to see Mr. Chwat last year. She didn't think she had much of an accent, she said, "but the moment I stepped out of the city, people began to notice, and to make fun of me." Professor Allaire, an assistant professor of mathematics at Queensborough Community College in Bayside, frequently speaks at professional conferences outside the city. And she found, to her dismay, that people often thought her New York accent was a joke.
"I think it's hard to be taken seriously if you sound like you're from New York," she said, recalling one time when she and a colleague were teased so mercilessly about their speech that they gave up any attempt at a serious presentation, put baseball caps on backward and made fun of themselves to the appreciative crowd.
Last summer, her speech therapy completed, Professor Allaire spent two weeks at a conference in Washington. "And nobody asked me if I was from New York," she said.
The peculiarities of the classic New York accent are well known, and the city's many ethnic groups can all claim the credit -- or the blame -- for some of its features, such as the reversal of the "oi" and "er" sounds, resulting in such bons mots as "terlet" for "toilet," "goil" for "girl" and "Greenpernt" for a certain part of Brooklyn, as well as the stress on the "aw" sound in words like "hawk" and "talk," all of which Mr. Chwat, the speech therapist, believes to be of Irish origin. The transformation of "th" to "t" (as when "with" becomes "wit") or to "d" (as in "my muddah and faddah"), is said to be typical of both Irish and Italian New York speech.
Jewish speakers are more likely to have a nasal "a" -- think of O. J. Simpson's erstwhile lawyer, Barry Scheck -- or to use a singsong cadence, like former Mayor Edward I. Koch's.
Speakers of Hispanic origin, like the actress Rosie Perez, often confuse the "z" and "s" sounds and sometimes drop the ends of words, though language experts say Spanglish, the combination of English and Spanish spoken by many people of Hispanic origin, is a national linguistic phenomenon.
Black New Yorkers may say "v" or "f" for "th" in words like "bathroom" or drop the plural and possessive "s," but these speech characteristics reflect black speech patterns across the country, Professor Stewart said. One reason for this, he said, may be the influence of segregation, which limited the interaction of black people with those from other other ethnic groups and encouraged the growth of separate speech dialects.
Still, whatever their ethnic heritage, many native New Yorkers use "cha" and "ja" in places Webster never intended. (Didja or didn'cha know that?)
Then there's the "r" sound. New Yorkers of various backgrounds often insert a gratuitous "r" into words, turning "law" into "lore," for example. And they drop the "r" from words where it belongs, which many Bostonians also do. "Heart" becomes "hot"; "super becomes "soopah"; "her becomes "huh." But Professor Jochnowitz, for one, believes that "r-lessness" is becoming milder. "By and large you hear it less," he said.
Change in language is inevitable, of course. Linguists say influences wax and wane, and so does the perceived prestige of differing forms of speech. Indeed, as anyone who's ever seen "My Fair Lady" knows, language is very much about class and other social differences.
New York dialect was always an underclass form of speech, according to Professor Labov, who said speakers often abandon it when they rise in social station. And, he said, attitudes about "prestige speech" filter down from the upper to the lower classes.
Back in the 1960's, Professor Labov, then at Columbia University, did one of the first studies to show that classic New Yorkese was linked to lower socioeconomic status. He figured that the correct use of the "r" sound would be a good indicator of social position. In other words, the higher people's social class, the more likely they would be to use the "r" conventionally.
The professor went to three department stores -- Saks, Macy's and the now-defunct S. Klein -- each catering to a different socioeconomic group, and asked employees for the location of a department he knew to be on the fourth floor. Sure enough, he soon discovered that that the clerks serving the more affluent shoppers in upscale Saks said "fawth flaw" far less frequently than their peers at bargain-basement Klein's, with Macy's somewhere in the middle. A 1986 study using the same methodology (substituting the now-gone J. W. May's for Klein's) confirmed that the trend still existed, and it almost certainly continues today, Professor Labov said.
But what of the words, the expressions and the cadences that, along with accent, gave a unique flavor to the way New Yorkers talk? If more people these days choose not to speak New Yorkese because they think it lacks dignity, can the city's classic vernacular -- the language of Damon Runyon ("guys and dolls"), Leo Durocher ("nice guys finish last") and Jimmy Durante (the "schnozzola") -- survive? To use a New Yorkism, that is the $64 question.
While people in this hurried city still talk a lot faster than those in most other places, their lexicon may seem less exotic. "Many of the older phrases are dying out," said Mr. Hendrickson, while other characteristic expressions -- "all right, already," for example, and "oh, yeah?" -- have been adopted by the country as a whole. Still, he said, "there are always new terms appearing."
One of them, which he attributes to Mr. Breslin, is the "Howard Beach wait," used to describe the pause people in the Howard Beach neighborhood have to make about every 20 seconds during telephone conversations because of jet planes thundering overhead on their way to and from nearby John F. Kennedy International Airport. Then there are "unshushable," Jerry Seinfeld's term, derived from Yiddish, for those in a movie theater who just never shut up, and "on the arm," meaning free of charge, usually said by police officers.
Over the years, lingo has also been coined by immigrants who have flocked to the city. For example, Mr. Hendrickson believes that use of the Spanish "bodega" for "grocery store" is of New York origin. But like many of the Spanish imports into the English language ("taco," say, and "loco"), it is used in many places across the United States, not just New York.
Mr. Chwat is among those who think New Yorkese will endure in one form or another. Though he agrees that people try to shake their accents as they assimilate in society and rise in economic status -- such people are his customers, after all -- he maintains that "there will always be ethnic neighborhoods and ethnic groups" that prize the peculiarities of their speech "and actually penalize members socially for speaking standard English."
As Professor Jochnowitz sees it, New Yorkese is moving toward standardization along with other regional speech variations, "but that doesn't mean it's ever going to get there." Sometimes, he says, "new things happen you don't expect."
So "dog" will never rhyme with "log" in New York, as it apparently does elsewhere?
"Fuhgeddaboutit," Mr. Chwat said.
 
How Tony Is the Department Store?
Find the Answer on the Fourth Floor
Language is a fluid thing, changing all the time. Words that may once have been slang become part of the mainstream, and preferred pronunciations go in and out of vogue.
For example, in New York City, so-called "r-lessness" (saying "cahd" for card and "bah" for "bar") is widely seen these days as a lower-class phenomenon, a mark of improper speech. But that was not always so. Earlier in this century, patrician New Yorkers like Franklin D. Roosevelt wouldn't have dreamed of pronouncing their r's.
This change in so-called "prestige pronunciation" occurred after World War II, and in 1962, William Labov, then a Columbia linguistics professor, began researching it. At the time, he theorized that affluent New Yorkers would be more attuned to the change in acceptability of r-less speech and more inclined to pronounce their r's than people with lower socioeconomic status. And in his 1966 study of the speech of sales clerks at three department stores catering to different socioeconomic groups, he indeed found that the more upscale the store, the more likely its employees were to use what was seen as the correct pronunciation.
In 1986, Joy Fowler, a graduate student at New York University, replicated the department store store study, discovering a similar relative distribution of r-lessness in New York stores, although fewer people overall dropped their r's.
But what about today? Does the pattern still persist? Based on my unscientific, undersampled and anecdotal survey, it looks as if Professor Labov's finding still holds: If ya got class, ya say "r."
I went first to Bradlees, the discount store on 14th Street, in the space formerly occupied by May's, the low-end emporium Ms. Fowler used in her study. When asked for the location of the toy department, almost all of the dozen cashiers and clerks I spoke to there said "fawth flaw." A couple said "fourth flaw"; one said "fawth floor."
At Macy's Herald Square, which both Professor Labov and Ms. Fowler used as their middle-class example, nearly all of the dozen or so employees responding to my questions regarding the location of the men's room offered a perfectly pronounced "fourth floor." Only one, a woman at the information desk, gave me "fawth floor."
On to Saks, where I had to ask about either women's clothing or women's shoes to get a pronunciation of "fourth floor." The responses I got would surely have gladdened Professor Labov: Of the 10 people I asked, every one enunciated perfectly when directing me to the fourth floor.
Everyone, that is, except for a woman working the information desk near the elevators. "Faarth flaar," she intoned, in what seemed to me to be some sort of a Slavic accent.
But even she got her r's right. BERNARD STAMLER

Chart: "LINGO: You Say Toemahtoe, I Say Tamahter"
"No dialect these days winds more gently through my ears than New York talk," writes Robert Hendrickson, the author of several dictionaries of regional expressions and a volume of New Yorkisms being published next month. Here are some excerpts from "New Yawk Tawk: A Dictionary of New York City Expressions" (Checkmark Books, an imprint of Facts on File):
 
BLACK ROCK -- A nickname for the black-colored CBS building at 53d Street and Sixth Avenue in Manhattan. The name, also applied to the television network itself, is said to have been suggested by the film "A Bad Day at Black Rock" (1953). In the trade NBC is called 30 Rock, from its address at Rockefeller Center, and ABC is called Hard Rock.
 
ERSTER -- A pronunciation heard in New York for oyster. "The poil was in the erster."
 
FAMILY HAMMER -- A hit man or assassin for a Mafia family.
 
HIT IN THE KISHKAS -- To hit someone in the stomach. Kishka is Russian for intestines. The word came to describe a sausage-like food of the Jewish cookery and finally suggested the Yiddish experssion above.
 
JEET -- An amazing condensation of "did you eat" that would make a Reader's Digest editor proud. "Jeet jet? Les gedda frank."
 
NO PROBLEM -- The modest New York way of saying "You're welcome." Who says New Yorkers don't got manners?
 
OFFUH YUH -- From you, off of you, as in "I wanna borra $10 offuh yuh." The expression has been around for at least 100 years and has a number of variations, including offa ya.
 
OH YEAH? -- Still a common feature of New York speech. "In his routine chatter," as the Federal Writer's Project "New York Panorama" (1938) put it, "the New Yorker cannot get along without his oh yea? It is his most valuable buffer, knout, pacifier and bubble-pipe, a necessary protective lubricant in the daily wear and tear of life."
 
OIM OWAN DA TOITY-TOID FLOHWAH OF DA NOO YWAK STADLA -- CAN OI HABA CUPPA KOWAFEE AN A GLAZZA WATTA -- "I'm on the thirty-third floor of the New York Statler -- can I have a cup of coffee and a glass of water." In a "Best New York Accent in Houston" contest held some 10 years ago, contestants had to give the proper New York pronunciation of the room service order. Former Brooklynite John Occhiogrosso won the grand prize expense-paid trip to Brooklyn with the above. When asked about job discrimination he had experienced because of his accent the winner mused (in translation), "If people don't like me for what I am, the hell with them -- that's the Brooklyn way."
 
ON LINE -- New Yorkers stand on line, not in line as other Americans do. Those of school age, however, are kept in line, or orderly, by their teachers while on line in the schoolyard. And once people are on line in New York, they ideally stay in line.
 
SLICE -- Usually used by New Yorkers as shorthand for a slice-a (piece of) pizza when ordering New York's favorite fast food in a pizza parlor: "Gimme a slice anna small coke." Whether it's a square cut of thick Sicilian or pie slice-shaped regular (Neapolitan) pizza, it's always a slice. When a whole pizza is ordered it's "Gimme a pie." Piece is rarely heard.
 
ZHLUB -- Zhlub during the past 25 years or so has been slang for an insensitive, boorish person. It derives from the Yiddish zhlub, meaning the same, which, in turn, comes from a Slavic word. A variation is zhlob.
 
Illustrations (James Yang)(pg. 1 & 11)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Spreading Global Risk To American Taxpayers

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
AS gyrations in emerging markets -- from Asia to Latin America to Russia -- cause sleepless nights for many investors, one group of politically connected and well-heeled financiers with big bets in these shaky regions can sleep better, thanks to the American taxpayer.
These well-rested folks are among the investors who have poured $3.2 billion into emerging-market funds sponsored by the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, a little-known Government agency that mixes private capital with Government guarantees to promote American foreign policy goals. OPIC's investment flag is now planted in 140 developing countries -- from obscure spots like Moldova and Botswana to nations at the center of today's global turmoil. No matter where it goes, though, OPIC has used the promise of eye-popping returns and the protection of Government guarantees to attract American investors to far-flung spots. 
 As capitalism has spread, so has the program. With direct foreign-aid dollars dropping in the last few years, OPIC's investment funds have become a leading tool in the Clinton Administration's efforts to get fresh capital -- quickly -- to emerging democracies. When President Clinton took office, there were just two OPIC funds, one in Africa and one in Asia, with combined capital of $100 million. Today, an assembly line of OPIC funds is churning in Washington: At last count, the number has risen to 26, with roughly two-thirds of the money coming from Government-guaranteed notes and the rest from institutional equity investors. By year's end, the OPIC program should swell to $4 billion.
However noble the foreign-policy goals, OPIC is making big bets with taxpayer dollars that its investment formula will pay off either politically or financially -- something that critics are questioning.
The funds buy stakes in emerging-market businesses. They are structured so that private investors -- typically large corporations and pension funds -- can invest with limited exposure to downside risk and, if their investments work out as expected, reap enormous gains. On the other hand, should every investment in all 26 OPIC funds fail, taxpayers would be on the hook for $3.3 billion in interest and principal on the notes.
OPIC has spread itslargess to many people with Government ties; the ranks of the funds' managers include leading campaign donors and former Government officials.
But a growing chorus of critics say OPIC funds often replicate what many in the private sector are already doing -- without Government protection -- and encourage excessive risks at taxpayer peril.
And to the frustration of many, OPIC runs its fund program almost exclusively behind closed doors, seeing no need to make financial details about the funds public, even though it is a Government agency.
"OPIC is gambling in Las Vegas with someone else's money," said James Sheehan, a researcher at the Competitive Enterprise Institute, an economic research group in Washington. "This is a subsidy for risk-taking. If these investment funds were based on the financial merits of the investments, you would not need subsidies to make them happen."
OPIC's point of view is that it is guilty as charged and proud of it. The whole point of the program -- which is modeled, very roughly, after successful domestic venture funds like Kohlberg Kravis Roberts -- is to encourage investors to go where they otherwise fear to tread and to stimulate economic development on unfamiliar turf.
"OPIC is trying to induce investors to do things they are not willing to do on their own," said Robert D. Stillman, a private investor who, until last April, headed the OPIC investment fund program. "If investors are not willing to put money into Eastern Europe, we will make it attractive. We're encouraging capitalism where the U.S. has a foreign-policy interest and getting investors comfortable with these places."
OPIC funds are closed-end limited partnerships intended to build on private-sector market discipline -- and capital. Each fund has slightly different objectives and different investors. Each is required to invest in companies overseas that either do not compete directly with American businesses or that help American companies. As in other venture capital funds, the money is invested for 5 to 10 years.
Right now, all eyes are on Russia. OPIC funds have committed a total of $1.5 billion to the former Soviet republics, nearly half the program's investment kitty. Eleven OPIC funds are now in this region, to the dismay of some. "It is the wrong policy to be channeling funds into those countries where their economic policies are not correct," said Ian Vasquez, a director of economic policy at the Cato Institute, a research group in Washington. "We are rewarding governments for not undertaking reforms."
But Robert Peyton, manager of Agribusiness Partners International, a $100 million OPIC fund with seven Russian investments, said the OPIC guarantee is important to him -- now more than ever.
"I just got back from Russia, and we are in fundamentally sound businesses," said Mr. Peyton, whose fund has invested in a soft-drink bottler in Moscow, a sparkling-wine plant in Georgia, dairies in Moldova and Ukraine, and Russian cheese and poultry plants. "If the politicians can hold the country, we'll be O.K. Our investors are glad OPIC is there. If the Russian economy survives, these investments will turn out to be good. Today the OPIC guarantee is more important than three months ago."
Charles D. Toy, vice president of OPIC's investment fund program, said it was too early to assess any damage. Because OPIC funds have long-term investing goals, the final reckoning is as much as a decade away. Currently, Mr. Toy said, taxpayer exposure from OPIC's Russian debt is about $400 million, because not all the money raised for these funds has been invested yet.
"It's a delicate situation," Mr. Toy said. "The impact of the market turbulence is that we will be more selective. Clearly, this shows why OPIC is needed. If you want to continue to encourage foreign direct investment as the vehicle for economic reform in any particular country and there is perceived political risk, we have to support and enhance returns to encourage private sector equity to be put at play."
Those assurances emboldened the managers of Allied Capital International Small Business, at $20 million the smallest OPIC fund. It has put money into small businesses including a pasta plant and a cannery in rural Hungary and a paging company in Brazil. If all goes well, the big payoff for investors will come in 7 to 10 years, when the businesses are sold or taken public.
"We wanted to do business overseas, but we didn't want to bet the bank on it," said Cabell Williams 3d, president of Allied Capital, a Washington-based private equity firm with $650 million in assets under management. "Our investments so far have been terrific. We will have a phenomenal return. We'll make a bloody fortune. Private capital won't go to some of these places; it's too risky. Who is going to go to Botswana and invest money? You clearly need a 50 percent return to go there."
While OPIC doesn't promise 50 percent returns, it readily suggests that investors can expect 25 to 35 percent annual returns; such boasts can be made because the funds are not registered securities. A recent solicitation memorandum issued by the United States Embassy in Tbilisi, Georgia, for a Caucasus region fund talked of returns in the range of "25 percent plus."
For every dollar of equity raised from investors -- a group that has included Archer Daniels Midland, the Coca-Cola Export Corporation, Citicorp and Continental Casualty -- OPIC typically provides a match of $2 in Government-guaranteed notes, backed by the full faith and credit of the United States. Some OPIC notes are bought by the funds' equity investors as a way of hedging their bets; any losses on their equity investment can be cushioned by gains on their OPIC notes. (Of course, some equity investors buy no OPIC debt at all.) Other buyers of OPIC notes are banks and insurance companies that are simply interested in owning Government agency debt.
Whatever the motivation of the note buyers, OPIC debt serves another important purpose: to bolster returns to the equity investors. In, say, a $300 million fund made up of $100 million in equity from institutional investors and $200 million in OPIC notes, nearly all the fund's earning power goes to the equity investors. This means that their returns are far greater than what $100 million alone could have earned. Only a small portion of the profits pays interest on the notes -- which generally carry a coupon rate about 50 basis points above that of Treasury notes.
NOT surprisingly, the OPIC guarantee is a powerful lure. "There is no chance we would have thought about any of these investment funds without an OPIC guarantee," said Stanley Zax, chairman of the Zenith Insurance Company in Woodland Hills, Calif. Zenith has invested in OPIC funds in Poland, Southeast Asia and Israel. "The fact of the matter is you have OPIC protecting the debt, which is two-thirds of the fund, and then you are getting the extra venture capital leverage of that debt. Without it, there was too much volatility in those markets."
Politics course through OPIC's fund program, traceable not only in the selections of countries to receive investment funds but, often, in links to the fund managers receiving lucrative contracts.
The enthusiasm with which the Administration has embraced the program is evidenced by the high visibility given to it by President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore: a West Bank fund announced at a 1996 White House meeting with Yasir Arafat, for example, and $750 million pledged for two sub-Saharan Africa funds during the President's highly publicized tour in Africa this year and a $120 million South Africa fund announced at a White House meeting in 1996.
But domestic politics gets OPIC's attention, too. Critics say there is a disturbing relationship between OPIC and major Democratic Party donors, often people who attended White House coffees or slept in the Lincoln Bedroom. Six funds valued at $585 million were approved in the election year of 1996 shortly after sponsors of four of them had attended White House coffees.
"This program exploded just after the Clinton Administration came into office," said Paul Hendrie, communications director of the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonprofit research group in Washington. "And a large percentage of them are going to people with strong political connections or who made big contributions to Democrats in the last election."
Among those are David Bonderman, a Texas investor with stakes in two OPIC funds who gave $140,000 to the Democrats in 1996. His business partner, Richard Blum, is a leading Democratic fund-raiser and the husband of Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California.
Mr. Bonderman's investment firm was also named manager of the $300 million Aqua International Partners fund, which has hired William Reilly, director of the Environmental Protection Agency in the Bush Administration, as its hands-on manager. Like all OPIC fund managers, Mr. Bonderman's firm will get a management fee equal to 2.5 percent of the fund's assets and 20 percent of the ultimate profits, which can run into the tens of millions.
The big contributors also included the New York investor Dirk Ziff, who, with his brother, gave $400,000 to the Democrats in 1996 and manages the $150 million South Asia Capital fund. Alan J. Patricof, a New York venture capitalist who gave $140,000 to the Democrats in 1996 and raised $600,000 more, is manager of OPIC's $40 million Israel Growth fund. And Maurice Greenberg, a leading Democratic donor, is chairman of the AIG Group, an insurance company that gave Democrats $245,000 and $213,000 to Republicans in 1996. That year, AIG was named manager of the $300 million AIG Brunswick Millennium fund, which has $30 million of AIG money in it.
Mr. Toy, the OPIC vice president, said politics plays no role in the selection of fund managers, who are picked by OPIC after a solicitation and competitive review. "OPIC fund managers have to be sophisticated world players," he said. "Therefore, it comes as no surprise that many OPIC managers have acquaintances with people in government. But our final decisions are economic. No institutional investor puts $10 million to $12 million in a fund on the basis of who the fund manager knows."
Still, for all its Government ties, OPIC is loath to disclose financial information to anyone but fund investors. It will not identify to outsiders the funds' investments or institutional investors, the rates of return or any fund's current net asset value. This C.I.A.-like secrecy has frustrated even members of Congress.
"Getting information from them is like pulling teeth," said Shawn C. McBurney, assistant to Representative Ed Royce, a California Republican who is chairman of OPIC's oversight panel. "They dodge a lot and are not forthcoming. We can't get any information about this little agency that exposes the American taxpayer to enormous risk off in a corner of Government."
In fact, OPIC prides itself on being more like a private company than the Government agency it is. "As a public agency, we are charged with transparency," said Mr. Stillman, the former OPIC fund director. "But we have to attract private capital, and private investors don't want to disclose what they are investing in."
THE shards of information available, however, from interviews and some sites on the World Wide Web, show that some OPIC funds do what private investors are already doing -- sometimes with the same fund managers. And this raises questions of why an OPIC guarantee is even needed.
Consider Newbridge Andean Partners, a $160 million OPIC fund investing in Colombia, Venezuela, Peru, Ecuador and Bolivia. To date, the fund has invested in a cable television venture and a gas distribution network in Venezuela. But it has also put $6 million into bonds of a financially troubled Argentine maker of Nike and Converse shoes, which is being restructured by a non-OPIC sister fund, Newbridge Latin America, owner of $80 million of its bonds.
Investor interest was so strong in a $180 million OPIC fund, South America Private Equity Growth, that the fund's manager set up a second, $37 million fund to make the same investments, but without OPIC guarantees. And when OPIC set up its Russian ventures, at least 28 other venture capital funds were also putting money there.
While some had ties to other United States and European government agencies, several were out-and-out private ventures, including those run by AT&T and General Motors pension funds. Junction Investors, a Boston-based group managing the $92 million Caucasus Fund, has had funds in the Caucasus and Russia going back to the early 1990's. And New Century Holdings, which has a $250 million Russian OPIC fund, also has three other venture funds in the region with more than $400 million invested and a track record there dating to 1991.
Even some OPIC fund managers question whether OPIC guarantees are needed. "We're delighted not to have OPIC in our new fund," said one OPIC fund manager, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "If you have the ability to raise money any other way, OPIC is not the best use of money for the taxpayer."
On that score, OPIC agrees. The agency, for instance, probably will not set up another Poland or Latin America fund, said Mr. Stillman, the former OPIC director.
"Our goal is to work ourselves out of business," he said. "If we can get people comfortable with these places, they will come in and do their thing."
Some of OPIC's institutional investors have a business agenda beyond receiving an attractive rate of return on their money.
At least two investors in the $25 million Africa Growth fund, Coca-Cola Export and Dresser Industries, benefited from its investments, which include aa Kenyan bottling plant for Coca-Cola and a transportation company used by Dresser.
The Israel Growth fund has taken stakes in the country's burgeoning software business -- including investments in two companies that later went public in the United States. The Massachusetts Institute of Technology, an investor in the fund, said it wanted to learn more about the high-technology business in Israel, where companies like I.B.M., Motorola and Intel have set up shop.
Still, critics of OPIC ask if all this business frenzy, especially with American taxpayers shouldering the risk, is a proper function of government. "If these are such good investments, then private money should go in and have all the risks and the benefits," said Douglas Bandow, a senior fellow at the Cato Institute. "If private enterprises want to do this, let them."

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Those Topsy-Turvy Bonds

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
THESE are strange times in bond land.
Normally, investors in fixed-income securities spend their time fretting about inflation, which erodes the value of their investment. But last month the world was tipped upside down. Worries about too much prosperity evaporated in the face of events that suggested recession, or even depression, in some parts of the world. 
 Inflation, it seems, is no longer the issue. The risk now is deflation -- falling prices.
In a conversation late last week, Jack Malvey, chief global fixed-income strategist at Lehman Brothers, talked about how investors might profit from the developments.
 
Q. A lot of people lost a lot of money in bonds in August. Just how bad was it?
 
A. Any way you slice it, August was the very worst month for all bonds, excluding Treasuries, since January 1973, when we began keeping our global family of bond indexes.
 
Q. What happened?
 
A. The big event was the Russian splash, the devaluation and default. But developments in Japan and Washington didn't help. Last month was a triple punch to the gut.
Those things led to this extraordinary rally in Treasuries, and left the rest of the sectors sadly lagging, most acutely in the market for emerging-markets bonds, but everywhere else as well.
 
Q. How much have the Treasury markets
improved?
A. At the beginning of the year, the 30-year bond was yielding 5.92 percent. Here we are almost two-thirds of the way through September, and the yield is down to 5.18 percent. It later closed the week at 5.14 percent. About three-quarters of that improvement happened in August. Except for 1987, when the equity market cracked, the Fed flooded the system with liquidity and rates plummeted, there has never been another period like this.
 
Q. Is the volatility behind us now?
 
A. If you are a short-term investor trying to outperform the indexes between now and the end of the year, we cannot say that this is the time to jump in. The uncertainties in the marketplace will not go away that fast.
 
Q. What about the Fed?
 
A. We think there is a very high likelihood the Fed will lower rates, but that it would prefer to have additional confirming evidence of an economic slowdown before they move.
We think that by November they will have that evidence, and will begin the process of bringing rates down. Over the course of the next 12 months, we think short rates could fall by as much as a full percentage point.
 
Q. At the moment, short rates are much higher than bond yields. If your forecast pans out, and the Fed does cut short rates by that amount, where does that put bond yields in a year's time?
 
A. We see bond yields declining, but in the interim we don't think they will come down as quickly as short-term rates. We think bond yields will fall below 5 percent, and perhaps as low as 4.75 percent as a preliminary target. But at this point that is not a bold prediction.
 
Q. Does it make sense for an individual investor to buy a 30-year bond that yields less than 5 percent?
 
A. Equity investors probably have better track records when they use a buy-and-hold strategy. Bonds require more management. If my father asked if he should buy a 30-year bond at this point, I would probably say no, buy something that matures in 5 years to 10 years. Intermediate maturities always make sense.
 
Q. What sort of a time horizon should an investor have?
 
A. I'd say about two years. There is probably a case to be made in being more nimble and actively involved in fixed-income investments these days. At some point, and I don't know when it will be, there will be clear evidence that inflation is back.
 
Q. How should an individual investor allocate $100,000 in the bond market?
 
A. It would probably make sense to put about 40 to 50 percent of the money in Treasury securities with maturities from one year to 30 years. I would put about $20,000 in a high-quality, short-duration corporate bond fund, another $20,000 in a short-term mortgage-backed securities fund. And I would not give up on the high-yield market. I would have at least 10 percent in good old-fashioned high-yield bonds. For the tax-conscious investor, put 10 percent of the money in municipal bonds, which are priced at their most attractive levels relative to Treasuries in about a decade.
 
Q. So what is your economic outlook?
 
A. We think there will be a growth recession next year, with the gross domestic product expanding at about a 1.8 percent rate. But like everyone else we think there is a big potential for error in that forecast. And there is a scenario where it is possible in three or four quarters the United States could be on the precipice of its first recession since 1990. But we are not looking for financial Armageddon.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 7; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Fear and Loathing at a Growth-Stock Gathering

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
ANYONE wondering what was on the minds of money managers attending the Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities investment conference last week got their answer Monday afternoon at a presentation by Judith Estrin, chief technology officer at Cisco Systems.
After declaring that she would not talk about Cisco's sales or earnings, or even its products -- which link millions of computers around the world -- Ms. Estrin enthused over her vision of the "new paradigm" taking shape through the convergence of data, voice and video technologies.
 When she finished, a hand went up in the audience. "Can you tell us," the questioner asked, "how this convergence will affect revenues?" 
 With their portfolios wracked by the stock market's two-month slump, the investment managers at this annual growth-stock carnival had little patience for paradigms, new or otherwise. And no matter how enthusiastically they had embraced such visionary pronouncements in years past, sales and earnings, or the lack thereof, were the only things that mattered last week.
For most, the slump began long before the Dow Jones industrial average peaked in July. Many of the managers date the decline to the spring, or last year. Since then, many small-company stocks have lost fans, momentum and half or more of their value.
The Montgomery conference, as the event is known, has long served as a coming-out party for young, rapidly growing companies. They are the type of companies whose price-to-earnings ratios are often measured in three digits -- when they have earnings. But this year, the ratios of many of last year's favorite growth stocks more closely resemble hat sizes.
That led to an interesting phenomenon. Gone was Montgomery's slogan, "The Power of Growth." And many of the most crowded sessions were for companies that were anything but traditional growth concerns, staid companies like Bell Atlantic, BellSouth, U S West and SBC Communications.
"We believe we are becoming a growth company," said F. Duane Ackerman, the head of BellSouth, at which Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities expects earnings to grow by 15 percent this year and 13 percent next year -- far below the 30 to 50 percent growth favored by high-octane investors.
Mr. Ackerman maintained, however, that while many of those high growth rates had deflated as quickly as they had grown, BellSouth's earnings were the real thing. "We know there's a difference between virtual profits and real profits," he said.
 But many portfolio managers are little worried these days about definitions. With many of their favorite stocks down 50 percent or more from their highs, they want to know two basics: Are the companies seeing recession signs? And will the next earnings reports fail to meet analysts' estimates?
Several corporate executives unabashedly said no to both questions. Mel Karmazin, president and chief operating officer of CBS, promised that while the company's third quarter would be strong, the fourth quarter looked even stronger. "Did you get that?" Mr. Karmazin demanded. "Even stronger. We don't see anything going on in the economy that is slowing down."
Among portfolio managers, the mood was more reserved and could best be described as one of cautious optimism. But the optimism appeared to grow as the week progressed. "I'm not hearing anybody talk about a recession in their business," said Dave Brady, a portfolio manager at Stein Roe & Farnham, the Chicago mutual fund company. For example, Mr. Brady said, companies like Clear Channel Communications and Outdoor Systems, whose billboard businesses should be among the first places where an economic slowdown would be evident, said they, too, saw no sign of a decline.
CORPORATE executives who did acknowledge seeing a slowdown said it was most likely to affect everyone else. "This is one of the most uncertain and turbulent times many of us have faced in our corporate careers," said Timothy Howard, chief financial officer of the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae. "But Fannie Mae's outlook is very strong in spite of the current business environment."
If a theme resounded among the 250 or so companies that made presentations, it was this: Forget what anyone might have said in the past about being a global company.
"We're not exposed to overseas vagaries," said Henry R. Silverman, president and chief executive of Cendant, a company whose vagaries have been of the domestic accounting variety.
The conference did make one thing clear: There are few creatures lonelier than a chief executive of a growth company abandoned by the madding crowd.
In 1995, the throng greeting Dave Corriveau and Buster Connell, co-founders of the restaurant chain Dave & Buster's, spilled out into the hallway. That year, as the company went public, earnings doubled. This year, with growth at a mere 30 percent, two out of three seats at the company's presentation were empty.
And, clearly, some stocks have fallen to ridiculously low levels. For example, the shares of Wolverine World Wide, maker of Hush Puppies and other famous brands of shoes, are trading for little more than the company's book value, or net worth, down 60 percent from their high in March. But Geoffrey B. Bloom, Wolverine's chief executive, said to the assembled few: "If there is a better company traded on the New York Stock Exchange that's currently trading at eight times earnings, I'd like you to introduce me to the C.E.O."

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
Lured to Enroll, Left To Squirm

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
WITH colleges facing persistent cost increases and a smaller applicant pool, what was once a gentlemanly competition for students has in many cases degenerated into a grim battle for survival -- in which scholarships are negotiated as crassly, and about as reliably, as the sale of used cars.
Taking many forms -- a scholarship, discounted tuition or some other benefit -- financial-aid packages can be dangled before prospective freshmen, and are often key in winning over applicants who might have opted to enroll elsewhere. But what incoming students do not always realize is that these packages can shrink or disappear once a "sale" is made. 
 "Bait and switch often happens once they enroll; there's no question about it," said Norman Smith, president of Wagner College on Staten Island, which he said guarantees its aid in writing for four years.
There are no statistics on how many students have suffered financial-aid shocks. But college administrators and financial aid specialists alike say that in the competition among private colleges and universities for applicants, games are often played with financial aid.
Once a desired applicant, enticed by an aid package, enrolls, it is not at all unusual for that aid to wither. Among the chief targets are those students who have made the most successful transition to college -- and are thus less inclined to transfer.
In general, parents and students are advised to examine closely a school's aid documents. The papers should specify how long aid will continue and, if for less than for four years, the terms for renewal. Cuts in aid can be appealed, but there is seldom full restoration unless the student has an outstanding record or has other leverage, like a connection with wealthy alumni.
Most student aid is based on financial need, as determined by a Federal questionnaire that each institution interprets for itself. And aid can be reduced legitimately for various reasons.
One is a significant improvement in parental financial circumstances, perhaps resulting from a job promotion, a remarriage or the graduation from college of a student's older sibling. Aid can also be cut off after a college catches up with parental misrepresentation or egregious hiding of assets.
Other legitimate reasons for cutbacks include adverse developments on the student's side: poor grades, slow progress toward a degree, alcohol abuse or other bad conduct. In cases involving athletic scholarships, a disabling injury can end the aid.
Some institutions, intentionally or carelessly offering more financial help than they can deliver, find pretexts to curtail it -- for example, by invoking fine print in the contract that requires achieving unrealistically high grades.
"One 'D' in your first semester, and you lose your financial aid" is a frequent ploy, said Patricia O. Ewers, president of Pace University and the chairwoman this year of the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities.
Another, according to Dr. Ewers, is withdrawing a scholarship when a student changes academic direction -- when a science major, say, decides to become an accountant.
She said Pace guaranteed scholarships, but noted that it and other schools generally did not protect against inflation's effects on awards with fixed-dollar amounts.
To be sure, some recipients do not fully understand the terms of their aid packages, which are often tailored to rely progressively less on grants and more on loans as students' ability to borrow improves.
But competitive recruiting also causes such "over-awarding" that a school, well intentioned or not, chooses to back away from some of its obligations. Some colleges have almost gone under because their financial aid offices have cut prices too much for too many.
In recent years, many institutions have revived scholarships and other aid based on merit, rather than need, as they try to lure a cadre of top-ranking students.
Carol Loewith, a private counselor to students and their families in Fairfield, Conn., says she has begun advising them to try to negotiate improved deals when more than one school seems strongly interested. "It's never a done deal," Ms. Loewith, president of the Independent Educational Consultants Association, said she tells them.
A common tactic, according to Dr. Smith of Wagner, is for a school to suddenly "find" some aid over the summer for students who have not yet accepted admission.
"Unsavory things are going on," he said, with many struggling institutions "turning themselves into used-car dealerships."
THE unexpected disappearance of financial aid, it is widely agreed, is confined mainly to second- and third-tier private institutions, including some relatively expensive schools concentrated in the Northeast that compete ferociously for students.
The Ivy League schools, by contrast, are richly endowed and suffer no shortage of top applicants, while state universities enjoy an increasing flood of applicants who see them as such bargains that further financial inducement is ruled out.
"It's the lesser institutions that are doing this, that are baiting and switching," said Leonard Krivy, an educational consultant in Cherry Hill, N.J.
According to David S. Crockett, senior vice president at USA Group Noel Levitz, which consults with colleges on enrollment issues, colleges traditionally dispensed financial aid haphazardly without enough regard to budgetary consequences.
"Now it's becoming more integrated, tied more closely to recruiting," Mr. Crockett said, a process that has led some institutions, which he declined to identify, to offer prospective students aid that is openly acknowledged as one-time-only -- the academic equivalent of a signing bonus.
"We're really opposed to these first-year scholarships," he said. "It seems like enticing them in with it."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Bracing for Mortgage Losses

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Investors are still reeling from the news that trading losses, mostly in emerging markets, will erase a lot of earnings from the books of leading financial services companies in the United States this quarter. Merrill Lynch said it lost $135 million trading bonds in July and August, cutting earnings to one-fourth their level during those months in 1997. Citicorp's losses will slice $200 million from third-quarter profits.
Financial stocks have been trounced on the news. Bankers Trust has fallen to $63.75 from an April high of $136.4375. Lehman Brothers is down 60 percent. 
 Time to bargain-hunt? Or is there another wave of losses out there?
The bad news is, surf's up. Falling interest rates mean fresh problems at banks and brokerage firms in their mortgage lending businesses or trading of mortgage-backed securities. As rates fall, homeowners refinance mortgages. What's good for consumers -- their borrowing costs shrink -- is bad for the institutions that made the higher-rate loans or serviced them. That's because the income and servicing fees on these loans vanish.
Even though mortgage rates have yet to decline sharply, the number of consumers refinancing their mortgages is way up. The Mortgage Bankers Association refinancing index is at double the level seen in May. And the index will skyrocket in coming weeks when mortgage rates really plummet.
How gnarly will the refinancing wave be? Nobody knows. "Mortgage rates have declined to levels not seen in the history of the modern mortgage market," said Bob Kulason, director of the mortgage strategy group at Salomon Smith Barney. Thus, predicting future prepayments is much tougher.
Prepayments are important because finance companies make assumptions about the profitability of a loan based on how long it is likely to stay on the books. If loans get paid down faster than anticipated, the assumptions are wrong and earnings need to be adjusted.
Shareholders in Green Tree Financial learned this the hard way last fall. The company, which makes loans to buyers of manufactured housing, found prepayments on its loans coming in faster than expected. It took a $150 million pretax charge to earnings, and the stock fell 20 percent on the news.
Wall Street firms that trade mortgage-backed securities are also vulnerable to lower rates; those with big mortgage holdings are already behind the eight ball this year. The return on the Lehman Brothers government bond index is 7.89 percent while that of a mortgage-backed securities index is only 5.21 percent. Mortgages typically beat Treasuries' returns by one percentage point.
Making matters worse, many trading houses and hedge funds bought mortgages and hedged the positions by selling Treasuries. As Treasuries rose and mortgages lagged, these investors took a double hit.
And those traders holding interest-only strips, a derivative security that pays out only the interest generated by a pool of mortgages and is not backed by the loan's principal, will find themselves with nothing when homeowners pay off their loans.
Why would a trader want such a security? If rates stayed where they were or rose, the strips would continue to produce income. And since few Wall Street traders believed rates could drop to their current levels -- 5.14 percent on the 30-year bond -- interest-only strips were the thing to own.
When will mortgage problems surface? Not until October or November at the earliest, says Charles Peabody, bank analyst at Mitchell Securities in New York. "The first losses are likely to be housed in hedging strategies," Mr. Peabody said. "Arbitrage losses first, absolute dollar losses later."

HEADLINE: DATABANK: SEPTEMBER 14-18;
In the Stock Market, a Tenuous Recovery

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN 

 BODY:
For most of last week it looked as if storm clouds had lifted, as the stock market began recovering from the mauling it had taken in recent weeks -- even managing to climb for four consecutive days for the first time since June.
Then came Thursday. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 216 points. On Friday, it edged up 21.89 points, to close at 7,895.66. That was especially welcome because Friday was a quarterly triple-witching day, when stock futures, stock options and stock index futures all expire, often setting off wild swings. For the week, the Dow was up 100.16 -- still 12 points below where it opened the year, and 15.4 percent below its peak of 9,337.97, set on July 17. 
 The market was buoyed on Monday after President Clinton, in a speech in New York, advocated a coordinated global policy for economic growth. But on Wednesday, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said in Congressional testimony, "I think I can safely say at the moment there is no endeavor to coordinate interest rate cuts" among the world's big economies. Thursday's tumble ensued. JAN M. ROSEN

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3029 words

HEADLINE: Loving A Stock, Not Wisely But Too Well

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
THE tip arrived at the rustic New Hampshire farmhouse of George A. Schrader Jr. in a large manila envelope, postmarked Boston and stuffed with the hopeful prospect of future riches.
The contents told of a promising young drug company called Seragen Inc., which was developing a new class of drugs that scientists believed might someday be a "magic bullet" in the fight against cancer. Seragen had good science, even great science, the papers in the envelope indicated, and Wall Street analysts predicted that with Food and Drug Administration approval, it would quickly become a biotechnology superstar. 
 Mr. Schrader decided to buy about $6,000 in shares of Seragen in that summer of 1992. A retired professor of philosophy, he did not know much about biology or the stock market. But he knew the man who had sent him the envelope -- John R. Silber, then the president of Boston University, who had been a brilliant student of Mr. Schrader's at Yale 30 years before.
Combative and charismatic, Mr. Silber was a true believer in Seragen and its drugs, and for a decade he was the company's most ardent salesman. He persuaded scores of associates, friends, and family members to buy in: his brother, sister-in-law and niece, and friends on the faculty. His secretary plowed in more than $10,000.
At Mr. Silber's behest, the university poured tens of millions into Seragen, a sum that grew even in the face of a formal rebuke from state regulators that the stake was too risky for a nonprofit endowment.
Mr. Silber himself sank $1.7 million, close to half his net worth, into Seragen in the early 1990's. And when his son was dying of AIDS, Mr. Silber saw to it that he was treated with Interleukin-2, the company's experimental drug.
To Mr. Silber, Seragen was not just the purveyor of a magic bullet against disease; it was also the cure for Boston University's chronic financial needs -- the wonder drug that would propel the university's modest endowment into Ivy League ranks and, maybe, win a Nobel Prize for one of its faculty members. He delved into the company's complex science much as he had immersed himself, as a philosophy student, in the ethics of Immanuel Kant.
But as with so many infatuations, this one came to an ugly end.
An F.D.A. advisory panel recommended approval of Interleukin-2 this year -- but not before Seragen, based in Hopkinton, Mass., ran out of money.
The stock collapsed, and the company, flirting with bankruptcy, was sold in August for a pittance. Boston University's stake today is worth just $8.4 million. Mr. Silber's holdings, which had grown to $2 million, are valued now at $43,000. Some investors did better, depending on when they bought in and whether they got out before the crash. By the time Mr. Schrader died in May, his investment had all but evaporated.
In the wake of the debacle, the finger-pointing has grown heated. Some shareholders have sued Seragen and Boston University, among others, contending that in the scramble to keep Seragen afloat, the university -- which took a controlling interest of the company in 1987 -- engaged in "sweetheart deals" and "self-dealing" that benefited the university while whipsawing the share price and ultimately undermining Seragen's prospects.
The collapse has also served as an opportunity for Mr. Silber's critics to resurrect accusations that he was blind to conflicts of interest arising from Seragen, including his and the university's financial dealings with trustees who both oversaw the university's investments in Seragen and invested in the company themselves.
Mr. Silber saw no conflict of interest. "I advocated that the trustees invest in Seragen, and I put my poke in Seragen," he said. "I think it would have been hypocritical if I said, 'You invest, but I won't.' "
He was, after all, in pursuit of what every investor wants: a huge score. He just happened to pick one of the toughest ways to make it.
"Biotech is a graveyard," said Mark Simon, an analyst at BancBoston Robertson Stephens. "This is a very risky area. It's like wildcatting, oil drilling. But when you hit a well, it can be very huge."
 
The Beginnings
John Silber likes to say that he has always been a risk taker. In 1971, he took a risk on Boston University, a school that he considered nearly bankrupt, academically and financially, and transformed it into a bastion of excellence. He hired what he termed a "murderer's row" of top scholars, bolstered the university's finances and gained notoriety as one of the nation's highest-paid college presidents, with compensation of more than $500,000 a year. In 1996, he was named chancellor.
The Texas-born Mr. Silber, a former professor of philosophy, has been called brilliant, arrogant, charming and elitist. Friends and critics agree he is direct.
He first became interested in Seragen in 1986, when Dr. John R. Murphy, a professor at the university, gave a talk about his discovery of "fusion toxins," genetically re-engineered proteins that acted as guided missiles, aiming at diseased cells and injecting them with a protein-destroying chemical. Dr. Murphy had helped found Seragen, with other Boston-area scientists, and his experimental drug, Interleukin-2, was later licensed to the company.
"I remember him coming up to me after the talk, and he was very interested in the nature of the science and the potential the science had," Dr. Murphy said, recalling his first discussion of Interleukin-2 with Mr. Silber. "He was very excited."
The next year, when a Norwegian pharmaceutical company decided to divest itself of its majority interest in Seragen, the university's trustees, at Mr. Silber's urging, bought the stake for $25 million. He was not about to repeat the mistake Boston University made at the turn of the century, when Alexander Graham Bell invented the telephone -- while on leave from the school.
"If we had just 5 percent of what eventually became Bell Telephone," Mr. Silber said recently, "we would be richer than Harvard today."
Critics at the university, however, questioned the Seragen investment almost immediately. Michael Manove, a professor of economics, complained that the school was putting "too many eggs in one basket." The school's total endowment at the time was valued at $175 million.
More serious questions arose when Mr. Silber, a conservative Democrat, ran for Governor of Massachusetts in 1990.
William Weld, his Republican opponent, accused him of personally profiting from the university's sale of a Seragen unit in 1989. Mr. Silber denied owning stock in the unit, but in 1993, long after Mr. Silber lost the election, the state Attorney General's office -- which regulates nonprofit institutions -- concluded that he indeed had received $386,700 from the sale. At that point, Mr. Silber said he had returned the payment as soon as he recognized that it was improper. Investigators determined that Mr. Silber had not broken any laws.
The investigation into Mr. Silber was part of a criminal inquiry, the Attorney General said, which was begun after his office received "credible evidence" that Mr. Silber had received a payment that he had denied receiving in public statements. Meanwhile, a separate civil inquiry examined the university's governance and its large stake in Seragen.
In 1992, the university signed an agreement with the Attorney General's office pledging to "significantly reduce" its financial exposure in Seragen. To spread the risk, an initial public offering was planned.
 
A True Believer
None of the criticism dampened Mr. Silber's enthusiasm for Seragen. He was enamored with the company and its technology -- in part because of the story of a Hingham, Mass., man named Bill Smith.
Mr. Smith had cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, a form of cancer that quickly covered his body with lesions. Chemotherapy had failed, and in January 1990, when he was 60, he was told that he did not have much time left. Mr. Smith was given a dose of Interleukin-2, then in the early stages of its clinical trials, and soon after, his cancer went into remission.
"They gave me six months to live, and I'm still here," Mr. Smith said in a recent interview. "It's a miracle."
His account, videotaped for Seragen, became a centerpiece in Mr. Silber's personal campaign to spread the word about the company. Although Mr. Silber says he never "touted" Seragen's stock, he did encourage people in his vast circle to invest once the company went public in April 1992, at $12 a share. Seragen, he would tell potential investors, was where his money was riding.
"Because he believed in it, and because he's an intelligent and persuasive person, I bought it," said Walter Lubars, a longtime professor of public relations at Boston University who bought about $30,000 worth. "I was getting ready to retire, and he convinced me, in '92, '93, '94, that by '97, Seragen would be at $64."
There was never any doubt about Mr. Silber's commitment -- or compassion. In 1991, he wrote to Roger Shattuck, a longtime friend who was a professor of modern languages at the university, that Seragen was developing a molecule that might offer a treatment for Mr. Shattuck's 40-year-old daughter Tari, a teacher, who was suffering from CML leukemia. Mr. Shattuck eventually invested in the company, but Interleukin-2 proved irrelevant to his daughter's disease; she died in April 1993.
A year later, Mr. Silber arranged for his 41-year-old son, David, an actor infected with H.I.V., to be treated with the drug. "Seragen is really our only hope, because the doctors agree that the other chemo is only slowing it down but cannot stop it," Mr. Silber wrote to a friend. "David is now in that difficult process for a young person of coming to terms with the fact that he is very likely to die within the next few months."
Actually, he died a month later.
 
A Flurry of Deals
Mr. Silber's enthusiasm could not disguise the difficulties Seragen was facing. The company raised $52 million through public stock sales in 1992 and 1993, but like so many young biotechnology companies, its cash needs were voracious.
In 1996, with F.D.A. approval of Interleukin-2 still just a dream, Seragen lost $26.3 million, pushing its cumulative losses to $200 million. The stock, which had reached a high of $15 in January 1993, ended 1996 at just over $1 a share. By then, Dr. Murphy, the father of Interleukin-2, had severed his ties to Seragen. Though his faith in the drug was undiminished, "it was clear," he said, "that the problems were business problems."
As tireless as he had been in promoting the public stock offerings, Mr. Silber worked just as hard to bring desperately needed money into the company when sales of common stock were no longer feasible.
There was a flurry of deals. In November 1995, Mr. Silber orchestrated a bailout of sorts that brought in $23.8 million through a loan backed by the university and two affiliated investors: Leon C. Hirsch, the chairman of the United States Surgical Corporation, who is also a university trustee, and Gerald S. J. Cassidy, the university's Washington lobbyist. The loans were later converted into preferred stock.
In September, the university, which had periodically poured new money into Seragen, invested an additional $5 million through a private placement of stock, bringing its stake to $84 million. (The state, which had directed Boston University four years earlier to reduce its holdings in Seragen, did not object, because with the overall growth of the school's endowment to $470 million, its relative exposure to the drug company's stock had diminished, said Richard C. Allen, head of the public charities division of the state Attorney General's office.)
In December, Seragen's board -- which included Mr. Silber, Mr. Cassidy and Kenneth Condon, the university's treasurer -- voted to raise the number of authorized shares in the company to 70 million from 30 million. It was an act of desperation that would dilute the value of existing investors' holdings.
Indeed, a small group of investors began complaining about the company's issuing what they termed "exploding puts": preferred shares or options with conversion features that could result in virtually unlimited dilution if the share price fell -- as, indeed, it did.
The struggle to raise cash continued into 1997, but there were no more deep pockets for Mr. Silber to plumb. In February, Seragen sold its manufacturing operation to the university for $5 million. The school leased services back to Seragen.
 
Questions of Conflicts
Deals like that one, critics said, indicated that Mr. Silber and the university had crossed the lines of propriety in their struggle to keep Seragen afloat.
Some investors complained that key backers of Seragen had conflicting allegiances. Mr. Silber and Mr. Hirsch, for instance, were trustees of the university, directors of U.S. Surgical and large shareholders of Seragen. Among other transactions, U.S. Surgical paid $5 million in July 1997 for the worldwide rights to one of Seragen's drugs, a deal that also gave U.S. Surgical warrants to buy 500,000 Seragen shares.
Mr. Silber owns 22,000 shares of U.S. Surgical, worth around $900,000. He has also been designated a director in Mr. Cassidy's lobbying firm, when it goes public.
Disturbed by what they said was the appearance of a conflict of interest, a group of U.S. Surgical investors called in May of this year for a vote to remove Mr. Silber from the company's compensation committee, citing an "inter-locking directorate relationship" with Mr. Hirsch and the men's business ties.
As Seragen collapsed, shareholders outside its inner circle also began to look askance at the blur of transactions. In August, an angry group of investors filed a lawsuit in Delaware contending that the interests of minority shareholders were damaged by Mr. Silber, the university and its associates, including Mr. Cassidy and Mr. Hirsch. The suit says they engaged in "sweetheart deals" and "self-dealing."
Mr. Cassidy and Mr. Hirsch declined to be interviewed.
Thomas G. Griffin, a lawyer for the shareholder group, said the "self-dealing" included the $23.8 million bailout of Seragen in 1995. The ties between the various parties, he said, obscured lines of fiduciary duty. "Boston University and Silber are controlling Seragen and saying, 'You're going to do this deal with B.U.,' " he said. "So they are both buyer and seller; they have these arrangements with themselves."
But R. Robert Popeo, a lawyer for the university who earlier represented Seragen, denied that the university or Mr. Silber were involved in any self-dealing or conflicts of interest. He said that his office had drawn up strict conflict guidelines that were closely followed and that Mr. Silber and other university officials did not participate in votes when there were deemed to be conflicts. At times, though, he said Mr. Silber and others -- including himself -- switched from representing the university to representing Seragen's interest. "Dual representation doesn't mean a conflict of interest," he said.
Nor were there "sweetheart" deals, he added; rather than damaging the company, he said, the university saved it from early bankruptcy.
"Seragen would have been out of business had it not been for the university, Hirsch and Cassidy," Mr. Popeo said. "Pick up a phone and call Salomon or Lehman and they'll tell you for $23 million they could have demanded 40 percent of the company."
Often, of course, conflicts are a matter of perception. "What is improper about an officer of the university having business dealings with trustees?" Mr. Silber asked during an interview last week. "Far from being a conflict of interest, it is clearly in the interest of the university to establish such business dealings."
 
The Denouement
Even now, Mr. Silber's faith in Interleukin-2 has not faltered. "The fact is, I was right about Seragen's science," he said defiantly in a recent interview. "For over 10 years, we've had good results."
In June 1998, an F.D.A. advisory panel recommended approval for the use of Interleukin-2 in the treatment of lymphoma. On final approval, the drug, known commercially as Ontak, may live up to the promise that Mr. Silber imagined for it when he heard Dr. Murphy's speech 12 years ago.
But Seragen, and Boston University, will not reap much of the benefit. Out of money and delisted from the Nasdaq stock market, Seragen was acquired in August by Ligand Pharmaceuticals Inc., a San Diego company whose shares promptly tumbled when the deal was announced. Ligand paid $30 million for Seragen, now a wholly owned subsidiary, and will pay an additional $37 million if Ontak gets a final Government O.K.
To the university, that represented a loss of 90 percent on its investment during a time when so many others were soaring. For just the $50 million that the school had put into Seragen as of 1989, it could have $175 million today had it instead put the money into a mutual fund that tracked the Standard & Poor's 500.
The cry among critics all along was that Mr. Silber just could not let go. They said the university refused to give up its majority stake in Seragen, making financing difficult.
Mr. Silber says that if the state had not restricted the university from investing more heavily, Seragen would have flourished. "Seragen has not fallen and Seragen has not failed," Mr. Silber said. "You want to talk about the rise and fall of Seragen's stock? Fine." Regulators say they saved the univeristy from losing millions more.
Mr. Silber's hope, now, is in Ligand, which may eventually bring Ontak to the market. What remains of his and the university's Seragen stakes have become Ligand shares.
Mr. Silber's friends must hope now, too. Despite their losses, few have soured on John Silber -- and some look on with sympathy.
"I feel sorry in a way for John, because he wanted to leave as a legacy a gigantic endowment," said Mr. Lubars, the retired professor who bought into Seragen on Mr. Silber's tip. "And I hope people don't think he's dumped Seragen on us, because he's done so many good things for the university."

Like so many other biotechnology companies, Seragen, of Hopkinton, Mass., had more promise than financial wherewithal. Even the persistence of John R. Silber, Boston University's chancellor and the company's biggest booster, could not keep it alive.
 
DRUG DEVELOPMENT
1982 -- Dr. John R. Murphy of Harvard University seeks a patent on the Interleukin-2 fusion protein toxin, a genetically engineered chemical that may lead to a new class of cancer-fighting drugs.
 
1984 -- Dr. Murphy joins the Boston University medical faculty and continues his research.
 
1989 -- Human trials begin on Interleukin-2.
 
FINANCES AND GOVERNANCE
 
1979 -- Seragen is founded by Boston-area medical researchers.
 
1980-85 -- Boston University puts $1.2 million into Seragen through its venture capital fund.
 
1987 -- Boston University buys a majority interest in Seragen for $25 million. Ten university trustees invest in the company.
 
1989 -- The university begins spending about $1.1 million a month to finance Seragen's operations.
 
1990 -- Questions about investments in Seragen arise during Mr. Silber's failed campaign for Massachusetts Governor.
 
January 1992 -- The university tells regulators that it will significantly reduce its stake in Seragen.
 
April 1992 -- Seragen goes public at $12 a share, raising about $36 million.
 
1992-93 -- Mr. Silber invests about $1.7 million of his own money in Seragen.
 
1993 -- The university agrees to follow new conflict-of- interest rules regarding financial disclosure and business relations with trustees.
 
1994 -- Seragen signs a development and marketing agreement with Eli Lilly & Company.
Mr. Silber's son David, terminally ill with AIDS, is treated with Interleukin-2. He dies in December.
 
1995 -- Seragen begins drawing down a $23.8 million loan from Boston University; Leon C. Hirsch, a university trustee, and Gerald S.J. Cassidy, the university's Washington lobbyist.
 
May 1996 -- An overseas offering of discounted shares raises $3.8 million from Paul Reichmann, the Canadian financier.
 
December 1996 -- Seragen directors vote to raise the number of shares to 70 million from 30 million, diluting the value of investors' holdings. Losses for the year total $26.3 million.
 
June 1998 -- A Food and Drug Administration advisory panel recommends approval of Seragen's fusion protein toxin, now called Ontak, for use in treating lymphoma.
 
July 1998 -- Ligand Pharmaceuticals of San Diego says it will acquire Seragen for $30 million, plus $37 million more if Ontak receives final Government approval.
 
August 1998 -- A shareholder lawsuit accuses the university, Mr. Silber and other Seragen officials of self-dealing. They deny the contention.
 
August 14 -- Seragen is delisted by Nasdaq. The stock closes at 45 cents a share.
