HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Newfangled Econ 101: Throw Caution to the Winds

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
THE Japanese are well versed in the art of fending off American accusations, including the perpetual hyperventilating over Japan's protectionist trade policies. But nothing from the past could have prepared the Japanese for the latest salvo by several prominent American economists who say the Japanese Government has been insufficiently reckless.
By running an overly tight monetary policy, these economists say, and by driving down inflation, the Government has inadvertently contributed to a downward spiral of prices and production that has cost the Japanese nearly a decade of growth and added to economic turmoil throughout the region and beyond. 
 To make amends, the Government must now "credibly promise to be irresponsible," says Paul Krugman, a professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. By that he means the central bank should embark on a crash program of printing yen -- creating not only inflation today, but also the expectation of inflation tomorrow and an indefinite number of tomorrows into the future.

Radical Advice
Faced with a financial crisis that has swept from Asia to Russia to Latin America, President Clinton and finance officials from the major industrialized powers suggested last week a concerted effort to emphasize growth over inflation fighting, presumably by cutting interest rates. These officials do not want to spur inflation, though it might be an unintended consequence of fighting off recession with looser monetary policies.
Mr. Krugman, by contrast, embraces inflation as an economic cure for Japan's maladies. And at a moment when a quarter of the world's population is living through recession or worse, there is good reason to focus on Japan. Solving the growing financial crisis in Latin America requires resolving economic chaos in Asia. And to solve Asia's problems requires re-establishing Japan as an engine of regional growth.
Mr. Krugman's puckish prescription sounds wacky enough to Western ears, but to the decorous, orderly Japanese, it probably sounds quite mad. Prof. Koiche Hamada of Yale University giggled when asked to contemplate how Mr. Krugman's formula would be received by most of the officials who run Japan's central bank.
But as Mr. Krugman points out, Japan's desperate plight cries out for unorthodox solutions. And there are signs that his ideas are making inroads: A prominent Japanese lawmaker recently embraced the notion of setting an inflation target.
Let's step back. The Japanese economy, whose rapid and noninflationary growth was the envy of the world in the 1970's and 80's, has fallen into dire straits. Industrial production has stagnated for the entire decade. Wholesale prices have fallen over the past five years, an improbably long time for prices to drop in industrialized economies. Land values have crashed, undermining the solvency of banks whose loans are tied to real estate. Stock prices have also plunged.
Deflation can be just as economically corrosive as inflation. Falling prices create an expectation of future decline, which compels consumers and investors to postpone spending, setting off a self-sustaining downward spiral of production, income, spending and prices.
So what should Japan do? There are any number of ideas, but these are the four usual suspects.
*Japan could close down its insolvent banks and bail out the others. Only then will the normal interplay between lenders and borrowers resume. A plan along these lines was announced last week. However, such restructuring takes time and provides only a partial solution.
The Government could try to spend its way out of recession by investing lavishly in infrastructure projects. But the Government has an unenviable record of building roads and bridges that go nowhere important, tailoring projects more to the needs of political cronies than to the economy. And this, too, is only a partial answer.
*Japan could cut taxes to boost spending. But the nation is aging quickly, and the Federal deficit will balloon as the elderly retire and draw pensions. So a tax cut today will have to be offset by a tax hike in the future. Japanese taxpayers know this and can be expected to prepare for the eventual hike by stashing money they temporarily save on taxes into their bank accounts instead of spending on consumer goods.

Start the Presses
The most popular way to stimulate spending -- cutting interest rates -- is impossible in Japan, because their rates are already within an eyelash of zero. The rate controlled by the central bank is already down to 0.25 percent, yet there has been no spending splurge.
Enter Mr. Krugman. He urges the central bank to drop its traditional mission of price stability and instead start printing however many yen it takes to generate lasting inflation. The goal is to turn expectations of deflation into their opposite, scaring people into buying goods now before they become more expensive. This pro-inflation policy would also spur investment by companies that could borrow yen that they know will be worth less by the time they have to repay their creditors.
Prof. Allan Meltzer of Carnegie Mellon University urges the Bank of Japan to pour out however much money it takes to stop prices from falling, a less extreme goal than Mr. Krugman's. Prof. Frederic Mishkin of Columbia University also wants to step on the monetary pedal, arguing that people would use the newly printed yen to buy land and other assets, thereby halting the slide in prices. He also says increasing the number of yen would drive down its value on foreign exchange markets and thereby boost exports.
These economists offer bold ideas. But, as Mr. Krugman says admiringly of his proposals, "Faced with a novel kind of economic malaise, the results of hard thinking deserve to be taken seriously."

HEADLINE: The Nation: Shadow Play -- Washington's Gears, Grinding;
Behind the Scenes, There Are No Wise Men Anymore

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHEN Speaker Newt Gingrich was hitting rock bottom in facing the House's ethics reprimand last year, he resorted to a time-honored insider technique: He reached out privately to one of the capital's political "wise men" -- to an elder of the rival Democrats known to offer stricken combatants confidential advice beyond the bounds of partisanship.
"I got Gingrich together with Bob Strauss," recalled Vin Weber, a Republican ex-Congressman from Minnesota who, working the subtler ways of politics, arranged for the Speaker to break bread with Mr. Strauss, a syrup-smooth, battle-scarred sage from the Carter era who offered a recovery prescription of sorts. 
 Similarly, Mr. Strauss, who has ranged over the years from Democratic Party chairman to ambassadorial missions, was privately called to the White House for advice in President Ronald Reagan's confrontation with Congress over the Iran-contra affair. He was also summoned to join President George Bush's private gathering of wise men, if only for reasons of bipartisan ritual, as the invasion of Iraq loomed. So, then, with President Clinton now passing through the political valley of darkness, surely he must be calling on Mr. Strauss or some such capital elder to help find the best way out for both himself and the nation, right?
Mr. Weber, who is very close to Mr. Strauss, thinks not. "I hate to say it, but I wonder if this President has ever been willing to listen to that sort of adviser," he said. When in extremis in the Lewinsky sex scandal, Mr. Clinton has most notably turned for advice to Harry Thomason, a figure from the world of television entertainment. Late, great Democratic elders ranging from Ambassador W. Averell Harriman to Mayor Richard J. Daley could only have been whirring in their graves.
Many Democrats, even as they wish for the half-measure solution of a Brahmin-brokered censure of Mr. Clinton, sadly agree that the time may have long since passed for summoning any of the Beltway's fabled wise men. This is the informal cadre of emeritus politicians and lawyers (historically, it's been a clubby men's preserve) who occasionally drop by the city's floating political crap game at critical moments, in between using their influence on behalf of paying clients, to lend it some class and even a touch of realism. The notion of a Republican wise man daring to approach the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr early on with a plea about the national interest amuses Democrats, who note that the special prosecutor law gives free rein to Mr. Starr -- and that his circle of party patrons features such anti-Clintonites as Senator Lauch Faircloth of North Carolina. Right now, the President's overheated scandal of sex and mendacity seems to be rattling down the Congressional tracks toward a formal impeachment inquiry.
"It's a different world in every way," said George Stephanopoulos, once one of President Clinton's strategists and now one of his unyielding media critics. "This wouldn't have happened in the 'wise men' days; they would have caught it before it got out," he said, finding the predicament rooted not merely in Mr. Clinton's gross excesses, but also in the demise of political parties with their elders offering deep experience. This is a change brought about by modern politicians like Mr. Clinton, driven by focus groups and personal fund-raising, attracted more to short-run strategy wizards like Dick Morris than to venerable mandarins. "Having wise men is connected to the idea that we have real parties," said Mr. Stephanopolous. "But if everybody is elected on his own, everybody lives or dies on his own."

Sages on Call
The "wise men" approach faded during the Vietnam War, when left and right exploited the anti-establishment backlash against government by "the best and the brightest." Right now, the need of the President if not the nation for a bipartisan stretcher team has rarely seemed clearer on Capitol Hill, where the impeachment scandal is threatening to become a serial pageant about the sex lives of the incumbent and righteous. Last week an adulterous affair from three decades ago suddenly surfaced about the avuncular Henry J. Hyde, the Congressman saddled with running the Clinton inquiry, who had been universally lauded as a dispassionate model of fairness. Rumors of further carnal outings of Republicans shook their ranks even as they voted on partisan lines Friday to release the videotape of President Clinton's grand-jury testimony.
At critical moments in administrations past, Presidents always had wise men at their beck and call. Lyndon B. Johnson had Clark Clifford, and even Jimmy Carter was not alone as he quietly relied on an Atlanta outsider, Charles Kirbo, to offer a Presidential reality check. Dwight D. Eisenhower charged his younger brother, Milton, an academic, with all manner of furtive oversight. But Mr. Clinton's chief confidential adviser, his wife, is now handicapped by having to share the strain the scandal has imposed on their marriage.
"Clinton is a President who shows no sign, throughout his career, of relying on paternal senior figures," said Michael R. Beschloss, a Presidential historian. "And there hasn't been a situation of a President being in a mess quite like this. The wheel is being invented on this one." Mr. Beschloss wondered whether this grave if lubricious crisis might stump even Chance the gardener, the surreal wise man of the satirical film "Being There." Chance's horticultural platitudes were taken as metaphorical wisdom by a crisis-ridden President. ("As long as the roots are not severed, all is well, and all will be well in the garden.")

The Good Old Days
Lloyd Cutler, the veteran lawyer who has served in the Carter and Clinton White Houses, has the silver-haired elan of a classic Washington elder. But he speaks of wise men more in nostalgia than as a promising dynamic in the current predicament. "Back in the days when we were more bipartisan in this city, we used the 'wise men' approach quite often, especially in foreign affairs," he said. "But impeachment is highly partisan in its nature, and it's very difficult to organize on a bipartisan basis." In Watergate, the approach was possible only after the prospect of removal from office became a certainty for Richard M. Nixon.
Some optimists talk of a wise-man bank shot: brokering a bipartisan compromise of censure by rallying nonpartisan sages and having them spark popular concern with a concerted warning that only a strong President will be able to deal with the economic crises sweeping the world. But one elder, wise enough to remain anonymous, despairs of even this. "The truth of the matter is Clinton just goes through the motions and doesn't appreciate the wise-men possibilities," this veteran summarized. "And the Republicans right now are mainly interested in milking their advantage through election day."
Clinton critics question whether a President who never courted wise men could turn now to such figures as former Senators Howard W. Baker Jr. or Sam Nunn. "George Mitchell is reported to have turned down the President's offer to become his wise man," said Tony Blankley, the conservative polemicist at George magazine, who rates the former Senator from Maine as Washington's truly wise man in declining to take up the President's folly. "Certain events can't be undone," Mr. Blankley said. "To avoid a bad news cycle, Clinton certainly has destroyed a Presidency and perhaps truncated it. This is no longer about the President; it's about the American people."
In one way, the White House agrees. President Clinton, clinging to job approval ratings of 60 percent, is counting on the public to eventually prevail as the truly wise one in the crisis, able to force a compromise on combative Republicans. "Life is a state of mind," as the tale of Chance the Presidential wise man concluded about Washington.

HEADLINE: The World;
China's Fine Art: Linguistic Survival

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH the world has focused its attention on the one-sided battle between the Chinese Communist Government and the political dissidents who press for radical change, there is also a large population here of intellectuals, many of them scholars or former officials, who work openly to nudge the system in a more democratic direction.
These people, known as liberals, borrow a term from ping pong to describe their strategy for stretching the bounds of political debate. They speak of hitting a "touch-ball" -- one that just grazes the edge of the table. 
 A risky hit, yet one that scores.
In this metaphor, the ping-pong table stands for the ideologically correct thoughts of the moment. Impatient progressives, as they write and speak, try to incorporate as much of the day's official jargon and ideas as they believe, or can stomach, while probing as far as they dare on issues like free speech, rule of law and political pluralism.
One problem is that the size of the table is constantly changing, and such people spend enormous amounts of time monitoring official talk and watching the experience of colleagues to figure out just where the limits are at any moment.
"If you hit it just right, then you can get away with saying something new or provocative," said a Beijing law professor. "If you miss the table, you lose."
"Lose" might mean anything from a reprimand at work to forced retirement, with a de facto ban on publication. Or the writer could descend into the ranks of the "dissidents," who are harassed and detained by police.
For the most part, the liberal scholars and officials are not to be confused with the beleaguered democracy dissidents, who push more directly, persistently and actively for radical change. The liberals hope instead that their more academic discourse will plant the seeds of a more open system.
Because every camp, from Communist leaders to dissidents, uses terms like democracy and the rule of law, it can be hard to tell who really stands for what.

Serious Hairsplitting
But in China, where ideas drove a revolution and words can bring jail, people are exquisitely attuned to linguistic cues. What might seem verbal hairsplitting in America is taken here with utmost seriousness.
In today's parlance, for example, the need for "political structural reform" is voiced by Communist leaders, starting with the Communist Party chief and President, Jiang Zemin. This seems to mean things like improving government efficiency, ending corruption and better enforcing party-dictated laws. Those with more Western notions of democracy often leave out the word "structural," and talk of "political reform."
The party's definition of democracy seems, again, to focus on improving "oversight" and "supervision" of bureacrats, to make sure they honestly carry out Beijing's edicts. (Genuine direct elections are limited to administrative jobs in villages.)
Thus at the Communist Party Congress last fall, President Jiang could declare, according to the official English translation, "We should promote democracy, improve the legal system and build a socialist country ruled by law," even as he reaffirmed the Four Cardinal Principles that the late Deng Xiaoping issued in 1979: keeping to the socialist road, upholding the dictatorship of the proletariat, upholding the leadership of the Communist Party and upholding Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought.
President Jiang's reference to a "country ruled by law" in that speech last fall caused no end of analysis among the cognoscenti, because of the particular Chinese characters used in the official transcript.
Communist leaders, and emperors before them, had long used one term to call for what is often translated as "rule by law" or "a strengthening of the legal system." This term is taken to mean improving the use of law and institutional channels to carry out party rule -- an improvement over the highly personal rule of the past, but hardly Western democracy.
More recently, liberals have used another term -- which sounds the same in spoken Mandarin but is written with a different character; this one is often translated as "rule of law," meaning that the entire nation, including the party, is governed under the law.
In a recent essay, Li Shenzhi -- a former vice president of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences who was sacked for not supporting the 1989 crackdown on student demonstrations -- writes that there is a big difference: Under "rule of law," he says, "no one is above the law or exempted by it." Not even a party chief.

What's That He Said?
So heads turned when the official written Chinese version of Mr. Jiang's speech used that second formulation. Was President Jiang floating a serious change in attitude? Or was his speechwriter merely toying with the country's intellectuals?
Mr. Li's essay appears in a recent book, "Political China: Facing the Era of Choosing a New Structure" (China Today Publishing House), in which Mr. Li shows himself to be an aggressive touch-ball player. At one point, he writes that China "should quickly adopt the common concept of the world: 'Human rights are civil rights.' "
The book, which includes articles by scholars and former officials, exemplifies the touch-ball approach. The clear intent is to foster discussion of serious change. Yet facing the title page is an artfully selected quotation from Mr. Deng, whose vaguest utterances, now elevated to the level of theory, are used by Mr. Jiang to legitimize his program. The quote reads, "If you only carry out economic system reform and not political system reform, then economic system reform will not work." It continues, "Whether all of our reforms ultimately succeed is dependent on political system reform."
The apparent homage may signal that the book is not intended to challenge the system brazenly in the manner of an impudent dissident like the exiled Wei Jingsheng. Nor does the book ever include words like "multiparty politics" or "direct election of national leaders." Aiming that far off the table would have guaranteed that the book would be banned.
The book prudently includes a spectrum of views, including an essay by a close adviser to President Jiang, Wang Huning. He calls for "political structural reform" in order to build a "socialist political system with Chinese characteristics" -- under the party's leadership. That, of course, lands well in the middle of the ping-pong table.
A spray of touch-balls, in contrast, comes from Liu Junning, a political scientist at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences who prefers exploring "liberal democracy" to "people's democracy." In one essay, "The Market Economy and Limited Government," he writes, "Individual property rights and a free market economy will not automatically lead to democracy, but without property rights and markets, it's absolutely impossible to have democracy." He also writes, "Guaranteeing property rights not only needs democracy, it also needs constitutional government and rule of law."
But many liberals find it puzzling and frightening that the authorities recently arrested one of the two journalists who were the book's editors. Shi Binhai, a senior editor of The China Economic Times, was detained on Sept. 5 by state security agents who gave his family no reason. Mr. Shi's associates say they do not believe his involvement with the book, which continues to sell in Chinese bookstores, was the reason. Apparently it was through some other, undisclosed, activity that Mr. Shi missed the edge of the table.

HEADLINE: The Nation: Shadow Play -- Washington's Gears, Grinding;
Surprise: Government's Not Necessarily Paralyzed

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
GIVEN the sheer volume of energy expended in weighing President Clinton's fate, given Washington's horrified fascination with every tawdry detail of his behavior, it would be easy to assume that the machinery of government and policy making has ground to a halt.
But on Capitol Hill last week, the Republican-controlled Congress began consideration of a tax cut, renewed its efforts to limit some late-term abortions, started wrapping up the spending bills needed to keep the Federal Government operating and pushed ahead with an overhaul of the bankruptcy system. 
 Hobbled though he may be, President Clinton set in motion an international effort to contain the financial crisis that began last year in Asia, considered a plea from the Pentagon for more money, received a report from his advisory commission on race and directed that the Government purchase only recycled paper.
It was hardly business as usual, and the effect of Mr. Clinton's woes on Washington will only grow with each Congressional move toward impeachment. At risk in particular are efforts to set the nation's course on big, evolving issues that require strong Presidential leadership, like shoring up Social Security or dealing decisively with ethnic conflicts and terrorism. Already, some Administration officials admit that it is all but impossible to get the attention of the President or top White House staff, boding ill for any policy initiatives working their way up the chain of command.
But the Federal Government has tremendous momentum, and even in times of war and political crisis it has a way of grinding relentlessly on. Moreover, the very threat of drift and paralysis in this case has provided both parties with tremendous incentive to keep pushing a substantive agenda -- maybe even to push harder than they would otherwise.
Republicans, confronting an electorate impatient with rabidly partisan politics and uncertain about how Mr. Clinton's transgressions should be punished, are hedging their bets; even as they turn up the heat on the President, they are taking every opportunity to tout their social and economic initiatives and their focus on the people's business.
 
Pressing Ahead

 Eager as well to probe for weakened resolve and cohesion among Democrats, Republicans have also decided to see what happens if they press on issues they had earlier given up on, most notably a tax cut this year.
For his part, Mr. Clinton said he should not be "trying to obscure my own personal acknowledgment and chagrin about what I did wrong." But it does not take a "Wag the Dog" scenario for a President to change the subject, as Mr. Clinton well knows, and last week he was clearly taking the opportunity to do so.
Halting the spread of the Asian financial crisis, he said, "is about the most important issue facing the world community." The Republican plan to finance tax cuts by dipping into projected budget surpluses could endanger the nation's fiscal health and undermine efforts to shore up the Social Security system, he said, fairly spoiling for an ideological, pre-election fight that could help unify his demoralized party.
Yet for Mr. Clinton, the situation creates a paradox. The more he talks about issues, the greater the sense that he is deliberately diverting attention from his own problems. Even pressing matters, like striking back at terrorists or protecting the nation's long economic expansion, can seem props in his personal drama.
Many people in Washington remember going down this route before. Consumed by Watergate in 1974, the nation floundered in many ways, not least in addressing the economic turmoil set off by the Arab oil embargo. Congress nonetheless found time to raise the minimum wage, limit school busing and establish Federal financing of election campaigns.
"At the time I was astounded at the resiliency both of the Government and of the people," said Bill Frenzel, who was a second-term Republican Congressman from Minnesota in 1974 and served in the House until 1990.
"The Government did not fall down, and actually most decisions that people could see and feel were made and the Government went right on operating and doing a reasonable job of it," he said. "I would say it's going to be similar this time. That is, we're at risk of falling behind in foreign policy, trade and security, but the things that people see and touch every day will reveal to them an operating Government that's doing just fine."
To some degree, Washington is a slave to the calendar. The Government's new fiscal year will start Oct. 1 regardless of Mr. Clinton's troubles, and that means Congress and the Administration have to agree on 13 spending bills, many of which are ideological battlegrounds, in the next few weeks. Presidential vetoes seem likely, and a partial shutdown of the Government is not out of the question.
Impeachment proceedings aside, Republicans were already on the defensive over Democratic complaints that this has been a do-nothing Congress, intent on little more than killing initiatives like tobacco legislation and an overhaul of health care regulation.
Still, it is an open question how much new policy will get a hearing once the immediate issues are out of the way. Dana G. Mead, the chairman of Tenneco Inc., a big manufacturer, was in Washington last week talking to Administration officials and members of Congress about issues of concern to the Business Roundtable, an organization of corporate chief executives that he heads.
Mr. Mead, who watched Watergate unfold as a domestic policy adviser in the Nixon Administration, came away wondering whether the White House and Congress would be able to take on any but the most pressing issues, especially if the impeachment process moves ahead.
"There are certain things that they must do, things that are important to their constituents or the national interest or both," Mr. Mead said. Beyond that, he said, the "nice to do items" will languish and a kind of rationing of time and attention will kick in.
There is already evidence of that phenomenon at work. Democrats despair that a weakened Mr. Clinton has been less effective than he would have been otherwise in rallying support this fall for an increase in the minimum wage and action on health care. The White House spin machine, which made an art of promoting small-bore policy initiatives, is now consumed with the President's day to day survival.
 
One-Track Minds
Policymakers within the Administration and some politicians from both sides of the aisle in Congress already admit to being discouraged.
After the campaign-finance overhaul bill that he co-sponsored suffered another procedural defeat earlier this month, Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican, was asked if he would continue bringing up the bill in the hopes of creating more pressure for its passage.
"Not as long as the President has got the problems he has," Mr. McCain said. "We don't talk about HMO's anymore, we don't talk about taxes anymore, we don't talk about Social Security anymore. There's only one thing on everybody's mind and everybody knows it."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 15; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: In America;
Running In Place

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
A few months ago a guy said to me, "If the economy is doing so great, how come I'm broke?"
A new study out of Washington shows that there are an awful lot of Americans who might ask the same question. 
 The study by the Economic Policy Institute is titled "The State of Working America" and has been published in book form. It doesn't dispute that the economy has improved since the dark days of the early-90's recession, but points out that there are still enormous numbers of middle-class and working-class Americans who have little or no reason to celebrate.
The study's findings included the following:
* The inflation-adjusted earnings of the median worker in 1997 were 3.1 percent lower than in 1989. Over that period, real hourly wages either stagnated or fell for most of the bottom 60 percent of the working population.
* Median family income was $1,000 less in 1996 (the most recent year for which complete data are available) than in 1989. Economists believe the final statistics for 1997, available later this week, will show some improvement, but only enough to bring the median income back to the 1989 level.
* The "typical married-couple family" worked 247 more hours per year in 1996 than in 1989 despite an 8 percent growth in the economy's productive capacity. That's more than six weeks' worth of additional work, just to stay even or keep from falling too far behind.
The report notes that early this year unemployment fell to its lowest point in three decades and, very recently, real wages have begun to rise for most workers. But those improvements have come at the end of a prolonged period of wage deterioration and other setbacks that have had a profound effect on the standard of living of most American families.
According to the report, "The typical American family is probably worse off near the end of the 1990's than it was at the end of the 1980's or the end of the 1970's." It says, "To the extent that the typical American family has been able to hold its ground, the most important factor has been the large increase in the hours worked by family members."
Except for the very wealthy, we are in something less than a golden economic age. The heralded stock market advances of the 90's have primarily benefited the wealthy few, despite the increased popularity of mutual funds and the expansion of defined-contribution retirement plans. Most families own no stock at all. Those that do own stock usually have very small investments.
According to the institute's study, more than 85 percent of the benefits from "the increase in the stock market between 1989 and 1997 went to the richest 10 percent of households."
The very recent and very modest gains in the real wages of American workers were largely linked to the tight labor market, which heightened the bargaining power of workers, and increases in the minimum wage.
Jared Bernstein, a co-author of the report with Lawrence Mishel and John Schmitt, applauded the policy decisions that led to those improvements. But he added that the low unemployment rate is a particularly "thin reed" for working families to hang onto.
"It's a cyclical variable," he said, "and the focus of the Federal Reserve has been imbalanced. It has been overly concerned about inflation and the erosion of the assets of the wealthy, and has not appreciated the importance of persistently low unemployment in reversing the long-term negative trends for working families."
As for the minimum wage, now $5.15 an hour, the feeling of the Republican majority in Congress is that we have gone far enough. Senator Edward Kennedy has proposed raising it by 50 cents an hour in January, and another 50 cents a year later. That way, as the Senator put it, "the minimum wage will reach the level of $6.15 at the turn of the century."
Some politicians will tell you that terrible things will happen if companies are required to pay American workers $6.15 an hour in the year 2000. On Tuesday a key vote is scheduled on Senator Kennedy's proposal. The hunt is on for enough votes to save it.
One of these days policy makers will come to realize that you can't sustain a real boom if workers and their families aren't getting a fair shake. The value of low unemployment and an honest day's pay for an honest day's work should not be matters for debate.

HEADLINE: That Delicate Balance: What About the Dads?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Women and Their Work: How Life Inundates Art" (Aug. 23), about a Brooklyn reading group's reactions to "mommy books" and their own balancing of the challenges of work and raising children: 
 The next time you do a roundtable about work and family, try inviting men. Could you imagine asking a group of fathers who are also lawyers, artists and editors how they do the balancing?
Men rarely must choose between raising children and pursuing careers. And when they have children, few ask employers to consider flexible schedules, part-time positions or time off to care for a 6-year-old with a stomach bug. Indeed, for some men even scaling back to a 40-hour work week might seem risky.
I, for one, would love to hear men agonize over this issue with the same concern, self-reflection and honesty as the women showed in the article.
 
SUZANNE KEATING
Providence, R.I., Aug. 26

HEADLINE: That Delicate Balance: What About the Dads?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
While those of us who stay home with our children cringe at the phrase sometimes used to describe us -- "sitting at home" -- there is some wonderful truth in the words. 
 I work very hard in my home, feeding, cleaning, teaching, loving and picking up after my children. But I choose to be at home with them -- in no way a luxury -- so that I can sit. I sit down to breast-feed my babies, to snuggle and hold them. I sit down to read them stories, to watch "Barney and Friends" with them and to look them in the eye and discuss the difficulty of the day. Sometimes I get to sit down with a sandwich and have sincere conversations with my 7-year-old, who starts the day asking "Why?"
My choice is not about working; it is about my children and who is best to sit with them.
 
CANDACE MOORE HILL
Evanston, Ill., Aug. 23

HEADLINE: BUSINESS: DIARY;
Hopes for Rate Cuts Are Raised, Then Dashed

 BODY:
The week began with President Clinton hoping to strike up the Group of Seven band of major economic powers in a rousing chorus of coordinated interest rate cuts, to relieve the pressure on embattled Latin American countries like Brazil that are struggling to contain currency and debt crises. World financial markets took heart. 
 But by midweek all was disharmony, thanks to political paralysis in Japan, election distractions in Germany and muddy political and economic waters in the United States. The chief soloist, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, made it clear that no sweet music would be forthcoming -- and the markets, disappointed, sank once more.
The week closed to the clangor of printing presses, as Russia's central bank, against all advice, tried papering over economic chasms with freshly minted rubles.

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
IN MY BRIEFCASE/JEFFREY D. SACHS

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Jeffrey D. Sachs, director of the Harvard Institute for International Development, spends roughly one-third of his life on the road, giving lectures and troubleshooting the institute's economic development projects from Indonesia to southern Africa. This day, he packed light for the flight back to Boston from Jacksonville, Fla., but included a lot of reading material in his briefcase, "in case we get stuck on the runway."
 The adapter plug "I take everywhere," he said. "You can plug it into an airport phone anywhere in the world and read your E-mail." And the ballpoint pens are "no-name cheapos -- I'd lose anything good in a minute." Indeed, conspicuously missing is his beloved Psion electronic organizer, which he used to fiddle with during dull meetings. "I left it on an airplane," he lamented. 
 Topping his reading list is "Consilience" by Edward O. Wilson, the sociobiologist. ("Everyone at
 the institute is reading Wilson right now," he said.) But the list also includes "Interactions of Desertification and Climate" and "Roll Back Malaria" because, he said, "Africa's on my mind."
 He likes his black canvas briefcase because it is "flexible enough to be stuffed."
 PETER PASSELL

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Jobless Rate in New Jersey Drops to 4.8 Percent

BYLINE: By KIRSTY SUCATO

 BODY:
New Jersey's unemployment rate fell a tenth of a percentage point to 4.8 percent in August, but remained above the national average of 4.5 percent even though the number of jobs reached a record high, the State Department of Labor reported on Tuesday. 
 Payroll jobs rose by 7,500 to 3,803,900, reversing losses of 5,400 in July. The gains were partly due to the return of 2,900 workers at the General Motors plant in Linden, who were idled by a strike of parts makers in Flint, Mich.
The largest growth was in the service sector, which gained 4,000 new jobs, a department spokesman said. KIRSTY SUCATO

HEADLINE: Brazilians Fret as Economic Threat Moves Closer

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Until recently, it seemed that Augusta Aparecida Pettinari's fortunes and the country's economic reform plan ran on parallel tracks, like twin locomotives taking the young receptionist and the modern currency toward a steadily more promising future.
As once-rampant inflation was brought down to negligible levels, Ms. Pettinari joined an emerging class of consumers, whose salaries for the first time maintained their purchasing power from one paycheck to the next. She smiles now as she remembers buying appliances, of going to the movies and of writing a check for a new dress. 
 "I was able to have a social life," she said.
The man Brazilians elected President four years ago in gratitude for taming inflation was Fernando Henrique Cardoso, the former Finance Minister. To back the new currency that gave his Real Plan its name, there was an array of proposed structural changes to attract foreign investment, privatize state industries and reform social security, the Civil Service and tax systems.
But now, two weeks before the Oct. 4 election, in which Mr. Cardoso is to seek another term in office, the financial tornado that has devastated parts of Asia and Russia has begun spinning toward Brazil.
In the last month, nearly $1 billion a day in foreign reserves has been flying out of the country, while the black market rate for dollars has veered from 2 cents above the official rate to more than 30 cents. Over the last seven trading days, the stock market has bounced from 15.8 percent losses one day to 18.7 percent gains the next, and then back down again this week after Alan Greenspan, the United States Federal Reserve chairman, ruled out lowering interest rates. The country has doubled the ceiling on interbank loan rates, to 49.75 percent from 24.75 percent.
And suddenly, the train that Ms. Pettinari once thought was carrying her steadily upward toward prosperity feels more like a roller coaster. Come Oct. 5, the day after the election, the now-unemployed receptionist confesses, she has no notion at all where this wild ride will take her.
"If we stay along the same lines we've been on, we'll manage," said Ms. Pettinari, 28. Then she recalled her country's last economic crisis in 1990, when Fernando Collor de Mello began his presidency by freezing all personal bank accounts and allowing Brazilians access to only $50 each. "But who really knows what lunacy is coming?"
Brazil, the world's ninth-largest economy and the pacesetter for Latin America, is once again in danger of collapse, this time crippled by growing current account and fiscal deficits. While Brazil does not have the threat of political instability or nuclear weaponry that makes a breakdown in Russia so fearsome, the opening of its markets has drawn billions of dollars in American investment, and its fall would bring economic turbulence dangerously close to American shores.
Brazil's budget deficit, at more than 7 percent of gross national product, and its current account deficit, at $35 billion, threaten to swell further with the steep interest increases of recent weeks, despite announcements of drastic budget cuts. Over the next two months, some $80 billion in Brazilian debt will need to be rolled over. According to Merrill Lynch, American banks had $27.2 billion at stake in Brazil at the end of March. In Russia, they had only $6.8 billion tied up. Moody's and Standard & Poor's downgraded Brazil this month.
For now, voters are holding fast to Mr. Cardoso, as the most responsible figure to face the looming crisis. In the most recent poll, 49 percent of those who responded supported him, a 27-point advantage over Luis Inacio Lula da Silva, a former auto workers union president and three-time presidential candidate of the leftist Worker's Party.
"Lula would be very strong on social issues, but a President isn't only that," said Daniella Cristina Turri, a 20-year-old office worker who has been trying to find work for four months. "The most important thing is the economy. It's the basis for everything else."
Already months behind on her night school tuition, however, Ms. Turri is no longer sure that she will vote for President Cardoso.
"Everything's getting worse for us," she said. "There are times when you think about leaving the country, because it doesn't give you any way to make a living." Unemployment in Sao Paulo, the financial and industrial heart of Brazil, is 19 percent, and is expected to worsen.
Though he is still well liked on Wall Street, Mr. Cardoso has lost credibility as investors battered by losses in Asia and Russia weigh his failure to deliver needed reforms. On his first presidential visit to the United States, in April 1995, Mr. Cardoso visited New York before Washington, underscoring the importance of investment to his country's future.
The President won fans in world financial capitals by removing exchange controls, opening markets and selling off state industries. Last year, with $17 billion coming in, Brazil became the world's third-largest market for direct foreign investment, following the United States and China.
But Mr. Cardoso proved less successful at getting the Government to live by the same fiscal discipline forced on middle-class Brazilians. Politically costly overhauls were either put off, as with tax reform; fumbled, as with social security reform; or were passed but not carried out, as with civil service reform. An assembly line of privatizations, however, helped offset soaring Government costs.
Mr. Cardoso contends that Brazil's vulnerability is not his or the country's doing, but the product of outside forces, and he is calling for a new international monetary system for the global era. The market reacts to every sign of outside backing for Brazil, in the form of reduced American interest rates, a bailout by the International Monetary Fund, or an I.M.F. line of credit. But so far, Brazil has not formally requested an I.M.F. bailout and Mr. Cardoso is loath to embrace I.M.F. conditions before election day.
The Government had already announced cutbacks to raise a primary account surplus of .87 percent, but reports here say the I.M.F. would demand a primary surplus closer to 3 percent next year as the price of its bailout. The primary account covers revenues less expenses, without interest on debts.
These days, Mr. Cardoso is walking a delicate line to election day, nudged by his politician's instincts that suggest that doomsday speeches about tax increases, unemployment and sacrifice are not the stuff of landslides, and by an international investment community clamoring for proof that Brazil will get its fiscal house in order, and soon.
"The only positive byproduct for Brazil is that he'll have to do these fiscal reforms," said Joel Korn, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Rio de Janeiro.
Brazil's most likely initial steps will combine tax increases, import restrictions and cost-cutting measures. Investors are expecting Mr. Cardoso to push through reforms before the lame duck Congress dissolves at year's end. The President has ruled out a devaluation, which would undoubtedly reignite inflation, but it is by no means certain, investment analysts say, that the country will not be forced into one. In recent days, the stream of reserves leaving Brazil has slowed to under $500 million a day, and the difference between official and black market exchange rates has narrowed.
More than ever, it appears that Mr. Cardoso, who spent considerable time and political capital pushing a constitutional amendment through Congress allowing presidents to run for re-election, will win on the first round. But he has never stood closer to seeing his legacy crumble in his hands. His inauguration is expected to be not so much a coronation, as his rivals once feared, but the threshold to a new era of sacrifice.
Even those struggling through a shrinking economy, though, say they would prefer sacrifice to inflation. Ms. Pettinari has been watching the sandwich boards with job offerings on Barao de Parana Piacaba street since April, when she lost her job.
She got married five months ago, but both she and her husband, who had been a bill-collector, are out of work, and have to live apart, he with his parents, she with hers.
"If it weren't for them, I'd go hungry," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Brazilians worry that their period of economic stability may be coming to an end. Daniella Cristina Turri, 20, an office worker who has been trying to find work, read job ads on sandwich boards in downtown Sao Paulo. (Alex Silva for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: After Dispute In Pakistan, Leader Leaves For U.S. Visit

BYLINE: By BARRY BEARAK 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif leaves for the United States today and could not have picked a better time for a getaway, with people here feeling he has just tried to eliminate democracy from the Constitution.
Whatever lies ahead for him this week -- and his schedule includes meetings with President Clinton and Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee of India as well as a speech before the United Nations -- the days should seem tranquil compared with those he just left behind. 
 Last week, two of Mr. Sharif's pet measures ran into unruly opposition in Parliament. One was a bill that gave the Prime Minister more power, all in the name of Allah, and the other was a permission slip to sign a nuclear test-ban treaty as a means to solicit aid from Western donors. In both instances, however worthy his intentions, Mr. Sharif's political antennae relayed all the wrong signals.
"He doesn't seem to ever think before he does something," said Maleeha Lodhi, a newspaper editor and former envoy to the United States. "He makes sudden moves and then ends up governing by retreat."
Mr. Sharif's plans to amend the Constitution were announced on Aug. 28, an unhappy time for him when the only distraction from rising prices in this near-bankrupt nation was the recent United States missile attack on suspected terrorist bases in neighboring Afghanistan. Mr. Sharif was widely thought to be insufficiently irate about the bombardment of an Islamic neighbor.
He chose this difficult moment to propose that Islamic justice be made the supreme law of the land, a tactical mix of politics and religion with a long history here.
"We must go down on our knees and bow before Allah," Mr. Sharif, a millionaire industrialist, said. By his reckoning, holy practices were the only way to end the nation's many years of "corruption, gratification and maladministration."
What he meant by full Islamic law was left vague, although he did promise to protect individual and minority rights. He denied trying to remold moderate and modern Pakistan into something like the Afghanistan of the Taliban.
Even a number of the devout questioned the need for the proposal. The Constitution already proclaims Pakistan an Islamic state, subject to the religion's fundamental principles.
For many, the true motive for Mr. Sharif's bill rested less in piety than in politics. It would change some essential numbers: in matters of Islam, a simple majority in both houses of Parliament -- rather than the current two-thirds -- would suffice to amend the Constitution. Also, the Prime Minister would be empowered to issue decrees that further entrenched Islamic practices.
What would then stop him, critics asked, from pushing bills through the legislature in the name of Allah? Could he dissolve Parliament if he considered its actions un-Islamic?
If Mr. Sharif expected support from Pakistan's small but vocal Islamic parties, he was mistaken. "He is exploiting the Koran to serve his own interests," said Amir-ul-Azeem of the Jamaat-e-Islami. "If the Government really wants to enforce Islamic law, the laws are now sufficient. The problem is in the practices, not in the laws."
Despite the opposition, Mr. Sharif expected his bill to pass last week. Instead even members of his own majority party, the Muslim League, rebelled. They, too, questioned his motives. Some threatened to quit. And, after a stormy late-night meeting on Thursday, Mr. Sharif announced that he was in no great haste to see the law passed.
Efforts to get comment from Mr. Sharif's Information Ministry as well as his Minister for Religious Affairs received no response.
Similar political pratfalls accompanied Mr. Sharif's request for a resolution of support on the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. He seems inclined to forswear any further nuclear tests, such as the ones he orderedin May after India, Pakistan's great rival and neighbor, had exploded its own nuclear devices. But first he wants the United States to end economic sanctions imposed after the blasts -- and to help Pakistan get an aid package that would, at least temporarily, keep it from defaulting on $30 billion in international debt.
Although the Prime Minister does not need legislative approval to sign the treaty, he asked for it anyway. He had reason to expect little resistance. His chief political opponent, Benazir Bhutto, head of the Pakistan People's Party, has urged him to sign.
But many members of Parliament were reluctant to agree without knowing the details of negotiations with the Americans.
When Mr. Sharif was not forthcoming, most opposition parties boycotted a special session of Parliament. The resolution was withdrawn.
What might have been termed a laudable effort at building consensus instead became "another bit of confused theatrics," the newspaper Dawn noted in an editorial.

HEADLINE: Better Schools Is Battle Cry for Fall Elections

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER 

 BODY:
The Democratic candidate for governor in South Carolina, Jim Hodges, has chosen as his logo a drawing of the back of a school bus and the slogan "It's all about our schools."
In Texas, Gov. George W. Bush, a Republican, is running a television advertisement that declares, "No goal is more important than making sure all Texas schoolchildren are able to read." 
 In California, voters ended 30 years of bilingual education by referendum in June and face another initiative over reduced class size in November.
And across the country this election season, scores of candidates for Senate and House seats, like the Democrats Charles E. Schumer of New York and Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas, are focusing on schools, vowing that if sent to Washington, they will get the Government involved in cutting the nation's class sizes, repairing school buildings and making them safer for learning.
"If there is a single motivating force in my public life," said Representative Glenn Poshard, an Illinois Democrat running for governor, in a comment that is echoed by candidates everywhere, "it is to provide a meaningful education to every child in this state."
While education has long been one of the voters' top five or six concerns, along with crime, drugs, the economy and foreign threats, the issue has been cited by pollsters this year as the voters' primary focus, especially in the many states with gubernatorial elections. Despite both parties' focus on the Clinton scandal, Democrats are emphasizing their traditional stake in education policy while Republicans are seeking to make the education issue their own.
But the impact of all this attention is far from clear, education advocates say. Is the talk of standards, class size and safety leading to improved education or merely serving candidates as "family values" campaign themes?
Chester E. Finn Jr., a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute in Washington and a leading conservative voice in education, says the vast majority of new state standards for students, instituted under political pressure, are too low to be meaningful and the bulk of campaign talk about education is useless or misleading.
"As in so many other policy debates, much of the education campaigning is based on focus groups and political consultant input," he said. "Look at Clinton's and other people's class-size reduction scheme. It is costly and problematic. Costly, because you have to hire more teachers and payroll is already the largest portion of the budget. Problematic, because there is so little evidence that, apart from kindergarten and first grade, class-size reduction produces any better education."
He added: "American class sizes have been shrinking for 50 years. Many countries that beat the pants off of us in international comparisons have much larger class sizes than we do. The biggest immediate effect of reducing class size in most places will be to draw more unqualified people into teaching and suck good teachers out of urban into suburban schools. Nonetheless, everyone is proposing class-size reduction."
Others say that the focus on education has produced results.
Robert B. Schwartz, president of Achieve Inc., a bipartisan and corporate-government partnership to improve schools, says efforts have paid off in states like Kentucky, Maryland, Washington and Oregon, where reasonable standards have been established, businesses are focusing on applicants' school records in hiring, and accountability procedures have been instituted for schools.
He said teacher quality had come under greater scrutiny, too, with many states raising the bar for certification and some, like Massachusetts, using budget surpluses to attract better candidates for teaching jobs with signing bonuses.
"I do think that in a significant number of states, the political conversation about education is qualitatively different than it was in the past," Mr. Schwartz said. "This is not just the equivalent of family values as a campaign theme. Many states have not only adopted standards but put in place assessments and systems of accountability."
Patricia Albjerg Graham, a professor and former dean of the Harvard Graduate School of Education, said: "The most important result of this prolonged debate on education has been the widespread conviction that children of all social classes are now expected to learn academic material. The idea that educational achievement is for everybody is revolutionary. That's real progress."
The debate over education often tracks the conservative-liberal divide over school governance and standards. Generally, conservatives favor local control and more rigorous standards while liberals tend toward a national approach and, while mindful of the need for standards, they emphasize inclusiveness.
"I find it hard to believe we are going to achieve national standards on education because liberals oppose standards and conservatives oppose national," mused Arthur Levine, president of Teachers College at Columbia University, who has been receiving a growing number of calls from politicians seeking briefings.
Nonetheless, what is striking about the debate is that if there is not agreement on the means, there is near-universal consensus on the ends of this education campaign.
"The traditionalists have won," remarked Larry Cuban, an education professor at Stanford University. "New math and whole-language reading are in retreat. Today there are more phonics, more multiplication tables, more tests. There is a consensus between the public and officials that the basic, traditional model is the one to pursue. Whatever experimentation is occurring today challenges the boundaries far less than two to three decades ago."
This means that in their public appearances both Democrats and Republicans are saying rather similar things about education -- vowing to provide more of it with better equipment, safer classrooms and better teachers -- with their disagreements focused on how to get there: whether to confront teachers' unions or cooperate with them, raise taxes or shift revenues, focus on traditional public schools or on alternatives, like government vouchers to pay for private schooling or independent but publicly financed schools known as charter schools.
Polls show the voters to be unsure which path is the more efficient -- they tend to favor most options that sound as if they would lead to improvements -- suggesting that candidates are competing over driving home their message that they care.
One reason there seems to be such a consensus on education is that the economic rationale for schooling has triumphed. As the economy has shifted from an industrial to a white-collar base, Americans have become increasingly persuaded that their children's personal financial success will depend on what kind of education they receive. This means that campaigning about education does not displace campaigning about the economy -- it is a proxy for it.
Economics aside, the prominence of education as a political issue results from a confluence of factors.
First, ever since "A Nation at Risk," the explosive 1983 attack on the quality of American public schools, policy makers, including President George Bush and President Clinton, have focused on schooling, and the impact of their sustained attention is being felt. Second, the 1990's, dominated by the breakup of the Soviet Union, a rising stock market and a plummeting urban crime rate, shifted the focus away from traditional front-runner issues, granting education more attention. Third, the demographically powerful baby-boom generation has children throughout the school system, so the boomers' attention is focused on the issue.
Moreover, women are often heavily involved in educational issues, so focusing on the issues is a way to appeal to them as voters. And finally, with the military draft ended, the public school system is one of the remaining places for large-scale inculcation of values. The system has had to bear a growing share of societal goals -- fighting poverty, absorbing immigrants, preparing the public for a multiracial future and instilling in the young a sense of moral order and discipline.
On this last point, many experts see voter concern over education to be largely anxiety over their children's character.
"Astute politicians realize that a lot of us are worried about our kids," said Theodore R. Sizer, an author who advocates school reform. "The moral dimension and the safety dimension overlap. More and more families are frightened by what they see."
Charles L. Glenn, a professor of education policy at Boston University, agrees. "There is a diffuse, general idea that America is going to hell on issues of moral character," he said. "Most parents say they are worried about discipline. What kind of kids will my kids be in contact with? Are my kids going to come home as strangers with different values than mine? Conservatives talk about school choice because they see the current monopoly of content to be relativistic."
Conservatives also focus on school choice because they think it will improve schools generally. They say that one of the most positive results of all the recent attention on education has been to open up school systems to competition from charter schools and vouchers.
"Twenty years ago, President Reagan tried to free markets from a lot of impediments like unions and taxation," remarked Lamar Alexander, the former Education Secretary and Tennessee Governor, who is expected to seek the Republican Presidential nomination in 2000.
"His idea was, if we free the market, we can get a good economy," Mr. Alexander said. "That's what we need to do with schools. We need to free the schools from all those impediments like unions and outdated practices. Let them flourish. America does best when we pursue freedom and choice and allow ingenuity to flourish.
"If there were a Republican President to lead the charge and give courage to governors and education entrepreneurs," he said, "sometime in the next 5 to 10 years we would see real results with higher academic achievement."
Others see the issue differently.
"If we were serious about our educational problems, we would go see what other nations are doing," said Marc S. Tucker of the National Center on Education and the Economy. "Not one of them is using vouchers as the secret of its success. They set high standards and have exams and curriculum to match. There is very little choice in the curriculum. This is true from Singapore to Japan to Denmark.
"It is universally applicable," he said. "Yet it doesn't apply here? That's absurd."
Nonetheless, tests and standards are slowly being installed in many states. In New York, for example, high school students will soon have to pass Regents examinations on more and more subjects to graduate.
All experts questioned said the real political test would be how voters react when, or if, many children fail such exams.
"Everybody is for high test scores till their kids get low test scores," Mr. Sizer remarked. "There is a kind of unreality to the policy debate. Are we really going to shut down schools that don't perform? I think the rhetoric and self-righteous table pounding will stop when the reality sets in. The attention will shift to a more varied approach. If all this attention doesn't lead ultimately to improved education, we have certainly blown it."

HEADLINE: In New Wild West, It's Cowboys vs. Radical Environmentalists

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: ERVAY, Wyo., Sept. 15

 BODY:
Robert L. Hendry should feel at ease, running a vast cattle ranch smack in the center of a state that since 1936 has treasured its trademark logo: a cowboy riding a bucking bronco.
But this real live cowboy darkened today at the memory of a rash of vandalism that struck ranchers along the Rattlesnake Range here as fundamentally "un-Wyoming." In mid-June, as the Wyoming Stock Growers Association was meeting in Casper, 40 miles east of here, a carload of vandals traveled 100 miles up and down dirt roads here, cutting 260 sections of barbed-wire fence. 
"Just in time for the welfare cowboys' convention," read leaflets nailed to fence posts. No group has taken responsibility for the action and no arrests have been made. But two months earlier, Earth First Journal, a clearinghouse for the radical environmental movement, hailed "rampant fence cutting" in central Wyoming, concluding with an appeal, "Dust off those wire cutters, folks!"
In this modern range war, radical environmentalists seek to force grazing cattle off public land by cutting fences and otherwise carrying out economic sabotage against ranching operations. With beef prices low, many Western ranchers already have their financial backs to the wall.
Now, in a throwback to the 19th century when fence cutting was a hanging offense in the wilder parts of the West, violence looms over barbed wire in big sky country.
"For their own safety, they better lay off," Mr. Hendry warned of the people who cut his fences in 60 places. "If the right group finds them, they might get shot."
Agreement came from Chuck Sylvester, a neighboring rancher who was also a target of the fence cutters, who drove a sports utility vehicle. He said: "Some day, they are going to make a mistake. Any number of my neighbors are now carrying rifles. They could knock out a tire, knock out a knee."
Across the West, stakes are rising in the battle between mainstream society and radical environmentalists and animal rights groups.
Last week, in one of the toughest sentences handed down in a case of animal rights terrorism, a Salt Lake City judge gave a seven-year sentence to Douglas Joshua Ellerman, a 20-year-old Animal Liberation Front member, for his role in the 1997 firebombing of Utah's principal mink breeders' cooperative.
 On Thursday, an Earth First member, David Chain, was killed by a falling tree as he tried to block the logging of ancient redwoods in Northern California. It is the first time a member of the group has been killed in more than a decade of confrontational protests.
In cattle country, vandalism has escalated to the point where more and more ranchers are starting to speak out. In Wyoming, a crackdown on fence cutters has become a campaign issue in this fall's county sheriff races.
"This has been going on for three or more years, but we have kept it quiet," said Ken Hamilton, a leader of the Wyoming Farm Bureau, an agricultural group. "We didn't want to give the terrorists more oxygen."
In central Wyoming, batches of fences were cut four times last year. But the public did not become aware until June 20, when the wide-scale attack on fences here was reported in The Casper Star-Tribune.
"My concern is: How far are they going to go?" said Sgt. Michael Sandfort, who is investigating the case here for the Natrona County Sheriff's Department. "Cut fences are an irritation. But what if we get shot livestock, destroyed windmills, shot up water tanks? Then we are talking big bucks."
Across the West, many environmentalists oppose allowing ranchers to graze livestock on Federal lands, whether national forests or lands of the Bureau of Land Management.
"Cows munch the trees, they destabilize the stream banks by tromping up and down, they compact the soil with their hooves," said Peter Galvin, a conservation biologist for the Southwest Center for Biological Diversity, a Tucson group that seeks to curtail ranching on public lands through lawsuits. "Millions and millions of acres have been stripped bare, just like in logging and strip mining. Only grazing has done it in a slightly more subtle level."
Most opponents of livestock grazing on public lands, like the Southwest Center, use legal means in their effort to turn the region's ecological clock back to 1875, the year that barbed wire began to fence the West's wide open spaces.
But a radical fringe prefers to take direct action, ranging from snipping barbed wire, to burning down cattle auction barns, to, in one case in southern New Mexico, mowing down cattle with an AK-47.
About 30 incidents of cattle shootings have occurred in the last three years, said Barry R. Clausen, private investigator in Northern California who monitors environmental extremist activity. Talking by phone from Tucson, where he was lecturing to ranchers, Mr. Clausen said of Arizona: "There have been 20 cases of fence cutting in the last six months. Water tanks have been damaged. Windmills have been damaged."
In 1985, David Foreman, a founder of Earth First, published a technical manual to "monkey-wrenching," which is jargon for sabotage. The book, which has been through eight printings, dedicates 14 pages to vandalizing ranches -- stealing salt blocks, plugging water pipes, smashing water tanks, disabling windmills, and cutting fences.
"Some experts estimate that 100 people cutting fences on a regular basis around the West could put the public-land ranchers out of business," wrote Mr. Foreman, who is chairman of the Wildlands Project, an environmental group in Tucson.
In spring 1997, Earth First Journal published a step-by-step guide to cutting barbed-wire fences.
"The Journal does not take a position on monkey-wrenching," said Theresa Kintz, an editor for the Oregon publication. "But, personally, I think it's pretty cool."
"There should not be ranching on public lands -- it's like welfare," she added, stressing that these were her personal opinions. "If people are out there using monkey-wrenching to keep ranching off public lands, I'm all for it."
Many ranchers have kept a low profile in the face of violence.
"People are upset," said Jack Roddy, a central California rancher who has lectured stock grower groups about the sabotage campaign problem. "But I can't see a lot of them stepping forward to organize to get this stuff stopped."
"A lot of people fear retaliation. I am a perfect example. I had 14 head of cattle killed because I talked."
Out here in the rural areas of Natrona County, where 10,000 people are scattered over an area the size of Connecticut, people are angry, suspicious and frightened. Ranchers, some of them deputized by the county sheriff, have begun to stop unknown vehicles, asking drivers what their business is, and writing down license plate numbers.
"It's not only shocking and frustrating, it's a little frightening," Gaynell Park, a rancher whose fences were cut, said today as she sat in her living room. "These people are faceless. We don't know what else they might do."
