HEADLINE: Plan for Tribal Casino Backfires On a Fading Jersey Shore Town

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: ANADARKO, Okla.

 BODY:
In 1995, the Mayor and business leaders of Wildwood, a struggling resort on the Jersey Shore, were certain that the path to prosperity ran through this parched corner of western Oklahoma. The idea seemed inspired: Take a bit of city land -- a two-acre parking lot, actually -- and give it back to Oklahoma's Delaware Indians, whose ancestors were pushed out of New Jersey in the 1830's. The Indians would open a casino, and Wildwood would finally tap into the river of dollars flowing to the mighty resort casinos of Atlantic City, 30 miles up the shore.
It has not worked out that way. 
 Far from gaining a small-scale gambling parlor to match its small-town hopes, Wildwood has seen its redevelopment plan pushed to the sidelines by battling lawyers who have literally made a Federal case out of it. The Delawares, once Wildwood's allies, have instead teamed up with a well-heeled national Indian gambling developer and filed a lawsuit claiming all of the city as their ancestral land. Wildwood tried to give the tribe the parking lot, but that only brought another lawsuit, from the State of New Jersey, seeking to block any deal that might undermine Atlantic City's casino monopoly.
And now, the Delawares are raising the stakes. Unless the state drops its opposition to an Indian casino in Wildwood, the Delawares' lawyer said, the tribe will sue for thousands of New Jersey acres outside of Wildwood that it says were taken in violation of a 1790 Federal law. A dozen or more tribes -- in California, Maine, Washington State and elsewhere -- have won thousands of acres and millions of dollars with such claims, and any land won could be developed into an Indian casino without state approval.
"So what started out as a 2.2 acre-case to revitalize Wildwood is turning into a suit involving potentially thousands of acres and millions of dollars," the tribe's lawyer, Glenn D. McGogney, said.
As Wildwood and its Mayor, Fred Wager, have learned, the world of casino development is not a penny-ante game.
"We've got 26 percent unemployment, we've got businesses boarded up right in the heart of downtown, we've got a high school that isn't properly funded, and we've got kids who have to leave town when they graduate," Mr. Wager said. "That's what we're facing in Wildwood, and all I can hope is that when this whole thing works itself out, the city will get back some of what we've lost."
When he talked about small-town problems, the Mayor could also have been speaking of Anadarko, a town of 6,600 in one of Oklahoma's poorest counties. From the Redskin Theater (closed) at the west end of town to the Indian City Lanes, Anadarko and surrounding Caddo County are propped up by their small farms and ranches; by some summer visitors to the Indian City USA theme park, and by the housing, education and health care that the Federal Government provides the area's seven tribes.
Of a dozen people interviewed here, no one was aware of the Delawares' New Jersey project, but the idea that a tribe would want to venture that far made sense to some.
"I guess they need to get some more business, the same as the people in New Jersey do," said Wayne Gomez, a reporter at The Anadarko Daily News.
The Delawares refused to meet with a reporter who visited their trust lands to discuss the Wildwood matter. The tribe's chief, Larry Snake, even denied in a brief phone conversation that Mr. McGogney was representing the tribe, an assertion that Mr. McGogney disputed. "We have a signed contract," said Mr. McGogney, who is listed in court papers as the tribe's lawyer.
Federal regulators say that Wildwood's experience, right down to its abject failure so far, has parallels all over the country. Governments or businesses seeking to revive depressed properties are cutting deals with Indians whose tribal lands are too remote to prosper. Bring Indian casinos to the customers, the thinking goes, and everyone will be happy.
This would be done by persuading the Federal Government to take a property into trust for a tribe -- creating a mini-reservation, in effect, that is under the tribe's sovereignty and removed from local and state control, including zoning regulations. But Federal Indian policy frowns on creating trust lands for gambling. So far only one such effort, in Wisconsin, has succeeded, and then only because the entire state leadership supported the idea.
New Jersey has no federally recognized tribes and no Indian trust lands, but it does have three state-recognized Indian tribes -- the Ramapough, the Nanticoke and the Powhatan -- that are demanding Federal recognition and their own lands. So far, the Bureau of Indian Affairs has rejected their pleas.
Indian gambling is a $7 billion-a-year industry, Federal officials say, with 185 tribes running 285 gambling operations in 28 states. A sliver of that action belongs to western Oklahoma's Delawares, a federally recognized tribe with 1,200 members on a few thousand acres of trust lands.
The tribe's Gold River casino and bingo parlor occupies a low steel building among the gnarled oaks and pines north of town. Every day until 1 A.M., local cowboys, a few tourists and transient retirees hunker down in the smoky air and the din of slot machines to feed dollar bills into the tribe's 50 or so "pull-tab" machines.
"They don't have to report their earnings, but I doubt they do very well up there," said Don Ashapanek, a land-use expert at the Anadarko Indian Agency. The agency works with the seven tribes -- the Apache, Caddo, Comanche, Delaware, Fort Sill Apache, Kiowa and Wichita -- that give Anadarko the nickname Indian City.
Because the Delawares' gambling parlor offers relatively low-stakes games, it is exempt from many of the Federal and state restrictions governing full-fledged casinos. Mayor Wager wants to open a similar operation -- a so-called Class Two casino -- in Wildwood as the only way to skirt the state's opposition. But he said he hoped the casino would someday grow to have roulette, blackjack, slots and the other games that Class Three Indian casinos offer.
An Indian casino was not even Mayor Wager's first choice. While he was still a City Councilman, in 1994, he opened talks with a race track operator who talked of bringing in riverboat gambling and even, the Mayor said, an airborne "Zeppelin casino." But the promoter dropped out and advised Mr. Wager and his supporters to see the Delawares. The tribe had a plausible tie to the Jersey Shore: it lived around the Delaware Bay before leaving for the West in the 1830's, and a splinter group of Delawares had already claimed -- though unsuccessfully -- a large part of ocean-front Asbury Park, N.J., as a "tribal homeland."
Wildwood's gambling advocates formed a committee to bring home a casino, and one of its leaders, John Nickels, the owner of Nickels' Midway Pier, called Mr. Snake.
"I said, 'I would like to invite you to Wildwood, New Jersey,' " Mr. Nickels recalled. " 'Take a look around; maybe we have some things to discuss.' "
In September 1995, Mayor Wager and Mr. Snake signed a two-year contract: For $1, Wildwood would transfer to the Delaware tribe an underused, seagull-spattered parking lot of 2.2 acres on Schellenger Street, behind the Red Owl All You Can Eat Buffet.
The Delawares, asserting ancestral ties to the Jersey Shore, would ask the Federal Government to take the land in trust for the tribe. Once that was done, the Delaware would build a Class Two casino, with or without New Jersey's blessing, and offer bingo, poker and pull-tab machines, but no lodging, liquor or food service that would compete with the surrounding town. The tribe would pay the city $8 million a year.
In Trenton and in Atlantic City, reaction to Wildwood's plan was swift and angry. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said she had "serious concerns" about allowing gambling beyond Atlantic City, which pays millions into the state's treasury each year, and whose gambling franchise is protected by the state's Constitution. The State Assembly passed a resolution noting that the Delawares have had no connection with New Jersey for more than a century and urging Congress to give states more control over Indian gambling. The Bureau of Indian Affairs was also uncooperative. Without the Governor's support, its officials said, the Wildwood project was as good as dead. "This is not going to happen in Wildwood," said Rex Hacker, a Bureau of Indian Affairs spokesman.
When the city's two-year agreement with the tribe expired last fall, the Indians looked for a new partner among the casino developers who had followed the scent of business to Wildwood. A deal with Ameristar Casinos, a big Las Vegas operator, fell through, so the tribe turned to Mr. McGogney's Casino Financing Consultants, a private partnership in Allentown, Pa., that Mr. McGogney said had several other Indian casino projects in development. (He declined to say which ones.)
Mr. McGogney said his next weapon was the Federal Nonintercourse Act of 1790, which says that only the Federal Government can take Indian land. New Jersey bought out all Indian land claims in 1820, he said, but the deal was never approved in Washington. "So it is our position that the transfer was void from the beginning," Mr. McCogney said, "which means that it never ceased being tribal land, and so we are allowed to create a gaming facility without permission of the state."
On Aug. 7, Mr. McGogney, acting for the tribe, filed suit against Wildwood in a Federal court, claiming that all of the town was on ancestral land. In anticipation of the suit, the city transferred the parking lot to the tribe as an offer of settlement. But on Aug. 10, the state filed suit against Wildwood to block the parking lot giveaway, on the ground that the transfer would change city boundaries without state permission. No trial date has been set.
"I can tell you, when we started out, we did not expect so many twists and turns," Mayor Wager said. "But we shall overcome."

Map of New Jersey showing the location of Wildwood: Wildwood, N.J., envies the casino revenue flowing to Atlantic City. (pg. 48)

HEADLINE: A Humbled Yeltsin Is Fading Away

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 19

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin made a rare appearance in public last Wednesday evening at a gala concert at Moscow's Conservatory. At least, he was there for the start of a performance by the Russian cellist Mstislav Rostropovich and Seiji Ozawa, the Boston Symphony's conductor.
By intermission, he was gone. 
 As Russia's new Prime Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, struggled to patch together a coalition Cabinet this week, Mr. Yeltsin's involvement in the affairs of his crisis-ridden country has provided the background noise, audible enough but increasingly distant.
In an eerie sequence reminiscent of the stylized protocol of Soviet times, television news broadcasts show him in his office, ushering a visitor to a table where the cameras silently track opening remarks. The next news item shows an identical scene, with a different guest. The images only support the growing impression that Russia's once powerful President, weakened by crisis and poor health, has been sidelined to a largely ceremonial role.
News agencies report his telephone conversations with world leaders, and his decrees on ministerial appointments, including one that was spurned by the appointee two days after its announcement. But Mr. Primakov, the artful diplomat, is clearly making the choices that will define Russia's future course, as he sifts through opposing political factions in the difficult search for consensus.
How Mr. Yeltsin will figure into that consensus is no longer relevant: his views on Russia's economic policies have been washed over by events that have left him isolated, and humbled.
For the first time in a career that capitalized on conflicts, Mr. Yeltsin last week backed away from a certain showdown with the parliamentary opposition over the nomination of Viktor S. Chernomyrdin as Prime Minister. In Russia's play-for-keeps politics, a compromise -- in this case, the nomination of Mr. Primakov -- carries with it the faint aroma of defeat.
"Today, very little remains of President Yeltsin's clout," Natalya Konstantinova, a journalist for the Moscow daily The Independent Newspaper, wrote this week. Even Boris A. Berezovsky, the Russian tycoon and master intriguer said to have close ties to the President's family, told British television this week that Mr. Yeltsin's time had run out, and he has lent support to Aleksandr I. Lebed, the former general who now governs a Siberian region and is seen as a top presidential contender.
Instead of statements of policy, or words of reassurance, the Kremlin has been the source of tales of shadowy intrigue in the last week.
Soon after Mr. Primakov's nomination was confirmed, two top Kremlin aides -- Andrei Kokoshin, secretary of the National Security Council, and Sergei Yastrzhembsky, Mr. Yeltsin's top press spokesman -- were summarily dismissed.
Neither has been available to provide his version of events, but according to press reports, and people who know the details, their transgressions consisted of going directly to Mr. Yeltsin with unsolicited advice to drop Mr. Chernomyrdin and choose another man as Prime Minister.
By picking Mr. Primakov, Mr. Yeltsin would seem to have heeded their advice. "It is a paradox, but it is in the tradition of Russian paradoxes," said Pavel Voshchanov, a journalist who is also one of Mr. Yeltsin's former press secretaries. "When servants come to their master with unwelcome advice with which he is obliged to agree, he accepts it grudgingly, and resentfully."
Although the dismissal of the two highly respected advisers was undoubtedly ordered by Mr. Yeltsin, it was pushed by his chief of staff, Valentin B. Yumashev, a former journalist who became Mr. Yeltsin's top aide and chief gatekeeper after he helped write Mr. Yeltsin's book, "The Struggle for Russia."
According to press reports, Mr. Yumashev and his close ally, Mr. Yeltsin's daughter and adviser Tatyana Dyachenko, 38, had pressed the President to stand firm against the Parliament. In the end, they were overruled, but took their revenge.
The departure of Mr. Kokoshin and Mr. Yastrzhembsky has depleted Mr. Yeltsin's already dwindling circle of close advisers. His team of young free-market reformers -- figures like Anatoly B. Chubais, the architect of Russia's privatization, and former Prime Minister Sergei V. Kiriyenko -- has been dispersed, unlikely to return. His old allies from Russia's democratic movement now lack a leader, or even a credible heir. Even Mr. Chernomyrdin, the yo-yo of Russian politics for his ability to rebound in difficulty, has been left stranded.
Mr. Yumashev, 40, has neither the skills nor the authority to fill the gap left around Mr. Yeltsin, according to people who know him. "I saw him at a number of meetings during the 1996 campaign, and afterward, and I don't remember him ever saying a word," said Vyacheslav Nikonov, head of the Political Fund, a Moscow research organization.
The leftist opposition continues to press its advantage. An impeachment process is still wending its way to the floor of the Parliament, even though its chances of clearing the constitutional hurdles remain slight. A series of legal changes to the Constitution that would reduce the powers of the presidency are a more realistic line of attack against Mr. Yeltsin and are also due to come before the opposition-dominated Parliament.
In tracking the decline of Mr. Yeltsin's influence, many look to Mr. Berezovsky, seeing in him a political bellwether whose main loyalty is to power, no matter who holds it. He seems to be shifting support toward Mr. Lebed; another top presidential contender with business backing is Yuri Luzhkov, Moscow's Mayor.
Mr. Yeltsin's health is another handicap, although what ails him is unclear, other than aftereffects of bypass heart surgery in 1996 and a history of heavy drinking. He has good days when his step is firm and his gaze focused. But he also has bad days, when his attention drifts.
And yet, in these past hectic weeks, Mr. Yeltsin has surprised his harshest detractors by proving that he can still make decisions, and even impromptu appearances. On Thursday, he paid a 15-minute visit to a Moscow grocery store, although no reporters or television crews were present.
Several analysts still caution against ruling him out entirely, noting that as long as he still has power he will try to wield it.
Mr. Yeltsin's retirement before the end of his term in 2000, followed by early presidential elections, is a recurrent theme here. But few who know the President expect him to quit voluntarily.
"I would give anything for Boris Nikolayevich to quit -- I would promise him anything he wants," Pyotr Sumin, the Governor of the Chelyabinsk region, told the Russian magazine Profil. "We could live without him. But he will not quit."

HEADLINE: THE TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Magazine Has Ideas for Post-Clinton Democrats, and Gore Looms Large

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
As the debate intensifies over President Clinton's political future, a new magazine will be introduced next week that is devoted to the post-Clinton era in American politics -- and, apparently, to the election of Vice President Al Gore in 2000.
The magazine, a slickly printed quarterly, is named Blueprint: Ideas for a New Century and is being published by the Democratic Leadership Council, a centrist organization that Mr. Clinton once headed and turned to for help starting his Presidential campaign in 1992. 
 "One way or another, Clinton is not going to be President for that much longer," said Andrei Cherny, a former senior speechwriter for Mr. Gore who is editor of Blueprint. "And the Democratic Party needs to figure out where it goes after him and what it stands for."
Al From, the publisher and head of the leadership council, insisted that the magazine, with a circulation goal of 35,000, "is a project to put the best thinking forward of the 'New Democrat' movement -- it's not just a project to help one person get elected." The magazine dwells more on ideas than practicalities of a Presidential campaign. But Blueprint, which is financed with donations to the Democratic Leadership Council, clearly looks like a Gore vehicle. Most references are not to the Clinton Administration but to "the Clinton/Gore Administration." The staff is stocked with Gore loyalists.
Most of the articles in the premier issue were written by former Gore aides or current advisers. One article, about demographic changes in the electorate, was written by Elaine C. Kamarck of Harvard University, who ran Mr. Gore's reinventing Government initiative in the first term, and by William A. Galston, a former Clinton domestic policy aide who is close to Mr. Gore.
Mark Penn, the White House pollster who is expected to sign on with Mr. Gore for 2000, wrote an article analyzing the Democratic electorate of the future and is expected to have a standing analysis in each issue. Another article, which explores "the growing phenomenon of economic free agents," is by Daniel H. Pink, Mr. Gore's chief speechwriter from 1995 to 1997.
One well-established weekly magazine, The New Republic, has long been viewed in political circles as a booster of Mr. Gore. The editor in chief, Martin Peretz, is a longtime friend of the Vice President and was one of his instructors at Harvard University, where they met in 1965.
More recently, other magazines have cropped up to push one political position -- or candidate -- or another. Just this week, Salon, an online magazine that is widely viewed as friendly toward Mr. Clinton, stirred a partisan frenzy by disclosing that Representative Henry J. Hyde, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, had an affair three decades ago. And The Weekly Standard was established after the 1994 elections to press Republican positions -- and as something of a political antidote to The New Republic.
Blueprint, with an estimated budget of $1.5 million, is expected to cease publication after six or eight issues once the 2000 Presidential campaign gets fully under way. The concept for the magazine came from Donald A. Baer, a former Clinton communications director and former assistant managing editor at U.S. News & World Report who is close to Mr. Gore. He is the magazine's senior editorial consultant.
Despite the Gore loyalists on the staff, the magazine does not hew to all of his policy positions. Though Mr. Gore has been mounting aggressive appeals to labor and liberal constituencies to help him in the Democratic primaries, articles in the magazine suggest that people who regularly use computers on the job have become more important politically than union members. Another article said Democratic candidates no longer have to gear their appeals to the left in the primaries.
For all its focus on the post-Clinton era, Blueprint carefully avoids injecting itself into the scandal that has engulfed the White House and that has left Mr. Gore's advisers unsettled.
Seeking to frame the scandal in positive terms for centrist Democrats, Mr. From and Will Marshall, the top officials of the leadership council and its spinoff policy institute, wrote, "President Clinton's ability to sustain support throughout much of his Presidency -- despite the miasma of scandals and investigations that hangs over Washington -- shows that Americans are ready to reward pragmatic problem-solving over reflexive partisanship."

HEADLINE: Texans Call Terror Suspect Apolitical

BYLINE: By RICK LYMAN 

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Tex., Sept. 19

 BODY:
By the accounts of those who worked for him at a ramshackle Fort Worth tire shop and lived near him in a rundown apartment block on a dead-end street here in Arlington, about a mile from the stately mosque where he prayed every Friday, Wadih el Hage was even-tempered, devout and utterly apolitical.
"I was shocked when I heard that he was arrested for being part of these terrorists," said Mahmoud Mazouni, who worked for Mr. el Hage at Lone Star Wheels & Tires and now is trying to run the place until his boss' return. "He never said anything political. Never. You know, he had a wife and seven children, and he was worrying for them all the time. That is what he talked about." 
 Mr. el Hage, 38, was arrested in New York on Wednesday night by Federal officials who said he was a close associate of Osama bin Laden, once serving as the wealthy Saudi financier's private secretary, and of many other members of Al Quaeda, the alleged terrorist organization run by Mr. Bin Laden that Federal officials say is responsible for the bombing of two United States embassies in Africa last month.
Mr. el Hage is the first American citizen to be charged with being part of Mr. Bin Laden's terrorist network.
"I just can't believe that it's true," said Mary Silburn, the manager of the Campus South Apartments in Arlington, where Mr. el Hage lived with his wife, April Ray, and their four sons and three daughters, ages 12 years to 3 months. "They were very nice, ordinary people."
Mr. el Hage's three-bedroom apartment, for which he paid $510 a month, is halfway down a dark, first-floor corridor in a whitewashed, two-story building surrounded by old, rusted cars.
"I have no idea what's going on," his wife said Thursday night, shortly after she had been informed of her husband's arrest. "I'm pretty much shell-shocked. I just barely heard what's going on, and I'm having a hard time dealing with it."
Ms. Silburn said the apartment complex was overrun with reporters and television crews on Friday, though Mr. el Hage's family declined to talk to anyone. Today, no one was answering the door at the apartment, and Ms. Silburn asked reporters to leave the family alone and get off the property.
"She is a proper Muslim wife, so she does not want to say anything, you understand," Mr. Mazouni said. "Her feeling is, if you have a question for my husband, you must ask him."
Mr. el Hage is being held without bail in New York, charged with two counts of lying to Federal officials in their investigations of Mr. Bin Laden's organization. Officials said more charges against Mr. el Hage were likely to be filed in the coming week. Thus far, he has not been charged with any complicity in the Aug. 7 bombings of the American embassies in Nairobi and Dar es Salaam, which left 258 people dead, including 12 Americans.
Federal officials described Mr. el Hage as a Lebanese Christian who had converted to Islam.
The authorities said Mr. el Hage, who had lived in the Forth Worth area in the 1980's, was with Mr. Bin Laden in the Sudan in 1994, acting as his private secretary. That year, Mr. el Hage moved to Kenya, where he established a gem business and was in contact with other associates of Mr. Bin Laden. One of them, Haroun Fazil, who shared a house with Mr. el Hage in Nairobi, played a role in the Aug. 7 bombings, officials said.
Federal have offered a $2 million reward for information leading to the capture of Mr. Fazil.
Mr. el Hage returned to the United States in 1997 where he has lived, it is believed, in modest apartments in the same neighborhood near the University of Texas Arlington campus.
In the financial affidavit that Mr. el Hage completed at the time of his arrest, he said that his wife was unemployed, that his earnings at the tire store were $1,600 a month and that the only items of value that he owned were a 1981 Honda Prelude and a 1984 Chevy Caprice.
"He has one big car for the children and one little car for himself," Mr. Mazouni said.
Tarrant County officials said on Friday that in 1986, when he was living in a working-class neighborhood on the north side of Fort Worth, Mr. el Hage was charged with writing $2,400 worth of worthless checks to 22 businesses in a little more than a week.
Before a hearing, Mr. el Hage disappeared, but resurfaced in 1992 and posted a $500 bond before disappearing again, officials said. In 1993, the case was closed and the file stamped "the defendant has never been apprehended," the Fort Worth Star-Telegram reported.
How Mr. el Hage found his way into Mr. Bin Laden's employ is unclear, but he was known to anti-terrorist officials by the time he was living in Nairobi in the mid-1990's.
Mr. el Hage was questioned by Federal agents in October 1997, after his return to Texas, and again on Aug. 20, two weeks after the embassy bombings. He is charged with lying to the authorities during those interrogations about his knowledge of some of the principals in the Quaeda organization and faces five years in prison on each of the two counts.
Mr. el Hage had managed his business in partnership with Braham Kheidar, the owner of another tire shop, A-Quality Tires and Wheels, in nearby Arlington, Mr. Mazouni said. A worker at the Arlington shop said today that Mr. Kheidar was out of town and could not be reached.
Today, Mr. Mazouni looked around the dark, musty tire ship on a commercial stretch of Fort Worth's industrial east side and said he did not know how long he would have to run the place by himself.
"I was here with my television on when the news of the bombings came on the air," Mr. Mazouni said. "When Mr. el Hage came into the shop, I asked him if he had heard about it, and he said yes, but he showed no emotion and said no more about it. He didn't act like a man who had been involved in it."
Mr. el Hage's business cards were still lying on a rack on the tire shop's counter, each one stamped "$2 off next visit," just a few yards from the spot where he knelt and prayed five times each day.
He had left the shop on Monday afternoon and told Mr. Mazounithat he was flying to New York for business but would return in two or three days. Mr. Mazouni did not know that his employer of six months was responding to a Federal subpoena, and did not know of his arrest until informed by reporters on Thursday.
"He was always very quiet, very calm," Mr. Mazouni said. "Who knows what is going on? Only God knows, as we say in Islam. Not the F.B.I., not the journalists. Only God."

HEADLINE: In Land of Home Rule, An Uncommon Merger

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: WEST NEW YORK, N.J., Sept. 18

 BODY:
In this densely populated town in northern Hudson County, where municipalities bunch up like boxcars in a train wreck, Dan McEldowney would often sit outside Engine Company No. 1, where he works, and watch the fire trucks from adjacent North Bergen barreling by toward fires on that town's eastern end.
That North Bergen's firefighters have to go through West New York to get to sections of their own town on the Hudson River has long been a fact of life here. But it has never made much sense to Mr. McEldowney and others. 
 "It was crazy, because we would be closer to some of those fires than they were," he said, shaking his head. "We would just wave at them as they went past."
Now, with the encouragement of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's administration, the Mayors of four tightly packed municipalities in the area have embraced a plan to consolidate fire services, to save money and to lower or at least stabilize property taxes.
The plan, formally introduced last Wednesday at the Town Council meetings of West New York, Union City, Weehawken and North Bergen, would cut nearly $5 million from the towns' fire service budgets, which now total $25 million. The job now being done by 347 firefighters would eventually be done by 302, and the area's 19 firehouses and 59 pieces of equipment would eventually decrease as well.
The proposal has made the area the poster child of Mrs. Whitman's campaign to encourage local governments to consolidate services, which she says could result in a savings of about $1.2 billion and lower local property taxes statewide.
In accepting the report by her Property Tax Commission, she rejected shifting local costs to the state, as many had urged, and instead offered a package of $35 million in incentives for local and regional consolidations. And at a news conference in Trenton, she singled out Mayor Albio Sires of West New York and his fellow Mayors for their willingness to take such steps.
In this, the most densely populated section of the nation's most densely populated state, consolidation would seem to fly in the face of New Jersey's history of home rule. Addition, and not subtraction, has been the predominant municipal math -- there are 566 municipalities, 611 school districts and more than 400 local authorities in the state's 21 counties. If this has succeeded in forging distinct local identities, it has also contributed to the state's having the nation's highest average local property taxes.
And that northern Hudson County, of all places, should be blazing a trail toward consolidation has prompted bemusement among many in the state for other reasons. The area's storied past has included such colorful characters as the political boss Frank Hague, whose machinations made area politics as byzantine as its boundary lines are serpentine. Patronage, turf wars and political corruption have been the hallmark here, not government efficiency.
"Everybody plays the game, but we get the name," said Union City's Mayor, Rudy Garcia, lamenting the area's reputation for corruption. "I wasn't even born when that stuff was going on, and the truth is that we in this area have been progressive for a long time because our relatively low incomes have challenged us to find savings without increasing taxes. The real question to me is, why isn't it happening in places other than northern Hudson?"
The desire to personalize services helps explain why fragmentation has been more common than consolidation, many local officials said. And once in office, those same officials have a vested interest in maintaining their ability to control, and get credit for services.
James E. McGreevey, the Democratic Mayor of Woodbridge Township in Middlesex County, said that while consolidation was "good public policy," few had been able to square the political risks with the fiscal benefits. The Governor's incentives had done little to alter that situation, he said, adding: "Municipalities are not going to rush to merge themselves out of existence."
Barbara Cannon, the Mayor of Old Bridge Township in Middlesex County and chairman of the Property Tax Commission, said one problem was that people tended to see consolidation as synonymous with disappearing. That need not be the case, and she predicted that economies from consolidation would wind up looking different all over the state. As an example, she pointed to her town, where the local school district and the various public works and fire departments had consolidated their vehicle fuel-purchase operations in a town-built fuel dump.
Many communities consolidate their recycling programs at the county level, but that is the outgrowth of another broader consolidation in the state that left a bad taste in the mouths of many localities. New Jersey's nearly 20-year-old program of waste flow control, which established county entities to control waste disposal of all of their towns, was found unconstitutional by Federal courts, but for years many local officials viewed this consolidation as both costly and inefficient.
John Rooney, the Mayor of Northvale in Bergen County and a critic of that system, said that unlike flow control, the consolidations encouraged under the Governor's proposals were voluntary and mirrored things that local governments have been asking the state to help promote.
Mayor Sires of West New York said that he and the other Mayors had few misgivings about consolidating their fire departments. The adjacent town of Guttenberg, however, chose not to. Weehawken, West New York, North Bergen and Union City are scheduled to vote Sept. 30 on the plan, which would establish a single department called the North Hudson Regional Fire Department.
More than 165,000 people live in the 80-by-30 block area of the four municipalities. The idea of consolidation had been studied and restudied since the 60's, but it was not until a new generation of Mayors, all in their 40's, began to replace longtime incumbents that the process took hold. The other two Mayors are Richard Turner of Weehawken and Nicholas J. Sacco of North Bergen.
It was the opposition of Mr. Sires's predecessor, Anthony M. DeFino, a 24-year incumbent, that was the last barrier to fall away when Mr. Sires succeeded him three years ago.
Still, the legacy of the past dies hard, and in proposing a five-member commission to run the fire services, the Mayors put in a requirement that there be a "super majority" of four-to-one to approve most actions. It was a recognition, Mayor Sires said, that politics can still be "hardball," and is often a "team sport" with coalitions arrayed against a single opponent.
Also, in pressing the plan, the Mayors were determined not to alienate the politically powerful firefighters' unions -- all eight of them among the four towns -- by promising to use attrition, retirements and buyouts in cutting personnel.
The result, said Joseph McLean, a 17-year veteran of the West New York Fire Department, is that the unions like the plan and younger members of the various departments see it as opening up chances for advancement that were few in the smaller units.
"Plus, it means greater safety because under the plan there will be twice as many firefighters responding to a fire than there are now," he said. "They aren't forcing something on anybody, because it makes sense."
Among the incentives announced by Governor Whitman was one to promote consolidations by giving localities state funds to assist in offering early retirement and buyout packages.
"We have been heading in that direction," Mayor Sires said, "but the Governor's plan for early retirement incentives is a real boost for what we are doing."

HEADLINE: Jet Crash Raises Question: Are Cockpit Crews Large Enough?

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Even before anyone knows what caused the fire that brought down Swissair Flight 111 off Nova Scotia on Sept. 2, aviation experts are debating whether the 229 people who died would have had a better chance in a plane with a cockpit crew of three, not two, and whether the airlines' continuing drive to economize with automation and smaller crews has taken a toll on safety.
Investigators in Halifax, Nova Scotia, hinted on Thursday that the investigation was still far from complete. But a suspicion persists among some experts that the computers that replaced the flight engineer on the Swissair jet, a McDonnell Douglas MD-11, left the captain and first officer without a colleague who could troubleshoot or innovate in a crisis. Others, though, say the difficulties faced by Flight 111 -- and its failure to descend immediately -- made the size of the crew irrelevant. 
Flight engineers, who keep track of a jet's fuel flow, engine performance and other details, are usually pilots-in-training. With an engineer, "you've got that pilot mind there, a second pair of eyes, and he's not that busy, he's not wrestling with the airplane," said Donald M. Tynan, a retired American Airlines pilot who once confronted a smoke emergency in flight. On Nov. 15, 1979, on a flight from Chicago to National Airport in Washington, a bomb exploded in the baggage hold of his Boeing 727, filling the plane with smoke.
Mr. Tynan said he was able to assign the other pilot to communications, fly the plane himself and dispatch the engineer to the passenger cabin to assess the situation. Experts say a captain is much less likely to send a crew member outside the cockpit if there are only two of them.
In that case, the engineer saw smoke filling the cabin and called for an immediate landing; Captain Tynan brought the plane down at the nearest airport, Dulles, so fast that, by his own account, he never got clearance from air traffic control, came too close to a plane already on the runway, and broke a Federal Aviation Administration speed limit on the way down. But 12 of his passengers suffered smoke inhalation; any delay, he said, and it would have been much worse.
Another oft-cited example of an extra crew member saving the day is the July 1989 crash of a United Airlines DC-10 near Sioux City, Iowa, after an engine disintegrated in flight and severed the hydraulic system. A training pilot who was traveling in the passenger cabin came forward to join the three-member flight crew, and figured out that some control could be obtained by varying the speed of the two remaining engines. Without that novel technique -- which required an extra person to manipulate separately the two throttles that are normally moved together -- experts believe that everyone aboard would have died; in the end, 112 died and 184 survived.
But three-person cockpits are a historical artifact now -- all the manufacturers have eliminated the flight engineer. The Boeing 747 was one of the last holdouts, but the current version, the 747-400, flies with a crew of two.
The flight engineer contributes to safety, said Dr. Earl L. Wiener, an expert on human factors in aviation and an emeritus professor at the department of management science at the University of Miami. "He may be the most mechanically sophisticated of the three people in the cockpit," Dr. Wiener said. And if there is any thought to pulling up the hatch cover behind the captain's chair and looking down into the electronics bay beneath the cockpit, where investigators think the Swissair fire may have occurred, a three-person crew is much more likely to do that, he said.
But Dr. Wiener added that captains never find it easy to supervise flight engineers, who sit over their right shoulders, and the dynamics of three people working together are more difficult than with two.
Robert van der Linden, the Smithsonian's curator for air transportation, said the flight engineer was doomed by the airlines' demands for lower operating costs and the arrival of computers that can do the work of engineers. "A third man wouldn't have made a whit of difference" in the Swissair accident, he said. "He'd have died, too."
Mr. van der Linden and others say that what killed the pilots and their passengers was not immediately recognizing the severity of their problem. Investigators in Halifax said on Thursday that the cockpit voice recorder showed the first mention of a smell of smoke about 3 minutes before the crew sent its first distress call, or 13 minutes before communications ceased, and 19 minutes before the crash, relatively short periods for a plane flying at an altitude of six miles, over water.
The smell of smoke in airplanes is not rare, pilots say, and they often hesitate to begin descent, for fear of crying wolf. Captain Tynan, who broke rules and saved his passengers and plane, had the advantage of hearing the bomb explode and knowing quickly that there was a problem; more often, smoke is slowly recognized and turns out to be minor.
"For me, the last time, it was a Pop-Tart," said another MD-11 pilot, who spoke on the condition his name not be used. Someone had left it in a galley oven too long, he said.
Another MD-11 pilot said that the computers that effectively replaced the flight engineer were very useful in an emergency landing. The fuel dump system, for example, automatically sets itself to get the plane down to maximum landing weight; the pilot has only to push one button, one time. And no matter what the weight, the computers tell the pilots what the minimum safe air speed is, automatically taking into account flap position and other factors.
At Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, in Prescott, Ariz., William D. Waldock, the associate director of the university's Center for Aerospace Safety Education, said that no matter how many people had been in the Swissair 111 cockpit, the problem was the confusing situation.
"I don't think either one of them thought they had that serious a problem," he said. "By the time it got upgraded to a point where the captain's beginning to think he's got a real emergency, probably it was past the point where a third person would have made a difference."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 18; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1540 words

HEADLINE: Experts Question Roving Flow of Global Capital

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 19

 BODY:
They were the world's richest and shrewdest investors, and they rode a wave of globalization to buy bonds in a promising developing country. When the country defaulted, they were livid. 
 "There should be lunatic asylums for nations as well as individuals," one investor wrote in The Morning Post of London, denouncing the defaulting country as "a nation with whom no contracts can be made."
It all sounds a bit familiar, but the year was 1842 and the developing country was the United States. After defaults by Maryland, Pennsylvania, Mississippi and Louisiana, the entire United States was blacklisted and scorned on global markets, with Americans barred from the best London clubs and the Rothschilds warning bitterly that America would be unable to "borrow a dollar, not a dollar."
Globalization, in other words, may not be quite as fresh as it sometimes seems. Since at least the 13th century, when Florentine merchants lent money to the English to pay for King Edward I's wars, international capital has roamed the world in search of high returns. (The start was inauspicious: England defaulted, causing the collapse of two Florentine banks.)
What has changed, economists say, is the scale of the capital flows and their ability to capsize small nations -- or even large ones. Many experts say that one factor behind the economic crisis that has devastated Asia and Russia, wobbled South America, and now come knocking on America's own door is the fantastic increase in the pool of capital that sloshes from one country to the next in search of safety and profit.
The sums are so gargantuan -- far greater than the amounts that governments can wield -- that a growing number of economists are calling for new steps to control these capital flows or at least soften their impact. Some say that the Bretton Woods economic system, which has governed the global economy for half a century, has been eclipsed by these vast pools of capital, and there are calls to design a new "architecture" for the global economic order.
The topic is expected to be widely discussed at next month's special meeting of finance ministers and central bankers from the Group of Seven industrialized countries, summoned by President Clinton to discuss the global crisis. Japan's Finance Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, has already discussed measures to ease the volatility of capital flows with Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and with his British counterpart, Gordon Brown.
The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, weighed in this week with a denunciation of rigid capital controls but a call to confront the problem by tightening supervision over banks that engage in international finance. All of a sudden, a vigorous debate is under way, and it may shape the global economy for decades to come.
"We'll have to rethink the system in a big way," said Jagdish Bhagwati, a prominent scholar of international economics at Columbia University. "The President has called this conference, and it should be the start of that process."
Professor Bhagwati urged that the new architecture should "give up the notion that the optimal world is one characterized by free capital flows, by capital account convertability, where you just press a button and take out a billion."
The Clinton Administration has led a global push to free the flow of capital around the world, and any new impediments to capital flows would be an abrupt step back for its campaign. As recently as last March, the International Monetary Fund newsletter carried a front-page headline cheerily declaring capital liberalization to be "an irreversible trend."
These days, it looks more reversible. Some economists believe that despite a wealth of scholarly research showing the need for caution, the United States pushed too hard for capital liberalization. The result, they say, was that tides of investment flooded into ill-prepared developing countries and created speculative bubbles, and then surged out, leaving behind shattered nations and a global financial crisis.
"I actually think the I.M.F. was too pushy in going around the accepted wisdom and encouraging countries to liberalize their capital accounts too soon," said Ronald I. McKinnon, an economist at Stanford University and author of a book on capital liberalization. "And not the least of the reasons behind this was arm-twisting by the United States Treasury, which always wants American banks and Wall Street people to be in there, competing freely."
Still, there is no question that freer capital flows have brought tremendous benefits to the global economy, as well as perils. Some places, like Hong Kong, have opened themselves to capital flows without restriction and are examples of the prosperity that free movements of capital can reap. Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, likens the flows to jet planes, observing that jets bring enormous efficiencies and benefits to the world -- but that the crashes are more spectacular than ever.
What are these capital flows?
They are not some sinister force, but simply the result of ordinary people's cash roaming in search of a good return. When an American deposits money at the corner bank, some of that may end up being lent to a Brazilian company, and the same person's pension fund may dabble in the Hong Kong stock market.
In the United States, trading in foreign securities amounted to 2 percent of gross national product in 1975 and 213 percent last year, according to data from the Bank for International Settlements.
Paradoxically, historians sometimes attribute the modern boom in international capital, beyond the easy reach of any regulator, to the Communists. In the 1950's, China and Russia kept their dollars out of the United States, for fear Washington would freeze their accounts, and instead deposited the dollars in Europe.
One result was the "Eurodollar" market and a growing investment pool that flitted from country to country and currency to currency in pursuit of higher interest rates. The amount of foreign currency bank deposits around the world reached $1 billion only in 1961 and now is almost $1.5 trillion.
One problem, though, is that a lot of this is "hot money," or short-term flows that are particularly volatile.
Even in the 19th century, sailing ships used to carry gold to distant countries in pursuit of higher interest rates. In 1849, England raised its interest rate by 2 percentage points, prompting an early demonstration of the volatility of capital flows: ships that were already at sea, headed for America with their gold, turned around and sailed to England to get the higher rate.
Most governments imposed capital controls early in this century and then lifted them in the 1970's and 80's, and limitations on changing money came to be seen as quaint. Paradoxically, it is the holdouts with capital controls, like China and India, that have weathered the financial crisis much better than others, because they were not vulnerable to a sudden exodus of capital.
"I've been told, 'China seems to be coming out of the crisis well because it has capital controls, so what's wrong with reimposing controls?' " said Linda Tsao Yang, the American envoy to the Asian Development Bank.
Ms. Yang and other American officials are wary of capital controls, however, particularly the rigid kind imposed by Malaysia that ban most investments from being taken out of the country within the first year. Scholars say that such capital controls offer short-term benefits but tend to discourage investment in the long run and often get mired in corruption and inefficiency.
"There is a significant risk that over the next three or four quarters short-term results from Malaysia will be seen as beneficial," said William R. Cline, the chief economist of the Institute of International Finance in Washington. "An illusory temporary success could tempt other countries to follow suit."
The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development this week backed the right of countries to adopt emergency capital controls like Malaysia's. Even the Far Eastern Economic Review, a conservative Hong Kong-based magazine owned by Dow Jones & Company, declared its sympathy for capital controls in a recent editorial.
"As we look to Malaysia's unorthodoxy," it said, "we hold our nose and cross our fingers."
While Western economists are mostly unimpressed by Malaysia's controls, many speak highly of a quasi tax that Chile has imposed on short-term borrowings from abroad. With that measure, which the country is in the process of dismantling, Chile has been able to attract foreign capital, but has been less vulnerable to a sudden exodus.
The specific proposals that G-7 finance ministers might discuss to deal with capital flows are unclear. But there is vague talk of increasing supervision over borrowing banks and of establishing funds that could be used to insure depositors or counteract speculative attacks.
"Outright controls on the flow of funds are virtually impossible in this modern, integrated world," said Yuji Tsushima, a finance expert in Japan's Parliament. "But we should have some device through which if the volatility of the market gets too disturbing, it could be mitigated."

HEADLINE: THE TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE LOYAL SUPPORTERS;
Clinton Expresses Thanks to Black Americans

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Speaking "from the heart" to some of his most loyal supporters, President Clinton thanked black Americans today for backing him in a time of trouble.
The President opened his remarks at the annual dinner of the Congressional Black Caucus, saying "I want to thank you for standing up for me and understanding the true meaning of repentance and atonement." 
 Mr. Clinton credited black legislators for supporting his policies and helping to promote "this treasured moment of prosperity and progress." But he laid out a long list of challenges yet to be conquered, from containing the global financial crisis to expanding access to health care and eliminating racism.
Over and over, he declared: "We cannot rest. We have work to do."
He listed a number of areas in which minorities are affected disproportionately, including certain health problems and fair housing. And he stressed the importance of making sure the next census does not leave out many minorities.
"This has enormous consequences for how we distribute the bounty of America," he said.
Representative Maxine Waters, Democrat of California, chairwoman of the black caucus, got a standing ovation as she told her organization that while blacks do not always agree with the President, "We support Bill Clinton at this critical moment in his career." She added: "It is because African-Americans are uniquely qualified to know unfairness when we see it."
The President was joined at the black caucus dinner by Vice President Al Gore, who earlier in the evening addressed the Human Rights Campaign dinner of about 2,000 gay and lesbian activists, another group that has remained loyal to Mr. Clinton.
Elizabeth Birch, executive director of the Human Rights Campaign, alluded to the investigation of the President in saying, "Let us not become a nation of hunters and the hunted, a condition that our community knows all too well." She spoke of supporting Clinton "as the President and his family work through this difficult time."
Mr. Gore used his speech to the Human Rights Campaign to urge the Senate to schedule a vote on James Hormel as ambassador to Luxembourg. Senate Republican leaders have blocked a vote to protest what some have called Mr. Hormel's promotion of a "gay life style."
Mr. Gore challenged the Senate to give Mr. Hormel "the up-or-down vote he deserves." He also urged the Congress to approve employment non-discrimination legislation and tougher laws against hate crimes.
At both dinners, Mr. Gore said the Clinton administration had been "one of the most successful administrations in history" for its diversity in Federal appointments.

HEADLINE: Political Briefing;
Wilson's Love-Him, Love-Him-Not Polls

BYLINE: By B. Drummond Ayres Jr. 

 BODY:
Pete Wilson has fought a lot of tough battles in almost eight years as Governor of California. But his toughest fight has always been with the polls.
Despite his respectable successes in pushing through legislative programs, despite his mostly middle-of-the-road brand of Republicanism and despite his impressive come-from-behind re-election victory in 1994, he has never gotten very high job performance ratings from his constituents. 
 With rare exception, they have always viewed him more negatively than positively when approached by poll-takers, with many saying the problem is not so much what he does in office as the dry, hard-edged way he tends to do it.
Polls taken over the last eight years -- and there have been dozens -- have typically found that roughly 35 percent of the respondents give the Governor a poor to very poor job performance rating, compared with only about 27 percent rating him very good to good. Thirty-five percent or so have rated him fair and the remaining 3 percent have been undecided.
But as the Governor prepares to leave office in early 1999, his poll numbers are starting to change, according to the latest survey conducted by the Field Poll, perhaps California's best-known public opinion organization.
Mr. Wilson's negatives versus positives have essentially flip-flopped, with about 35 percent of the respondents now rating his job performance very good to good, compared with less than 30 percent rating it poor to very poor. The fair and the undecided ratings remain about the same.
Why the flip-flop?
The Governor may have mellowed a bit recently. But the real reason for his improved poll numbers, the poll-takers say, is a perception among Californians that with the economy up, crime down, roads better, the environment cleaner and taxes holding steady, life is better in the Golden State -- and Mr. Wilson should get some of the credit.
Still, the pollsters caution the Governor about reading his current numbers as an all-clear for him to run again for President, something he has been considering.
Californians didn't want him to run in 1996 and, according to the new Field Poll, close to two of every three don't want him to try it again in 2000.
Without biggest-of-all California, a second Wilson candidacy almost certainly would be doomed, too.

HEADLINE: Inyourface the Nation

BYLINE: By James Traub; James Traub, a contributing writer for the magazine, most recently wrote about Nathan Glazer.

 BODY:
It's 3 P.M., Monday, Aug. 17. President Clinton is in the White House Map Room, testifying, and Chris Matthews, the flaxen-haired, pink-faced, know-it-all and occasionally unhinged host of "Hardball With Chris Matthews," is sitting in his office in the Washington quarters of CNBC, scarfing a basket of Wendy's fried chicken. For Matthews, this is the Day of Days -- to be equaled later, of course, by Sept. 11, the day of the Starr report's release -- and in his excitement he's spraying bits of biscuit on his tie. "Hardball" is one of a half-dozen shows, mostly on cable, that for the past seven months have been Monicamonicamonica. There's "Rivera Live," also on CNBC; "The Big Show" and "The News With Brian Williams" on MSNBC, and "Hannity & Colmes" and "The Crier Report" on Fox News.
It's a Darwinian world out there, and in this jungle of passion and diatribe, Chris Matthews is not about to end up as anybody's lunch. He calls Bill Clinton a liar about a hundred times a night, and he mows down the defenders of the President foolish or desperate or brave enough to appear on the show. There's an almost Rabelaisian zest about Matthews: he lays about him with such indiscriminate excitement that he flattens friend and foe alike. "Hardball" is the most fervent of a fervent lot; it's also probably the most entertaining. 
 Matthews, 52, is a political junkie of classic lineage. A streetwise Catholic kid who grew up in Philadelphia, he was trained by the Jesuit fathers at Holy Cross, served in the Peace Corps (rather than Vietnam) and worked as a speech writer for Jimmy Carter and as an aide and quotemeister for House Speaker Tip O'Neill. He now writes a newspaper column for The San Francisco Examiner and has written a book about Capitol Hill (also called "Hardball") and a perfectly creditable book about the relationship between Nixon and the Kennedys. He is a pol, a moralist and a philosopher. He has more theories than a Yale English professor; he has a theory about why he talks fast, a theory about why he yells and, of course, a theory about our obsessional interest in the President's sex life.
Matthews tends to keep talking until he's interrupted (and beyond), so his theory is rather involved. It goes, in part, as follows:
"The great defining circus of our time was the cold war, which was the great gladiatorial spectacle, Us against Them, Us at home against Us. Every great gladiatorial contest was part of this wonderful, unbelievably stark, Manichaean struggle. And that went away. The bad guys are gone. Now you have bread; you have bread like you've never had it. Bill Clinton thought it was just about bread, he was convinced it was bread -- give these people their market, give them their Dow, give them their unemployment rate down to 4, 3. Bread! But there's something missing, something we need to have in our life, something gladiatorial, something Kulturkampf, the big question, who we are, who's in, who's out, who's right, who's wrong. Hey, O.J. came along. And Lady Di came along for working women. That stunned me. That story was a Roman candle: it only lasted a week and a half or two, but it was really hot. Why do we have these things? We want to be tested. Think about the Roman Empire, about the circuses of Nero. Think about a circus as establishing a society's tests -- who's in, who's out, who's part of us, who's not part of us, what kind of country do we want to live in? I haven't figured this out yet, obviously. It's a great metaphor."
Or, possibly, it's an appalling metaphor that makes for great TV. I asked Matthews if maybe the reason most Americans say they want to hear less, not more, about Monica is that they don't want their politics to be a circus. "Yeah," he conceded, with the air of a man accepting a premise to rebut an inference. "That's the way some people look at it." Several journalists who have appeared on the show told me that they believe Matthews's assault on the President is dictated strictly by ratings, not belief. Matthews angrily denies this. Though he remains at least a semi-chastened liberal, he also describes himself as something of a William Bennett conservative who considers nonchalance toward the President's sexual behavior to be a sign of loose cultural moorings.
And yet, one of the great oddities of the Lewinsky affair is that elites in the media and politics -- the very class that people like Matthews accuse of waging a war against traditional American values -- have been far more exercised about it than the citizens whose views they claim to represent. So if ordinary Americans are not clamoring for more Monica, who is the "we" who need a Kulturkampf? Perhaps it's the media -- that is, perhaps "Hardball" creates Monica, rather than the other way around. The cold war didn't need "Meet the Press" to grab the nation's attention; but O.J. needed Geraldo, and Geraldo, obviously, needed O.J. The nexus between mega-event and talk show has grown ever tighter since the hostage crisis created "Nightline." Now it seems naive to speak of such events as existing independently of their coverage. The shows live from event to event, circus to circus. When Matthews's program was first shown in 1994, on the short-lived America's Talking channel, it was called "In-Depth," a name that already sounds quaint. In this feverish new world, Monica was a godsend; no matter what Matthews says about ratings, it was the scandal that persuaded CNBC to expand "Hardball" from half an hour to an hour in March.
And after Monica? We'll have to have something else -- a new cliffhanger, a new personal drama inflated to apocalyptic proportions.
Talk about "wonderful" -- on the day of Days, CNBC decided to air "Hardball" live rather than taped, in two segments, before and after the President's 10 P.M. speech. Waiting to go on before the speech, Matthews sat in his office, furiously scribbling questions on blue cards. A TV set in the corner showed a fixed image of the White House entrance through which prosecutors were expected to exit -- tedium laced with tension. Matthews felt history floating in the atmosphere; he wanted to be equal to the moment. "My goal for tonight," he told his staff, "is three different levels. We treat the moral, the legal and the political, and we ask ourselves the right questions, as Roger Mudd did back in '74," during Mudd's post-mortem analysis of Richard Nixon's resignation speech.
At 20 minutes till 8, Matthews took the elevator down to the studio and seated himself at a crescent-shaped table. His guests for the first hour included Stuart Taylor, the respected legal journalist and a harsh critic of the President; Ron Nessen, the former White House spokesman (for Gerald Ford); Marcia Clark, the former O.J. prosecutor, and Elizabeth Holtzman and Dennis DeConcini, former members of Congress. The Monica shows have been a tremendous boon to former everythings. The cable programs have so much air time to fill -- Matthews alone runs through 50 guests a week -- that they often have to rely on people with only the kind of hypothetical expertise conferred by resumes.
Matthews opened solemnly. The ultimate question, he said, was, "Can the chief law-enforcement agent of the nation play with the truth and still lead the nation?" Then, with the magic words, "Let's play hardball!" the circus began. Stuart Taylor said reports indicated that the President would admit in his speech to "some sort of sexual relationship" with Lewinsky, and that he had not been "completely candid about it." Matthews jumped on him. "Why do you use terms like 'some sort of' and 'completely?"' Taylor was on Matthews's side, but he had made the mistake of stating the case in neutral terms. On "Hardball" there is no middle. If you have trouble with that, you don't get invited back. "He lied," Taylor said, dropping the legalistic phrase. "We all know he lied."
The gladiatorial combat that gives "Hardball" its faintly sadistic appeal is not, interestingly, between the guests but between the host and his guests. Matthews is a gleeful warrior, by turns mocking, witty, high-minded and bullying. Even if he doesn't know more than his guests, he can generally out-argue them; and when he can't do that, he can just talk them into the ground. Now he turned to Marcia Clark, in Los Angeles, and said, "He's now saying that the kind of sex he had with Monica Lewinsky did not constitute sexual relations, and it seems to me by that definition, Hugh Grant should be exonerated for what happened to him on the Sunset Strip several months back, and every hooker that's picked up on Broadway tonight for selling sex should be exonerated." Clark had battled wits with Johnnie Cochran, but Matthews reduced her to an equivocal stammer.
By now, Matthews didn't need his guests at all. He turned to the camera and shouted: "I'd like to suggest that in every household and every car pool and every barroom in America, and every party you've been to in the past seven months, there's been somebody who's spoken up for the President and said, 'I believe he didn't have this relationship.' All of those people are part of the recruited, commissioned and put-in-the-field army of Clinton liars. He has made them all into liars. . .and tonight he better come on and apologize to those people." It was a majestic outburst, at least if you hate President Clinton. If you didn't, it was just plain menacing. Then he cut to Elizabeth Holtzman in New York, a staunch Presidential defender, and reduced her to waving her hands and saying, "Chris . . . Chris . . . Chris" as he buried her beneath a torrent of words.
Afterwards, back in his office, Matthews looked out the window and said: "I got too emotional. What happened out there?" What happened to restraint -- the whole rising-to-the-moment thing? Matthews genuinely would like to give off light as well as heat, but some combination of intellectual vanity, lack of table manners and sheer passion does him in every time. Of course, that's why he's on the air. If you want depth, you can read a book.

GRAPHIC: Photo: (Jill Greenberg for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Books in Brief: Nonfiction

BYLINE: By Christina Cho 

 BODY:

Something to Declare
By Julia Alvarez.
Algonquin, $20.95. 
 The experience of enduring the disorientations of learning a new culture informs "Something to Declare," a collection of personal essays by the poet and novelist Julia Alvarez, who emigrated at the age of 10 from the Dominican Republic to the United States. With admirable candor and gentle touches of humor, she describes her struggles with cultural hybridism, historical and personal memory, the English language and the effects of all these on her literary career, which became for her an endless language lesson, an endless exploration of "how words can contain and hold and pinpoint experience." But while these essays offer a highly accessible introduction to Alvarez's work, much of their substance has been better expressed in her other work. She defines "Something to Declare" as a response to queries from her readers, since "I could not really say to any of them, 'Read my novels or my poems or my stories.' These folks wanted what my boarding-school housemother used to call a straight answer." What gets lost in translation, so to speak, is the graceful fusion of lush imagery and poetic economy that emerges in her fiction and poems. These essays merely retread the familiar terrain of Alvarez's finer work, which has rendered superfluous hundreds of pages of straight answers. Christina Cho

HEADLINE: The Work Must Go On

BYLINE: By Leonard Garment; Leonard Garment was counsel to President Richard Nixon and is the author of "Crazy Rhythm," a memoir about Watergate.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Ihad lunch with President Clinton last week. Well, not quite. I was at the counter of a pizza parlor next door to my office, wolfing down a slice to the accompaniment of the restaurant's television set, which was tuned to cable news. Mr. Clinton was on the screen, but his voice was inaudible in the bedlam of the restaurant. He was addressing the National Farmers' Union and saying something about providing emergency financing to farmers.
I was more interested in the television image: the President's handsome head bobbing and weaving from side to side, the picture of a cheerful, vigorous, buoyantly confident man. It seemed surreal. This man is in trouble? You can't be serious. 
 President Clinton is of course in the deepest trouble, sliding steadily toward impeachment proceedings. It is impossible to know whether he will dig himself out, how long the drama will drag on, and what effect the distractions and anxieties of the gathering storm may have on the nation's business. I have seen the process before -- as counsel to Richard Nixon in 1973 and 1974 during the decline and fall of his Presidency.
The course of the Nixon Administration's dissolution after the Watergate break-in was nasty, brutish and very long. During Nixon's last two years in office, he suffered the forced resignations of his principal aides, Bob Haldeman and John Ehrlichman; the conviction of John Mitchell, his friend, law partner, Attorney General and campaign chief; the discovery and release of the humiliating and incriminating White House tapes, and the forced resignation of his Vice President.
These blows left Nixon desperately wounded, yet he considered the prospect of leaving the Presidency before finishing his term an unacceptable shame. Even after impeachment was inevitable, Nixon struggled to survive in the only life he considered worth living. For the last year of his Presidency he was imprisoned, psychologically and politically, in Watergate.
Yet the world did not stand still. This was a time of international change and crisis. There was detente to be implemented, China to be opened, a Vietnam peace to be maintained. In 1973 the Middle East erupted in war and there was an Arab oil boycott, which rocked the world economy.
Watergate severely diminished Nixon's ability to deal with these crises. It virtually destroyed the prestige and power of his Presidency. By 1974 his standing among foreign leaders, once pre-eminent, was reduced to a pantomime of ceremonial courtesies. The historic foreign policy structure that Nixon and his national security adviser, Henry Kissinger, had painstakingly assembled during their first term became a hollow shell. The fragile peace in Vietnam soon collapsed.
Watergate also depleted Nixon's energy and distorted his judgment. Monica Crowley, whose biography, "Nixon in Winter," chronicles the former President's last years, says he repeatedly told her that his judgment was "off" as a consequence of his bitter and exhausting effort to survive.
The night Nixon called me to the White House after midnight simply to hear a long, furious denunciation of a leak of one of his tapes epitomized his distraction from his Presidential duties. Watergate was the order of the day every day until the end.
President Clinton and his senior political advisers are alert students of Presidential history, and their response to his present crisis is no exception. Even as the nation awaits release today of videotapes of Mr. Clinton's testimony under oath, he seems determined to ignore the scandals and hammer away at national issues, raise campaign money and rally his political supporters.
The subtext in each event is clear. The President met with Vaclav Havel last week to confer about Europe. Peace is fragile, Mr. Clinton was saying; the President's resignation would increase the peril. Another emerging theme is that the global economy is in great danger, and that impeachment would add grievously to the threat of economic instability.
A newcomer to national attention, Chaka Fattah, a black Democratic Representative from Pennsylvania, is arguing on many cable news shows that the impeachment of President Clinton could cause the loss of two to four million American jobs, a burden that would be visited disproportionately on African-Americans and the poor. In a show of forensic chutzpah, Mr. Fattah supported this thesis by asserting that Nixon's resignation caused a similar rise in unemployment.
Will Mr. Clinton's strategy work? This President has the advantage of job approval ratings higher than Nixon enjoyed and an economy that is more robust. Mr. Clinton has the added asset of a temperament far different from Nixon's. Nixon could not lie without betraying acute embarrassment; Clinton is -- well, different. Nixon brought to the Presidential office a collection of angers and resentments that seriously distorted his political calculations. Mr. Clinton bears fewer of these deforming wounds.
Still, over time, it is certain that the pressures will take their toll, even on a President as sturdy as Mr. Clinton. For this reason, the country has to begin an orderly process for resolution of the charges against him. We cannot achieve closure overnight. Some Congressmen, pundits and editorial writers have begun to call for the President's resignation -- but that, in Nixon's immortal words, would be wrong. The country is not yet ready for such a trauma.
The constitutional process should go forward, and though this formula may seem like a conventional piety, it is not. The impeachment process -- the consideration, the hearings, the drafting of impeachment articles, the debate and vote -- take time, and that time is needed for the country to consider its options.
This purgatory will impose painful human costs, but they can be borne. The other night I ran into a member of a major regulatory commission, a supporter of the President and the First Lady since their first national campaign. He was dismayed by the current mess. "What would you do?" he asked me.
"No anguished press conferences," I said without hesitation. "No resignations on principle. Just keep working."
I was surprised at my swift certainty. But, then, I've been there. As Watergate's clouds gathered and swelled over the Nixon Administration, people on the inside had to decide each day whether to keep working or to detach themselves from their jobs and from the President. His problems increased the nation's problems, which was all the more reason that those of us who chose to stay and cope never regretted it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed
