HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
TrueNorth's new unit aims to reach ethnic households, which have money to spend.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
A GIANT agency company is stepping up its efforts in multicultural marketing, forming a unit devoted to encouraging advertisers to keep pace with the changing face of consumers by increasing sales pitches aimed at ethnic groups.
The unit, New America Strategies Group, is being introduced by True North Communications in Chicago, the world's sixth-largest agency company, with estimated billings of $10.8 billion handled by units like Bozell Worldwide and Foote, Cone & Belding. The start-up is timed to coincide with a three-day conference, beginning tomorrow in Chicago, that describes ethnic marketing as a "gateway to America's trillion-dollar growth markets," which include black, Hispanic and Asian-American consumers. 
 As part of the conference, sponsored by True North and the Strategic Research Institute in New York, New America Strategies Group will share results of a study analyzing household shopping and spending propensities of multicultural and white families.
The most intriguing initial finding of the study is that household spending of multicultural families, on purchases deemed essential and discretionary, is growing faster than for white families in 10 of 13 categories in a New America Market Basket Index, which include vehicle purchases, clothing and utilities.
"Multicultural Americans are in many ways the growth engine of the economy," said Alfred L. Schreiber, who becomes managing partner of New America Strategies Group, based in New York.
"C.E.O.'s who can manage change will be the winners," he added. "And one of the biggest coming changes is the rise of what we call the New America, which probably offers the best opportunity for companies for organic growth."
True North is joining a lengthening list of mainstream agency companies that are devoting additional resources to multiethnic marketing. For instance, Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York, which already owns shops specializing in advertising aimed at Hispanic and Asian-American consumers, is acquiring operations of One World Communications, a unit of Leap Group in Chicago dedicated to multicultural marketing.
Those intensifying activities have stirred irritation and anxiety among the smaller, independent agencies -- many of which are owned by members of minorities -- that have long focused on the ethnic market.
"There are a number of outstanding ethnic agencies and I applaud them," said Charles D. Peebler Jr., president of True North and chairman and chief executive of True North Diversified Companies, the division under which New America Strategies Group will operate.
"But we are looking at the broader, total multicultural picture," he added, "which marketers have yet to give the substantial time and attention they should be."
The new unit is offering clients a planning tool called the Multicultural Marketing Opportunity Model, intended to analyze the return on investment of initiatives aimed at ethnic consumers.
New America Strategies Group will comprise three agencies and a marketing consulting company. These are the agencies:
*Siboney USA in New York, which specializes in advertising, direct marketing, promotion and public relations directed at Spanish-speaking consumers. Siboney, which also has offices in Dallas, Los Angeles and Miami, has billings estimated at $50 million from clients like the Colgate-Palmolive Company and Mastercard International.
*Stedman Graham & Partners in Chicago and New York, which specializes in marketing communications campaigns aimed primarily at African-Americans. The agency, founded in 1996 as Graham Gregory Bozell, works for such advertisers as Johnson & Johnson and Merrill Lynch & Company.
*Admerasia in New York, an affiliate of True North that creates campaigns in languages including Chinese, Indian, Japanese, Korean, Russian and Vietnamese for marketers like the American Express Company and the Citibank unit of Citicorp.
The consulting-company component of the new unit is Skunkworks Marketing Lab in New York, whose clients include the AT&T Corporation and the Coca-Cola Company.
New America Strategies Group will be overseen by a partners board. The members are: Mr. Peebler, 62; Mr. Schreiber, 52, who is also executive vice president and general manager at Graham; Stedman Graham, 47, chairman and chief executive at Graham; Jose M. Cubas, 68, chairman at Siboney; Richard Mascolo, 43, president at Skunkworks, and Val Zammit, 51, president and chief operating officer at True North Diversified Companies.
The market basket study, developed in alliance with the Demograph Corporation, a management consulting company in Miami, concluded that spending by multicultural households has grown 17.8 percent from 1995 to 1998, compared with an increase of 13.1 percent for white households in the same period.
The categories in which the growth rate in spending in multicultural households most exceeded the growth rate in spending in white households were entertainment, vehicle purchases and health care. As a sign of upward mobility among ethnic consumers, the study showed, spending has been shifting from public transportation to purchasing vehicles and from rental housing to homeowning.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Double Bind in Nebraska: Farming and a Marriage

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
It's a delicate matter. Juanita and Darrel Buschkoetter are not made-for-television characters whom a reviewer can kick around without getting personal. They are a young Nebraska farm couple, parents of three, whose ordeal of dry weather with its crop of economic and emotional troubles is the subject of "The Farmer's Wife."
David Sutherland, the conscientious filmmaker who culled six and a half hours of television from 200 hours of shooting over three years, trains an intimate yet generally unsentimental lens on the Buschkoetters and their children, parents, creditors and others involved in their battle for a way of life and for a marriage. 
 None of them are noticeably put off by the prying cameras or sound equipment, but their collaboration, which invites comparison with the 1973 television portrait of the Loud family, seems to go on forever. Mr. Sutherland demonstrates that given enough time, a likable, hard-working couple on the edge of disaster can make pretty wearing company.
As the title suggests, Juanita Buschkoetter is at the heart of this chronicle of tough going on the Nebraska range. It begins in the spring of 1995, when the couple are battling to hold onto their small farm. "Am I going to be farming this fall or am I going to be forced to sell out?" Darrel asks and keeps asking. "How can it get any worse?"
Wait and see. If you had any doubt about how hard farm families still work, it should be laid to rest as Darrel takes a job in a factory and Juanita hires out as a housekeeper. Darrel says, "Trying to farm at night and work all day for somebody else, it's worse than a living hell." The pressures, which threaten to reduce the pair from independent farmers to a beaten-down peasantry, buffet their marriage. "The Darrel that's on the surface right now," Juanita says, "it's really hard to deal with him." Fortunately, self-esteem counseling is available even in rural Nebraska.
You have to sympathize with the couple's grit and perseverance, but six and a half hours of worries about getting a Government loan (Senator Bob Kerrey helps) and accepting handouts and enduring family nagging is demanding on the audience, too.
The dialogue can be relentlessly real.
Juanita: Do something. You're sitting here in my way.
Darrel: Like what?
Juanita: Take a bath or. . . .
Darrel: How can I take a bath? Can't take a bath yet.
Juanita: Why?
Darrel: Well, the kids running all over the place.
There is plenty of sensitivity on show during these three long nights -- Mr. Sutherland catches all the nuances of pillow talk -- and no resort to the sensationalism that gave the Louds of Santa Barbara their soap-opera appeal. Missing, however, is a compelling narrative.
"The Farmer's Wife," with its unsparing theme, just doesn't produce enough drama to repay watching unless you have a soft spot for in-law spats and domestic bickerings. By the end, when the weather finally improves, the series slips into a feminist fable, with Juanita going to school and finding a fulfilling job and a newly respectful Darrel taking over the housework.
None of this is a criticism of the Buschkoetters. Few lives are made for television, and their troubles deserve attention. Mr. Sutherland has delivered a respectable sociological document. But for six and a half hours, it would be helpful to have a more eventful story to tell or more variety in the telling.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
Is the Global Capitalist System Collapsing?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Last week, the world's best-known money manager, George Soros, warned that the global capitalist system "is coming apart at the seams."
His view reflected the fear -- felt more strongly by investment professionals than by the individual Americans who entrust their money to the pros -- that the global financial system is under the greatest strain it has faced in decades. 
 Mahathir Mohamad, the Malaysian Prime Minister, imposed capital controls to make it harder for investors to take money out of his country, saying he acted because the "free market has failed disastrously." Mr. Soros, a hedge fund manager previously blamed by Mr. Mahathir for causing Asia's problems, did not sound all that different when he testified to Congress. "Instead of acting like a pendulum," he said, "financial markets have recently acted more like a wrecking ball, knocking over one country after another."
That may be overstating it, but there is no question that international investors have grown very worried. The Dow Jones industrial average is down only 15 percent from the peak it reached in July, but virtually every other market in the world has done much worse. There is a flight of capital from emerging markets, and from less solid companies in established markets.
As that has happened, losses have piled up. It should surprise no one that hedge funds such as those managed by Mr. Soros have done poorly. They make money by using leverage -- that is, by borrowing money -- and placing big bets. If the bets go wrong, they can lose big.
But there have also been large losses in established, and one had thought, more conservatively run, financial institutions. Hardly a day goes by that some bank or brokerage firm does not announce it has lost another $100 million or more. The result has been a fast-fall in the prices of financial stocks.
Those losses reflect the fact that derivative securities are far more prevalent than they ever were before. There is nothing inherently bad in such securities. They simply make it possible to buy or sell risks -- of currency moves, or interest rate rises, or lots of other things -- in ways not possible before.
When Russia's Government and its banks essentially defaulted on their debts, some Western banks found that they faced big losses that they thought they had laid off. They had, for example, entered into trades that would compensate their customers if the ruble plunged in value. Then they covered that bet by entering into the opposite trade with a big Russian bank. When the ruble plunged, they lost money in honoring the first guarantee, and could not make up the loss through the second transaction.
Those losses have stunned investors and reminded them that the current accounting system does not allow them to gauge accurately the risks being taken on with derivatives. Managements of financial institutions have responded by being much more careful in taking those risks. There are signs of a global credit crunch, in which only the safest borrowers can get cash at reasonable rates.
At the same time, the confidence in the ability of the International Monetary Fund and the major Western governments to keep things on an even keel has been shaken. The belief that they would somehow protect imprudent investors grew after the Mexican bailout in 1995, and contributed to the flood of money that went into emerging markets in 1996 and 1997. Now that money is coming out, the I.M.F. is nearly broke, and Western governments have done little.
In that atmosphere, it is easy to talk of the disintegration of the world financial system. But it may also be overdone. In a few months, investors may become less risk averse if they see the world has not collapsed.
As for countries, those that most alarmed investors may be having second thoughts. Russia, which had all but repudiated its foreign debt, last week said it was looking for ways to treat foreign investors better. As for Malaysia, after it was done denouncing the global capitalist system, it hired Salomon Smith Barney to try to float an international loan.

HEADLINE: Maui's Mayor to Challenge Cayetano in Governor's Race

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: HONOLULU, Sept. 20

 BODY:
Linda Lingle, the two-time Mayor of Maui, won the Republican nomination for governor by a wide margin on Saturday and will face Gov. Benjamin J. Cayetano, a Democrat, in the general election on Nov. 3.
With 99 percent of the precincts reporting, Ms. Lingle had 105,626 votes, or 69 percent. Her opponent, the five-time Mayor of Honolulu, Frank Fasi, received 46,946 votes, or 31 percent. 
 Mr. Cayetano got 93,012 votes, or 86 percent. His closest competitor, Jim Brewer, got 5,963, for 6 percent.
Ms. Lingle attributed her victory in this overwhelmingly Democratic state to crossover votes and said she would need to hold that support if she hoped to defeat Mr. Cayetano.
"I know many of you in this room are not Republicans," Ms. Lingle said at a victory celebration, "and I know that many of you have never voted for a Republican before, or worked on a campaign for a Republican. This election is not about Republicans and Democrats. It's about the future of our state."
But Mr. Cayetano warned Democrats not to be fooled by Ms. Lingle's statement. "That is exactly what this election is all about," he said. "We Democrats have built this state."
Republicans have not occupied the governor's mansion here since William Quinn left office in 1962. But an economic slide over the last eight years or so has stifled business growth, caused a significant drop in tourism and led to a record number of bankruptcy filings, fueling widespread discontent that Republicans are trying to exploit.
That discontent was demonstrated by the crossover votes. Typically, Democrats get twice as many votes as all other parties combined in Hawaii. But this time more votes were cast for Republican candidates, according to early totals of precinct returns and absentee ballots. Turnout was estimated at 45 percent of registered voters.
Both candidates expect a close race, although recent polls give Ms. Lingle a double-digit edge over Mr. Cayetano. A poll conducted a week ago found Ms. Lingle ahead by 48 percent to 34 percent, with 18 percent undecided. The telephone survey of 800 registered voters was conducted for The Honolulu Advertiser and KHON-TV by Ward Research Inc. on Sept. 9-13. The margin of error was 3.5 percentage points.
Elsewhere on the Democratic side, Senator Daniel K. Inouye, who is in his sixth term, got 89 percent of the vote, easily defeating Richard Thompson, an English teacher.
In the Republican race for Mr. Inouye's Senate seat, Crystal Young, a legislative aide, defeated five opponents with 28 percent of the vote.
Two incumbent Democratic Representatives, Patsy T. Mink and Neil Abercrombie, both earned victories in their primaries.
Mr. Abercrombie will face State Representative Gene Ward. Ms. Mink will face Carol Douglass.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Needs 8 Seats To Take Texas House

BYLINE: By RICK LYMAN 

DATELINE: BIG SPRING, Tex., Sept. 18

 BODY:
It is a warm, cricket-loud Friday night in West Texas, which means the parking lot is jammed next to the high school football field, big enough to hold much of the town, which it does.
Just a few feet away from the man selling chances on a football autographed by the whole team and the woman handing out discount coupons for chicken fried steak ("50 percent from every purchase goes to the boys," she says) is Scott McLaughlin, wholesale plumber and Republican candidate for the Texas House. 
 "People out here are so conservative," Mr. McLaughlin said as he handed out campaign pamphlets to people carrying their seat cushions through the stadium gates. "Either side, either party. The Republicans, of course, are shocked about what's come out about the President and the Democrats have been somewhat taken aback by it."
There are more than a dozen states, including Texas, where the turnover of a relative handful of seats this November would change control of the Legislature, at a time when an increasing share of the nation's business is being conducted at the state level.
And candidates and political strategists all across the country are wondering how, if at all, President Clinton's troubles might affect state races.
"I still think there's a gap between what happens at the national level, even at the Congressional level, and what happens lower down," said Janice May, a professor of government at the University of Texas in Austin. "In the South there has been a tremendous increase in Republican support, but it takes time to get down to the legislative level. Still, we could very well have a sweep for Republicans in Texas this year."
If eight seats change hands in the Texas House in November, the Republicans, who have controlled the state Senate since 1996, will have sway over the entire Legislature for the first time since Reconstruction in the 1870's. The party is giving extra money and support to candidates, like Mr. McLaughlin, who are in key races.
But some experts caution that a Republican turnaround is not guaranteed.
"I did a study back in June based on primary turnout and other things in which I was absolutely sure there would be a downturn in turnout and that would benefit the Republicans, especially in states like Texas," said Curtis Gans, director of the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate. "But we've got a couple of wild cards now that make me want to hedge my bets a bit."
Among the wild cards are the state of the economy. For instance, Mr. Gans said, if the stock market dips even more, which is entirely possible, or unemployment rises significantly, which seems much less likely, it could burst public optimism about the economy which has buoyed the campaigns of incumbents.
Even more vexing, he said, is whether the President's troubles will dampen Democratic turnout, or whether perceived Republican missteps in handling the crisis will rankle the Democratic rank-and-file sufficiently to get them out to the polls.
Mr. McLaughlin, whose great-grandfather began by selling windmills to farmers and who now sells well equipment, plumbing fixtures and high-end kitchen appliances from a two-story building off Interstate 20, says that he intends to include a pitch about character and integrity in the new television spots he will shoot next week for the fall campaign. He knows it is a way of talking about Mr. Clinton.
The trick, he said, is to choose just the right words to raise the character issue without making it look like the Republicans are taking advantage of the President's situation. He is still working on it.
"I can definitely tell you that the issue of virtue and character will be a part of my message this fall," he said.
Republicans in Texas, sensing an opportunity, are redoubling their efforts in the wake of the release of Kenneth W. Starr's report on the President.
Besides the state party's financing efforts, a separate "Eight in '98" political action committee was formed earlier this year to feed money into targeted races, like Mr. McLaughlin's, that could shift the balance in the House, which currently has 68 Republicans and 82 Democrats. In the state senate, the Republicans hold 17 seats to the Democrats' 13.
"I would say the President's problems are a factor, but not the only factor," said Robert Black, a spokesman for the state Republican Party. "We've also got an extremely popular governor in George W. Bush at the top of our ticket in November, and a strong slate for all the statewide offices. We definitely feel we have a good shot at it."
No consensus has formed on what the Democratic Party's national problems might mean in statewide races in battleground states like Texas. Guesses are all across the map; from no impact to full impact.
And at least one veteran Texas prognosticator, Robert Stein, a professor of political science at Rice University, believes that Republicans eager for a November rout here may well be in for a surprise.
"My money now is on the House staying Democrat and the Senate possibly going back into Democratic hands," he said. "Although the whole thing is very much up for grabs. A lot depends on how good these campaigns are in the coming weeks and how much ticket-splitting there is going to be. Mostly what you hear from candidates is that no one wants to listen. Voters are disinterested."
The 70th Legislative District sprawls across 12 rural counties in West Texas, coming up to the edge of, without entering, three of the region's biggest cities: Lubbock, Midland and Abilene. The district encompasses mile after mile of cotton farms, ranches and small towns.
The district has been represented for a decade by David Counts, a Democrat from Knox County, on the far side of the district from Mr. McLaughlin's home in Big Spring. Mr. McLaughlin first ran against him two years ago, losing by a slim margin.
In 1996, Mr. McLaughlin focused his campaign on neighborhood walks, knocking on more than 10,000 doors. This year, he said, he will knock on about the same number.
His message is drawn directly from the Ronald Reagan playbook, by way of Newt Gingrich; smaller government, fewer regulations, strong family values.
Mr. McLaughlin spent about $140,000 on the 1996 campaign, he said, and plans to spend roughly the same amount this year in his rematch against Mr. Counts. Some of that money comes from local donors, but some comes from "Eight in '98," which offers logistical and strategic advice, as well as money.
Mr. Counts was at a Democratic event earlier this month in a church picnic grounds north of Abilene. "The Republicans came after me two years ago and they're doing it again," he said. "They keep trying to tie me to President Clinton, but it won't work. I personally think this Clinton thing is going to go away real quick. The last straw was the lurid detail that Ken Starr put in that report. Now the people know his heart was black and his cause was not pure."
Mr. McLaughlin does not really know how much national political crises will affect his race, nor how much he will benefit from Governor Bush's coattails in November.
"We like to tie ourselves to Bush as much as we can," Mr. McLaughlin said. "After all, we're both singing from the same sheet of music."
The Governor has been in the district a couple of times to campaign for himself and for local Republicans, and each visit has meant a boost for Mr. McLaughlin.
What would happen, Mr. McLaughlin is asked, if President Clinton came to the 70th District to campaign for his opponent?
A smile spread across his face.
"The election," he said, "would be over."

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 576 words

HEADLINE: Mr. Clinton's Strange Power

 BODY:
The Lewinsky scandal has weakened Bill Clinton's grasp on his office, but it may have given him a peculiar new weapon in the budget wars. Only a few weeks from adjournment, Congress is engaged in the annual autumn ritual of confronting the White House over taxes and spending, just when Mr. Clinton is braving the impeachment firestorm on an island of his own contradictions. But in that weakness lies a paradoxical kind of strength. The more feeble the President seems, the more seriously Congress takes his demands. The last thing Congressional Republicans want is to distract the public from Mr. Clinton's troubles and provoke a searching look at the G.O.P. budget priorities.
Republicans in the House are threatening to find money for emergency spending on Bosnia, farm assistance and embassy security by cutting summer jobs and home heating assistance for poor people. Mr. Clinton says he will veto if they do. In the Senate, Republicans want to attach 24 anti-environmental riders to the Interior Department appropriations bill, while cutting funds to combat water pollution and to restore the Everglades. The President says he will veto the bill if it reaches his desk in its present form. Republicans have provoked another veto warning by threatening to attach a school voucher program to a District of Columbia spending bill. Proposed amendments to other bills would undermine family planning programs at home and abroad. 
 To all these threats, the White House is saying, "Make my day." It is itching for a fight on anything that will portray Mr. Clinton as a man of principle, thereby throwing the Republicans on the defensive. The fire breathers in the House, like David McIntosh of Indiana, want to press an ambitious agenda on spending, tax cuts and social issues. But calmer heads like House Speaker Newt Gingrich and Bob Livingston, the Appropriations Committee chairman, believe that it would be folly to allow President Clinton to campaign on the issues and thus deflect attention from a scandal that they believe has lifted their chances in November.
Hoping to carve out something for the voters, Republicans in both houses are scrambling to bridge their differences on a tax cut of as much as $80 billion, paid for by this year's budget surplus. Last week, the President vowed again to veto it, arguing that the money should be set aside to rescue Social Security. The White House worries that some Democrats will defect, which is possible because they fear that Mr. Clinton will simply make a deal that undercuts them and makes them look foolish. The Lewinsky scandal is not the only reason that some Democrats doubt Mr. Clinton's constancy.
In all this strategizing is the sad spectacle of what might have been. No wonder the Democrats are despondent and mutinous. Earlier this year, they had polls showing that the public was placing its confidence in Democrats on health care, education and the economy for the first time in years. There would be a competitive race to control the House, and Richard Gephardt allowed himself to dream the dreams of becoming Speaker.
Now it is all gone. The public can only look with wonder on these developments. Mr. Clinton's leverage, a zen mutation of weakness into strength, may work this year to advance his budget goals, and victory on these items would be good for the country. But it will mean little if he cannot pump other kinds of authority into his hollowed-out Presidency.

HEADLINE: Darkest Hour at U.N. For Richest Deadbeat

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 18

 BODY:
In the annals of American relations with the United Nations, supporters and critics of the organization broadly agree, there has never been a more dismal moment than this.
When President Clinton, personally tarnished by the Monica Lewinsky scandal, speaks here on Monday, he will face an organization that is likely to strip the United States of its General Assembly vote by the end of this year for nonpayment of dues. Washington owes the organization more than $1.5 billion. 
 Mr. Clinton, the political heir to Presidents Roosevelt and Truman -- who fought to create a strong United Nations and give it Washington's firm bipartisan support -- is now viewed by many diplomats and officials here as too weak or unwilling to battle a hostile Congress to preserve that pivotal American role.
And the United States is now without a chief representative to the organization since the departure of Bill Richardson and Republican blocking of Richard C. Holbrooke's appointment as his successor.
The organization's largest contributor is now Japan, which kept its dues payments up to date despite a recession. What is helping keep the United Nations afloat -- barely -- is that the Japanese, Europeans and some developing countries have not been reimbursed for providing peacekeeping troops, allowing the money to be applied instead to the operating budget.
"People are furious -- our allies are furious," said Alvin P. Adams, a former ambassador who is president of the United Nations Association of the United States, an advocacy and research organization with chapters around the country.
Mr. Adams' organization, known as UNA-USA, recently announced poll results showing that a growing percentage of Americans approve of the United Nations and want the United States to pay its overdue assessments, without conditions. Eighty percent of those polled opposed linking the payments to anti-abortion restrictions on international family planning groups, as Congress has done.
In the UNA-USA survey, conducted Aug. 21 to 25 by Wirthlin Worldwide, 72 percent of 1,005 adults said it was "very important" that the United States remain an active member of the United Nations, which they ranked higher than NATO, the World Bank and the World Health Organization. Seventy-three percent said Washington should pay its dues.
Sixty percent of those surveyed also said the United Nations was doing a good job, the highest rating UNA-USA has seen in a variety of polls since 1959. Contrary to what some members of Congress and the Clinton Administration believe, the poll found that many Americans say that they would take attitudes toward the United Nations into account when voting for members of Congress, although this would not be a major factor.
"These polls have taken a jump in public opinion since we took our last poll two years ago," said John C. Whitehead, a former Deputy Secretary of State and chairman of UNA-USA. Speaking at a news conference here on Thursday, Mr. Whitehead said there has long been a "some kind of disconnect between public opinion on the United Nations and the voting record of Congress, at least in recent years."
The new poll also found a much higher approval rating for Secretary General Kofi Annan -- although 25 percent of those polled had never heard of him -- than a similar poll in late 1995 found for his predecessor, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, whose name had become the butt of Republican ridicule. Mr. Annan's performance was given a 53 percent approval rating compared with Mr. Boutros-Ghali's 30 percent.
Mr. Adams said Mr. Annan's political skills and personable approach to Americans is probably helping improve the image of the United Nations in the United States.
"He's has a sense of the politics of the public that it's hard to think of any other Secretary General who's had that," Mr. Adams said in an interview. "Some of the good movement in public opinion about the U.N. is due to the fact that there is a face now, a face that is warm and approachable, and people identify with him."
But even Mr. Annan has become disillusioned with Washington, as protestations of support for the United Nations in the Administration and Congress fail repeatedly to turn into tangible support.
In order to avoid losing its General Assembly vote, the United States will have to pay about $200 million by Dec. 31. But even if Congress, which is locked in a confrontation with President Clinton over an anti-abortion amendment to legislation, is able to authorize the money in the current session, dozens of conditions, some requiring Administration certification, are expected to block payment to the United Nations.
Congress has demanded that the United Nations write off some back dues; some members insist that the organization owes money to Washington and not the other way around. Congress is also demanding further budget and staff cuts at the United Nations and a pledge that the organization not create a standby peacekeeping force that some Americans see as a potentially inimical international army.
Senior officials here say that with every day that passes, it is more likely that the United States will fall automatically under Article 19 of the United Nations Charter, which strips a country of its General Assembly vote when its debt equals or exceeds the assessments due for the preceding two years.
Eighteen nations now fall into this category: Bosnia, Burundi, Cambodia, Comoros, Congo, Dominica, Equatorial Guinea, Georgia, Guinea-Bissau, Iraq, Liberia, Moldova, Sao Tome, Somalia, Tajikistan, Togo, Vanuatu and Yugoslavia.
The United States seat on the Security Council would not be affected.
However, diplomats, including Americans, say that anger toward the United States is beginning to erode support on issues vital to Washington, and that General Assembly votes do decide elections for rotating Security Council seats as well as major initiatives and appointments within the organization at large.
Still, John Bolton, who was Assistant Secretary of State for international organization affairs in the Bush Administration and is now at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington, said in an interview that the loss of a General Assembly vote would not jolt critics.
"If the vote is lost in the General Assembly, that's not going to make people in Washington jump up and say, Gosh!," Mr. Bolton said. "It's going to have exactly the opposite effect."
"This is not a bean-counting argument," he added. "This represents a fundamental divergence of opinion on the right course for the organization."
In Washington, a General Accounting Office report in June said the United Nations' financial problems "have been primarily caused by the accumulation of of unpaid assessments and late payments of assessments by a large number of members." But the G.A.O. report adds that no nation has run up such a large debt to the organization, which amounts to more than half of the organization's annual operating budget of $2.4 billion.
The United States is assessed 25 percent of the regular budget, based on its share in the world economy, though Congress had wanted this reduced to 20 percent by the year 2000. A 31 percent share of peacekeeping has already been unilaterally reduced by Congress to 25 percent, putting the United States in perennial arrears because such changes are recognized only if made according to the Charter by a committee of member nations.
Even when the United States pays on time, its payments have been received late in the year because of a decision in 1983 to tie disbursements to the Federal budget cycle. While the United Nations bills members in January, the United States never pays the bulk of its debts before Oct. 1.
"The U.N.'s cash flow problems stem largely from this U.S. delay in payments," the G.A.O. report said. "The United States is the only major country that regularly schedules payment with this delay factor."
Supporters of the United Nations say that Americans, who take part in increasing numbers in many international activities organized here, from grassroots groups up to national professional organizations, are spreading the word around the country that the United Nations is in trouble, and that the United States is the major cause.
"Perhaps the American public is beginning to become aware of the gravity of the crisis that is facing the organization," said Jeffrey Laurenti, director of policy studies at UNA-USA. "Three out of four said in the poll that the American forfeiture of the vote under Article 19 would be at the very least an embarrassment," he said. "Possibly for many -- almost 40 percent say -- it would actually severely impact on America's ability to do business with other countries."

HEADLINE: Indian Reservations Bank on Authenticity to Draw Tourists

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: UMATILLA RESERVATION, Ore.

 BODY:
The mercury had pushed over the 100-degree mark again here in the high desert, but the tourists from Germany were undeterred, looking for clues to life in the American West before every small town had an espresso bar. 
 "As children we used to play cowboys and Native Americans," Klaus Pumple, a 37-year-old construction manager from Stuttgart, Germany, said recently. "Now when you pass through the Native American zones in this country, it's kind of depressing, not like you expected. But also, it is so very interesting to see how these people live today."
On the Blackfoot Indian Reservation in Montana, at the high drama nexus of the Great Plains and the Rocky Mountains, Vicky Kilian of the Netherlands had just spent another night sleeping on a dirt floor inside a tent and was wondering whether she could ever return to her life as a business consultant in a very flat country.
"When I sleep in the teepee, I feel a lot of connection to the earth," said Ms. Kilian, 29, who is on her first visit to America. "I have had a fire every night and I have been able to walk over the prairie. It has a very special energy."
American Indian reservations, long considered economic deserts in a landscape of general prosperity, are finding that they have a lot more to offer the world than casinos and art galleries -- they have their homes, their backyards, their stories.
Visitors, especially a growing number of Europeans, are traveling to some of the country's most remote places, like this Indian reservation in central Oregon, in search of life many Americans overlook on their vacations. No theme parks built around fantasies for these travelers. In fact, some of the biggest new attractions are rooted in today's world and in authenticity -- even if it leaves visitors feeling more guilt than vacation relief. Tourists to Indian country spend their holidays hearing tales of heart-numbing atrocities or listening to songs in languages that never show up in Frommer's guides. They come away thrilled.
And for Indians who have figured just how to market this niche of native society, business is booming.
"Europeans have been visiting Indian country since the time of Columbus, but what's really new is Indians getting control of it," said Gordon Bronitsky, a Denver tourism marketer who has just produced a catalogue of Indian travel packages that is going out to 5,000 travel agents in Italy.
A cruise ship full of Germans will tie up next spring near the western Oneida Reservation, next to Green Bay, Wis., after the tour operator reported that visitors requested a stop at an Indian reservation as part of their itinerary.
"We're not going to sit there and say, 'How,' and paint our faces," said Jeff House, a spokesman for the Oneida. "We will try to give an impression of how people live today. We're business people. We go to Packer games."
Other tribes are trying to blend the old with the new. Will Tsosie runs what might be called an Indian bed and breakfast on the Navajo Reservation not far from Canyon de Chelly National Monument in Arizona. He charges $85 a night to stay in a traditional earthen-floored hogan, a cylindrical house with no running water, and a structure in which few Indians live. But he also takes people to visit the local community college.
"Our European guests are very well-prepared and very well-read -- unlike most Americans," Mr. Tsosie said. "If they show up with too much of the wrong attitude, we turn them away." Recently, he said, some people came to the Hopi Reservation looking for a sun dance, and asked whether they could be "pierced" in the chest.
"We told them they had the wrong Indians," Mr. Tsosi said. "Try a thousand miles to the north, with the Lakota."
Roberta Conner, director of the new $18 million Tamastslikt Cultural Center, on the Umatilla Reservation, said, "We get a lot of people who expect they are going to find the Hollywood stereotypes, the beads and feather Indians."
The center, whose Indian name means interpreter, opened this summer after nearly 10 years of planning and is drawing visitors from around the world.
Tamastslikt is the only Indian-run, Indian-owned interpretive center along the entire length of the old Oregon Trail, Ms. Conner said. The trail, from St. Louis to Western Oregon, has long been a magnet for fans of heritage tourism. With the opening of Tamastslikt, she said, there is now another side of the story of Westward expansion, as well as a history of the Indians who have long lived in this region.
The Umatilla and the two other tribes that live on the reservation, the Cayuse and the Walla Walla, sent a delegation to Berlin this year, to the world's biggest tourism trade show. They handed out posters of a Cayuse Indian leader in a buffalo headdress with the slogan "Nicht Ihr Durchschnittlicher Reisefuhrer" or Not Your Average Tour Guide.
Germany is often the focus of the marketing because the country has more than 300 Indian clubs, where people adopt a tribe or a chief and study the history. Plus, millions of Germans have grown up on the books of Karl May, a German author who wrote a series of stories about an Apache and his white sidekick.
"There is this sort of noble savage image, unfettered by civilization, which they like," Mr. Bronitsky said. "God forbid that anyone should ever discuss that Indians have VCR's and microwaves."
But a thrust of the new interpretative center, which is part of a resort that includes a casino, an 18-hole golf course, a hotel and recreational vehicle park, is to show how Indians of the Columbia Plateau live today.
"We would like to be perceived as dynamic, evolving, healthy people," Ms. Conner said. "That's not exactly what people expect to see when they visit a reservation."
Still, the fact that these Columbia Plateau Indians have lived in roughly the same places for thousands of years is a tourist draw in a country where so many of the human attachments to the land are ephemeral, tribal officials say.
"We pretty much live where we've always lived, and people are fascinated by that," Ms. Conner said. The center tells a story of independent people whose lives were forever changed by the schooners that came over the Oregon Trail. It shows the effect of disease, of boarding schools that disrupted families, and of poverty. And it ends on a hopeful note, with visions of a tribe flourishing.
"People are very moved by it," Ms. Conner said. "We get these notes in the suggestion box: 'I'm sorry for everything we've done to you people.' It awakens a lot of trauma, a lot of fear."
Despite the guilt-swollen effect of some heritage tour sites, tour operators outside the reservation say there is great interest in all things Indian. A record number of people, about 600,000, visited the National Museum of the American Indian in lower Manhattan last year, double the attendance of the year before. And out near the reservations, museums report a similar trend.
At the Museum of the Plains Indian, on the Blackfoot Reservation, near Browning, Mont., nearly half the visitors this year have been from Europe.
A huge majority of the guests at Darrell Norman's village and horse ranch on the Blackfoot Reservation are from Europe. They take pictures of the bison herds that wander around the reservation, ride horses that are descendants of the mustangs brought to the Americas by the Spanish and learn about the culture of Northern Plains tribes.
"They want to know what the Blackfoot are all about," Mr. Norman said. "They want to taste our food. They want to sleep on the ground -- the whole package. They may show up with stereotypical image, but they leave with the sense that we have a very alive culture. We do not have dead arts, dead language."
Ms. Kilian, the Dutch visitor to the Blackfoot, said she had considered going to China on her vacation, but chose the Blackfoot Reservation instead. "Before I came here I heard that they had a dislike for whites," she said. "That is not true. I have felt very welcome."
One problem that concerns the tribes is trying to hold the line between sharing culture and exploitation. The Umatilla, for example, found that many Germans want to stay with Indian families -- but the Indians themselves do not feel like opening their homes. The Blackfoot, who are enjoying a banner year for tourism, are grappling with the same problem.
"There's always been this question," said Ray Montoya, the Blackfoot tribal planning director, "of how far we develop this industry while maintaining a pristine environment and our culture."

HEADLINE: Report Calls for Higher Education Reform

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
A new report by the State Comptroller criticizes higher education policy making as haphazard and often politically influenced, and calls on the state to establish a higher education coordinating board to replace or supplement the Board of Regents, the panel that is responsible for education planning in the state.
The report by the Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, is particularly critical of the roles that both Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani have played in higher education. It attacks the often political nature of appointments to the boards of New York's public universities and calls for a new system of appointing trustees for the State University of New York and the City University of New York. 
 Representatives of both the Governor and the Mayor, who are Republicans, dismissed the report itself as political in nature. Mr. McCall, a Democrat, is up for re-election in November.
The 44-page report is scheduled for release today and is to be posted on the Internet tomorrow (www.osc. state.ny.us). Although the report does not cite Mayor Giuliani by name, it is both directly and indirectly critical of his involvement in CUNY.
It recommends, for example, that university trustees not be employed by the politicians who appoint them -- a clear slap at the Mayor. Of the five trustees Mr. Giuliani has named to CUNY's board, two are city employees and one is his appointee as president of the United Nations Development Corporation, a quasi-governmental organization. Their independence has become a subject of debate within the board and elsewhere.
The report also discusses the importance of keeping education free from direct political control of the sort the Mayor displayed last spring in shaping a new policy that would bar students who need remedial classes from entering CUNY's senior colleges. "It was very clear," the report says, "that the actions of some trustees were being driven by the explicit direction of outside politicians," including the Mayor.
Finally, the report calls for "broad access to post-secondary education," and refers to concerns that CUNY's new remedial policy could significantly cut new enrollments at the university's senior colleges.
Cristyne F. Lategano, a spokeswoman for the Mayor, said she had not seen the report, but said, "Charges of politics from Carl McCall are pretty ironic," adding that the Mayor typically does not respond to the Comptroller's reports because he considers them political.
The report is generally less critical of Mr. Pataki. But it cites his veto in April of additional aid for community colleges -- and his later reversal of that position -- as an example of the "piecemeal decision making" that Mr. McCall would like to change.
The Governor's office also dismissed the study. "It is clearly a politically partisan report that is designed for political purposes just a few weeks ahead of the election," said Charles H. Deister, a spokesman for the Governor.
Mr. McCall said in an interview on Friday that he recognized that some might view the report as political, but he said he expected that people would focus on its content "rather than on who put it out or when."
"We have a policy vacuum for higher education in this state, with choices made almost exclusively through our dysfunctional budget process," Mr. McCall said, adding that he hoped to "create a dialogue" about the role of the state in planning higher education.
"We are facing a period when the demands of the workplace will require people with a very high degree of skills, and I want to make sure we are preparing our students," he said.
Over all, the report offers a critical snapshot of higher education in a state that spends only $157 per capita on higher education -- 15 percent less than the national average and 41st among all states -- and one where students must pay "significantly more" to attend a public university than students in the rest of the nation.
It charges that although New York spends $3.7 billion a year on higher education, it has cut support for public and private universities "without adequate consideration" of the impact on the state and its economy.
Mr. McCall released a copy of the report to The New York Times last week, as well as to a handful of education experts he consulted in developing it and a few top education officials.
Richard P. Mills, the State Education Commissioner, who was not consulted in advance but received a copy of the report, cheered the Comptroller's effort to focus attention on higher education, even though he disagreed with some of the report's conclusions.
"Is there room for a thoughtful, critical report?" Mr. Mills said. "Certainly. I don't have a quarrel with a paper like this. There are problems in higher education. For me, that is a given."
The report is also critical of the Board of Regents. It says that although the board was intended as an "ambitious higher education governance and planning structure, the system has not worked for some time."
"They are, of necessity, too preoccupied with elementary and secondary education," the report says, adding that none of the board's recent four-year master plans have been acted upon.
Mr. Mills challenged those conclusions, saying the Regents have aggressively carried out a clear plan for improving the state's colleges and universities. Among the actions they have taken, he said, was the removal of trustees at Adelphi University for mismanagement; the setting of stiff new standards for teacher education and certification, and the closing of hundreds of substandard commercially owned trade schools, known as proprietary schools.
At the same time, Mr. Mills said, the Regents see room for improvement in their own approach. "We have a master plan system," he said, "and the Regents do not think it works as effectively as it should and plan to change that."

HEADLINE: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: THE SENATOR;
In Upstate Swing, D'Amato Attacks Schumer on His Voting Record

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Sept. 20

 BODY:
In his first major swing of the general election campaign, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato barnstormed across the Republican-friendly reaches of northern New York State today, repeatedly accusing his Democratic opponent, Representative Charles E. Schumer from Brooklyn, of being blithely indifferent to the needs of upstate residents.
The whirlwind six-hour trip brought Mr. D'Amato, a Republican seeking his fourth term, to the state's largest upstate cities -- Albany, Syracuse, Rochester and Buffalo -- and provided a television backdrop for his unusually blunt appeal to the regional resentments that have defined state politics for decades. 
 Echoing the television advertisements that he and the state Republican Party have saturated the airwaves with in recent days, Mr. D'Amato derisively referred to Mr. Schumer as a "Brooklyn liberal" and lambasted him for having once quipped that "the West starts on the other side of the Hudson River." Mr. Schumer's aides said the remark was a joking reference to his friend and former roommate, Senator Richard J. Durbin, a Democrat from Illinois.
"Maybe he thinks that's funny," Mr. D'Amato said at a news conference at Buffalo International Airport this afternoon. "But take a look at his votes. In his votes, he has demonstrated a pattern of not only indifference, not only of negligence, but indeed of outright damage to upstate New York."
Those damaging votes, according to Mr. D'Amato, included Mr. Schumer's support in Congress for reducing price supports for dairy farmers and for increasing Federal gasoline taxes, and in the State Assembly two decades ago for establishing a state property tax. Mr. D'Amato contended that since many Brooklyn residents do not own homes or cars, the taxes Mr. Schumer voted for would have fallen disproportionately on upstate residents.
While Mr. D'Amato was touring upstate, Mr. Schumer took to the steps of City Hall in New York City to criticize Mr. D'Amato's opposition to gun control. Asked about the Senator's criticisms, Mr. Schumer returned to a core theme of his campaign: that Mr. D'Amato has been in office for too long, an attack the Republicans used effectively upstate against Gov. Mario M. Cuomo four years ago.
"I would ask what kinds of concrete things Al D'Amato has done for upstate," Mr. Schumer said. "He's supposed to be the pothole Senator. But upstate New York is one of the three regions in the entire country that has lost jobs. Al D'Amato has been there 18 years. He's utterly failed in helping upstate New York. And people in upstate New York, wherever I go, are looking for a change."
Mr. Schumer's campaign also faxed to reporters information on Mr. D'Amato's record indicating that he had allowed property taxes to rise in the town of Hempstead, on Long Island, during the 1970's, when he was Town Supervisor there, and had voted repeatedly in the Senate to raise Federal taxes.
Though Mr. D'Amato's news conferences were filled mainly with attacks on Mr. Schumer, he did refer to Federal aid that he claimed to have directed to upstate communities, including for airport renovations in Buffalo, a bridge over the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway in Schenectady and improvements at the Albany rail station.
The harsh tone of both candidates' remarks today was in keeping with the negative tenor that has dominated this still-young race and provided new evidence that it is likely to be a bare-knuckles affair down to the wire, much like the 1992 race in which Mr. D'Amato defeated Robert Abrams, then the State Attorney General, by a single percentage point.
Democratic politicians said Mr. D'Amato's upstate strategy indicated that he was concerned about the region's lagging economy and perceived a softening of his support there. "This is what he does when he's in trouble: he tries to divide," said Josh Isay, Mr. Schumer's campaign manager.
But Republicans said Mr. D'Amato was simply playing a classic Republican card, one that might work especially well this year because of President Clinton's problems. Many strategists in both parties say Democratic turnout in places like New York City may be particularly low this year because party stalwarts are demoralized by the continuing inquiry into the President's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky.
"The intangibles are looking good for D'Amato," said Anthony H. Gioia, a Buffalo businessman and fund-raiser for the Senator. "He's got a popular Governor at the top of the ticket to bring out Republicans and the President's troubles keeping Democrats at home."
Political analysts said Mr. D'Amato's efforts to stoke regional frictions so early was extraordinary. But they said his strategy was not surprising since Mr. D'Amato's chances of re-election depend heavily on overcoming New York City's strongly Democratic vote with heavy Republican support in the north.
They also noted that Mr. D'Amato's fellow Republican, Gov. George E. Pataki, used a similar tactic to great success in the final days of the gubernatorial campaign of 1994, when he played on upstate resentments against the city to undermine Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's stunning endorsement of the Democratic incumbent, Mr. Cuomo.
"This is the culture of New York politics," said John Zogby, a pollster from Utica. "Upstate New York is D'Amato's base. It's important that he mops up there because he'll lose the city, and probably fairly badly."
In 1992, Mr. D'Amato lost by 451,000 votes to Mr. Abrams in New York City. But he was able to squeak out an 80,000-vote victory by soundly defeating Mr. Abrams in the suburbs and routing him in all but three upstate counties.
Mr. D'Amato's campaign swing today also underscored the degree to which this campaign will be played out almost entirely on television. In his few hours upstate, Mr. D'Amato did not venture out to meet voters but instead conducted news conferences attended mainly by local television reporters in airport conference rooms and at departure gates.
Mr. D'Amato is scheduled to continue his upstate campaigning on Monday, visiting Elmira, Binghamton, Niagara Falls and Utica.
Much as he had sought to depict Mr. Abrams as a big-city elitist who was out of touch with the feelings of average small-town residents, Mr. D'Amato tried to portray Mr. Schumer, whose father ran an exterminating business, as an effete, Ivy League-trained snob.
"He should know better," Mr. D'Amato said in Albany, referring to Mr. Schumer's attacks on him. "This is the great Harvard intellect."
Later, the Senator said of Mr. Schumer, "He simply doesn't understand what hard-working families in upstate New York have to go through."

HEADLINE: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Focusing on a Rival's Votes on Taxes

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:

This is a 30-second advertisement that Gov. George E. Pataki's campaign began broadcasting Friday. 

PRODUCER -- Chris Mottola
 
ON THE SCREEN -- The ad opens with a picture of the Democratic nominee, Peter F. Vallone, against a background of dollar bills, his name displayed in white letters. When the narrator accuses Mr. Vallone of voting for higher taxes 78 times, the ring of a cash register is heard, and a tab with the legend "Voted 78 Times for Higher Taxes" pops up. This pattern -- cash register ringing, tab popping up -- continues four more times, as the narrator says that Mr. Vallone voted for higher property, commuter and sales taxes. At the end, Mr. Vallone's name and image remain, but the tabs are replaced by the words "Very Taxing."
 
THE SCRIPT -- "Peter Vallone is very liberal with taxpayers' money. He voted 78 times for higher taxes. He voted 20 times for higher income taxes. Vallone voted 18 times to raise property taxes. Peter Vallone voted 14 times to extend the suburban commuter tax and Peter Vallone even voted 20 times for higher sales taxes. Peter Vallone, very taxing."
 
ACCURACY -- Most of the 78 votes cited, some dating to the 1970's, were not tax increases, but extensions of existing taxes. The largest of those, a personal income tax surcharge to pay for more police officers, was enacted in 1991 and extended last year, each time with Mr. Pataki's support, and it was eliminated this year by Mr. Vallone. Some of the taxes cited have since been eliminated. The reference to property taxes is also misleading, referring, in many instances, to the city's annual adjustment of tax rates. In this decade, those adjustments have kept the overall tax burden roughly unchanged, though it has raised the tax assessment on properties whose values have risen sharply. In the eight years since the Council gained some power over the city budget, the city's tax collections have risen more slowly than inflation, and more slowly than the state's.
 
SCORECARD -- Mr. Pataki is relying on the most tried-and-true Republican formula, calling Democrats "liberal" taxers and spenders, which surely has worked in the past. And while the ad does not mention New York City directly, it plays into the belief of many upstate and suburban voters that politicians from the city, like Mr. Vallone, want nothing more than to bleed them dry through taxes. But it is unusual for an incumbent with an enormous lead in the polls to go on the attack first, and so early in the general election campaign. And while Mr. Pataki may simply be trying not to take anything for granted, negative advertising always runs the risk, however slight, of backfiring on the attacker. --
 RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

HEADLINE: Japan Sees Itself as a Scapegoat Of Washington in the Asia Crisis

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 20

 BODY:
Japan is often seen these days as an insouciant bumbler, fiddling while much of the world's economy burns. But Government officials here, grimly plodding the corridors of power, see things rather differently.
As Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi prepares for a summit meeting with President Clinton on Tuesday in Tarrytown, N. Y., some officials here are irritated at what they perceive as American arrogance and scapegoating of Japan. They say that Japan tried several times to grapple with the Asian economic crisis in the early stages, but each time the United States slapped Japan down. 
 When the crisis was in its infancy a year ago, for example, Japan proposed setting up a $100 billion fund to help Southeast Asian countries pull through. The United States swiftly killed the idea, sending a humiliated Japan slinking back to its corner.
Now many economists think that Japan's idea should have been tried, and even the United States sounds humble on that point. "I think we've all learned a lot of lessons over the last year or so," said Stuart E. Eizenstat, Under Secretary of State for economic affairs. "Perhaps with 20-20 hindsight, this was an idea that might have gotten more attention."
Japan was the first major country to pay attention to the crisis unfolding in Thailand in the summer of 1997, and then-Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto tried to get world leaders to discuss the economic instability in Asia at the Denver summit meeting, two weeks before the crisis exploded into the public eye. But no other leader wanted to discuss what then seemed like an obscure topic.
Then just this month, Mr. Obuchi proposed that leaders of the industrialized countries meet to consult on the Russian crisis and global economic risks. Washington killed that idea, too. But a few days ago, as the crisis became more serious, President Clinton summoned finance ministers and central bankers from the same countries to discuss the problems.
Japanese officials are not exactly gnashing their teeth, nor do they want to be hailed as visionaries who saw the crisis coming and tried to galvanize international action.
But they do bridle at the suggestion that they are part of the problem rather than the solution, and that Japan is the culprit in the Asian crisis.
"That is a wrong perception," complained Kaoru Yosano, the Minister for International Trade and Industry. "Sure, Japan has lots of political problems. But Japan has contributed more than any country in the world to the Asian countries hit by the crisis since Thailand, and we intend to continue those contributions."
Mr. Yosano noted that Japan has contributed $43 billion to rescue packages in Asia, compared to $12 billion from the United States and $7 billion from Europe.
"Japan is not paralyzed," he added. "It would be an interesting yarn if it were true, but it's not."
When asked if he was annoyed at repeated American statements urging Japan to do more to address the crisis, Mr. Yosano allowed a smile to flit across his face.
"We're used to it, so we're not frustrated by it," he said. "It's like a church bell ringing at the same time every day, so that after a while you don't notice it. But of course if you say things too many times, then nobody will listen to you any more. So I think it would be more effective to speak less often."
Not everybody in the Japanese Cabinet is quite so patient. Seiichi Ota, the director of the Management and Coordination Agency, complained at a press conference the other day about the impact of international banking standards stipulating the appropriate levels of capital that banks should maintain.
"I wonder if everyone is just accepting this because it is decided by Anglo-Saxons," Mr. Ota fretted. "Everyone, including Japan, bows to these rules, because Anglo-Saxons are powerful in the financial world. But being powerful is not the same as being right."
For all their frustration, Japanese officials still go out of their way to try to pacify American demands. Late last week, for example, leaders of the ruling and opposition parties stayed up all night and worked frantically to cobble together a frail agreement on stabilizing the banking system, all so that Mr. Obuchi would have the deal in place by the time he met Mr. Clinton.
The simmering resentments in Tokyo may grow with the summit meeting, since one of its purposes seems to be to give Mr. Clinton a chance to drum into Mr. Obuchi the importance of rapid action to revive Japan's economy. Mr. Clinton said a few days ago that in terms of resolving the global financial crisis, "the key here is Japan," and he added: "It is difficult to see how any actions of the world community can be successful in restoring growth in Asia in the absence of the restoration of growth in Japan."
Yuji Tsushima, a prominent member of Parliament for the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, warned that if Americans continue to complain about Japan, then there could be a serious backlash. "If American policy-makers continue to criticize us or push too hard, a sentiment might develop here similar to that in Malaysia," Mr. Tsushima said, referring to the strong strain of anti-Western opinion in Malaysia. "That's what we have to avoid."
American officials respond that while they would prefer not to give offense, the world is at an extremely delicate juncture and requires dramatic action from Japan to stimulate its economy.
"The United States feels quite acutely that Japan must bear its share of responsibility for mitigating as much as possible the Asian crisis," said Charlene Barshefsky, the United States Trade Representative, who was in Japan last week. Ms. Barshefsky said that Mr. Clinton and Mr. Obuchi would speak "in an unusually forthright manner for a first-time meeting."
"We can express perhaps exasperation, but it's up to Japan to take the measures," she added. "The President will certainly make clear that Japan must act."
There has been some disagreement in the Administration about how harsh to be with Japan, and the result is an inconsistency in tone. Ms. Barshefsky and Treasury Department officials have been unrelentingly tough, while State Department officials have soothingly offered advice rather than making demands.
Some American officials say that one reason why Washington has often made tough statements is the feeling that pressure to the point of rudeness is the only mechanism that has ever worked in Japan. "I think it's demonstrably the case that external pressure tends to help more than it hurts," Ms. Barshefsky said.
Early last year, for example, the United States politely urged Japan not to raise its national consumption tax. Japan raised it anyway, and fell into its worst recession in half a century -- threatening the global economy.
Likewise, even after falling into recession, Japan felt much less urgency than other countries. Tokyo delayed action on measures to stimulate the economy and tackle its bad debt, and the frustration in Washington grew so acute that some Treasury officials dubbed Japan's Finance Minister the "minister for the destruction of the world economy."
Such sarcasm is particularly painful for Japanese officials, who try hard to build good relationships with their American counterparts.
"Japanese officials are really interested, almost obsessed, with the reaction of Americans, and so these days they are very resentful because the reaction is bad," said Yasuaki Onuma, a law professor at Tokyo University. But he added that fundamentally the blame should lie with the Japanese officials because, he said, they are invariably disastrous at public relations and thus never get credit even when they manage to do things right.
One reason why Japanese proposals for summit meetings or other global measures have not been taken seriously is that the Japanese Government has almost no credibility abroad. It has insisted for so long that its economic problems are under control that the assumption whenever a Japanese Prime Minister speaks out on global issues is that he is simply trying to divert attention from problems at home.
The distress of Japanese officials at being blamed for the global crisis comes on top of the distress at seeing the once-great Japanese economy steadily lose strength. The Japanese stock market is at a 12-year low, and Japan's banks are now not just the world's biggest but also among the world's shakiest.
A headline this week on a column in the Asahi Shimbun, perhaps Japan's most respected newspaper, grimly described the despair at Japan's economic morass: "The Feeling of Losing a Second War."
In the Japanese public at large, the measure of resentment at perceived American arrogance has been no greater lately than usual. One reason may be that the public is focusing its indignation on its own leaders.
Indeed, Mr. Obuchi can make Mr. Clinton look comparatively strong politically. A poll this week for the Asahi Shimbun found only 21 percent of the public supported Mr. Obuchi's Government, and even members of his own party are jockeying to succeed him.
"Right now, most of the public frustration isn't with foreigners," said Charles Y. Horioka, an economist at Osaka University, "but with the Japanese Government and its difficulties in getting things done."

HEADLINE: As Russia Teeters, the Rest of Us Should Worry

 BODY:

To the Editor:
President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia should disavow the new Prime Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, and the new cabinet being imposed on him by the Communist-dominated opposition (news article, Sept. 18). The plan to print rubles to pay for accrued wages and pensions can only result in hyperinflation, which will lead to greater social distress and protests. The election of a new Parliament is scheduled for December 1999. By that time, the devastating effects of skyrocketing prices and unpredictable shortages will be evident. 
 If President Yeltsin publicly opposes deficit financing, the lines may be drawn clearly enough in December 1999 for voters to support a Parliament composed of deputies who will support the agrarian reforms, tax restructuring and parliamentary approval of long-term mineral production agreements (production-sharing) that the Communist opposition has blocked for the last five years.
 
JONATHAN RUSSIN
Washington, Sept. 18, 1998
 
The writer is an international lawyer based in Moscow.

HEADLINE: As Russia Teeters, the Rest of Us Should Worry

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Joseph Stiglitz (Op-Ed, Sept. 16) would have us believe that Brazil and other South American countries have been tainted undeservedly by economic turmoil in Russia -- victims of an "irrational panic." This is not completely true. 
 While the region's afflictions are indeed different from those on the other side of the world, they are ills nonetheless: a current account deficit of 5 percent of gross domestic product, overvalued exchange rates, excessive interest rates, profligate fiscal spending, low tax collection and weak banking institutions.
Latin America has made great progress, as Mr. Stiglitz notes, in undertaking neoliberal economic reform. However, the job is half-done; the region must complete the task to speed recovery and insure sustainable growth.
 
JERRY HAAR
Miami, Sept. 17, 1998
 
The writer is senior research associate, North-South Center, University of Miami.

HEADLINE: Compressed Data;
What's in a Web Name? Sometimes, Mistaken Identity

BYLINE: By PETER WAYNER 

 BODY:
Jeff Woods, the owner of an Internet service provider to Raleigh and Durham, N.C., has discovered that using an address, or domain name, that people associate with a well-known company may not be worth the free publicity that comes with mistaken identity. He owns delta.com, a domain name he chose in 1993 for his company, Deltacomm Internet Services.
Trouble is, nearly everyone who comes to his Web site (www.delta.com) is really looking for the site of Delta Air Lines -- sometimes as many as 10,000 people a day. Over the years, as traffic on the World Wide Web has meant more and more mistakes, Mr. Woods has tried to sell the address to Delta Air Lines. But the airline, which does business on the Web as www.delta-air.com, has repeatedly rejected his asking price as too high. 
 Mr. Woods said he had lowered the price, to a "five-figure amount," which he contends will barely cover the cost of reprinting brochures and manuals and changing his customers' E-mail addresses to a new domain. Because he pays another Internet company to carry his Web site's traffic, Mr. Woods says, he is incurring extra costs to redirect Delta's traffic. And he says he gets no extra advertising value from most of the people who visit in search of the airline because his business serves only customers in the Raleigh-Durham area.
Delta Air Lines disputes Mr. Woods's economics. "His asking price is much higher than his cost to migrate his customers," a spokesman, Kip Smith, said. "We don't feel that Delta should subsidize his business interests." And besides, Mr. Smith said, Delta Air Lines has a recognized Web address that has been in place since December 1995. "We're really not interested in pursuing it, although we are always open to discussion," he said.
Evidently. The airline recently acquired another Web site name, www.deltaairlines.com from Dennis Toeppen, a speculator in Internet names, who had originally registered it along with 100 or so other corporate names. Delta would not comment on the terms of that deal.
After one conversation with Delta that did not go to his liking, Mr. Woods removed all links to Delta Air Lines' official site. But he soon received so many complaints that he restored the link.
To goad Delta, he also stuck in a link to its main rival, American Airlines, with a free testimonial that reads, "If you're looking for an airline, try American Airlines, the frequent-flier airline the owners and staff of Deltacomm Internet Services flew 100,000 miles on in 1997." PETER WAYNER

HEADLINE: Family Feud Touches Down in Newburgh

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

DATELINE: NEW WINDSOR, N.Y., Sept. 20

 BODY:
One after another, the cars pulled up to the chain-link fence at Stewart International Airport. One after another, curiosity seekers squinted through the fence at the turf-green-and-white Airbus A300 wide-body jet sitting on the tarmac, silent and still except for the fabric covers on its engines flapping in the breeze.
"The Feds were checking it out last week, and customs," said a man in a red car who would not give his name because he works at the airport. "We thought they were going to fly it out of here, but then they came and wrapped it all up." 
 The object of all this intrigue is an $80 million aircraft apparently frozen in a growing financial feud between Prince Jefri Bolkiah of Brunei and his older brother, the Sultan, the second-richest man in the world after Bill Gates.
The ownership of the plane itself is in dispute. What is agreed is that the plane landed at this airport near Newburgh, 70 miles north of New York City, in Prince Jefri's care on Aug. 7. Sometime after that, Federal officials say, the prince's big brother essentially took away the keys.
"The State Department told us that the plane had been taken out of Brunei without permission," said Andrew Zarutskie, the press secretary to Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, Republican of Greenville, whose district includes part of the airport and who is chairman of the House International Relations Committee. "They said the Government of Brunei had asked the Government of the United States as a courtesy not to let the plane take off."
Representatives of the State Department, the Federal Aviation Administration and the United States Customs Service did not return calls today seeking comment.
An associate of the prince's in London, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said that the jet belonged to the prince, who he said was in self-imposed exile in New York City, and that he could move it any time he wanted to. But an operations supervisor at the airport -- who also spoke on the condition of anonymity -- confirmed that the plane had been grounded. And today it was being watched by a man who said he had been hired by Alliance Private Investigations, a company in nearby Goshen, and who was taking notes on anyone who looked at the plane.
"My job is to notify the boss if anybody starts taking the plane, if anybody tries moving it," said the man, who would give neither his name nor the name of his client.
The operations supervisor said that dignitaries visiting New York frequently parked their planes at Stewart, both because its storage fees are relatively low -- $600 a day for an A300 cannot seem like much to a man whose family is worth at least $35 billion -- and because it provides a low profile.
For several months, as plummeting world oil prices have strained Brunei's oil-based economy, tensions have grown between Prince Jefri, who is accused of squandering huge sums on luxury hotels and a lavish life style, and the rest of his family.
The Sultan, Hassanal Bolkiah, recently removed his 44-year-old brother as head of the state investment agency and a private company, Amedeo, amid reports of losses that some analysts said could amount to billions of dollars. Prince Jefri is fighting efforts to strip him of those and other assets.
The royal family has also been stung by charges by a former Miss U.S.A., Shannon Marketic, that the prince and the Sultan flew her to Brunei with the promise of a diplomatic job but tried instead to turn her into a sex slave.
All of which helps explain why Dominick DiGioia, a retired Army chief warrant officer, brought his family out from Newburgh to look at the plane after reading an article about it in The Times Herald Record of Middletown. "It's beautiful," Mr. DiGioia said. "I think it could seat quite a few women. And all those windows" -- there were 41 on each side of the 177-foot-long plane -- "have got curtains on them."
His daughter, Cindy DiGioia, a manager at a Caldor department store, was less impressed. "It's no different than Air Force One," she said. "It's just a green plane."

HEADLINE: Television in Review

BYLINE: By RON WERTHEIMER 

 BODY:

'The King of Queens'
CBS, tonight at 8:30
(Channel 2 in New York)
 Jerry Stiller could be funny bellowing excerpts from the telephone book. Too bad he doesn't get material that clever on "The King of Queens." He is saddled with lines like "I got two words for you: I'm stayin' right here." 
 Mr. Stiller, in full Frank Costanza mode, is Arthur, the dotty father-in-law who moves in with not-too-bright Doug Heffernan (Kevin James) and Doug's a-little-too-bright wife, Carrie (Leah Remini). Carrie's kooky sister, Sara (Lisa Rieffel), an unemployed actress, moves in, too, and now Doug and Carrie's comfy little home has become crowded.
The performers are pleasant enough, and Ms. Remini almost gives Carrie some zing. But they can't overcome the stale setup. As for the title, there is no obvious connection to Queens, for which residents of the borough can be thankful. RON WERTHEIMER
