HEADLINE: THE TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: FOREIGN POLICY;
Troubled Nations May Look at Clinton at the U.N. and See... Trouble

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20

 BODY:
If President Clinton wants a sense of how dangerous a place the world has become in the midst of a scandal over his personal conduct, he could study the grim faces in the audience when he rises on Monday at the green marble podium of the United Nations General Assembly in New York.
There will be the leaders of Asian nations that are being convulsed by the most severe economic crisis since World War II, and delegates from Russia, which is facing its own economic and political meltdown. 
 There will be diplomats from the nations surrounding Kosovo, where a war is raging in the heart of Europe and where tens of thousands of refugees are in danger of freezing to death; from India and Pakistan, which now face off across their common border with nuclear-tipped missiles, and from Israel and the Palestinian Authority, which are still far from the peace agreement that the United States had hoped to broker.
And to the dismay of many in the United Nations, one face will not be in the crowd of diplomats at the General Assembly, that of an American ambassador. The nomination of Mr. Clinton's choice for the post, Richard C. Holbrooke, has been sidetracked until at least early next year by a Justice Department inquiry.
Many on Capitol Hill say that because of the scandal resulting from his relationship with a White House intern, Mr. Clinton lacks the political capital to move Mr. Holbrooke's nomination any faster -- or for that matter, to champion any significant initiative on foreign policy that requires Congressional approval.
Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, the ranking Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said that American foreign policy was being "sidetracked" as a result of the President's problems.
"Foreign leaders who know about the President's difficulties, who know about the attitude and partisanship of the Congress, are wondering whether this is a President who can deliver," he said in an interview. "I think in a sense, foreign policy has been paralyzed."
It is a view stated even more forcefully by Republicans. Senator Chuck Hagel, a Nebraska Republican who is a fellow member of the Foreign Relations Committee, returned last month from a trip to the Middle East, where he met with government leaders in Israel, Egypt, Syria, Saudi Arabia and Lebanon.
"And every one of those leaders told me that as a result of the President's problems, his motives when he acts in foreign policy will be called into question," Mr. Hagel said.
"The coin of the realm in foreign policy is trust, and when you are not trusted, you cannot lead," he said. "If foreign leaders don't believe that the American people and the Congress trust our President, the next question for them is: Why should we?"
No one in Congress has been heard to blame the sex-and-lies scandal for last week's vote in the House to rebuff the Administration and provide only $3.4 billion in new credits to the International Monetary Fund, a fraction of what the Administration has said is necessary for the fund to deal with a global financial crisis. But it certainly did not help.
"It is almost impossible now for President Clinton to pick up the phone and ask a favor from a member of Congress on a tricky matter of foreign policy," said a senior American diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity. "If there is any lingering good will in Congress, he'll want to cash that in to prevent his impeachment."
Senior Clinton Administration officials say that the President remains fully engaged in the conduct of foreign policy. They say that he may even be more interested in the details of foreign policy since it provides him with a welcome diversion from his troubles in Washington.
Last week, the President directed White House meetings on the crisis in the Serbian province of Kosovo, where the United States is threatening to use air strikes to end a Serb onslaught against the ethnic Albanians who make up a majority of the population there, and over the standoff with Iraq for its refusal to let United Nations weapons inspectors there to do their work.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and Defense Secretary William S. Cohen have expressed confidence in the President.
Ms. Albright's spokesman, James P. Rubin, said: "Secretary Albright has made clear that she has never had a problem in recent months or years in getting the President on the phone when she needs him and doing the work that she needs to do when it needs to be done. She has expressed her strong confidence in the President's leadership and his ability to make sound judgments."
Mr. Cohen, the sole Republican in the Cabinet, said at the Pentagon last week that Mr. Clinton "continues to be effective in dealing with national security and foreign policy issues, and as long as he's able to do that, then he will have the support, I think, of the American people."
But while the evidence suggests that the President remains fully engaged in debates within the Administration over foreign policy, his aides say they are dismayed that almost any decisive action taken by Mr. Clinton is now being viewed in Washington and around the world through the prism of the scandal.
That became alarmingly clear, they said, when the President decided to bomb Afghanistan and the Sudan on Aug. 20 in retaliation for terrorist attacks on American embassies in East Africa.
Within hours, members of Congress were publicly questioning whether the air strikes were simply an attempt to divert public attention from the furor over his acknowledgment to a Federal grand jury of his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky.
In an age of satellite television and the Internet, the news of the President's sexual misadventures -- and the cynicism over his motives in conducting foreign policy in light of the scandal -- spread to virtually every corner of the globe in a matter of seconds.
In the Sudanese capital of Khartoum, anti-American demonstrators took to the streets the day after the bombings carrying signs that bore cartoons depicting Ms. Lewinsky. Other protesters carried signs with the words "Wag the Dog," a reference to the recent Hollywood comedy about a President who launches a war in Albania to divert attention from allegations that he molested a girl scout.
Mr. Biden said he feared that every critical foreign policy action taken by the Administration would now be viewed with the same skepticism, and that it could hinder decision-making as the White House pondered whether to launch military strikes in Kosovo and against the Iraqis.
"When it comes time to pull the trigger, the White House will have to think and expect that every serious observer in the country, as well as every wacko, is going ask: O.K., is this 'Wag the Dog'?" he said.
Senator Hagel said he did not see how President Clinton could ever again reassure foreign leaders that his decisions were not being influenced by the scandal. "The fact is that when you've lost that confidence, you've lost it forever," he said.
American diplomats abroad say the scandal has begun to color the way the United States and its leaders are being perceived abroad, particularly among nations considered adversaries of the United States.
Muslim clerics in Iran, where the name of Ms. Lewinsky is becoming nearly as well known as that of the President, have cited the scandal as proof of the decadence of the United States.
A senior American diplomat, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said that intelligence reports showed that leaders of unfriendly nations as far-flung as Libya, Cuba and Myanmar had obtained copies of the full report to Congress by the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, from the Internet.
"I suspect that it is being translated into 100 different languages for 100 different governments, and every foreign leader will be reading it with the same idea in mind," he said. "They see the President as tarnished, probably irretrievably, and they're wondering how they can capitalize on it."

HEADLINE: Schroder the Invulnerable? Look at His Record

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: HANOVER, Germany, Sept. 18

 BODY:
He went to the opera in Vienna with the chairman of Volkswagen. He took a spin on the Boeing yacht in Seattle last year. He has visited with Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft.
If Gerhard Schroder has tried to communicate anything during his long quest to unseat Chancellor Helmut Kohl, it is that he is worldly and modern. A Social Democrat who started out as a Marxist student leader, he now talks easily about working with both business and labor to tackle Germany's high unemployment and prepare for the future. 
 But with elections just one week away, Mr. Schroder's past is coming back to haunt him. As the Premier of Lower Saxony since 1990, he presides over a state with nearly 11 percent unemployment -- one of the highest rates in western Germany. The state's budget is a shambles, groaning under a mountain of debt. Job-training, school budgets and community programs have been cut back, and bigger cuts are likely next year.
Not surprisingly, Mr. Kohl and his Christian Democratic Union, steadily gaining in national polls, have begun to hammer at Mr. Schroder's problems at home. The issue was a major theme in the Sept. 12 state elections in Bavaria, where the Social Democrats suffered a major setback by receiving only 28.7 percent of the vote. Mr. Schroder continues to lead Mr. Kohl in national polls by two or three percentage points, but many voters are still undecided.
Opponents charge that Mr. Schroder is all show and no substance, a person who thrives on dramatic gestures but whose state nevertheless lags behind in key respects.
"He loves to be the trouble-shooter, to jump into situations where he can rescue a factory from being shut down," said Fritz Muller, a senior economic adviser to Christian Democrats in the state parliament. "The problem is, he doesn't have any fundamental economic policy."
Mr. Schroder has shown a knack for bailing out troubled local factories. Brushing aside objections from environmentalists, his government has spent hundreds of millions of marks to deepen a small river so that a family-owned shipbuilder could build luxury liners and deliver them to the Baltic Sea.
When Preussag AG wanted to sell its steel mill in March to an Austrian company, Mr. Schroder's government bought the factory for about $600 million and then quickly listed it on the stock exchange. It has also propped up the Continental Tire company based in Lower Saxony and taken over an airplane maintenance center that Daimler-Benz wanted to shut down.
Mr. Schroder and his supporters say such actions show their resourcefulness as the state's old manufacturing industries struggle with global competition.
"The question is not how we compare with other states today, but whether things look better now than they did when we came into power," said Alfred Tacke, Mr. Schroder's state secretary for economics. "We think there has been progress."
But government statistics show that Lower Saxony has grown more slowly than most other western German states for the last several years -- and more slowly than several eastern German ones. While industrial growth has roared ahead in states like Bavaria, Germany's wealthiest, it barely limps along here. And while Mr. Schroder talks about creating 100,000 more job-training positions and investing in technology, his own state has invested much less than many others.
Mr. Schroder's record here provides a vivid insight into his personality and his style of governing. The picture that emerges is of a relentlessly pragmatic leader who thrives on protecting jobs but is bored by economics.
"I have a lot of sympathy for him," said Gernod Preuss, president of Lower Saxony's association of employers, who has known Mr. Schroder for two decades. "He has learned a lot about business, and he has consistently said that the state can only be successful if the economy is successful."
He relishes his role as a member of Volkswagen's supervisory board, a position he holds because the government of Lower Saxony owns 20 percent of the company. When Volkswagen was in danger of bankruptcy in 1993, he strongly supported brutal cost-reduction measures that raised howls of protest from suppliers.
But Mr. Schroder gets much poorer grades as a thinker. Executives and many local government officials complain that he was sloppy about finances when the state was booming in the early 1990's and then caught by surprise when the economy slowed to a crawl. And they were infuriated this year when Mr. Schroder unilaterally vetoed Preussag's decision to sell its steel mill and had the state take it over instead.
Today, Mr. Schroder's budget problems are among the most acute of any state in western Germany, and his lieutenants have been scrambling to keep them from damaging his campaign for Chancellor. The state's total debt has ballooned from 37 billion marks in 1989 (then about $23 billion) to more than 62 billion marks (about $34 billion) last year. The debt here has grown faster than in any other state in western Germany.
Last November, the state supreme court ruled for the second time that Lower Saxony's budget deficit violates legal limits. Local governments, meanwhile, have sued the state, maintaining that it shortchanged them by about $300 million a year.
Opposition leaders now contend that Mr. Schroder faces a shortfall of nearly $3 billion in the two-year state budget for 1999 and 2000, and they are asking a court to force him to disclose his budget before the elections. Mr. Schroder's lieutenants have said they will not even show their draft to the parliament until just before Christmas.
The financial straits have cut seriously into social programs. Local school districts have all but stopped hiring new teachers, and one town on the northern coast went so far as to use its own money to do so. The University of Hanover has been forced to increase the size of classes, delay renovations and lay off clerical workers. At a community counseling program in Hanover for battered women, workers have gone without pay since the government cut off money several months ago.
Lower Saxony's level of joblessness, at 10.7 percent, is markedly higher than the western German average of 9.1 percent. Its level of youth unemployment, at 13.9 percent, is the highest of any western state.
Yet because the state's budget has been so cramped, Mr. Schroder's government has spent far less than other states on training programs and investment in new industries.
Lower Saxony has privatize about $1 billion worth of state-owned companies, but it has used almost all that money either to make interest payments on its debt or support entitlement programs. Defenders of Mr. Schroder say he has had to wrestle with long-term problems that were evident before he came to power. Lower Saxony's industry was dominated by old-line manufacturing companies that have been battered by global competition since the 1980's. Volkswagen, the state's biggest company and the anchor for an extensive industry of parts suppliers, came perilously close to bankruptcy in 1993 before it put itself through brutal cost reductions.
"You can't blame Schroder for everything," said Wilfried Prewo, president of Hanover's chamber of commerce and industry. "Unemployment was high before he came to power. He started out with a pile of debt."
But Mr. Prewo did say that Mr. Schroder had made mistakes. When Mr. Schroder was elected Premier in 1990, Lower Saxony was in the midst of a boom resulting from the re-unification of Germany. Because the state lies right on the old eastern border, its companies sold vast amounts of equipment and services when the Bonn Government pumped hundreds of billions of dollars into rebuilding the east.
But instead of using the good years to shore up the state's finances or invest in new industries, it embarked on new entitlement programs such as giving free school materials to every child in the state. When the economy in eastern Germany went into a deep slump around 1995, Mr. Schroder was left with billions of dollars in additional debt.
"His miscalculation was that the growth would go on forever," said Mr. Prewo. "He didn't invest his surpluses, but rather consumed them on long-term commitments."
But even his critics acknowledge that Mr. Schroder has an unorthodox cleverness, which he showed after acquiring Preussag's steel mill in February.
The move outraged free-market purists and many business leaders. But then Mr. Schroder took advantage of what was still a booming stock market and listed the company on the stock exchange in June. The government sold most of its stake for a cash profit of about $25 million, and still owns shares worth several hundred million dollars.

HEADLINE: HIGH NOTES AND LOW: A special report.;
A Jazz Success Story With a Tinge of the Blues: At Lincoln Center, Defining the Canon Draws Fire

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

 BODY:
The scene at the Supper Club on West 47th Street seemed to evoke the glory days of jazz -- an ebullient swing band playing classic Ellington tunes as dancers in period costumes rocketed around the dance floor.
But rather than a throwback to the past, the filming for a PBS special was a snapshot of the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra as one of the great cultural success stories in New York. In just a decade Jazz at Lincoln Center has become the flagship jazz organization in the United States. Led by Wynton Marsalis, the most celebrated jazz musician of his time, it is scheduled to move to the kind of coveted location that comes along only once every few decades. 
 Nothing has highlighted the growth of Jazz at Lincoln Center, a constituent of the center for only two years, as much as the announcement in July that the redevelopment plans for Columbus Circle will include an 1,100-seat concert hall and complex of offices and rehearsal rooms for the program. The concert hall is billed as the first to be acoustically designed for jazz.
But the growth of Jazz at Lincoln Center, whose new season is in full swing, is also a reminder of the program's ambitious agenda and its contentious place in the jazz world.
Jazz at Lincoln Center is not just about making music. It is also, very consciously, about making choices, about defining the canon of an art form that is less than a century old. That goal has almost inevitably brought controversy and with it a question at the heart of the program's mission: Does it exist mostly to celebrate jazz's past or should it be helping to shape its future as well?
By almost any conventional measure, Jazz at Lincoln Center has been an astounding success. The program's budget has grown in three years from $3 million to $9 million, and this year it will present nearly 400 concerts, lectures, classes and workshops in New York and around the world. Most concerts play to sold-out houses. Last year Mr. Marsalis became the first jazz artist to win a Pulitzer Prize for music. On Friday he played and spoke in a program at the White House. Officials are confident they will be able to raise the $65 million it will take to build their new home.
"They've done a marvelous job, and incorporating jazz on an equal basis at Lincoln Center is very important," said Dan Morgenstern, director of the Institute of Jazz Studies at Rutgers University. "Jazz has never had a space like the one at Columbus Circle. It's quite wonderful what they're doing."
But in the jazz world, which often is as factionalized as a lost Trotskyist tribe, the reviews are more mixed.
At the heart of many criticisms is the sense that Jazz at Lincoln Center is using its bully pulpit to foster a cautious, unadventurous view of what jazz is. Given Mr. Marsalis' celebrity and commercial success, its programming is having an effect beyond Lincoln Center to help determine what kind of jazz and jazz musicians are recorded and promoted.
Some critics and musicians say that the program's commissions have too often gone to Mr. Marsalis, that he has used his influence to polarize the jazz world and that the program has slighted white artists at the expense of a pointedly Afrocentric view of jazz's history and traditions.
Most pervasive is the criticism that Lincoln Center is purveying a cautious, static and dated approach to jazz.
"They've done a lot to take the essence of jazz and distort it; they've put a damper on the main ingredient of jazz, which is innovation," said George Russell, a much-admired jazz composer and pianist who has been an important figure in jazz since working with Dizzy Gillespie in the 1940's. "I think whatever happens at Lincoln Center, history will have to correct it, because it does need correcting terribly."
Rather than just a window onto Jazz at Lincoln Center, the disputes are highlighting two vexing issues in jazz overall.
The first is the generational flip-flop in which most of the innovators are in their 40's, 50's and 60's, while the most conspicuous younger musicians, modeled after Mr. Marsalis, are viewed as polished, cautious traditionalists.
The second is the ill-defined cultural status of jazz, with some skeptics questioning whether it belongs at Lincoln Center and others questioning whether it will inevitably be watered down because it is there.
Mr. Marsalis said the criticisms, which have played out in the jazz press almost since the program began, are old issues recycled too many times.
"Ellington faced this; Coltrane had to defend himself in writing," he said. "There's always some side story that becomes the issue instead of the music. And my whole thing is, What about the music?"
The writer Stanley Crouch -- who along with Mr. Marsalis, Rob Gibson, who is Jazz at Lincoln Center's executive producer and director, and the author Albert Murray has helped define the program's approach -- says the criticisms reflect envy more than substance.
"If you've got a classic Rolls driving by on a hot day and a guy standing in the sun waiting for a bus, that guy is going to have one of two reactions," Mr. Crouch said. "Either the Rolls is no good or he should be driving it. Most of the criticisms come down to either 'I'm not being hired there,' or 'My ideas are not being adopted.' "
 
After Just 11 Years, An Equal Partner
Beginning with a three-concert jazz program in 1987, Jazz at Lincoln Center became a department, dependent on Lincoln Center for money in 1991, and in 1996 became the 12th independent constituent on an equal footing -- if not with equal resources -- with powers like the New York Philharmonic.
"We've had astounding growth, and it's the result of the incredible power of this music," said Gordon Davis, the program's chairman, a former city parks commissioner and now a powerful real estate attorney. "We're all riding a mission here because we're involved in something we believe is profoundly important, which is this music, in this country at this time."
The mission translates to acclaimed education programs, particularly those taught by Mr. Marsalis. And the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra has the most extensive touring schedule at Lincoln Center, with 90 cities on five continents this year.
The program's mission also consciously extends to trying to define what jazz is. Mr. Marsalis and Mr. Gibson argue that just as European music has an established canon of essential music, jazz too needs to establish its own canon, with Louis Armstrong, Duke Ellington, Charlie Parker and others as its version of Bach, Mozart and Beethoven.
Many jazz fans, particularly those in the large group more likely to hear jazz at a concert hall than a downtown club, find it hard to fathom what could be wrong with a vibrant jazz presence at the leading American performing arts complex.
"Anyone doing as much as they're doing to promote the appreciation and respect and love of the music is doing the right thing," said Richard Cohen, a creative director at a Manhattan advertising agency.
But in the jazz world the picture is far more mixed.
"What they do there sounds so old," said Sonny Fortune, a saxophonist who has played with Miles Davis and many others. "I want to get excited by music, but a lot of what they do there, you can go to sleep on it. I don't know if I'd say absolutely that what they do is bad for jazz, but surely, absolutely I wouldn't see it as good."
Similarly, many musicians scoff at the notion that it is the role of Lincoln Center to establish a canon for jazz, saying such a canon evolves naturally and that Lincoln Center's version is pallid and limited.
Others say Lincoln Center's institutional heft and commercial muscle has distorted the economics of the jazz business.
 
Other Musicians Find Less Work
Marty Khan, whose company, Outward Visions, has represented jazz artists and promoted jazz concerts and events for more then two decades, said that when he started out, colleges and arts groups used to program 4 to 12 jazz events a year, paying $4,500 to $7,500. Now many just do a few dates, usually including one by Mr. Marsalis or the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra at several times that cost. This results in less work for other artists and audiences weaned on classical, mainstream jazz rather than more adventurous fare.
Greg Osby, a saxophonist who has moved between mainstream jazz and more progressive jazz, said the passions about Lincoln Center's direction have cooled since they were the talk of jazz a few years back, partly because not many musicians outside what he described as "a select few people who pander to a certain taste and ideology" now expect to play there.
"There's plenty of resentment, but everyone has come to the conclusion that no matter who gripes, it's not going to change anything," he said.
He added that most artists realized that Lincoln Center did not represent all of jazz, just one facet of it, and that venues more partial to experimentation could flourish at the same time. Still, he said, given its visibility and resources, many musicians wish Jazz at Lincoln Center had a broader vision.
"Jazz is a living art form that feeds on contemporary trends, steps across fences, borrows from alien sources and brings them back in a new way," he said. "You have people doing incredible things today, but they never get a chance to play at Lincoln Center because they seem to think jazz stopped in 1967."
 
In a Black Forte, Race Is an Issue
And, in a field where racial issues, including questions about whether whites can play jazz, have been tossed around for decades, it's not surprising that some white musicians and critics say Lincoln Center in its programming, tributes and commissions has regularly slighted the contributions of white musicians. Of 16 musicians commissioned to create original music cited by Mr. Gibson, 4 four were white, 1 was Latino and the rest were black. The commissions range from $2,500 to $15,000. Mr. Marsalis, whose composing gets more mixed notices than his playing, has been commissioned to do a work every year but one since they began as part of his contract. Mr. Gibson declined to say how much Mr. Marsalis is paid.
Mr. Marsalis and Mr. Gibson dismiss any notion of a racial slant, and others say that almost any fair reading of the giants of jazz would have a preponderance of blacks. And Mr. Gibson said many criticisms reflected the misimpression that Mr. Marsalis's work is synonymous with Jazz at Lincoln Center.
"I think lots of the people who criticize us have never looked at what we do," Mr. Gibson said. "You can't look at the musicians we've featured and say this is a predictable, narrow approach."
Mr. Gibson cited musicians as diverse as Benny Carter, Ray Santos, the Japanese conductor and arranger Katsuhiko Tanaka and Joe Lovano as evidence of the range of works presented at Lincoln Center.
In addition to a broad range of concerts, programming this year includes a yearlong celebration of the centennial of Duke Ellington's birth and collaborations with the New York Philharmonic and New York City Ballet.
Mr. Marsalis said he makes no apologies for making esthetic judgments of what musicians to feature, decisions that have largely tuned out both avant-gardists on one side and purveyors of pop jazz or electric funk on the other.
He said the focus on a jazz canon is not a static approach to jazz but a way of establishing a bedrock of excellence that all great players need to master before they can develop fully on their own.
"If you're a writer, it's assumed that you should know Shakespeare or Melville or Dickens," Mr. Marsalis said. "But in our field, for some reason, you had people saying to be great in jazz you're not supposed to know anything. That's the view that was prevalent when I was coming up, and that's what's helped to deplete our field of musicians."
Some musicians say the real problem is not what Lincoln Center does or doesn't do, but that so few others are trying to do the same thing. There are plenty of jazz orchestras, including Jon Faddis's Carnegie Hall Jazz Band, but no major arts institution has made the commitment that Lincoln Center has to a continuing presence.
"Wynton has to be himself; if Ornette Coleman was heading Jazz at Lincoln Center, it would be very different," said Joe Lovano, a white saxophonist, who received a Lincoln Center commission for a work. "What Wynton is doing is great. The trouble is you can't expect them to do everything. What you'd like to see is for this to springboard across the country, so that every city that has a major symphony orchestra has a jazz orchestra as well."
Even some of the critics say Lincoln Center's role in many ways mirrors the commercial currents of jazz in general and the constraints of trying to run a nonprofit organization at high-cost venues like Alice Tully Hall. Thus Lester Bowie, a trumpeter and vocal critic of Mr. Marsalis, said he did not expect to play at Lincoln Center because his work is more popular in Europe than in the United States.
Mr. Gibson said much of the backbiting had reflected the inevitable growing pains of a program starting with the most essential music and slowly making its way through the rich panoply of the jazz world.
 
New Solutions In a New Home
He said the new hall would allow Jazz at Lincoln Center to present 5 to 10 times as much jazz in New York as the organization has been able to do in the past, some of it in smaller or less expensive spaces that will be more conducive to commercially marginal fare.
"There are a lot more musicians and a lot more of the jazz community we want to put on our stage," he said. "I mean we're just getting to Hank Jones. This is one of the most important jazz musicians of our time. He's 80 years old, and we've never had him on our stage. We're not trying to be politically correct. It just takes time to get to everyone we'd like to have. People forget that we're a very young organization in a very young art form. We're at the mezzanine level of a 20-story building."

HEADLINE: In Peru, Evidence of an Early Human Maritime Culture

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD 

 BODY:
ABOUT 12,000 years ago, people living in what is now southern Peru camped on the Pacific shore and feasted on fish, seabirds and shellfish. The remains of stone tools, hearths and butchered bird bones found at two Peruvian sites are the earliest known evidence of maritime-based cultures in the New World, scientists reported last week.
The findings, described in the current issue of the journal Science, also provide further proof that people were in America earlier than once thought. Of possibly even more importance, they support an emerging view of how the first Americans lived and how they migrated through the length of North and South America. This rethinking of the peopling of the New World is becoming one of the liveliest areas of research and controversy in American archeology. 
 In the new view, it appears that the earliest Americans were not all hunters spearing big game like mammoths and bison, as they have long been portrayed in prehistoric studies. The Peruvian discoveries, along with other recent research, show that many of the people who first inhabited the Americas relied on diverse resources for survival: big game and small, plants and fruits, marine life and just about anything at hand.
Dr. Daniel H. Sandweiss of the University of Maine at Orono, who directed research at one of the sites, said in a telephone interview: "This finally makes it abundantly clear that these people had a very diverse subsistence system and were prepared to exploit all different kinds of food sources almost as soon as they arrived in America. We had thought this before, but we can prove it now."
Research by Dr. Anna C. Roosevelt, an archeologist at the Field Museum and the University of Illinois in Chicago, had already found that people living 11,000 years ago in the Amazon basin had opportunistic subsistence economies that seldom included big game. Likewise, the oldest confirmed settlement site in the Americas, at Monte Verde in southern Chile, was occupied 12,500 years ago by people who ate mastodon meat when available but more usually dined on potatoes, mushrooms, grasses, nuts, berries and freshwater shellfish.
"Now there's recognition that early Americans did not live by mammoth alone," said Dr. David J. Meltzer, an archeologist at Southern Methodist University in Dallas, commenting on the Peruvian findings.
Until last year, when archeologists finally accepted the antiquity of the Monte Verde site, the earliest confirmed traces of human activity in the Americas had been 11,200-year-old stone spear points discovered in the 1930's near Clovis, N.M. The distinctive points were later found scattered throughout much of the two continents, creating the impression of the first Americans as almost exclusively big-game hunters. This led to the prevailing hypothesis that the New World was first populated in the last ice age when sea levels were low. Hunters walked across a land bridge at the Bering Strait in pursuit of game, then moved south through an ice-free corridor between glaciers in the continental interior and eventually made it by foot all the way to the tip of South America.
Dr. David K. Keefer of the United States Geological Survey in Menlo Park, Calif., a geologist and leader of the team that explored the second Peruvian site, said the new evidence of such early maritime-oriented cultures bolstered the case for an alternative migration theory.
"Our site," he said in a telephone interview, "is about the best kind of evidence you're going to find for the idea of coastal migration -- not conclusively probably, but very strong evidence."
Dr. Knut Fladmark, an archeologist at Simon Fraser University in Vancouver, British Columbia, proposed the coastal migration hypothesis in the 1970's, but the idea gained few adherents until recently. Geologic and paleoenvironmental studies have begun showing that there probably was not a clear passage between the glaciers early enough to enable people to migrate through the North American interior in time to reach places as far south as Peru, Brazil and Chile when new archeological evidence establishes that they were there.
New estimates, Dr. Fladmark said last week, indicate that the corridor between the glaciers, on the eastern flank of the Rocky Mountains, did not open until 11,500 years ago. If the newcomers to America could not move south through the interior, they might have migrated along the western coast, on foot along the shore and by skin-covered boats for stretches.
Dr. Sandweiss is reserving judgment as to whether the Peruvian sites support the coastal-migration hypothesis. At the site he studied, the people appeared to have occupied it seasonally and spent the rest of the year in the nearby highlands, possibly engaged mostly in hunting.
"The coastal migration is possible, but neither site provides clear evidence for it at this time," Dr. Sandweiss said. "We need a good number more sites up and down the coast to establish anything about migrations."
An advocate of the coastal-migration hypothesis, Dr. Carole A. S. Mandryk of Harvard University, said the Peruvian findings "make me really happy" because they show a culture oriented to the sea and its resources that was living as far south as Peru early enough that their ancestors presumably could not have found a way through the interior glaciers of the ice age. Instead, she said, they would probably have taken the coastal route.
Finding evidence of early coastal settlements and migrations was once thought to be hopeless. At the end of the ice age, melting glaciers raised sea levels and inundated what had been the ancient shorelines. But off Peru, the sea floor drops off so steeply that when the sea levels rose, not much land was submerged. Buried remains of settlements close to the ice-age coast might still be recoverable.
Both discovery sites are in the arid south of Peru, near Arequipa. The site Dr. Keefer's group excavated, called Quebrada Tacahuay, was about a half-mile from the present shore. As a geologist, Dr. Keefer was originally looking for buried evidence of the effects of ancient El Ninos on early cultures. Layers of sediments revealed deposits of mud and rock from floods brought about by El Nino, a Pacific Ocean warm-water current that every few years generates storms and heavy rain along the western coasts of the Americas and droughts in Australia and Asia.
Deep among the flood deposits, the geologists and archeologists found the charcoal and stones of a cooking hearth, radiocarbon dated at 10,700 years, or about 12,700 calendar years old. Further exploration turned up an abundance of seabird bones, particularly cormorants and boobies. Butcher marks suggest that the people were removing the meaty breast parts. The second most abundant remains were anchovy bones. Only a few bones of terrestrial animals were found.
"The remains of such small, schooling fish at the site suggest the use of specialized fish-netting technology," the scientists reported in the Science article.
The second site, called Quebrada Jaguay and worked by Dr. Sandweiss's group, was a few miles inland by the bed of seasonal stream flowing out of the highlands to the coastal desert. People occupied the site for a time 13,000 to 11,000 years ago, gathering clams and small fish of the drum family. Archeologists found some stone tools, petrified wood and small pieces of obsidian as cutting tools.
In their Science report, Dr. Sandweiss and his colleagues said the bones and stones at Quebrada Jaguay suggest that the people there were foragers who spent part of their time in the highlands and part on the coast exploiting marine resources. While at the shore, they relied almost exclusively on the sea for food.
"This conclusion supports other recent studies showing early diversification of subsistence beyond an economy based on the hunting of large game," the scientists wrote.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A stone-cutting tool about two inches long and some 12,500 years old surrounded by seabird bones as found at Quebrada Tacahuay, Peru. (David K. Keefer)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
A Fourth Day ofPrice Gains Lowers 30-Year Yield to 5.12%

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury yields declined yesterday for the fourth consecutive session, with no significant economic reports to move the market.
In addition to the scarcity of economic data, many investors were observing Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, and trading volume was down about 11 percent from normal, according to Govpx, a bond pricing service. 
 By late in the day the 30-year bond was up 12/32 to a price of 105 27/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, slipped to 5.12 percent, from 5.14 percent on Friday.
Widening concern among investors that Japan's recession will worsen and cut into corporate profits, and questions as to whether Japan will be able to overhaul its battered banking system anytime soon, once again increased the attractiveness of Treasuries as an alternative investment to stocks, lowering long bond yields to levels not seen for 30 years.
The telecast of President Clinton's grand jury testimony in the Monica Lewinsky matter appeared to have little impact on the market.
Bill Gamba, vice president and manager of taxable fixed-income securities for the S. G. Cowen Private Client Group, said the market had been anticipating the videotape since last week and had already priced in all the negatives, so when the tapes were released, "There was a relief rally in stocks, and that helped take some of the flight to safety out of bonds."
"We have the second-quarter G.D.P. report this week, which is considered important, and a two-year-note auction on Wednesday," Mr. Gamba said. "Given the current condition of the global economies and financial markets elsewhere in the world, I think the two-year will have no problem getting done."
In when-issued trading, dealers were offering the new two-year issue at a price to yield 4.61 percent.

HEADLINE: Grupo Televisa to Cut 20% of Its Staff

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Grupo Televisa S.A., Mexico's largest television network, plans to cut about 4,000 jobs, or nearly 20 percent of its work force, by the end of this month as part of a yearlong effort to trim costs.
The cuts, which will leave Televisa with about 17,000 employees, are aimed at achieving $60 million in annual cost reductions, executives said last week. That would add to $25 million in annual savings from layoffs made in the first six months of the year. 
 The latest cuts will come from all departments and all seniority levels. Many of the affected employees will have to leave the company this week.
Shortly after its longtime chairman, Emilio Azcarraga Milmo, died last year, Televisa vowed to cut $100 million in annual fixed costs. It sold corporate jets, cut executive pay and closed offices in New York and Los Angeles.
The cost-cutting drive is being led by Gilberto Perezalonso, who was hired by Televisa as chief financial officer earlier this year from Cifra S.A., one of Latin America's best-performing retailers.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Selloff Abroad Is Deflected By Wall St.

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stocks weathered a sharp selloff on European markets yesterday and finished modestly higher, led by strong gains among bellwether technology issues.
The Dow Jones industrial average overcame an early 185-point deficit to close up 37.59 points, or five-tenths of 1 percent, at 7,933.25. The advance leaves the Dow with a small gain for the year. 
 Earlier, however, traders reacted with alarm to developments in foreign markets, particularly in Europe, where prices on most major exchanges tumbled on renewed worries about Russia and Japan, as well as concerns over President Clinton's videotaped grand jury testimony in the Monica Lewinsky matter.
"A sense of foreboding about Clinton didn't help the European markets," said one block trader, who insisted on not being identified. "And in our market the testimony was a big distraction."
Every major stock market in Europe fell yesterday, with drops of more than 5 percent on the Swiss, Italian and Dutch exchanges. The CAC-40 index in France was off more than 3.5 percent, the DAX index in Germany fell 3.98 percent, and the FTSE 100 index in London lost 1.29 percent.
There were also sharp drops in Asia and in Brazil. In Japan, the Nikkei index fell 2.76 percent, and the Hang Seng index in Hong Kong dropped 3.70 percent. The Bovespa index in Brazil lost 3.87 percent.
The selling continued when trading shifted to New York. But the early losses were reversed as the session progressed, and by late in the session the Dow moved into positive territory.
Some broader market indexes also had modest advances. The Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 3.80, or four-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,023.89. And the Nasdaq composite index was up 16.66, or 1 percent, to 1,680.43. But the Big Board's composite index fell 0.11, to 507.43, and the Russell 2000 index dipped 0.62, to 362.64.
Declining issues outnumbered those that gained by a margin of about 3 to 2 on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume fell to 609.9 million shares, from 795.7 million shares on Friday.
Traders said the observance of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, and the broadcast of Mr. Clinton's Aug. 17 testimony helped depress the level of activity.
Some traders did say, however, that they were encouraged by what has happened recently. "We are climbing the infamous wall of worry," one said. "And with interest rates where they are, there is no way stocks can go down. They can trade off for a while, but then they will bounce back."
Technology stocks, which played a critical role in the climb of the market averages and have had a leading part in the recent selloff, were impressive performers yesterday.
Motorola gained 2, to 48 1/2. International Business Machines was up 3 1/2, to 128 3/16. Microsoft closed at 107 7/8, up 2 1/2. And shares of the 3Com Corporation, the second-largest computer-networking company, rose 1 5/8, or 5.3 percent, to 32 1/16, on optimism that it will meet Wall Street's expectations when it releases quarterly results today. Although many companies have already braced investors about coming earnings reports, traders remain nervous about the numbers that will be announced in the next few weeks. And they are quite willing to punish companies that have unexpected bad news.
An example yesterday was Praxair Inc. The company, the third-largest supplier of industrial gases, said that earnings for its 1998 fiscal year would be less than expected because of slower domestic sales.
Traders responded by pounding Praxair's stock, pushing it down by 2 13/16, or nearly 8 percent, to 32 13/16.
And Praxair was not alone.
The American depository receipts of Royal Philips Electronics fell 5, or 9.8 percent, to 46, after the Dutch company warned that its third-quarter results would be lower than expected. And shares of Xerox lost 4, to 79 9/16, after analysts at Lehman Brothers cut 1998 earnings estimates, citing the company's exposure in Latin America.
"The market is in a recovery that began at the start of the month," said Phil Roth, chief technical analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "But it has not really demonstrated sustained strength. We have had shake-outs, and it has held. But we are not seeing genuine investment demand. I don't think the selloff is over."

HEADLINE: Jobs Going Begging, Companies in Florida Adapt

BYLINE: By DENNIS BLANK 

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., Sept. 21

 BODY:
BellSouth Telecommunications of Miami, a unit of the BellSouth Corporation, says it has taken more than six months to fill 500 newly created jobs in Florida. Even more surpisingly, it went through 10,000 applicants before getting the people it wanted.
The story is the same for other big corporate employers throughout the South but particularly here in Florida, where a lot of companies have largely abandoned normal recruiting procedures such as classified advertising to rely on signing bonuses, putting notices on the Internet and offering prizes to employees who bring in new workers. 
 Joe Lacher, president of the BellSouth unit, is frustrated that high schools and colleges are not turning out more qualified people. "We have made 10,000 contacts, and we cannot find a sufficient number of people," he said. "That certainly raises questions about our education system."
It also says something about the tightness of the labor market at a time when unemployment nationwide is just 4.5 percent and even lower in many economic hot spots such as Florida and California.
BellSouth Telecommunications now has a work force of 12,000 in Florida, and customer demand for more phones forced the company to create the new jobs last December. Starting pay for phone service representatives is $19,200 a year and for installers, $21,000.
"There has been a virtual explosion in people adding second lines," said Spero Canton, a company spokesman. "Growth has gone beyond people's expectations. The demand for second lines for modems, fax machines and a kid's line is standard now."
The company has a very "demanding" test, which results in a high number of failures, Mr. Canton said. Among other problems, most applicants do not have enough technical education and some do not pass the company drug test, he said.
"In many cases, it has taken longer than we expected," Mr. Canton said, "but we are still making progress."
The pool of qualified applicants for both skilled and unskilled jobs continues to shrink as the state's unemployment rate rides at a low 4.3 percent, with Orlando the lowest at 3 percent, according to the latest figures. It is common for major employers like the Walt Disney Company, the Harris Corporation and Stein Mart to have thousands of vacancies posted all the time.
More employers are extending their searches to other states and scouring the Internet job boards.
"Florida is tight up and down the skill levels," said Kevin Brickey, an economist with the Florida Department of Labor. "We're seeing quite a lot of employers expand their efforts to a larger radius than they once did."
Even in some less skilled jobs, such as those in fast-food restaurants, employers are raising wages for new workers by 25 cents an hour or more to attract help. And many jobs still go unfilled.
Disney, the largest employer in the state at a single site -- with 51,000 workers -- has more than 1,000 job openings and is looking at ways to improve recruiting. "We are constantly reinventing ourselves," said Kelly Frank, Disney's director of employment in Orlando. "We are constantly evaluating our recruiting tactics."
Disney frequently offers signing bonuses of $2,000 and in some cases up to $10,000 for hard-to-fill high-technology jobs. Moreover, seasonal workers now get a full 40-hour workweek with benefits and more flexible schedules. A few years ago, most got part-time hours and no benefits.
At Stein Mart Inc., a chain of 900 family clothing stores in 30 states that is based in Jacksonville, Fla., its stores are "never totally staffed," said Hunt Hawkins, the human resources director. "It is like spitting in the wind, to put out expensive classified advertising," he said.
Stein Mart replaced classified advertising with a reward program for employees who refer new store clerks, who start at $5.50 to $6.50 an hour. The recruiting employees are given shirts and hats, and managers get annual $100 bonuses. Even so, the chain says it takes at least 10 interviews to hire one person.
A task force is putting together a plan to "identify creative approaches" to recruiting the workers needed, especially in major population centers such as Atlanta, Chicago and San Jose, Calif., Mr. Hawkins said.
At the Harris Corporation, a military contractor and manufacturer of communications equipment that is based in Melbourne, Fla., and employs 29,000 worldwide, it usually takes six to eight weeks to fill an opening, Ronald Hutt, senior manager of human resources, said. Computer-related high-technology positions may go unfilled for four to five months.
While Harris continues to use classified advertising, job fairs and $2,000 signing bonuses, it has also found a new conduit by opening a Web site for college graduates. The candidates can look over available jobs and file their resumes electronically. In addition, Harris has built up an internship program with specific schools that refer top students who alternate working a semester and going to school a semester.
Some employers have also established junior college branches at work locations to allow workers to take courses in the evening so they can advance. The Peabody Hotel in Orlando, which employs 800, has expanded its offerings from food service to marketing, accounting and convention management courses on a cooperative agreement with Valencia College.

LENGTH: 337 words

HEADLINE: Japan's Paralysis

 BODY:
A political deal on how to close insolvent Japanese banks appears to be unraveling rapidly, raising the specter of continued inaction on the financial crisis facing the world's second-largest economy. That would constitute an abdication of responsibility not only to the Japanese people but to the global economy that needs a healthy Japan.
Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi, who is to meet with President Clinton today, supposedly had worked out a deal with opposition parties in the Japanese Parliament to have the state take over insolvent banks, but it is now in doubt because of opposition to the use of public money to keep such banks afloat before they are taken over. Moreover, the Prime Minister, in an interview with editors and reporters from The New York Times, said yesterday he believed that stockholders in the banks should be compensated by the Government, a misguided position that is likely to be unpopular in Japan, and deservedly should be. 
 The Japanese Government needs to make it clear that it will bail out depositors, but not owners, of failed banks. The Government also needs to move promptly to determine which banks must be closed and which can continue. Protecting depositors will cost large amounts of public money, and the political opposition needs to understand and accept that.
Without action, the credit crunch, which has made loans hard to come by for Japanese businesses, will continue indefinitely, delaying recovery from Japan's severe recession and thereby making recovery even less likely in other Asian countries.
The bad-debt problem for Japanese banks is huge, but it is manageable in an economy as wealthy as Japan's. Japan would benefit from quick action, but even if there were agreement, it would take time to institute a plan. With the risk of Japanese inaction high, it is more necessary than ever for the other major economies -- particularly Germany and the United States -- to take steps such as lowering interest rates in an effort to stimulate world growth.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE UNITED NATIONS: BRITAIN;
Remodel World Bank And I.M.F., Blair Urges

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain yesterday urged a revamping of the way the world's financial institutions deal with global economic turmoil, and said the procedures of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank had to be updated.
He noted that the I.M.F. and the World Bank, set up 54 years ago at a conference in Bretton Woods, N.H., "were constructed for a world of fixed exchange rates and capital controls, when capital flows were much smaller." 
 "The current crisis illustrated the weakness of the existing international financial system," Mr. Blair said. "It needs to be modernized to meet the challenges of a new century."
"Reform there has got to be," he said, departing from his text and glancing up at the group of 24 top executives and other officials in the ornate boardroom of the New York Stock Exchange.
"We should not be afraid to think radically and fundamentally," Mr. Blair told the group, which listened silently, then rose to applaud him at the end and followed him to a luncheon. He cut short his speech after an address at the United Nations in which he urged greater world cooperation against terrorists.
The Prime Minister, who the current chairman of the Group of Seven leading industrial nations, e said he was considering calling a meeting of the group's government leaders to push for the reforms. The Group of Seven is made up of the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Japan, Italy and Canada.
Mr. Blair outlined a series of changes that he said were necessary to deal with the current and future global economic turmoil.
He said there was a need for greater openness and transparency, which would include the setting up of international accounting standards. He welcomed an attempt by the I.M.F. to come up with a code on more fiscal openness.
He also called for improving financial supervision and regulation and said the I.M.F. and the World Bank needed to give those areas a much higher priority.
The world, Mr. Blair continued, had to develop better ways to respond to a short-term crisis of liquidity when a country has trouble converting its money into other currencies.
"The I.M.F. does not and cannot play this role -- the finance it provides is strictly limited and is usually provided in return for specific demands negotiated over a period of time," he said.
He added that the vast flows of capital in the current economic crisis posed some new challenges.
"It is vital that global investors assess more carefully the risks associated with their lending decisions and price their loans accordingly," he said. "We need a new mechanism to insure close and regular contact between governments and the private sector that can provide early warning of problems."
He also called for greater openness and accountability by international financial institutions.
"I would like to see improved openness in procedures and more systematic external evaluations of I.M.F. policies," he said. "It is important, too, that programs should take full account of their impact on the poorest sections of society."
He said that to put through the current reforms "we will have to reach out to a wider community -- both the developing nations and outside experts -- including financiers, economists and businessmen." The governors of the I.M.F. and the World Bank are scheduled to meet from Oct. 6 to 8 in Washington, where they are expected to discuss the proposals made by Mr. Blair and others.
The I.M.F., which has lent about $25 billion in the last year, has run into sharp criticism in nations like Thailand, Indonesia and South Korea, where its aid has been coupled with requirements for tough changes such as closing down of weak financial institutions. Interest rates have also been pushed up sharply in those countries.
As a result, governments have been forced to cut spending, which led to the killing of social programs and public works programs.
Mr. Blair said the resources of the I.M.F. needed to be strengthened. Last week some members of Congress blocked a move by President Clinton to increase the funding of the I.M.F.

HEADLINE: NASA Wants Money to Save Russia Partner

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
Worried that trouble in Moscow is threatening its own dreams, NASA wants to spend up to $660 million over five years to bail out its Russian partner in building a planned international space station, agency officials said yesterday.
Key members of Congress immediately faulted the proposal as too expensive, clouding the fate of the biggest science project of all time. But NASA officials argued that the American and Russian programs were now linked so intimately that the Russian effort must be preserved lest the American space program suffer greatly. 
 In just two months, orbital construction is to start on the sprawling outpost for astronauts, which is expected to cost more than $40 billion.
But even if the new bailout goes through and keeps the Russians afloat, the station project is facing another round of construction delays next year because of Russia's problems in building a crucial part. The lag in that work will also have costly repercussions for the nation's fleet of space shuttles, which are to carry station elements into orbit.
Already, past delays have cut the flight rate of the shuttles to unusually low levels, and NASA officials are scrambling to find new shuttle payloads to compensate for looming gaps in outpost construction.
"The Russian economy has spiraled down, dramatically," Joseph H. Rothenberg, the associate administrator for space flight at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said in an interview. "We are actively looking for what payloads may be available" to make up for station lags.
In total, Mr. Rothenberg said, the new bid to save the Russians and the beleaguered outpost is likely to cost about $1.2 billion, including the new money for the Russians as well as $540 million in new American work like modifying the shuttles so they can do more station lifting.
"This is a plan," he said of the Russia aid. "No commitment from anybody has been made" to provide new money.
Mr. Rothenberg said that the space agency had already squeezed its own $13.6 billion budget as far as possible to find emergency money for the outpost's rescue and that it was eager for new money.
Over all, he said, NASA wants to pay the Russians $60 million this fiscal year for new goods and services and then up to $150 million a year over the next four years as an aid to station construction. The $660 million is to help make up for money the Russians would have put forth themselves had their economy not fallen apart.
The $1.2 billion in emergency money, Mr. Rothenberg said, was much cheaper than loosing Moscow's help altogether. "Any alternative you look at without the Russians would hit the program hard," he said, because their absence would delay the outpost's construction by years and add up to $2 billion in costs.
But top members of Congress are questioning the new bailout.
"Given NASA's track record, we are justifiably concerned and skeptical," said Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who heads the Senate Commerce Committee, which oversees NASA.
Some critics go further, saying NASA officials should put the whole station project on indefinite hold.
"They're trying to stick with a failed strategy," James E. Oberg, a American expert on the Russian space program, said in an interview, adding that the station's problems threatened to add billions of dollars in hidden costs to NASA's shuttle operations. "Next year's shuttle schedule is entirely up in the air."
At worst, Mr. Oberg said, NASA could end up with a half-built station and the Russians entirely out of the picture if their downward spiral continues. He said it would be much better to pause now and rethink the station venture from the ground up.
The plan for station cooperation arose in 1993 after the cold war. The Clinton Administration saw Moscow's participation as an important symbol of new cooperation between East and West. Supporting the Russian program was also viewed as a way to keep Russian space scientists employed in peaceful pursuits.
After five years of close collaboration, ties between the Russian and American space station efforts are now so extensive that repercussions of Russia's financial turmoil have increasingly roiled American plans, budgets and gear. Last month, for example, Russia's main spaceport temporarily lost power because of unpaid bills, postponing a number of rocket launchings and sending shock waves through Washington.
The situation "is deteriorating," NASA told the White House in a confidential briefing in late July that was made public by NASA Watch, an Internet publication.
In the briefing, NASA said the Russian Space Agency needed $340 million this year to build parts for its share of the international outpost, but so far had received only $20 million from its Government. The outlook for improvement "is bleak," the assessment said.
Jeffrey Manber, managing director of Energia Ltd., the American arm of a top Russian contractor making station parts, strongly agreed.
"The philosophical question," Mr. Manber said in an interview, "is whether you maintain the illusion that the Government of Russia can keep its objectives or do you deal with Russian industry for goods and services."
Over the years, Washington has paid Moscow $742 million for station-related work, Congressional experts say.
Recently, the White House has taken to rejecting NASA requests for new bailout money to aid the Russians, so the agency has raided its own budget. But criticism in Congress, among scientists and in the aerospace community is rising.
"NASA needs to stop draining other vital programs to feed the space station's voracious hunger for more money," Space News, an industry publication, said in an editorial last month.
The developing crisis in the International Space Station has been overshadowed in the past year or so by the travails of its wobbly predecessor, the Russian Mir outpost, which has suffered a fire, navigation breakdowns and a collision with a supply ship.
Originally, orbital construction of the follow-on station was to begin in November 1997. But the threadbare Russians kept missing deadlines. So the starting date slipped to June of this year and then to November, a year later than planned.
The outpost's first element, 43 feet long, paid for by the United States and built by Russia, is now scheduled to ride into space atop a Russian rocket roughly two months from now. Then, over five or six years, scores of Russian rocket and American shuttle launchings are to loft 500 tons of parts and supplies.
When it is finished, the outpost of laboratories and living areas will be nearly the size of two football fields and will orbit hundreds of miles above Earth, powered by huge arrays of solar-energy cells.
Today, the main hurdle is not the station's first element, which the Russians have ready to go for launching in November, nor the second, which the Americans have ready to go for launching in December.
Rather, it is the third, the first element to be fabricated by Russia on its own. This so-called service module would provide early living quarters and, more important, would have propellant tanks and thrusters to keep the craft from plunging back to Earth. It is officially set for launching in April but is unfinished and its fate is increasingly uncertain.
American experts say Russia needs up to $210 million to finish, test and launch the crucial unit. It might be ready to fly in July 1999 at the earliest.
Meanwhile, American officials are loath to send up the first modules without confidence that the vital third one will show up relatively soon thereafter.
To aid the Russians, the space agency is now seeking to buy two lifeboats for the station from Russian at a cost of roughly $100 million, Mr. Rothenberg said.
Mr. Rothenberg insisted that taking $100 million from other NASA programs was prudent and that the money would eventually be paid back. The current goal, he added, is to rush Moscow $60 million by the end of this month.
In the meantime, NASA is working on its own partial backup to the Russian service module, a skeleton unit would periodically lift the outpost into a safer orbit. The agency is also preparing to have the shuttles modified so their engines can aid the lifting job.
Things will be clearer after agency officials meet with the Russians late this month, after which schedules will be recast, yet again.
Originally, most shuttle flights that NASA had planned for this year were for station construction. But delays cut this year's flights from four to one. As a result, by the time Senator John Glenn rockets into space in October there will have been no shuttle launchings for five months, a silence on the launching pad that private experts say is dangerous.
NASA officials say the rocket specialists at the Florida spaceport must loft shuttles regularly or loose their edge. Today, they are struggling to keep launching teams in Florida sharp with computer simulations, while they search for alternate payloads.
One developing plan is to have the shuttles send up logistics materials and supplies ahead of schedule. Another is to add a science mission unconnected to the outpost.
In the more distant future, Mr. Rothenberg noted, demands on the shuttles will actually soar since Russia has informed NASA it cannot afford to launch unpiloted resupply ships to the outpost at the rate it expected.
While 33 Russian supply ships were originally promised to haul up cargo and propellant, the number has now dwindled to 15 or 17, and the shuttles will have to take up the slack.
"That's put a change into the program," Mr. Rothenberg said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japanese Bank Compromise Frays Already

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 21

 BODY:
A broad-based banking compromise measure that Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi had hailed as the foundation for Japan's economic recovery began to fray today, just as Mr. Obuchi prepared to meet with President Clinton in the United States on Tuesday.
The banking deal, which Mr. Obuchi had pursued intensely in advance of his meeting with Mr. Clinton, at the Rockefeller estate near Tarrytown, N.Y., had been many weeks in the making. It was intended to help stabilize Japan's shaky financial system and to be the basis for legislation to restore international confidence in the nation's economy. 
 Japanese markets reacted to the development negatively. Stocks fell sharply here today, with the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues dropping by 385.82 points, or 2.76 percent, to 13,597.30, a 12 1/2-year low. The exchange value of the yen declined against the dollar. On Tuesday morning, both stocks and the yen were up modestly.
Also today, a major bond-rating agency, Fitch IBCA of London, lowered Japan's long-term foreign currency debt rating from AAA to AA+.
It said that with the nation's deteriorating banking system, increasing Government debt and slow response by policy makers, the risks of lending to Japan by overseas investors could no longer be ignored.
The banking agreement was supposed to forge a sweeping plan that ranged from a framework for rescuing Japan's very large, very weak banks to a sharp reduction in the power of the Finance Ministry, which had been the nation's most influential bureaucracy.
The central dispute today concerned whether an old fund to rescue weak banks -- which Mr. Obuchi promised to dissolve -- would still be used. Since the Government had agreed to abandon old financing devices, many people had assumed that it would not be used.
But Mr. Obuchi's aides now say that they may use the old system anyway because it is necessary to prevent a disruption in the banking system.
"The current scheme will be effective until a new scheme is formed," the top Government spokesman, Hiromu Nonaka, said. "The Government will need to cope without disturbances."
Another top official, Yoshiro Mori, general secretary of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, suggested over the weekend that the old system could be used to assist the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, which is floundering and may need assistance in the coming weeks.
As the Government appeared to backtrack from the agreement, opposition leaders warned that the entire accord might be scrapped.
The leader of the main opposition Democratic Party, Naoto Kan, objected on Sunday to the Government's interpretation. In particular, he rejected the idea of using tax money to bail out the Long-Term Credit Bank under the current setup. Mr. Kan was reported in the Japanese news media to have said that he was braced for the collapse of the compromise.
The disagreements will have to be resolved when Prime Minister Obuchi returns to Tokyo from the United States. And the opposition groups do not seem to be in a mood to give in and allow the use of public funds to help the Long-Term Credit Bank.
"That constitutes a clear violation of our agreement," said Motohisa Ikeda, a member of Parliament who was chief negotiator of the agreement for the Democratic Party, in an interview today. Asked whether it was possible that the agreement would totally unravel, he replied, "I cannot exclude the possibility."
Liberal Democrats and banking officials have suggested that the Long-Term Credit Bank could face a severe upheaval toward the end of this month, when the bank settles its half-year accounts. Yomiuri Shimbun, Japan's largest-circulation daily, carried a report containing charges that the bank had covered up huge amounts of bad debt. The bank, denying this, said there had been no cover-up.
Comments by Mr. Mori, the governing party's general secretary, also suggested that the Liberal Democrats might be backtracking on stripping financial regulatory power from the Finance Ministry.
But Mr. Ikeda, the opposition legislator, said it was more likely that the Liberal Democrats would go back to the agreement.
The heated exchanges, however, underlined the extent of confusion over the compromise, which was marked by the kind of ambiguity that led one Democratic Party official to describe Friday's deal as "tamamushi iro" -- the color of a Japanese insect that seems different depending on the angle from which it is seen.
Party politicians on both sides of the argument acknowledged that a great number of details needed to be ironed out.

HEADLINE: THE UNITED NATIONS: IRAN;
Iranian President Paints a Picture of Peace and Moderation

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Introducing himself as "a man of the East" from "a great and renowned nation," President Mohammad Khatami of Iran tried to woo his global audience today with talk of how freedom-loving and law-abiding Iran is these days and asked for help in resolving the crisis in neighboring Afghanistan.
In his first address to the General Assembly -- and his first trip to the United States -- Mr. Khatami quoted from the New Testament, the Koran and 13th-century Iranian poetry in arguing in philosophical language that dialogue is the key to understanding among nations. 
 What was remarkable about the speech is what it did not say.
There was not a word of criticism of the United States. Indeed, the only direct reference to the United States was an expression of confidence that "powerful nations, such as the American people," will reject the idea that one nation should aim to rule the world as its only superpower.
There was much milder criticism of Israel than usual, and certainly no call to free Jerusalem from Israeli rule and no attack of the 1992 peace agreement between Israel and the Palestinians.
And there was no threat to invade Afghanistan, despite the presence of 200,000 Iranian troops on the Afghan border and Iran's relentless condemnation of the repression of Afghanistan under the rule of the militant Taliban movement. In fact, Mr. Khatami said, "there is no military solution to that country's predicament."
Mr. Khatami branded the recent killing of nine Iranian diplomats and a journalist by the Sunni Muslim Taliban part of a pattern of genocide against Shiite Muslims and called on the United Nations to bring all the warring parties into negotiations.
After Mr. Khatami's speech and an eight-country meeting on Afghanistan sponsored by the United Nations that included the United States and Iran, James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, said Washington was encouraged by Mr. Khatami and other Iranian officials who said they wanted a peaceful resolution to the Afghan crisis.
Wearing a tan clerical robe, a sheer black cloak and the black turban signifying that he is a descendant of Mohammed, Mr. Khatami seemed more eager to present himself as a global philosopher than a politician with an agenda for change.
"Allow me to speak here as a man from the East, the origin of brilliant civilizations and the birthplace of Divine Prophets: Abraham, Moses, Jesus and Mohammed, peace be upon them all," Mr. Khatami said. "I come from the noble land of Iran, representing a great and renowned nation, famous for its age-old civilization as well as its distinguished contribution to the founding and expansion of the Islamic civilization."
As he spoke, a woman burst past guards into the General Assembly hall and screamed that Mr. Khatami was a murderer and torturer. The woman, identified by United Nations officials as Laila Jazayeri, a 37-year-old Iranian, was subdued by the United Nations security police, who handcuffed her and strapped her to a wheelchair before turning her over to the New York police.
A block away, about 2,000 demonstrators representing the United States-based National Council of Resistance of Iran protested Mr. Khatami's visit and demanded the overthrow of the Teheran Government. The protesters were joined by Senator Robert Torricelli, the New Jersey Democrat, and two Democratic Representatives, Carolyn Maloney of New York and Robert Menendez of New Jersey.
The last time an Iranian President addressed the General Assembly was in 1987, at the height of Iran's eight-year war with Iraq.
The President at that time, Ali Khamenei, who is now its spiritual leader, delivered a speech that blasted the United Nations as "a paper factory for issuing worthless and ineffective orders" and the United States as a lying, imperial-minded "Great Satan" whose military activities in the Persian Gulf had turned the region into a "dangerous powder keg."
In his current position, Ayatollah Khamenei is in charge of the armed forces, the intelligence and security forces, the judiciary and radio and television, and wields much more power than the President. But Mr. Khatami's only reference to the Ayatollah today was to reaffirm support for his proposal that an Islamic country be made a permanent member in the Security Council.
Since Mr. Khatami became President 13 months ago one of his main themes has been the need for a "dialogue among civilizations," code words for bridging the gap between an Islamic Government like Iran's, which is still subject to American economic sanctions, and secular nations around the world.
So it was not surprising that his main proposal today was that the United Nations declare 2001 the "year of dialogue among civilizations." But so far Iran has rejected an American proposal for an official political dialogue with the United States, and Mr. Khatami made no mention of it in his speech today.
As for Israeli-Palestinian relations, Mr. Khatami said peace and security would come to the Middle East only when all Palestinians had the right to "exercise sovereignty over their ancestral homeland." He blamed Israel for making co-existence in Jerusalem impossible.
"Palestine," he added, is the homeland of Muslims, Christians and Jews, "not the laboratory for the violent whims of Zionists."
In the last year, Iran has muted its opposition to the Israeli-Palestinian agreement, but it still supports guerrillas in Lebanon intent on sabotaging the peace effort.
The State Department, in its most recent annual report on terrorism, ranked Iran as the world's leading state sponsor of terrorism, but Mr. Khatami insisted that Iran was a victim, not a perpetrator of terrorism.
And he called for the world to be "liberated" from nuclear weapons and other weapons of mass destruction. The United States believes that Iran is intent on developing a nuclear weapon, a charge Iran denies.
