HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Japan's Prime Minister Cites Others' Costly Errors
Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi of Japan, blamed his predecessor, the nation's powerful Finance Ministry and the heads of the country's huge financial institutions for wasting years before the country began to deal with its crippling banking crisis and a deep recession that is worsening the world's economic turmoil.
Mr. Obuchi's comments, in an interview as he prepared to address the United Nations, was the first acknowledgment by a Japanese leader that his country's leadership, both in government and in the private sector, had made huge errors that have now ricocheted around the world. Page A13. 

Financial Promises in Russia
Russia's leaders offered assurances that the country's fiscal crisis could be tamed without provoking high inflation or social unrest. But few people seemed convinced. Neither President Boris N. Yeltsin nor his new Prime Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, has settled on a choice for Finance Minister. A3.
 
NASA wants to spend up to $660 million over five years to bail out its Russian partner in building a planned space station. A1.
 
A New Airline-Marketing Link
British Airways and American Airlines announced a new marketing link called oneworld with Canadian Airlines, Qantas Airways and Cathay Pacific. It is intended to compete with the Star Alliance headed by Lufthansa and United Airlines. C2.
 
Lockheed Martin Stock Falls 5%
Shares of Lockheed Martin fell 4.9 percent amid concern that the world's largest military company is putting earnings at risk with its $2.7 billion bid for Comsat. Created by the Government, Comsat is the United States gateway to Intelsat, among the world's largest providers of commercial satellite services. C6.
 
A Rift at Nationsbanc Montgomery
Thomas Weisel resigned as chairman and chief executive of Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities L.L.C. after months of bitter quarreling with his new bosses in Charlotte, N.C. Nationsbank bought Montgomery Securities of San Francisco, which Mr. Weisel founded, for $1.2 billion in October. C4.
 
Philips Electronics Shares Off 17%
Royal Philips Electronics shares fell 17 percent, to the equivalent of $43, in Amsterdam after the company warned of a signifcant decline in profits. C2.
 
Concession Offered on Merger
American Home Products and Monsanto offered to scale down their proposed $37.8 billion merger to overcome European Union antitrust hurdles. C2.
 
Blair Calls for New Procedures
Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain called for modernizing the way of dealing with global economic turmoil. The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, which were created 54 years ago, "were constructed for a world of fixed exchange rates and capital controls, when capital flows were much smaller," he said. A13.
 
Rule Eased on Cash Reports
The Treasury Department said it was trimming its requirements for reporting large cash transactions to ease the paperwork load on banks. Bankers will still be responsible for reporting any sign of criminal activity. C6.
 
New Pressures on Labor Market
The tight labor market -- unemployment nationwide is just 4.5 percent -- has put new pressures on many economic hot spots like Florida and California. BellSouth Telecommunications of Miami, for example, says it took more than six months to fill 500 newly created jobs. C4.
 
Treasury Bond Yields Decline
Treasury bond yields declined for the fourth consecutive session, with no significant economic reports to move the market. C10.

SECTION: Section A; Page 13; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1083 words

HEADLINE: THE UNITED NATIONS: JAPAN;
Tokyo Leader Blames Many for Banks' Crisis

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

 BODY:
Japan's Prime Minister, Keizo Obuchi, today blamed his predecessor, Japan's powerful Finance Ministry and the heads of the country's huge financial institutions for wasting years before facing up to the crippling banking crisis as well as a deep recession that is worsening the world's economic turmoil.
Mr. Obuchi's comments, in an interview yesterday as he prepared to address the United Nations, amounted to an unusual acknowledgment by a Japanese leader that the Government and private sector had made huge errors that have ricocheted through economies around the world. 
 Nonetheless, he failed to lay out any new initiatives, and appeared to acknowledge that an agreement on the banking crisis reached late last week with opposition leaders failed to work out critical details about how the Government will deal with bank debts of nearly a trillion dollars.
That accord was fraying in Tokyo even as Mr. Obuchi prepared for what promises to be a tense first meeting with President Clinton today at the Rockefeller family estate in Tarrytown, N.Y.
As politicians in Tokyo bickered over whether the accord limits the ability of the Japanese Government to pump billions of dollars in public funds into failing banks, the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell drastically, hitting its lowest point since mid-1986.
Mr. Obuchi arrives here a besieged man. Both Britain and Germany have joined the United States in urging Japan to act immediately, and Japanese officials fret these days that they are being blamed -- unfairly, in their eyes -- for the economic meltdown of Southeast Asia and Russia.
Today the International Monetary Fund, which is normally extremely cautious about criticizing a nation that is also one of its largest sources of funds, declared in its annual report that one of the leading risks to the world economy now is that Japan "will not move promptly and resolutely to address its financial sector problems while insuring adequate domestic demand."
"Speed is becoming increasingly critical," the Fund's report concluded.
Mr. Obuchi was clearly prepared today for the inevitable criticism: His briefing papers included a small tab to bring him directly to his talking points on the mounting criticism. The handwritten tab was marked "Too little, too late."
He volunteered, however, that "unfortunately, the Japanese people in general still lack the awareness" of how the country's economic troubles are affecting the rest of the world. He said the lack of awareness has contributed to problems with Parliament.
Mr. Obuchi's portrayal of the Japanese political system as insular is hardly surprising -- critics of the country have been offering similar analyses since Commodore Perry forced the country to open to foreign trade 130 years ago -- but it is a sharp contrast to the way Japanese politicians spoke during the height of the country's prosperity in the late 1980's. Then, they justified Japan's worldwide buying spree as natural for a country that had used the power of the yen to internationalize.
Today Mr. Obuchi gave a very different interpretation of those events.
"It's no wonder the Japanese financial institutions are criticized," the longtime Japanese politician said. Pointing to the view of the New York skyline outside the floor-to-ceiling windows of his hotel suite opposite the United Nations, he said: "Someone even bought Rockefeller Center. What did they produce? Losses. And now they impose them on the Japanese people."
At another point Mr. Obuchi even took a mild jab at Japan's Finance Ministry, which would see some powers stripped away under last week's agreement.
He also indirectly criticized the performance of his predecessor, Ryutaro Hashimoto, describing how his policies of austerity and higher taxes were overwhelmed by the economic crisis that began in Thailand 14 months ago.
"Japan was not able to make a rapid turnaround in its policy," he said. But he insisted that now Japan has made a major shift in economic policy. "Instead of 'too little too late' we want to deal with this in ways that people say 'too big too fast,' " he said.
So far, he is at little risk of facing that criticism. While the Parliament passed legislation during Mr. Hashimoto's term that authorized spending of more than $100 billion to inject capital into failing banks, the accord reached last week scraps that system. It is unclear what will replace it, though Mr. Obuchi insisted today that "public money will be used to buy up the shares" of failing banks.
Whether and how that happens, however, is likely to be the subject of considerable debate at the meeting with Mr. Clinton.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin was quite specific in Congressional testimony last week, arguing that Japan's problems -- and Asia's -- cannot be solved without the use of taxpayer dollars to pump capital into otherwise insolvent banks. The United States has also called for the management of those banks to be dismissed, for the shareholders to be wiped out, and for their assets -- property held as collateral for loans -- to be auctioned off quickly, to revive a frozen property market.
Mr. Obuchi skirted most of those subjects, however, saying "those matters are not yet worked out." But he did argue that Japan could not risk the uncertainty of letting major banks fail. He noted, for example, that the total liabilities of the virtually insolvent Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, known as L.T.C.B., are "worth 1.2 or 1.3 times the total economy of Indonesia."
"Obviously, we cannot tell L.T.C.B. to quit operating simply because the management of that bank was incompetent," he said.
The mechanics of bailing out banks is not the usual stuff of meetings between prime ministers and presidents, but the session today is bound to focus on those subjects.
"We have to be highly specific," one of Mr. Clinton's top economic aides said last week. "No one has the luxury for the kind of happy-talk generalities we've had in most of these meetings."
But Mr. Obuchi and Mr. Clinton, in a break from past practice, are making no joint public appearance to help calm the markets. Some White House officials say that the Japanese are not eager for their leader to stand before the press silently while Mr. Clinton receives questions about the Monica S. Lewinsky matter. The Japanese say that the White House did not appear eager for a joint appearance.
"They have their problems," one Japanese official said, "and we have ours."

HEADLINE: Michael Currier, 37, Philanthropic Rancher Who Helped Tibetans

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Michael Stephen Currier, a rancher and philanthropist who was the manager of the Economic Development Fund for the Tibetan Community in Exile, died on Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 37, and lived in Santa Fe.
The cause was injuries suffered in a fall in Santa Fe, his family said through a spokesman. 
 For 11 years before his death, he was the manager of the exiles fund, which he also established. The revolving loan fund provides technical and other aid for small businesses operated by Tibetan refugees and their descendants in India and the United States. Those businesses include various Tibetan crafts.
Mr. Currier, who visited Tibet and made many trips to meet with Tibetans in India, wanted to help make Tibetan refugees economically self-sufficient and to help preserve Tibetan religious and cultural traditions. The fund was a major recipient of his philanthropic largesse in the last decade.
His family said that they had received a message from the Dalai Lama, whose headquarters are in India. "He has been especially generous in the help he gave us Tibetans," the message said, "and we will always remain grateful."
In 1995 the Dalai Lama presented the Light of Truth Award, a high honor, to Mr. Currier.
A native New Yorker, he was the son of Stephen Currier and the former Audrey Mellon Bruce, co-founders of the Taconic Foundation, whose operations have included programs to further equal opportunity with emphasis on housing and jobs for young people.
Michael Currier's mother was the granddaughter of Andrew W. Mellon, the financier, industrialist and philanthropist.
Mr. Currier's parents vanished in 1967, while in a private plane flying over the Caribbean Sea. They were never found.
He was raised by a guardian, graduating from Collegiate School in Manhattan, Putney School in Vermont and Williams College.
In his early 20's he was a patron of the Morgan Library and of the Gauchos, a basketball program for children in New York.
An orphan himself, he was devoted to his own children and gave many grants to programs providing nurturing for children.
A grant from him in 1985 helped expand a community foundation founded by blacks in Pittsburgh. Other grants from him in the same period helped found a mental health crisis center and a wild horse sanctuary, both in California.
After he moved to Santa Fe, his philanthropies, mostly anonymous, came to include Southwestern charitable organizations concerned with the environment, rural economic development, care and education for needy children and human rights.
He was on the boards of the Taconic Foundation, the Putney School, the Forest Trust of New Mexico and the Santa Fe Waldorf School.
He also collected art, chiefly drawings of the Old Masters and Chinese works.
He is survived by his wife, the former Karin Griscom; two sons and a daughter; two sisters, Andrea Currier and Lavinia Currier of the Plains, Va., and a grandmother, Mary Warburg of Wilton.

HEADLINE: N.Y.U. Relishes Visit From Clinton on High-Profile Day

BYLINE: By SUSAN SACHS 

 BODY:
L. Jay Oliva, the president of New York University, likes to describe the school as a reflection of the city: a world compressed into a village that is at once neighborly, multicultural and second to none when it comes to self-promotion.
"I firmly believe that if you're doing something interesting, you ought to tell people about it," Dr. Oliva said. "And if you're blowing your own horn, do it loudly. There's no sense giving it a little toot." 
 The scrappy university, always looking to raise its profile in the intensely competitive world of higher education, made some big noise yesterday.
The N.Y.U. School of Law played host to President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton, as well as other stars of the political and academic worlds, at a forum on globalization just as the President's videotaped testimony before the Starr grand jury was released to the public on network and cable television.
Some university officials had worried that the latest disclosure from the independent counsel's investigation might upstage what the law school called its "megasummit," which was beamed by satellite to 20 universities around the country and in Europe and simultaneously shown live over the N.Y.U. Web site.
But having Mr. Clinton and the First Lady on campus at a time when dozens of American and foreign journalists were on hand to scrutinize their every move, exchange and reaction, turned out to be a happy convergence of events for the university. The place was packed, monied alumni were in great abundance, and Mr. Clinton joined such political figures as Prime Ministers Tony Blair of Britain and Romano Prodi of Italy in expressing effusive thanks for having been invited.
"This is literally a unique moment on this extraordinary day," responded John Sexton, the dean of the law school, who had conceived of and organized the high-profile event.
Dr. Sexton, who described himself as "the P. T. Barnum of legal education," said the forum, which was called Strengthening Democracy in the Global Economy, was meant to showcase what the school calls its global law school initiative.
The global law program was created five years ago, he said, and incorporated into the traditional N.Y.U. Law School to infuse the school with an international outlook that takes into account the increasing globalization of political and economic institutions.
In the beginning, Dr. Sexton said, his colleagues at other schools teased him that he was dean of "the first intergallactic law school."
But by hiring top foreign legal experts from the Middle East, Asia and Europe, and revamping the way some law subjects are taught, he said, New York University's law school has become a pioneer.
"It's now clear we went to a place where the rest of legal education is going to strive to be 5 or 10 years from now," Dr. Sexton said.
He added that the daylong forum, which featured three panel discussions on civil society, economics and democracy, "is a visible manifestation" of what the law school has been doing on a less glittery scale.
Dr. Oliva, the N.Y.U. president, said that the university had begun organizing the forum less than two months ago, and that from the start, it was to revolve around the Clintons.
Life around Washington Square, across from the law school, came to a standstill for the day. The western half of the square was closed, several Greenwich Village streets were closed to traffic and the streets around the law school were clogged with enormous vans that held the digital production equipment needed to broadcast the forum by satellite.
Several students who had won a lottery for seats to watch the forum on closed-circuit television in the law school said they had the technical advantage of seeing President Clinton twice -- and in any order they wished. The forum was beamed into dormitory rooms and student centers on the university network, while the presidential testimony was available on commercial television.
"I watched the Clinton videotape on TV all morning," said Jasmine Campirides, a third-year student who attended a panel session to see the President. "And I have a VCR so I taped the first panel from the forum so I can watch it at home later."
